text:
I went threw pages and pages of reviews trying to find out how this recipe works after being frozen.  I took a shot and here's what I have to say--this is a great cinnamon roll recipe.  Everybody raved about them the first time I made them--one day in advance, sat in fridge overnight, and then baked in the morning.  The next time I made them on a Wednesday up until the point of putting the cut cinnamon rolls in the pan. I put the entire pan of unbaked rolls in the freezer until Saturday.  I took them out on Saturday and set them out on the counter for a few hours, and then refrigerated them overnight.  I baked them Sunday morning.   They were not the same, to me.  They were more dense and less fluffy.  The family still raved and said they couldn't tell a difference, but I could.  I probably won't freeze them again. If I don't have time to make them the day before, then the fam will have to go without!

text:
These were amazing! I was a little worried about the dough because it seemed overly sticky. I made these without a bread maker (proof yeast in the warm milk w. 1/4 c of sugar for ten min, added butter, eggs, salt, remaining sugar, then flour 1 cup at a time, knead til smooth, let rise 1 hour) I ended up adding between 1/4 and 1/2 c more flour than the recipe called for to make the dough easier to handle but this doesn't seem to have effected the end result at all. Also as another reviewer suggested I mixed the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together and spread this on the dough instead of sprinkling sugar. The only way I could get this mixture to spread evenly was by using a butter knife repeatedly dipped in warm water. I also added about 1 T of milk to the frosting to get it the consistency I like. The first thing my bf said when they came out of the oven and he saw me frosting them was "omg, one of those big ones is $6 at *insert name of mall chain here*!" so Marsha isn't the only one thinking of saving $ with these! Thank you for a wonderful recipe.

These were not as easy to make as I had imagined from reading the other reviews: it's quite a work-out to roll out the dough, even though I let it relax for the recommended time. The dough also took quite a bit more time to rise than 30 minutes, actually more than double the time, but the result was still good.

text:
Delicious and very easy!  I had never made my own cinnamon rolls before and I can't believe how simple and quick it is to do.  I did not use a bread machine but instead listened to reviewers who said you could do it without.  I have made these three times. One of the great things about this recipe is the fact that I always have these ingredients on hand. I definitely think that 2½ tablespoons of cinnamon is too much; they tasted overwhelming spicy/burned cinnamon tasting.  I prefer them with a ONE heaping tablespoon (but that is strictly my personal opinion) After cutting the rolls and placing them in your pan, make sure you let them rise for 30 minutes prior to baking.  The first two times I made them I forgot this step.  The last time I included this step and the resulting rolls were light/melt in your mouth delicious. I also make them with a butter/confectioners sugar/milk/vanilla glaze and not the heavy cream cheese icing.  These rolls are too good to cover up with thick cream cheese.  A+ recipe!  Thank you.

2001051
Display Name:
BakersDaughter5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've make these rolls 4 times without using a breadmachine or mixer & baking at 350 for 20-25 min.: the first 2 batches were sensational but the last 2 batches were just awful!  The last 2 batches resulted in hard, dense rolls that didn't brown like they should have.  I would suggest that you check the expiration date & proof your yeast before adding to the flour mixture.
WEIGH your flour!  4.5 cups of flour equals about 558 grams.  Kneaded dough should be "smooth and slightly shiny, almost satiny".  My failed batches weren't... probably because of too much flour.  Rolling the risen dough onto a surface sprayed with Pam was much easier & had a nicer result than rolling onto a floured surface.  I cut 26 rolls out of the batch which was a mistake.  You can definitely make these without any special equipment...try again if your batches haven't come out right.  I would imagine it might be because either the yeast isn't activating because it's old or the liquid was too hot or cold, too much flour, or it hasn't risen enough before baking.
Review:

888822
Display Name:
Wannabe Virtuous Woman

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/232451.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!!!!! These were awesome!  I made them for company that we had over for the holidays, and they raved and raved that they were better than "that store in the mall".  It's the icing that does it.  I replaced 3/4 of the bread flour with whole wheat for extra fiber (will probably do all whole wheat next time, with the addition of vital wheat gluten to help the rise).  I also used light cream cheese in the icing with no problems.  To make these (up to one month)ahead of time, make and assemble the rolls as stated in the recipe, and then place them in the greased pan wrapped with plastic wrap and foil and place in the freezer. The night before baking them place them in a cold oven and let them sit overnight.  In the morning they will have thawed and completed their second rise, and will be ready to bake.  Take them out of the oven, unwrap, and place them back into a PREHEATED oven and continue to bake according to recipe instructions. Top with icing and devour.  Your family will no doubt have a new found love and respect for you!  Thanks for sharing this recipe!!!!!!!!!!!!

I don't have a bread machine, so I did all the kneading by hand.  I also had the same problem with my rolls not doubling after cutting them so what I did was cover the pan with aluminum foil, baked it at 250 degrees for 30 minutes and boy did it doubled!  I then upped it to 350 degrees, removed the foil and it came out perfect.  Thanks for sharing.  P.S.  the lady asking about why her rolls are coming out not moist and soft, you're probably overcooking them.

country:

text:
I had not been to Cinnabon in a long time since there are none where I live now. I had one just a few weeks ago though, and the ones I make from this recipe are soooooo much better. Fluffier, gooier, tastier. Just plain better in every aspect. Plan ahead to make them though. The longer you can let them rise the better. Start the day before, and let them rise for a good 3-4 hours each time. Put them in the fridge overnight after the second rise, and then it's an easy bake and serve breakfast the next morning. P.S. I don't use a bread machine, just a stand mixer and keep the dough warm for the first rise.

Review:
Rating:

userID:
14205660
Display Name:
Shelly Bakosh
isPro:

followersCount:
16

favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2558450.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the closest recipe I have found to a "Cinnabon". I followed the sweet dough recipe as stated except I used almond milk instead of cow milk. Still came out perfect. 
For the filling I adjusted my cinnamon back 1/2 Tbl. This will depend on the quality of your cinnamon. Cinnabon uses a high quality korintje cinnamon. If you have great cinnamon you will not require quite as much. I rubbed a thin layer of butter in the rolled out dough and mixed the rest of the cinnamon, brown sugar and butter together and rubbed on dough. 
I made my own icing according to my favorite cream cheese icing recipe. Whip your frosting with the whisk attachment for 5-10 minutes to get the airy fluffy icing texture. 
When it came to baking: if you do my have parchment lightly spray with non stick cooking spray. It them it took approx 30min covered to double in size prior to baking. Baked at 350 for 25 minutes, they were cooked but moist all the way through. I did not frost the whole pan, we are frosting them as we eat them.
This will be our new cinnamon roll recipe and will debut at poker night soon for our friends. Be careful, it's hard to have just one!

text:
This recipe is great, but made a few changes. I used buttermilk instead of regular milk, muscovado sugar in place of brown. Both worked fine. Also, I don't have a bread machine, but using the kitchen aid mixer worked perfectly, with normal yeast. Finally, after putting the buns in the pan I covered the pan with plastic wrap and put the rolls in the fridge overnight.  Then I took them out in the morning, let them sit for 45 mins, then baked. Also, flipped them out of the pan as soon as they came out of the oven as someone else suggested, thanks. Perfect clone for Cinnabon!

text:
WOW!! These are AMAZING! I had a group of people over for dinner and they all said that they are the best cinnamon rolls they have ever had, even better than Cinnabon! My husband is a huge cinnamon roll fan and even said that they are the best he ever had!  I don't have a bread machine so I mixed the milk, sugar and yeast together and let it sit for 5-10 minutes until it was bubbly and then mixed in the eggs, salt and butter.  Next I mixed in the flour and then kneaded it with the dough hook in my kitchen aid mixer for a few minutes until it was a soft ball. I put it in an oiled bowl, covered it with a towel and let it rise in a warm spot for about an hour until it was double in size. I then skipped to step #2. I will make these often!

text:
FREAKING FANTASTIC!  This is the BEST recipe for cinnamon buns I've ever tried.  I did double up the brown sugar as suggested by some other reviews as I like a sticky sticky bun.  One tip to get that super tender cinnabon dough on your buns is to cover the pan loosly with foil while cooking for the first 10 minutes.  Remove foil for last 5 minutes of cooking and DO NOT overcook or the dough will be hard instead of tender.  And of course flip it over into another pan as soon as it comes out of the oven, all that good goey stuff in the bottom of the pan will drip all over the buns.  YUMMY!

text:
Easy to make without a bread machine.  Warm the milk to a temperature that feels the same as body temp (which means it's 95-105 F), then add the yeast and sugar.  Wait to see it foams a little, then add salt and butter.  In order to get the dough manageable to knead I had to use probably about 5 cups of bread flower.  Allow an hour for the dough to rise in a warm place.  For baking, I did 20 minutes at 375 degrees.  And at first I doubted whether there was enough icing but they were perfect!

text:
Made this recipe with my bread machine exactly as described and was thrilled with the results. (I used a package of rapid rise yeast which was exactly 2 1/2 tsp). The best cinnamon rolls I have ever made myself and some of the best I have ever tasted anywhere. I think the frosting is perfect! Also, we love lots of cinnamon so 2 1/2 tbs was just right for us. These are large and filling, you will only need one each for breakfast or dessert. Even my teenage boys could only eat one they are so rich and satisfying. The best advice on here is to flip them out onto a cookie sheet as soon as they are done and separate them as they cool so the filling stays in them.

text:
wow these really live up to their name. the only change i made was to use bread flour and i didn't use but about 3 and a half cups and i also used active dry yeast and did everything the old fashioned way with my stand mixer and dough hook because i don't have a bread machine. i tried this recipe before i learned how to make yeast bread and i turned out dry and boring but i tried it recently after i have learned a lot about bread making and i realized that you never follow the flour amount exactly. i start off with half the flour and keep adding a little bit at a time until the dough comes together. the wetter the dough the softer and more moist the bread. also i always use bread flour. i always use kosher salt. and i always use my kitchenaid mixer. with me improving me method not the recipe i was amazed along with everyone else. they are definetely something to serve when you are tring to impress. also when you use bread flour your rising time is a lot shorter.

text:
Unfortunately bread flour was all out at the supermarket when I went, so AP flour had to be used. Surprisingly the rolls still came out with a good texture, although the outer part of the rolls was a bit dry, so next time I will brush with butter. I used mascarpone cheese for the frosting instead of cream cheese (personal preference) and these were absolutely delicious. As others suggested, if you don't have a bread machine let the dough sit for about an hour or until it is roughly double in size, then resume from step 2. Also, if you're not using a bread machine and use packaged yeast, make sure you give it about 10 minutes to dissolve in the warm milk.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were really yummy, but very rich and sweet - neither my husband or I could eat more than one.    I made them exactly as written and baked in a glass 13X9 pan.  I do have a couple of hints  1) This makes a lot of dough, as much as a 2 lb. loaf.  Be sure your bread machine can handle it or cut it in half.   2)  I used King Arthur bread flour (my favorite) and had to add almost 1/4 cup water to get the dough to the right consistency.  Be sure to add it only a tablespoon at a time.  As it kneads, your dough should become soft and shiny - this makes tender bread.  If your machine is struggling, you may need more liquid. 3)  Like other reviewers, I mixed my butter, sugar and cinnamon mixture together before spreading over the rolled out dough.  This worked to keep most of the filling inside the roll 3)  After rolling up, cut off the ends of each roll to make them nice and straignt then cut roll into 1 1/2 inch buns. If you want to use the ends, put them together to make the "cook's sample" 4)  I cooked mine about 17 minutes.  You can tell they are done because the center of the roll should rise above the sides, but don't get them too brown! 5) Cool buns slightly before removing from pan and placing on waxed paper to ice

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe doesn't really need another testimony to its fabulousness.  Instead, I will offer another baking method.  I use Rapid Rise yeast when I bake these.  One packet of yeast combines with the dry ingredients in the mixing bowl.  Then add the wet ingredients (I combine the milk and margarine) heated to 130*.  Then add the eggs.  Fortunately, I have a Kitchen Aid, so I let it take the dough to town with the dough hook for 5-8 minutes.  You could also knead by hand.  Let it rest for 10 minutes, then roll out and fill.  Roll up, slice (dental floss can't be beat for this), and place in greased pan for the final rise.  I usually do this part overnight.  Just cover those babies up and let them sit out on the counter and get fat and happy.  In the morning, bake as directed and watch your family bow down in the presence of your excellence!

userID:
2889417
Display Name:
jynx

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am struggling to see why this recipe was rated a four time and time again. First of all, if you are making a true "clone" of a cinnabon then you need to use vietnamese cinnamon. Secondly, if you want the gooey cinnamon mix to stay between the rolls you need to add flour to the sugar mix, cook at a lower temperature and for a longer time.  It also has to do with how you "roll" your rolls.  The bottom section needs to be silghtly compacted together as you roll with the "top" of the bun rolled looser. You need to chill the rolled dough for about 30 minutes. Place your rolls in an oversized muffin tin and cook. They'll "pop up" and the mix will stay inside the roll. Finally if you want the true flavor of a cinnabon you need to add vanilla, allspice and a pinch of clove to the sugar mix.

text:
I just finished eating one of these and it was sooo good! I've been wanting to make these for a while now and finally did because I needed to use up some cream cheese frosting I had made. Well, they were pretty easy to make and this is the very first time I've made cinnamon rolls that didn't come out of a tube. I did halve the recipe so I got 6 big cinnamon rolls. I don't have a bread machine, so I followed some other reviewers advice. I mixed the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together for the filling and I have to say it was plenty. Also, I flipped the pan over onto a cookie sheet right after I took them out of the oven so all that gooey filling would recoat the rolls, like other reviewers said. These really were great and I know I will make these again.

text:
Delicious. For a small potluck, I prepared the original recipe's 12 buns up to the final rising stage, then only rose and baked six and froze the other six. This morning I got the second half from the freezer, let them thaw and rise, and baked them according to directions. They turned out just as beautifully as the first batch!
Don't be afraid to freeze your fully prepared but not-yet-baked roll dough!

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was terrific!! I live pretty far away from a Cinnabon and I wanted a recipe I can make at home and this really is it!! The bons come out fluffy and full, very satisfying.
 Like some other reviewers I don't have a bread machine, so this is what I did:
 I separated the milk in half, putting the yeast and 1 teaspoon of sugar into 1/2 cup of the milk for about 10 minutes. I mixed the sugar, butter and salt with the other half cup until the butter was melted. I mixed the yeast mixture, the butter mixture, and the eggs together with the flour until it became a dough and allowed it to rise for an hour (using the oven techinque of another viewer).
 I've made cinnamon buns before and I have found that it's easier to mix the butter with the cinnamon/brown sugar before spreading it onto the dough, this prevents it from leaking out during baking.
 I also noticed another used who was looking for a carmel sticky sauce with pecans, I wanted the same thing and I used: 1 cup of brown sugar and 1 cup of butter. Heating the butter over medium heat until melted, add the brown sugar. Allow the mixture to bubble for 3 minutes.

text:
1/29/07   I rate this recipe a Ten.
Everyone should try this recipe.These rolls were out of this world.  
I did  follow  the recipe  that Marsha  wrote for her Clone of  Cinnabons, but I did make a few changes in the ingredients as follows.

Add 1/4 cup of water and 1 cup of milk  instead of what this recipe called for.
Add  1/2 Cup of melted butter instead of what the recipe called for.
Addd 1/2 tsp. of salt instead of what the recipe called for.
Add 1 tsp. of vanilla, Marsha's recipe did'nt have  vanilla and I add this ingredient.
Try my changes in this recipe. I promise you won't be sorry.
I rolled my douugh out on a greased cutting board,it works so much better then rolling it out  on a floured surface. 
I put my cut rolls in a greased cake pan and cover them and  put them in the refrigerator and  let them rise over night in the refrigerator and take them out the next morning for 45 minutes.
Uncover rolls and bake at 350 for 30 minutes.
After you take them out of the oven Imediately turn them upside down on a cookie sheet.
Only frosten what your going to eat,as
You can freeze what you don't eat.These rolls freeze really well.
These rolls taste as wonderful as the ones you buy at the supermarket in the can. 
If you love to bake or want to try making cinnamon rolls this recipe is super delicious.

text:
These were fabulous!  So soft and moist.  As suggested by another reviewer, I combined the butter, cinnamon and sugar in my food processor, then sprinkled it on the prepared dough.  None of the filling ran out and therefore, no problems with the buns sticking to the metal pan.  I lowered the oven temperature to 350 and baked them for about 21 minutes.  I also agree that a single serving of the frosting was plenty.
  When heating the milk, place the milk and butter in a saucepan and heat just until the butter melts, no longer.  This should be the correct temperature when you add the yeast to the entire mixture, as you don't want the liquids too hot.

Display Name:
CHRISTMAS8

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't have a bread machine so I just use the dough hook of my mixer. If doing it this way, it's best to mix less than half of the flour with the liquid first and add the remaining flour gradually. I also use just all-purpose flour, which may be the reason why the dough is sticky, but I like the gooeyness.  Many people made comments on the cinnamon sugar running to the bottom -- I think this is because 1/3 cup is too much butter for spreading.  I probably use about 3 tablespoons only, really just to make the sugar and cinnamon stick to the dough -- apparently, too much butter defeats this purpose.  By the way, I had the same problem when I tried the second rising overnight in the ref.  Lastly, one time I was making this I ran out of milk.  I used half cup evaporated milk diluted with half cup of water, and I loved the result!  The bread came out creamier, so I've been doing it that way ever since.  As suggested by many, I lowered the temperature to 350 for 20 minutes.

text:
These are a real treat. One thing I suggest is to spoon your flour into the measuring cup whenever you are making bread or cake. If you use the cup to scoop out the flour, you are packing in too much flour. Always spoon it in and you will notice a big improvement in your baked goods.

Display Name:
Lucky Nikki

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These will be, by far, the best cinnamon rolls you have ever had.  Go back and read the other reviews, they really help with this one. Make sure you cream together the ingredients for the filling and spread the combined ingredients over the dough (this keeps more of the filling in your rolls instead of on your pan), and taste your filling to make sure you have about the amount of cinnamon that you like.  I increased the amount of filling by about a half because i like mine really gooey.  Also, use a glass pan if you have one, and adjust the cook time to 20 minutes at 350.  When your buns come out of the oven flip them out of the pan, and scrape the extra filling drippings back over them (this makes them completely gooey and delicious, and also eases cleaup by leaving you with less sugar in the pan), and then frost them immediately.  They are absolutely delicious and reheat wonderfully in the microwave, and i am told they are even amazing cold.  Next time i am planning on trippling or even quadrupling the recipie and freezing a couple batches for a rainy day.

text:
I own a bakery/cafe and am always looking for something new for our customers. Haven't been very happy with the cinnamon rolls we've had and have been looking for a replacement.  THIS IS IT....amazing.  Changes made:  no changes in ingredients they're fine.... we don't use a bread machine so did the following...try it before you discard the idea...put all ingredients into your mixing bowl (flour, margarine,eggs, milk, salt, sugar AND YEAST) ... I don't know what bread machine yeast is but plain old yeast did it for me.  Make sure you are using high gluten bread flour and also that your milk is hot enough.  Mix until it comes together and then a minute more.  
Follow the recipe and you'll be enjoying the best cinnamon buns in the world!  For the filling I did try melting the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon as suggested..didn't spread as evenly as I had hoped but they were still great....I'll try using melted butter and sprinkling on the dry ingredients to see how that fares. Icing is, well, the icing on the cake.  An absolutely wonderful recipe! Thanks Marsha!

text:
The Best Cinnamon Rolls ever!! I don't use the bread machine because i prefer to hand-knead the dough myself. I do, however buy a box of hot roll mix instead of making the rolls from scratch. text:
These turned out really good!  I had been wanting to try them for awhile - but there are only two of us at home.  We each had one and I took the rest in to work and everybody (who were lucky enough to snag one)loved them! One lady said that they were BETTER than Cinnabon!  I expected them to rise more after they had been cut into rolls, but it could have been that my yeast was old. They were still wonderful!  NOTICE TO FIRST TIME CINNIMON ROLL MAKERS (like me):  rolling out the dough takes patience and elbow grease, but don't give up!  Flipping the dough from time to time helps.  The results will be worth it!  Also - at first the frosting will look too dry and like you may need to add a bit of milk - just keep mixing!  It'll get smoother and creamier the more you mix!  Beyond yummy!

text:
I've made this recipe frequently and everyone loves it. I do find that it is a stiff dough that labours my bread machine and that this recipes makes 12 large rolls that requires in my household a few days to consume. I have successfully made a smaller batch by dividing all the ingredients by half, rolling the dough out to 12 by 14 inches, slicing into 9 rolls and using an 8 by 8 inch square baking pan. This amount is nice in that it can be consumed while the rolls are still fresh.

Followed other reviewers suggestions and let sit overnight in the refrigerator after first rise and took them out in the morning and let sit in warm spot for 30 min or so before baking them. text:
No one else has said this so I am posting the problem I had with this recipe. The bread machine kneaded the dough then which was very solid -- not nearly enough liquid in it, yet I had used the cup of milk and two very large eggs. I had to remove it from the machine, add water by guessing, and use the processor to make a softer dough. It is now doing its rise in what I hope is warm spot. I checked another recipe book that called for two cups of liquid for six cups of flour. I am surprised I'm the only person who has posted about this problem. I have no idea what it will be like but with the ingredients it ought to be good -- but dough heaviness remains to be seen.

text:
I just made these for the first time. I'm a Cinnabon aficionado (you could call it a hobby) and these rival the best. The dough is perfect and it was easy to work with, and the filling is perfect although I think I will make extra filling next time as there was not nearly enough goo at the bottom of the pan. The frosting tasted a little different than Cinnabon's, but it was still very good. 

I don't see a reason to ever go to Cinnabon again now that I know how to make my own for a small fraction of the cost. I especially like that I can use regular ingredients without wondering about possible preservatives and transfats (I subbed butter for margarine) that are probably in the originals.

text:
My family LOVES this recipe! We made a 1/2 batch because I had not been successful at making cinnamon rolls up to this point, by the time they were going into the oven, we were working on the 2nd FULL batch!! Only negative... we consumed 18 cinnamon rolls in less than 24 hours! 

As suggested by a few reviews 1. for the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture - I mixed both into the softened butter & crumbled over the dough  2.I sliced the first batch w/ dental floss & the second batch with fishing line - this tip was awesome, worked wonderfully!!

These are fool proof! I am adding pictures only because I still can't believe I created something so beautiful! My previous attempts at making these have been a complete failure! We made everything exactly according to the recipe! 5 Stars!! Delicious!

userID:
3459544
Display Name:
Domesticgoddess
isPro:

48

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've had this recipe saved for years to make, but either never had the ingredients, time, occasion or excuse to eat such a rich and delicious breakfast. I finally made them last night and baked them this morning, and wow! They were worth the 3 year wait.
I use my kitchenaide stand mixer to prepare the dough. I made the bowl warm, warmed the milk and mixed in the yeast. (Make sure to check the expiry on your yeast if you don't bake often). Once dissolved (Aprox 10 minutes) I mixed in the other ingredients using e dough hook. I let it rise in the oven (preheated to 200 than turned off, covered with a damp tea towel). Then I rolled out the dough and added the cinnamon mixture. I rolled from the short end of the rectangle. I didn't have a tape measure so just guessed the size. i cut the dough roll with a sharp knife in half, then each half in half again and then each quarter into 3. I put them in a glass baking dish and into the fridge over night. For the cream cheese frosting I took just less than half of a brick of cream cheese (our cream cheese is sold in 250 gram bars- which is equivalent to 8 oz). Mixed everything together and put int he fridge over night as well. In the morning I baked for 25 minutes in a 350 degree convection oven for 25 minutes. Once out of the oven I spread the soften icing (took it out of the fridge earlier) over them which melted a little more. Mouth watering amazing! And really not that hard to make! The house also smells amazing for our morning guest

text:
These are delicious! I don't have a bread machine, but used the info from a comment here and it worked great. As other reviewers said, these are great if you make them the night before and put them in the fridge. I liked them better when I let them rise a little before baking, though. For the cinnamon filling, I melted the butter and mixed the cinnamon and brown sugar in to make it a spread (I made twice as much as the recipe calls for). We like lots of frosting at our house so I doubled that, too. Adds calories and fat, but at this point, who is concerned about that?!?!? If you are, just stay away from this recipe :)

I think they were even better than Cinnabon!  I took one reviewers suggestion of flipping the over once I took them out of the oven, I scraped the melted brown sugar filling off the bottom of the pan, flipped them back in, spread the cinnamon sugar mix on them and then topped with the icing.  perfection!  Next time I will try refrigerating the dough so I can have them freshly made in the morning with a nice cup of coffee!

None
text:
The recipe is perfect if you follow carefully.  I wait awhile to add the frosting.  If you add frosting immediately after the buns come out of the oven the butter in the frosting separates and it turns oily.  Wait a few minutes to spread the frosting.  I usually wait 10 minutes so the buns are still warm but cool enough so the lipids in the butter don't separate.

text:
To dreamich2003. it seems like your problem is yeast. Bread machine yeast should be available in the supermarket near bread machine mixes. If you are not using a bread machine use a quick rise instant yeast (in sachets) You have to KNEAD the mixture till smooth and springy, then REST in a warm spot in a bowl sprayed with nonstick spray. After doubling in size, punch down and roll out. After its all ready in pan give it a while  (20 mins ish) to rise again before baking.

text:
Followed the recipe except I used AP flour as I didn't have any bread flour and used butter instead of margarine. The bun as sweet enough without the cream cheese topping. I made it with KAid, even though it first looked too dry, it still doubled beautifully and non sticky at all to the surface. The only problem I got was that the brown sugar did not melt after baking, they remained grain-like so next time I will def. beat them along with butter till creamy first. Took out another star cus I honestly think it was too dense. Soft and sticky yes, but TOO heavy and DENSE (moist?). Oh, and I baked for 25min 185C, was fully cooked and wet.

text:
I guess I am one of the few who did not like this.  There was way too much sugar in this recipe.  I thought it would melt away with the butter and make a caramel sauce but it didnt.  The sugar just remained in the bun and made it very sweet and very grainy.  This bun also does not need frosting.  My family ate them but did not love them at all.  The cooking time for these did not turn out for me either.  They got really dark on top and under cooked in the middles.  That may be do to the altitude changes but I usually do not have problems cooking as directed on recipes.  These were good tasting once you got past all the sugar tho.  I suggest cutting sugar in half and cooking them at lower degrees for longer time.

country:
None
text:
I can't believe how many people are giving this 5 stars... this is a decent cinnamon roll and good for beginners, but NOT a Cinnabon clone by any stretch of the imagination.  The dough is pretty good and easy enough to work with, though it benefits from the addition of 1/2 to 1 teaspoon vanilla extract or other flavoring of your choice (rum, coconut, etc).  Also, be sure to let the dough "rest" before rolling it out or it will be too elastic.  The cream cheese frosting is pretty good and is the right ratio of frosting to dough.  HOWEVER, the cinnamon filling is way off.  You can hardly taste it at all.  It should be doubled, at the very least.

text:
I made three delicious foot-long FRENCH Breads (subsandwiches) using this recipe!!  Double the recipe.  Cut the sugar down to half.  Substiute 3/4 cup of the white bread flour for whole wheat bread flour.  Cut dough into thirds.  Roll dough into a foot-long like stick.  Press down the dough flat.  Allow to rise in the oven at about 170 degrees F for 30 minutes.  Bake at 375 for about 18 minutes.  Wallahhh!!

text:
First time ever attempting to make this delicious dessert,  and it turned out to be the most exceptional Cinnamon Roll I have ever tasted! In my opinion, Cinnabon does not come close in comparison!! I do not own a bread machine so I made the rolls by hand.  As recommended by another review, I dissolved yeast in warm milk and added margarine, salt, sugar and eggs. At this time, you should add flour to mixture 1 cup at time.  When dough is kneaded and all flour mixed in, roll into a ball and set aside(covered) to rise for about 1 hour.  Now you can follow the rest of instructions from main recipe page... Try these Cinnamon Rolls because you'll NEVER want to purchase from the store or another venue ever again!!! Absolutely delightful:)

country:
None
text:
These are A-MA-ZING.  I don't have a bread machine and these turn out wonderfully made by hand.  I double the filling to make them extra gooey.    To save time, I double the recipe and after the rolls have been sliced I lay them on a cookie sheet with parchment paper and freeze them.  When they are frozen, they can be stored in the freezer in a ziplock bag.  The night before I serve them, I put as many as I want in a baking dish and let them thaw and rise overnight.  They are ready to be baked in the morning.    These also bake well in individual size ramekins if there's just a couple of you at home.

Really amazing... definitely NOT a Cinnabon though!! Hubby thinks they're better. Things i'll do differently next time--more cinnamon sugar filling. Like this recipe needed another review but my oh my YUMMY! I made the dough in my bread machine. My machine came with a book of recipes and there is one for cinnamon rolls so I just put the ingriedients in the order that that recipe suggested. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/137213.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making cinnamon rolls from scratch!  I don't have a bread machine, so I dissolved one packet yeast in one cup warm milk and added 1/4 cup sugar.  I let that mixture sit for 10 minutes to activate the yeast and then added the eggs, salt, the rest of the sugar, a bit of vanilla (personal preference), and 2 cups of the flour and mixed well.  Then I added the other 2 1/2 cups of flour and kneaded until the dough pulled away from the bowl.  I set in a greased bowl, covered with a towel in an oven that had been preheated to 250 degrees and then turned off, and let the dough rise for one hour.  Then I proceeded with the rolling out portion of the recipe.  I made 78 rolls for my husband's co-workers and got rave reviews!  On two pans of rolls I combined 1 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup butter, and 2 T. corn syrup in a pan over medium heat until melted.  I removed from heat and stirred in 1 tsp. vanilla.  I divided the mixture between the two pans and spread evenly in the bottom before putting in the rolls.  Presto - caramel rolls!  No need to frost!

text:
THESE CINNAMON ROLLS ARE TO DIE FOR!!!!! I have spent years  trying to 'per-fect' the cinnamon roll! I found these are absolutely the perfect cinnamon roll!!!   Its one of my all time favorite things to make so I make cinn. rolls a lot.  I thought I would give this recipe a go since it had so many reviews.  I did tweak it a little based on a friends recommendation and tidbits I've read on the internet.  In the roll recipe, it calls for sugar.  I used honey instead to see if I could get an even softer and moister roll.  Sure enuf!! Honey did the trick! I also used a higher quality cinnamon.  Saigon Cinnamon.  I went to Costco and got a 10oz. container for $3.60. I certainly noticed a difference in tastes between my old cinn. and the higher quality cinnamon! I also used 1/2 c. heavy whipping cream in the filling and put on frosting as soon as rolls came out.  Uh, lets just say I skipped dinner that night and ate nearly 1/2 the pan.   Using the tips I just shared, I have never tasted a better cinnamon roll than these!! And I've made A LOT of cinn. rolls over the years. I think they  were MUCH BETTER than  the ones you get in the mall by far!!!!!

I don't need to tell you these are great.  2000 people before me have done that!  They are so easy!  I usually divide the recipe into 2 8 x 8 or 9 x 9 pans and bake one (usually make the night before, put in fridge, in a.m. let warm to room temp, then bake) and freeze one then let thaw overnight in fridge.  I put 9 rolls in each pan.  My family loves them.  At Thanksgiving I gave everyone a pan to take home to make the next morning or freeze and make whenever they wanted.  They all loved me!

text:
To reviewer Julielynn...Yes you can make these the night before and bake in the morning.  That is the only way I have ever made these.  After making them you will obviously store them in the refrigerator overnight.  Pull them out in plenty of time to come back to room temp before baking.  They will take at least a couple of hours so plan accordingly.  I agree with other reviewers that these are best baked at 350 for a bit longer than 20 minutes.  Hope that helps!

text:
Been using this recipe for years, it is wonderful! A few things I learned: Once you roll it out if you take your measuring tape across the roll you can "indent" where you should cut, then use dental floss (just place under it and cross on top). Also I melt a cup of so of ice cream (any flavor Vanilla, Carmel, ect) with some butter and brown sugar together and pour that in the bottom of the pan, then when done cooking I Flip them into another pan, extra gooey that way!

text:
WOW were these good!!!!  They are very, very sweet (some suggested doubling the frosting - I love frosting and found that the original recipe amount is plenty).  I turned the oven down as some recommended and baked them a bit longer, they got somewhat brown on top but not burnt.  I also added chopped pecans in half of them - both with and without pecans they were great!!!!  I think they tasted pretty similar to a cinnabon, esp the dough - the frosting is a bit different but still VERY good.  They also reheated very well in the microwave and tasted just as good, if not better than the day I made them!!

Update 7/6/08 - made them again....they are sooooooooo good.  I omitted to say the first time I reviewed this recipe that I turned the pan upside down on a baking sheet lined with foil (for easy clean-up) for about 5 minutes after they were done baking to recoat the rolls with gooey goodness.  I made these again adding pecans to half of them - my husband and I can't decide which ones we like better!!!

text:
I made these for our Mother's Day brunch and they turned out perfect!!  I don't have a bread machine so I used the tips from another reviewer (mcatherwood) which were spot on.  1.) 7-8 oz Active Dry Yeast instead of bread machine yeast.  2.) Mix with hands 3.) heat oven to 200 degrees and turn off.  Let dough rise in oven for 1 hour in mixing bowl with damp paper towels covering bowl. 4.) line 9x13 with buttered wax paper. 5.) I made my dough and assembled the rolls the night before and put them in the fridge overnight.  I took them out of the fridge about 1 hour before I wanted to cook them so they could come to room temp and rise a bit more. 6.) Bake at 350 for 20 minutes. 7.) Took the rolls out of the pan immediately then spread the frosting on top 8.) made double the frosting so we would have extra (also great for fruit dipping or Oreos).  Thanks for the great recipe and instructions.

text:
I worked at Cinnabon a long time ago, and this is as close it gets w/out literally stealing their recipe. I agree with another comment....flip the pan to keep all of the cinnamon. Another variation is the pecan roll. Same recipe, but take a piece of wax paper, and press it in the bottom of your 9X13 pan. Use these ingredients: 
6 tbl unsalted butter, softened
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 cup brown sugar
30 pecan halves
Cream together the butter, salt and sugar. Spread this topping evenly on the wax paper covered bottom of the pan. Place your rolls on top of this mixture and bake as usual. While still hot,invert immediately onto a plate. If you wait until it cools, the caramel will harden and it will be difficult to turn out.

text:
This is now "my" recipe. I make this over and over, and it's the only cinnamon role recipe I will use. I found a way to make them ahead of time is to get them all ready in the pan, cover them with plastic wrap, and put them in the fridge until morning. Then pull them out and take off the plastic, set the oven to low (turn it off again once it preheats) and cover the pan with a towel and place it in the oven for about 40 minutes (or until doubled), then take them out, preheat the oven to baking temp, and bake! This way, they're ready in about an hour. ENJOY!!!

text:
I just made these today and they are awesome.  I did not use my bread machine but did use my food processor with my dough hook instead of kneeding by hand. It's best to add liquids to flour when using your food processor   To do this, first stir in yeast to dissolve in warm milk (110 degrees) with sugar and salt.  Let sit 5-10 mins then add melted margarine and beaten eggs to milk/yeast and stir. Slowly pour into flour already in food processor and process while adding liquid just until the dough forms a ball.  I preheat my oven to 200 and then turn it off to create a warm, dry place for the dough then placed it in a greased bowl with damp cloth or paper towel covering it for 1 hour to rise.
I used the method of combining the butter and sugar/cinnamon into a spread - although we did find it harder to spread this on the dough it did not all leak to the bottom on the pan when baked so the rolls are full of the ooey gooey cinnamon goodness :0)
thanks for the great recipe !

text:
I have been making this recipe for a long time, and it is one of my favorite recipes of all time.  I stumbled upon a solution to the much-lamented filling running out of the bottom that really makes them perfect.  When making the filling mixture, do everything exactly according to the recipe but double the cinnamon.  For some reason this makes it stick to the sides and they end up looking like the insides of Cinnabons, but it definitely doesn't make the cinnamon flavor too strong.  I have made three batches this way and they all turn out perfect.

text:
This Recipe is truly inspired. I cannot tell you how good this was. you have got to try it for yourself to believe it. I didnt have bread flour so i used all purpose flour... a website suggested that you add 1 tablespoon of all purpose flour extra per cup to effectively substitute the bread flour. 
i dont have a bread machine and i followed the advice from the most helpful reviews on how to make it without. NO ONE can tell that i didnt use butter. I used vegetable ghee (widely available in south asia and often used as a substitute when recipes call for crisco or shortening). I used  tablespoons of cinnamon but if I had used the full amount I am sure it would have been good still. i did not make the sauce so i cannot pass judgement on that just yet. if you store them in an airtight box as soon as they are warm you can keep them from going hard. they are fabulous even the next day.. cant say more than that... they didnt last 24 hours in my house.

Just to add my applause to the list - these were fantastic! I also made by hand (no bread machine), and used a quick-rise method - placed the dough in a warm oven for 20 minutes, then when baking, started the oven on a very low temp for 5 minutes (150 F) and then cranked it up to the right temperature for 15 minutes. text:
Wow!  Excellent recipe.  I am a beginner bread maker and this is the first time I made these rolls...they turned out fantastic!  I didn't expect them to turn out so huge.  I did make a caramel sauce (taken from this site from another review of a diff't cinnamon roll recipe) to spread on the bottom of the 9x12 pan before putting the rolls in to rise a second time.  Caramel sauce - melted 1/3 cup butter, w/ 1/3 cup light brown sugar, and 1/2 cup vanilla ice cream till thickened and bubbly.  It made the rolls really ooey, gooey and so fantastically luscious.  I also flipped the pan over so the caramel sauce and the cinnamon sugar will recoat the rolls and flipped it back after 5-8 minutes or so.  Next time I will bake at 350 for 20 minutes instead of 400 at 15.

text:
I'm in love....lol.  And very impressed with myself- they are so beautiful!  I used my Kitchenaid because I have no bread machine.  I warmed up the milk and melted the butter in it, added the sugar, and when this mixture measured 110 degrees (on my meat thermomter) I added the yeast and let it bloom for 10 minutes.  Then added the rest of ingredients.  I used 2 cups whole wheat flour and Neufchatel cheese.  The dough was a little sticky.  I let it rise for one hour, then proceeded with the recipe.  I might reduce the brown sugar a little next time, these were pretty sweet.  I did not double the icing, and it was the perfect amount.  If I had doubled it like many other reviewers, I would have had waaaay too much icing left over.  I used natural, un-waxed dental floss to cut these.  I had trouble making each one exactly the same size, but no one seems to care!  Now I know I can make cinnamon rolls!  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Excellent!  I followed the recipe exactly, and the bread machine made these very easy.  I've never successfully made any sort of rising bread before, so I was happy to have very clear instructions.

We only used about 1/2 the icing, so I'll adjust next time, and I'll cut the cinnamon a bit (I love cinnamon, but I think the stuff I used was very strong).  

Other reviewer tips I followed:
- flipped the pan once they came out of the oven to coat the rolls in the filling, and it worked wonders.
- baked in glass vs metal, and they turned out nicer than the first time I made them
- baked at 350 for 25-30 mins

Thank you for sharing this recipe - they are a wonderful treat!

**I just realized I used an 8oz package of cream cheese instead of a 3oz package!  That explains the not-too-sweet taste and the amount of icing left over.  It was still delicious!

city:

country:
None
text:
Although I thoroughly enjoyed making these from scratch cinnamon buns - I wasn't entirely impressed.  The overall flavor was good, but not close to resembling a cinnabon!  I used 1/2 cup dark brown sugar and 1/2 cup light brown sugar and increased the cinnamon to 3 tablespoons.  I didn't bother making the frosting as stated in the recipe.  Too much butter and not enough cream cheese - so I recommend:  8 oz softened cream cheese, 1/4 cup softened butter, 1 1/2 cups powdered sugar, and a generous tsp of vanilla (or almond).  This will give you a true creamy (cream cheese flavor) frosting and not an overpowering icing... so you can enjoy the flavors of the cinnamon bun without it being toothachingly sweet.      

This recipe can be done without a bread machine.  I don't own one so I did it with my Kitchen-Aid stand mixter; everything came out as it should.  (Let milk, sugar and yeast sit for 10 minutes.  Add other ingredients, mix well, then slowly incorporate the flour 1 cup at a time.  Kneed dough until it pulls together.  Turn out onto floured surface - lightly flour dough so it's not sticky.  Clean out mixing bowl, grease the mixing bowl with butter, return dough to mixing bowl; cover and let rise 1 hour in a warm place.  Follow remaining steps as indicated in the recipe.  
  
Rated 3 stars because these weren't the "the BEST" cinnamon buns I've ever had.  Delicious, but just average.

country:
None
text:
This is the exact same dough recipe that is in my "Better Homes and Gardens" cookbook--that old classic with the red & white cover.  LOL!  Just a slightly different filling and icing.

For a lower calorie roll, divide dough in half.  Roll each half into a 12X8 rectangle.  Spread with half of the butter and cinnamon mixture.  Roll from 12" side.  Cut each 12" roll into 12 1" pieces--a total of 24 rolls.  Bake in 9" round pans at 350 for 20-25 minutes.

I make mini-rolls by cutting the dough in half, rolling into 12X12 sheet, spread with half of the butter & cinnamon mix.  Then cut in half and roll up each rectangle from the 12" side.  Cut into 1" rolls.  Repeat with the other half of the dough.  You'll end up with 4 dozen mini-rolls. Bake at 350 for 15 minutes.

If you want to go a tiny bit healthier...use half whole wheat flour.  ;-)

text:
YUM, these came out absolutely perfect!  They looked and tasted like the ones you'd pay several dollars a piece for, but they are cheap to make.  Yes, you need to invest some time into this recipe, BUT it will be worth the wait.  The neater you roll out and shape the "roll" of dough, the prettier they will be.  The amount of cinnamon & brown sugar for the filling is right on, and the only additional item I added was gluten, because I put it in almost everything that goes into my breadmaker.  OH- and you really MUST make the icing to have an authentic experience.  IMO- if you don't have a breadmaker & want one, go to your local Goodwill store.  (I got an excellent one that looked brand new for $10.  Just make sure it has the blade and the basket.  Even if it doesn't have the instructions, you can pretty much use any you find on the web.)

This recipe was perfect! I used a bread machine (which made it so quick and easy), turned down oven temp to 350 for 20-25 minutes and placed the pan on the rack one down from the center, and added toasted walnuts to the brown sugar and cinnamon filling - 12 rolls, gone in 2 days :) I have always wanted a good roll recipe but had been intimidated by thoughts of sticky dough, messy non-rising or dry results - this recipe was very EASY, neat and with a FANTASTIC taste! Reading others reviews and comments really helped to make the recipe flow smoothly - thanks to whoever suggested greasing a sheet of waxed paper with butter and putting it on the bottom of the pan when rising & baking - clean up was a snap and the rolls looked like showpieces!
THANK YOU MARSHA!

I tried this recipe - thinking the whole time that I would never be able to do it - but they were awesome!  My bread machine was broken, so I had to make the dough by hand and they STILL turned out.  I just used regular yeast and let it rise in the oven for an hour at 200 degrees (it's turned off before you put the dough in).  I also used floss to cut the rolls, which worked really well.  One note - I had to add more flour both times I've made these, although it may be becuase I made them by hand!

hansberryd

None
text:
Oh my goodness I'm crying. These are soooo good!! As an American now living in Australia, cinnabons were my favorite growing up (until I learned what was in them!), but Australia doesn't really do cinnamon rolls, not like this anyway, so I haven't had one in a long time. I did make a few changes based on some of the reviews. I let the bread machine do all the sticky work (mixing and kneading the dough until it was smoother). I took it out and kneaded it a little more for about 10 minutes. I found the dough easy to roll out thin, perhaps because I gave it some extra kneading time and made it a bit stretchier. I combined the butter and cinnamon sugar and spread it on the rolled out dough. I baked them at 350 (175C) for 20 minutes. Perfect. Cooked all the way through, golden brown on top, no leaky filling.

I have a small bread maker (1kg) but all the ingredients fit fine. In fact I would not recommend cutting this recipe in half unless you're going to make the dough by hand because there wouldn't be enough dough to engage the hook of the bread maker and it won't knead the dough properly. These are very rich and sweet, so if that's not your thing then don't make these. People seem to be impressed that I made the dough myself, but it was very easy. I can't wait to impress all of my sugar addict friends with these!

These are absolutely wonderful!  The dough is very easy to work with and has such a good texture once baked.  I'm not a big fan of icing on my cinnamon rolls so I increased the butter for the filling to 1/2 cup and decreased the cinnamon to 1 1/2 Tablespoons (personal preference). edgeycook

city:

country:

text:
Let me start with - I am a fairly good cook and don't intimidate easily in the kitchen - BUT have never used yeast & I NEVER made cinnamon rolls. I scrolled through a lot of the comments and wrote down those suggestions that were common and came up with 'my' recipe.  I couldn't believe how easy it was.  Here are some of my suggestions.
1.  1 1/2 times the 'filling' mixture.  I did 2X-was just a bit much for me.
2.  Frosting - made it as directed.  It's WAY to much. It's great but really too much.  Could probably do 1/2 to 3/4.  
3.  I don't have a bread machine so followed the nice folks suggestions on how to make it without a bread machine.  I did let the mix butter/warm milk with the yeast for just a few minutes and then finished it up.
4.  I doubled the recipe and it worked fine. Split the dough into two balls, let it rise separately and essentially treated it as two batches except for the actual making of the dough.
5.  I did brush the dough (once rolled out) with milk.  To be honest, I don't know if it really made a difference or not.  I just know my cinnamon rolls turned out great.  (this was one of the common suggestions in the comments)
6. Used parchment paper, flipped rolls for a few minutes and flipped back so filling goes back to top for a bit
7. I rolled & cut the cinnamon rolls and cut them.  Put them on parchment paper lined baking sheet and froze solid and then stored in zip lock bag.  Thaw overnight, covered w/plastic in pan you will bake in.  Perfect!

Display Name:
AZ93

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/971944.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think many people are making 2 mistakes. One is that they might be using regular yeast instead of bread machine or instant (also called rapid rise) yeast. If you are using regular yeast, you need to proof it first! This gives it a chance to start growing and will help your dough to rise properly later. Second mistake sounds like improper flour measuring. Are you scooping the flour out with the measuring cup? This compacts the flour and adds up to 20% more flour per cup. The dough will then come out dry or too dense. Go to the King Arthur flour website and watch their video (~3 minutes) on proper flour measuring. Speaking of King Arthur flour....the flavor and texture is heads and tails above the other ones in the store. Trust me, it's worth the extra dollar. They also have this exact same recipe on their site (called "cinna-buns") with a lot more direction. If you are a beginner or have questions, I would start there. Good luck!

text:
Delicious! I don't have a bread machine so I used 2.25 tsp of regular yeast and let is sit in the warm milk for 10 mins. From there I added the sugar and salt, eggs, margarine, and flour.  The dough is EXTREMELY sticky so I recommend kneading it on a floured surface. You'll need flexible hard plastic spatula to get all the dough from the bowl. Knead for 10 mins, make a ball, and place in a lightly oiled bowl. Cover and place in a warm spot for 1 hour. From there you can move forward with the directions as written. Definitely worth the extra work.  Thanks for the recipe.  Fabulous!

karla

text:
No bread machine so here's what I do: 

Add yeast and 1 tsp of the sugar to the warm milk, stir to dissolve, and let it sit for 10 mins until foamy.  I use shortening softened a bit in the micro for the dough b/c I don't use margarine.   I use my mixer to mix the dough on the knead setting.  

After it's formed a ball, this is sticky dough, I turn it out onto a WELL-floured surface and knead it a couple times by hand, form into a ball and place in a bowl sprayed w/ cooking spray, cover it with a damp cloth and let rise in a 200 deg oven that's been preheated and then turned off. 

After 1 hr, roll it out on a VERY WELL-FLOURED surface.  If you don't flour the surface well, you'll have a mess trying to roll your stuck dough off the surface.  

Roll a 16x21" rectangle, spread on butter and sprinkle/spoon/pour on the brown sugar mix, leaving 1/4" margin of no butter/no sugar at the far end of the rectangle so I can seal the roll, as another review suggested.  Also per said reviewer, I use my rolling pin over the sugar mixture to smoosh it into the dough and to compress it so it's not falling out all over when I roll up the dough. 

Cut into 12 rolls, use a glass 9x13 pan, cover and let rise 10 minutes in 200 deg oven again, cover in plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.  No problems with loosing goo, so not sure why that happens to some.

Cooks perfectly in the a.m.  Frosting makes too much though.  I put it on when the rolls are hot or it's too thick.  The family loves it.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-02-12T14:51:07.79

text:
I'm never buying cinnamon rolls again.  This is simple and good!  I don't have a bread maker so I proofed the yeast by adding a package of active yeast to the warm milk & 1 tsp. of sugar - let sit for 10mins until frothy.  Added the wet ingredients and with the hook attachment on the Kitchen aid, added the all purpose flour until a ball formed.  Let rise and followed the recipe instructions from there.  I used dental floss to cut the rolls.  Baked @ 350 for 30 mins.  DELICIOUS!  Definitely worth the effort, though it wasn't much effort at all.  My family loved it.

text:
OH MY GREAT GOOGLEY MOOGLEY!!  My family and I devoured the first batch immediately (minus the last one, everyone is always leery about the last one).  The first try was kind of dry, even with flipping them over to cool, though, so I made an alteration that made it all better and so wonderfully moist!  They were so easy to make and I'm excited to use this recipe from here on out! I did go with some of the alternate suggestions; I don't have a bread machine, so I used the first review to mix it up.  Immediately after they came out of the oven, I melted extra butter and mixed in more cinnamon and brown sugar, then I poured it over them, sealed it up with aluminum foil, let it sit for about 5 minutes, then (using a cooling rack to hold the foil and rolls into place)flipped the pan over and let it cool.  (plan to experiment with adding extra sauce before baking as well). When I served them, I just put them individually in the microwave or all together at a low setting in the oven.  Anyway, thank you so much, Marsha!!  They are fantastic!

text:
These are amazing. I just use the dough recipe and they are very  fluffy and just like the ones as cinnabon. I had good luck with these over the summer because the yeast made the dough rise beautifully in the hot weather. For winter months I'll use instant yeast, double checking that the temp is between 105-110, then use the proofing button on my oven. As long as there are some great rising, this recipe will work perfectly. Good sweet icing too!

text:
Much thanks to Marsha for the recipe! With a few tweaks I've gotten this close to my own experience of a Cinnabon--which I need to do since the only Cinnabon in town closed a few years ago and I don't spend much time in airports.

Increased the butter spread on the dough to a full stick (1/2 cup) and decreased baking time to 11 minutes 30 seconds to get the classic Cinnabon gooey center.   Recipe as written with 15 minute baking time came out too brown and baked in my oven.  I'm one of those guys who gets annoyed with the "excellent recipe, I changed everything" reviews, so I saved the changes as a new recipe called Clone of a Cinnabon trial 3.

Thanks again to Marsha!

text:
I LOVE this recipe! I did tweek it though. I doubled the amount of ingredients for the cinnamon, butter and brown sugar. I found that the extra helped bring a more true Cinnabon middle. I also used DARK brown sugar instead of light. I also melted the butter down and mixed the cinnamon and brown sugar into it to make like a paste and used hands to "spread" it. For the icing I increased the amount of cream cheese to an 8oz pkg, 2 tablespoons of sour cream and 2 tablespoons of butter only because I like a sweet/tangy icing.

text:
Well I rarely rate recipes probably because most are not 5 stars but this one I had too. I made this for a morning I had a houseful of kids who love Cinnabon, and every person had seconds. They LOVED them! I made the night before also, if anyone has trouble getting them to rise after you put them in the pan you really need a warm spot, I was running the drier so I put the covered glass dish in the laundry room and closed the door, in about 45 min they rose nicely. I then put them in the fridge, the following morning I put them on the counter when the oven was preheating popped them in at 350 degrees for 25 minutes and they came out perfect. I doubled the iciing recipe since I had many kids, the only comment I heard from almost everyone was if I make them again to cut the cream cheese amt in half for Cinnabons iciing wasnt so cream cheesey tasting I would substitute with more butter, I agreed. These were amazing!!

text:
These are excellent cinabuns and I will never buy the frozen ones again!  I use my zojirushi bread machine which I love and they come out perfect.  I spray the pan with nonstick coating and never had an issue of them sticking.  I also melted the butter by accident one time and found that the filling didn't roll out of them when they were cooked like they did before.  My kids LOVE them so I freeze the uncooked ones in a ziplock bag and cook them when they want them.  
 
I make extra icing as one user already mentioned and used her measurements: the entire package of creamed cheese which is an 8 oz package of lowfat creamed cheese (2/3 c butter, 4 cups powdered sugar, 1-1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/3 tsp salt) and after I beat it well I drop spoonfuls on wax paper and freeze them.  Once frozen I wrap them individually in plastic wrap and into a ziplock and back into the freezer so when my kids want them I have everything ready!

OMG these are so good (eating one atm).  Have never made cinnamon rolls before and these turned out perfect.  I did double the filling because the "goop" is the best part, and used part light brown sugar and part dark brown sugar.  I don't have a bread machine, so I followed other suggestions for making them in my kitchen aid.  Super easy.  Rolled and cut them and put them in a glass baking dish in the fridge overnight.  Pulled them out in the morning 30 minutes before baking and baked for 30 minutes at 350 degrees.  Whooooo!

These were absolutely the best and very forgiving. Like others I didn't have a bread machine or bread flour. Just proofed yeast for 10 minutes in 110 degree whole milk with 1 teas of sugar.  I followed recipe exactly except after mixing all the wet ingredients with the flour I guess I should have kneaded the dough but didn't, just allowed it to rise. Even without  the kneading dough easily doubled and they couldn't have been any better! The softest cinnamon rolls I've ever made. Will be making these again and often for overnight company.

Display Name:
Terri Rice Cornell

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2302228.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good! No bread machine so proofed 2 1/2 tsp of active dry yeast in warm milk w/1 tsp sugar for 10 minutes, added the other wet ingredients then the bread flour. I use Pam instead of flour on my work surface, flour dusted rolls are yuck :) Let it rise 1 1/2 hours. Mixed the melted butter w/the cinnamon & sugar then spread it on the dough, left 1/2 inch at the end for the dough to seal together as another suggested. Rolled from the short side, cut it in half then cut those 2 pieces in half again (4 pieces now) then cut each of the 4 pieces into thirds, nice and uniform that way. Baked in lower 3rd of the oven at 350 for 23 minutes. Couple popped into cones LOL but pushed them back down w/a knife, think it's because the pan was so full they ran out of room! Will definitely make these again, thanks!!

We follow the recipe except add 1/2 cup chopped walnuts and 1/2 cup raisins to the filling.
Gives them more flavor and makes them more interesting. We bake at 350 (for a couple extra minutes) instead of 400 degrees to ensure the filling is fully cooked before the rolls get too dark.
In order to keep from gaining 50 pounds we limit ourselves to making this recipe only once per month.

Yum!!! After looking through countless cinnamon roll recipes, glad I tried this one. Didn't have bread flour so used all-purpose and used butter in place of the margarine. Also, the full cup of brown sugar seemed like too much so reduced it to 3/4. Family raved. Time consuming but worth the effort. :)

These are fantastic. I've made them several times and they are always a big hit with my friends and family. There is only two things I do differently. I proof my yeast in water (so a reduce my milk by a bit) since it doesn't like to proof in milk for me. I also bake them on a larger baking sheet to they don't stick together and they come out all round and perfect. Other than that, I think this recipe is just wonderful.

country:

text:
Oh so excellent...  Follow BDBCOOK's frosting/freezing/refrigerating ideas.

I use a total of one stick of butter. A little over half goes in the dough (in place of margarine), a tablespoon or so is spread on the dough before the cinnamon, the rest goes in the frosting, and the wrapper is used to grease the pan.

Flip the pan when it comes out of the oven.

It helps to run the rolling pin over the cinnamon/brown sugar mix once it is sprinkled on.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Dissolve an 8 g packet of dry active yeast in warm milk and 1/4 c sugar. Let it stand for 10 minutes,till yeast is foamy.Then add the remaining wet ingredients.In the end add the flour and mixed with the dough hooks of my beater till dough ball is formed .Heated oven 200F,and turned it off.Cover dough with moist kitchen towel over bowl.Put in oven for 1 hour.By then the dough will have doubled in volume.Then roll out the dough in rectangle shape.Spread butter,and then sprinkle brown sugar and cinammon mixture on top.Roll it,slice in 12 pieces and put in greased 9 x 13 in glass baking dish.Cover for 30 more minutes.Then bake in 350 F oven for 20-25 minutes,(Set pan on lower rack to bake-i read this but forgot it.will try itnext time and see the difference.)Also someone mentioned that right after taking it out of oven invert the pan so that the drippings recoat the buns.SInce I didnt have much drippings didnt do it. Thanks for this deliciously and easy recipe.

text:
I have made this a few times. A few things to note, always use bread flour, not all purpose flour. Bread flour has more gluten, which makes the dough more elastic, springy, and chewy. Which is good for breads, but not cakes or cookies. I always use butter and it turns out great every time. Those who say that margarine makes it lighter are wrong. The lightness of the bread depends on the type of flour used.

text:
These are really good.  I have made them several times.  You can use one cup of whole wheat bread flour and the rest white bread flour.  You won't notice the difference.  The only recommendation I would make is to bake them for longer than 15 minutes.  They are too doughy for me and my family when only baked for 15 minutes.  I bake them for at least 25 minutes.

text:
These are diffucult for me to rate. The dough gets a 5 star. The frosting gets a 1 star and the filling gets 2-3 stars. First off, I do not like things that are very sweet so that affects my rating here. I think I would like them with no icing at all, or perhaps just a light glaze. Also, I would cut back on the brown sugar for the filling. I think that way, they would get a 5 star rating from me.For anyone who really likes sweet, these would be perfect.    I used my kitchen aid to make these, turned them upside down as soon as they came out of the oven and let them rise overnight in the frig. Put them in a cold oven in the morning. Turned the oven to 350 degrees and backed for about 35 minutes. This worked GREAT!!!! The dough is very tasty and so easy to work with. I just happen to not like really sweet rolls.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made without a bread machine.  So easy and beyond delicious.  I baked mine about 3" apart on a greased cookie sheet and they turned out beautifully.  I lowered the temp by about 25 degrees since my oven tends to be hotter.  I checked them every few minutes towards the end to make sure they were not burning.  Nothing worse than overcooked burned rolls.  I'd rather have them slightly undercooked.  Once they were golden brown and I pulled them out, turned them onto a big cutting board and scrapped off the drippings back onto the rolls.  I let everyone ice their own.  I can't say enough on just how pretty these looked and how awesome they tasted.  Note on the freezing.  I froze a second batch AFTER I cut them each into individual rolls.  You also freeze them BEFORE the second rising.  Just pop them into a freezer bag right after cutting.  Set them out the night before you are ready to cook them.  I put the frozen ones in a round pan and covered with SaranWrap sprayed with oil.  I put them in the fridge about 12 hours before I cooked them.  That gave mine time to defrost and rise.  Hope this helps.

text:
I have had this recipe saved for ages, and I finally made the time to prepare it.  As a chef, I don't keep or use a bread machine, so I used my stand mixer and dough hook to prepare the dough.    4 3/4 cups of strong baking flour (Lehi Mills/Turkey Brand), 1/3 cup melted butter, and 2.5 tsp. active dry yeast were the only changes I made.  For the frosting, I used 8 oz. cream cheese and 8 oz. softened butter, plus vanilla and confectioner's sugar.  It achieves a more Cinnabon-like consistency with the added butter, though I prefer this preparation even to Cinnabon's.  A great recipe, with some patience for the rising time.  My husband declared them the best cinnamon rolls "known to man."

text:
These are perfect! If you're making them ahead of time, I flash froze the unbaked rolls individually on a cookie sheet. Then when my family wants cinnamon rolls, I just put however many we need into a greased baking pan, cover with greased plastic wrap and leave out on the counter overnight. Come morning, the deliciously plump rolls are ready to be baked per the directions. The frosting also freezes nicely too. I double the frosting and then seperate into 2 ziplocs. To make frosting the finished rolls easy, simply snip off a corner of the ziploc bag and squeeze the frosting out. Simple and no mess!

text:
Awesome! This is my first time working with bread dough - never even made a loaf of bread before and it was so easy - everything turned out perfectly. I don't have a bread machine, so I followed one reviewer's suggestion of dissolving a packet of dry active yeast in the warm milk, then adding the other ingredients, kneading by hand, and letting rise in an oven that was heated to 200, then turned off before putting the ball of dough in. Covered it with a moist paper towel and waited for it to double in size, about an hour. I started baking them at 400 and after 10 minutes they were getting too dark and the middles seemed to be doughy still, so reduced heat to 350 and covered them with foil, baked another 5 minutes. Next time I will bake them at 350 for 20 minutes. I doubled the icing as suggested by some reviewers, but had half left, so won't do that again. Great recipe!

text:
These were sinfully delicious! I did not use a bread machine, but combined all of the ingredients (note: only 2 cups of the flour) into a bowl and used my hand mixer on low for 1 minute, then on medium for 1 additional minute.  I then added an additional 2 cups of flour and mixed it by hand. I then turned it out onto a well foured surface and kneaded for 5 minutes. I let the dough raise, covered with plastic wrap, for 1 hour and 15 minutes on top of my oven, which I heated to 250 degrees. I then followed the recipe, until it came time to bake. I baked them at 375 degrees for 22 minutes.This was perfect. I ate 3 of them myself and got a horrible, gluttonous stomach ache!

I have read so many reviews about what to do about the ingredients that fall out of the roll and end up in the bottom of the pan. And the one with the best answer( most helpful ) is still short as to what should be done about it.      When I make this recipe I NEVER have this problem and I believe its because when I rolls up the dough I roll it tight at least 7 turns per log of dough. After baking , there is no ingredients in the bottom of the pan, Its Still In the Roll. I hope this helps Ray

favoritesCount:
8
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/121086.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe.  Duplicates the Cinnabon very well.  I made a half batch and found that it was more than enough.  I increased the amount of powdered sugar in the icing because I thought it tasted a little too much like the cream cheese.  If you are making a full batch, I recommend increasing it from 1.5 to 2 cups, though doubling the entire frosting recipe is not a bad idea (in which case you'd up sugar from 3 to 4 cups).  You definitely don't need a bread maker - just mix up the dough ingredients and knead for 5 mins.  Let it rise an hour in a warmed oven and you're set.  I made smaller rolls, and 18 mins at 350 was perfect.  Some say this recipe is not like a *true* cinnabon.  And they're right.  If you want to make it a "true" cinnabon, double or triple the filling ingredients, especially the butter, and pour some butter on top.  In fact, just take a stick of butter and eat it straight.  Or better yet, melt the butter and set up a butter IV to save yourself the time.  Overall, a great recipe.

country:
None
text:
YUM!!! These are money makers baby! I brought them to work and got rave reviews. I made the cinnamon rolls the night before and also the frosting and pulled them both out of the fridge 1/2 hr before baking. I found that putting the rolls in the fridge the night before helped the butter harden in the rolls and when I cooked them I had no problem with the cinnamon/brown sugar filling running out the bottom. They were perfect and oh so gooey. I also didn't use a bread maker. Easily done without, just look at other reviews. I also didn't put the frosting on until they were just warm to the touch, but the pan was still hot. That way most of the frosting stayed right on the cinnamon rolls and didn't melt off the sides. I also doubled the frosting, you have to! These are just as good heated up in the microwave the next day.

text:
Delicious!  My tweaks:  I like the taste of whole wheat flour so I subbed two cups of whole wheat for two cups of the white flour.  I also sprinkled a big handful of chopped toasted pecans over the sugar/butter mix on the dough before rolling it up and slicing it.
Someone else posted about tipping the buns out of the pan right after baking to get the syrup that flows out to go back into the buns and it works really well. The buns were so much moister.  I iced the bottom of the buns and the syrupy stuff melted into the frosting which was so amazing.

text:
Excellent, absolutely delicious recipe!  I followed a reviewer's advice about increasing the amount of cream cheese to 8 oz., and it was perfect.  The second time I made these rolls, I reduced the frosting's sugar to just one cup.  Also, I decided to add about a tablespoon of vanilla to the wet ingredients of the dough.  This is definitely a family favorite and shall be made on a regular basis.  In 2009 I started using Neufchatel cheese instead of cream cheese, which made the frosting easier to spread; and my family seemed to like it better.

text:
These are great and easy! I pull out the bread machine and keep making batches the whole day, stocking my freezer with rolls to keep my kids happy.  Place in a tin or 10 in a ziplock gallon bag to place in pan when ready to cook. Bakes best in glass pan. I like to bake at 375, and if frozen, I put them in as the oven is preheating to help them rise more. Cooking time can be a fine line, too little is doughy in center but once browned they can get pretty crispy around the egdes. Also, I just use butter cause I never buy margarine, put it in my quisinart cut into pats, throw in the cinn. and b. sugar, pulse to blend. Then crumble and spread around on the rolls before rolling. I found that sprinkling the filling on the butter, alot of it falls out when cutting the rolls apart.

These rolls were awesome!  I didn't use a bread machine, Just made the dough by hand added about 2 tsp extra white sugar and kneeded it until smooth and then placed it in a large oiled boil.  I put the dough in the fridge and let it slowly rise overnight.  I took the dough out,  punched it down, let it rise again for about 2 hours.  I rolled out the dough, filledit, cut and again let the rolls rise.   I threw a bunch of pecans in the bottom of my pan becuase I like to eat them afte the rolls have been baked on top of them.

Display Name:
Jaclyn G.

city:
