region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these three times now and each time they seem to get better. I have picked out my favorite alterations from the multitude of comments and this is what I came up with: 
I make them by hand, not a bread machine (dont have one). They never seem to double in size for me at first, but the second rise always helps. I have baked them in both a glass 9x12 dish, and cookie sheet, both work fine but I like the cookie sheet more just because they seem like they just keep growing! I usually have a few more than 12, more like 14 or so. I keep the ingrediants the same, but I mix the filling ingrediants together to make a paste so I can spread it easily. Also, when making the icing, I use melted butter and then heat it all up in the microwave for about 30 seconds before putting it on the rolls. It helps spread it out a little more. I also add a few drops of lemon juice to the icing (like 6-8 drops) just because I like the flavor. Lastly, if I am having chocolate cravings, I will add some semi-sweet choc chips on half of the filling, which melts in the oven and its sooooo good. But rich, so only try if you are a true chocoholic.  I am trying it overnight for the first time today, so I hope they come out as delicious as always!

city:

country:
None
text:
What to add...I made this for my sister's family Sunday morning and they were a hit.  Fairly easy to prepare,  the 200 degree preheat, turn off the oven and let the buns rise for about 40 minutes is a good method, especially since I refrigerated them overnight and did the second rise and baking the next morning.   I did double the icing recipe as someone else had suggested...good call... and the amount of cinnamon is not a mistake.  Two and a half tablespoons makes it a cinnabon. Also I baked them at 350 for 20 minutes and they were just cooked through.  FYI, I did not melt the butter for the dough as I thought hot butter would compromise the yeast.  Good recipe, thanks for sharing.  Update: I made these with 1/2 tsp orange peel in the cinnamon/brown sugar mixture and used 2 1/2 tbsp. orange juice concentrate in the icing mix instead of vanilla.  Wonderful!! I had an idea I might try...I love maple bars and I bet you could make the dough in that shape (omitting the cinnamon and brown sugar...or not)and using mapleine flavoring in the icing mixture.  FYI..I like the dough better if done by hand.  The bread machine method, at least my bread machine, seems to make the dough a little more dense than the hand kneading method. But I love this recipe either way.

text:
Decadent and oh so sinful.  So good.  I couldn't quite get them to rise after rolling them out, so I preheated my oven to 200 degress, shut it off, and then put the rolls in the oven with a towel over them while the oven cooled down.  It worked perfectly and they rose beautifully.  I also used just regular flour because I didn't have bread flour and they turned out just fine.  I'll definitely be making these again and again and again.  Thanks for the recipe!  ONE LAST THING.....  Since there's no way we could eat these at once, I made the icing and save it in a plastic container and then we heated the rolls as we ate them and then spread the icing on after we heated each.  So good!  UPDATE!!!!  Just made these again.  Heavenly.  Turned out perfect again.  Letting them rise in a semi warm (definitely not hot) is definitely the way to go.

I don't make cinnamon rolls because I have never found any that turn out very good.  I LOVED THESE! I don't have a bread machine so I combined all the ingredients (flour last) and mixed.  It was SO doughy and sticky but I managed to get it under control while kneading it with floured surface and hands. They rose great but I should have oiled the bowl for easier removal.  I also made these the night before, my daughter wanted them for her birthday breakfast.  I just put them all in a wax paper lined pan and put it in the fridge overnight.  Then I took them out in the morning and did the 200 degree - turned off oven and let them rise for about an hour.  They filled the pan and then I baked them for about 15 min at 350.  They were done in the middle and barely golden on top!  Perfect! Now the girls want them for Christmas morning! Thanks!

text:
Definitely better than Cinnabon!!  Even my picky kids agreed.  Just up from the table where each of us ate 2 of these in one sitting - ouch. I even healthed these up a bit with 3/4 whole wheat flour, reduced butter in the dough and added flaxseed meal.  I did not have cream cheese so used the sugar, vanilla, butter, maple extract from another site for the frosting. These were the best - one other tip use 1 TB flour in with the sugar/cinnamon mixture to keep the sugar mix from disappearing. UPDATE:  I've been making these for years now - following the recipe exactly and with small variations as above can't go wrong.  They are best when following the recipe exactly including using margarine and bread flour - small but important ingredients for the best possible result.

text:
Is there really anything to add to what's already been said?  These are super delicious!  These would have been gone within minutes if I didn't take half out after they cooled a few minutes, so I could freeze them for another time.  What was left was gone almost instantly.  These freeze great and I almost prefer them frozen and then heated in the microwave than fresh out of the oven.  Don't know why, but they tasted better that way.  I freeze them individually on wax paper in my freezer and once they are frozen, I put them in a freezer bag and pop them in the oven when someone wants one.  I've also made these for family and friends and I always get asked for the recipe!  Huge hit!  Oh yes, I also don't make these with a bread machine, but by hand.  Thanks so much for the excellent recipe!

text:
I got a bread machine at a garage sale and decided to try this out as my first recipe. I had never baked any kind of bread from scratch before, and this recipe came out absolutely perfect. I feel like they needed to have a little more filling, which is why I rated it a 4 instead of a 5 (next time I'll double the filling and it should be perfect) I followed other reviewers advice and baked them at 350 for 20 minutes and they were cooked perfectly throughout. I did double the icing recipe because I like a lot of frosting on my cinnamon rolls. I used 8oz cream cheese, 1/2 cup sweetened, unsalted real butter, 3 cups powdered sugar, 1.5tsp vanilla, and 1/4 tsp salt - it was honestly the best cream cheese frosting I've ever tasted - I can't wait to try it on cakes and cupcakes as well! I will definitely make these cinnamon rolls again. They're not quite as gooey as a Cinnabon, but they're still absolutely delicious!

text:
I took the advice of another reviewer, and mixed the butter with the cinnamon and sugar. It worked perfectly. Another trick I learned a while ago, is to mix a small amount of flour into the mixture as well. No more than a tablespoon is enough. It turns the cinnamon and sugar into almost a sauce inside. Also I do not have a bread machine either, so I did this by hand. The result was perfect. A great tasting cinnamon roll. One other thing, do NOT change the amount of cinnamon in this recipe, it is perfect as is. I have always found that a majority of cinnamon roll recipes do not have enough!

I'm a Family and Consumer Science teacher (Home Economics) and this is the one sugary recipe I have my students make.  I've made this with over 400 students and they have turned out wonderful every time.  I had to make some adjustments because of 40 minute periods, but I now have it down to a science. text:
OMG!  These are the best cinnamon rolls ever!  My whole family loves them and requests them often.  A lot of the time, I make the dough the night before and out in a ziploc in the fridge over night; allows it to rise quite a bit, makes them huge and fluffy!  HINT:  For a shorter 'dough cycle,' stop the cycle after 10 minutes of kneading (mine machine beeps at that time) and then let rise.  They turn out perfect and the dough cycle is like 15 min instead of 1 1/2 hours!

These are fantastic!  I've made them several times over the past few months--more cinnamon rolls than I've made in my whole life!!  I've made them with and without dough conditioner and there doesn't appear to be much difference.  I've also made them with Splenda in the dough and have only made them with Splenda Brown sugar and they taste GREAT! text:
Awesome, awesome, awesome!!!  Much better than the original IMHO.  The only "glitch" I had was that it took more than an hour for these to rise properly, so in the future I'll be able to plan more appropriately.

Also, I've read some of the reviews where folks had difficulty rolling out the dough.  I used a 20" french style straight rolling pin and rolled a couple of times vertically, a couple of times horizontally, pulled the corners by hand to form a rectangle and then repeated until I got to the desired size.  It was a snap, but I do believe that if I had used the common short two handled rolling pin, I'd still be rolling out the dough!

When you overhear your teenage sons tell their friends, "Mom makes THE BEST cinnamon rolls," you know you have a winner.  Tried starting them the night before and baking them off in the next morning.  Really, it's best to do it all at once for high rising, light rolls.  Make sure you roll the cinnamon mixture into the dough.  I watched the actual Cinnabon movie about it.  It keeps the filling from sinking to the bottom of the pan!

text:
Used a bread machine. Used directed amounts of butter, brown sugar and cinnamon (use less if you don't want to taste the cinnamon so clearly). Doubled cream cheese topping (just the right amount. Maybe that's why they didn't seem dry.) Also removed from pan immediately by flipping pan so juices stayed on buns. I even did the make the dough one day, put in fridge overnight, and cook the next morning. RAVE reviews. Very doughy recipe. It's a fork-and-knife kind of cinnamon roll. BIG servings. Roll tightly or they're HUGE.

userID:

Display Name:
QuebecGirl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5106483.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my mom's birthday and she was REALLY pleased! I had to make a second batch because they were gone within an hour. I used regular FAST acting dry yeast in the machine and it worked just fine. I let it raise more then I was supposed to, and waited 30 minutes with the dough on the counter before I rolled it. When ready to roll, I set my oven to 200F and shut it off when it reached the correct temp. Then I left my rolls sitting in the oven (covered with a damp cloth) next to a bowl of water until they touched each other. Pulled them out, cranked it up to 400F for the actual baking time. Mine were ready in 12 minutes. I added an extra ounce of cream cheese for the second batch of icing. Yum! This is a keeper! Notes: place the “ends” at the bottom of the pan. Also, you can spread the icing almost immediately as it does not melt as much as the commercial stuff. The 9x13 dish would have been too small, I use one size bigger and sprayed it with butter flavored non-stick spray, and I had no problems removing the buns.

text:
This is a great recipe!  I followed the recipe, except that I added about 1/3 cup of granulated sugar to the filling... honestly, it is almost too sweet for my husband and my tastes, but we are used to eating health-food :)  My first time, I didn't have any cream cheese, so I made an icing out of milk and confectioners sugar, but it really wasn't a great icing... I'm baking some right now and I'll use the recipe's icing.  Mine almost burned the first time, even though they still had 5 minutes to go, so watch them closely and taken them out when they are golden.  They're great re-heated in the mircowave!  Just be careful to not eat too many because they will cause a tummy ache... Thanks for this awesome recipe!

text:
I also hate giving this another 5 star, but this is the best cinnamon roll recipe.  It even beats my mothers.  !?!?  I made the dough, rolled it out and let the rolls rise over night, then cooked them in the morning.  ::::::TIP:::::::  When cutting the cinnamon roll "log", use dental floss.  Slide the floss under the log, then 1-2 inches in, bring the floss ends up and over to cross each other, pinching the cinnamon roll off.  Does that make sense?  It make perfectly cut rolls!  (now THAT I learned from my mom!)

text:
this recipe is awesome.  but since i hate using bread machines, i did it without.  i mix the eggs with the sugar with an electric mixer until pale, about 7 minutes. then i add the milk (which i let stand for 10 minutes with the yeast), melted margarine, and salt.  using a wooden spoon i stir in the flour gradually, until i can knead it, which i do for 10 minutes.  then i let it rest till doubled, and carry on with the recipe.  this is the best way to do it if you don't have, or don't want to use a bread machine. :)

text:
These are the best cinnamon buns I have ever made. Even the icing is fabulous. Thank you.

Here is a tip for others using their bread machines: 
Before you add warm milk, warm eggs, and melted butter, make sure you check the directions of your bread machine. If you are using a rapid cycle then your machine will skip the warm up stage and it is important those ingredients are warm. If you use the regular cycle (mine takes 2 hours) your machine will go through a warm up stage so you should add COLD milk, and if you want to add cold eggs and firm cold butter that is ok too. The temperature of the liquids could make all the difference in the dough.

As close to a cinnabon as you could get. I think the real key in this recipe is to roll the dough out thin, to the full size recommended, 16X21. Use a ruler if you have to to be sure you get it large enough. That gives them that cinnabon-like quality. Also, use the full amount of cinnamon if you like cinnamon, it makes a big difference. Just great!!!

text:
Terrific recipe.  I make these the evening prior in my food processor (process for 45 seconds).  I get them ready for baking and hold the buns overnight in the fridge to bake the next morning. Easy, easy.  To save time I microwave the milk, drop the butter in the warm milk to melt it and when this mixture cools to lukewarm, I drop in the eggs and pour the mixture thru the processor tube.    Also, I add the filling ingredients (softened butter, cinnamon, brown sugar and sometimes chopped pecans) by eye to save on clean up of measuring utensils...a bit more or less of any of the filling ingredients doesn't matter much.

text:
I will add my EXCELLENT to the chorus of positive reviews.  I used all butter in the recipe, instead of margarine in the dough, and also used all purpose flour in place of the bread flour listed in the recipe.  Dough and finished buns turned out fantastic, so if you don't have bread flour in your cabinet--make these all the same for great results.  You can also mix all the ingredients in a standard mix master with a dough hook or paddle if you don't have a bread machine (as I don't).  Even the "dieters" and Atkins followers had to try at least a half of one.  Not difficult at all.  Will definately make for special Sundays and parties!

None
text:
I had a problem making this right off the bat.  My yeast had expired a month ago and my bread machine doesn't have a 'dough setting'.  I called my 87 year old Grandma for advice.  She advised me to 'attempt' my yeast by withholding 1 cup of flour and mixing all of the dry ingredients together(including the yeast)...adding additional flour if necessary...and to do it all by hand.  Well, even with her advice, my dough never did rise the first time.  I called her back, she said not to panic...just roll the dough according to the directions.  But the second rising never occured either, once again my Grandma came to the rescue!  She simply explained to me that I am NOT making bread, just cinnamon rolls...she said that even though my yeast was old, it should at least, partially rise in the oven if I reduced the temp by 25 degrees and added 10 minutes to my cooking time. 

I served them to my husband and neighbors, they were 'out of this world' fantastic!  I've promised my Grandma that I will make another batch to overnight to her and my 90 year old Grandpa, THANKS for the recipe!!!!

country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe! I worked for Cinnzeo for a few months, and find these rolls pretty much exactly like theirs. 
The only difference is the frosting.  I changed the recipe by not adding salt (salt is only needed in the dough to activate the yeast), and in replace I added lemon extract. 
This gives those rolls that extra kick!

One thing I would suggest is, once the dough has been rolled out, to leave about an inch at the bottom without butter. 
This way it will stick when you roll down to that last piece.  If you butter the entire surface, it tends to have problems sticking. 

Thanks for the recipe!  It really is fantastic!! =)

These cinnamon buns are delicious.  My whole family loves them.  I love that I can make the dough in my bread machine and then do the rest myself.  I have followed other reviews and frozen the unbaked rolls in a foil pan to bake later.  I have also placed unbaked rolls in the fridge overnight to bake in the morning.  Both turned out awesome.  I have difficulty rolling up the dough so that the outside edges are equal to the rest, so I just took the cinnamon rolls from the edges, chopped them into 1-inch pieces and make cinnamon roll monkey bread! We ate it without icing but it would be good with warmed cream cheese icing for dipping.

Display Name:
Tyler Gressmen
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls were amazing and they tasted just like cinnabon, if not better.  I've had my fair share of cinnabon rolls over the years, so for those who say that these were terrible or that they didn't taste like cinnabon--you did something wrong.  However, the frosting wasn't up to par so I experimented with ingredients to get closer to the cinnabon frosting.  Here is what I came up with.  1 (8 oz) package of cream cheese, 1/4 C butter softened, 2 C confectioners sugar, 2 Teaspoons vanilla extract, 1/2 Teaspoon fresh lemon juice.  In order to get it nice and fluffy I used an electric hand blender for about 12 minutes.  Lastly, as others have suggested, cooking at 350 for 20-25 min works best.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-11-02T12:56:23.007
helpfulCount:
4
userID:
2738930
Display Name:
Robin Beaver
isPro:
False
followersCount:
14
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
83
favoritesCount:
933
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6542832.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Follow the recipe as written. I write quite a few reviews, and I love reading the reviews of other cooks. Only one time (in years) have I mentioned that I was disappointed to follow another's advice. This will be the second time. Based on one review, I mixed the cinnamon-butter-sugar with my food processor ahead of time. I also added nuts. It sounded like a great, time-saving idea, but I ended up with clumps of a gritty mixture that did not want to smooth out across the dough. I ended up heating it in the microwave and then spreading/patting it on, but next time I'll follow the recipe -- just spread the softened butter over the dough, and THEN sprinkle on the cinnamon and sugar. The second piece of advice I followed that was a huge mistake is to invert the rolls onto a platter after removing them from the oven. Bad idea. Because the rolls do not rise to the same height, I had rolls of various sizes sort of teetering on the plate. (Even a half-inch in height can make a difference if inverted.) I slathered a bit of cream cheese frosting on the inverted rolls and then quickly turned them right side up. They don't look like pretty brown cinnamon rolls if inverted onto a plate. That said, I also added some raisins, and I made extra frosting but really didn't need to.  I'll save it for another use. Other than my own poor judgment, this is a wonderful recipe!

text:
After receiving a Kitchenaid stand mixer as a gift from the hubby, I decided to play around with it.  This was the first recipe that I went for.  I have NEVER worked with any sort of yeast dough before, so I was nervous.  Even as a first-timer, these turned out amazing!  One item that I will mention is the need for more cinnamon filling. Some said that the recipe called for a bit too much cinnamon.  I would have to disagree.  I was going for the ooey gooey richness of the real thing so I could have probably doubled the cinnamon/brown sugar, and butter filling.  Additionally, instead of butter, I used margarine in stead for the cream cheese frosting.  It adds that bit of extra buttery saltiness that true Cinnabon icing has.

text:
Really delicious! I was worried there wouldn't be enough filling as I was assembling them but it turned out to be perfect after I baked it. I followed other users' advice and mixed the filling ingredients together and spread on the dough. I upped the butter a little to get it to mix properly but probably wouldn't again - it took some of that great chewiness out of the filling. I also turned the whole pan upside down when they came out of the oven so the drippings coated the buns and it was soooo much better. The frosting was tasty but there was a bit too much of it - I'd cut it in half next time. Will make again for sure!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So this is my 3rd or 4th time making this recipe. I actually just joined Allrecipes just to write this review. After reading various ways to make Cinnamon Rolls, I've finally mastered it. When I made this before it's always been dry, never "gooey" like Cinnabon. This was the first time making it with a bread machine as well (although the dough hasn't changed from before). When rolling out your dough into a rectangle, brush milk all over the dough before putting the cinnamon/sugar mixture on. Semi-melt the butter in the microwave and mix it together with the sugar and cinnamon. I've always sprinkled the sugar/cinnamon over the butter but that is going to make it dry! Spread the butter/sugar mixture over the dough. After rolling, brush milk along the seams to keep them together! Now you will have a clone of a Cinnabon!!

text:
I love these cinnamon rolls!  Very easy to make and so tasty.  I made them for my son's birthday sleepover and all the boys devoured them.  I just made them again to freeze for our Easter brunch.  The first time I froze after baking, thawed, warmed in oven and added frosting/icing. I only changed one thing - I used butter rather than margarine in the first step to make the dough. After I rolled the dough up I stretched it a bit before cutting to help lenghen the middle out. The middle would turn out thicker for me and I wouldn't get even rolls once I got towards the ends.  I will be keeping this recipe!  Thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We were blown away by these delicious cinnamon rolls! My search is over for a great recipe. I followed this recipe exactly for the dough, which baked up gorgeous, light, tender, moist and flavorful. I think using the bread flour is important as others have said as well. I tweaked the filling a bit, more butter, less brown sugar and less cinnamon, and I added plenty of finely chopped pecans. I frost as soon as they come out of the oven. I have tried baking them after being refrigerated overnight, and after being frozen as well, and they are perfect both ways. They seemed to have a chance to raise a bit more with the following process--Place rolls from the refrigerator into a cold oven, and set oven temp on warm or lowest setting for about 20 minutes. After 20 minutes, reset oven temp to 350 degrees and bake till done, about 20 minutes for my oven. If the rolls are frozen, thaw in fridge overnight.

text:
This is a great recipe- a little time consuming, but they came out very good. I was a little nervous about the amount of time it took and the fact that all other rolls I have attempted to make did not turn outand ended up in the trash. This recipe, while it takes a little while, is easy to follow. I almost took shortcuts but then went out and bought the bread flour instead of substituting. It was well worth the trip to the store in my pj's. Received many compliments on them. Will make a larger batch and give out on christmas eve as a gift for people to bake in the morning.
DON'T TAKE SHORTCUTS OR SUBSTITUTES and use QUALITY INGREDIENTS. It really does make all the difference. Definitely a keeper!

I made these a few weeks ago for my son's family, which includes 4 granddaughters!  They were a huge hit and my 4 princesses were able to help me make them.  I used a Kitchen Aid instead of my bread machine but I will take others advice from this site and add the yeast to the warm milk and sugar first. I am going to make them again tomorrow but will split the dough in two before rolling it out (8 x 12) and make 24 buns to take to an association meeting on Saturday morning.  I love the suggestion of letting them rest in the fridge overnight and popping them in the oven in the morning.  I will keep an eye on them to make sure they do not over-bake, but only 10-12 minutes in the oven should be good.

text:
Excellent.  Not exactly Cinnabon,  but just as good.  I can't quite pinpoint what makes it not quite Cinnabon, but no matter.  I did not have the problem of the filling running out like some complained of.  I'm guessing they did not roll them tight enough.  Another reviewer said to turn the pan over when baked to let the filling run bake in.  This was not necessary for me.  I did combine the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon to spread all together as someone suggested.  Not sure if that made a difference or not.  That method was hard to spread evenly though, so next time I'm going to try it as the recipe says.  I took the advice of another reviewer who said to double the icing, but double is about twice too much.  Someone must have a major sweet tooth.  I think double icing would make me sick.  So I will make another batch in a few days to use up the other half of the icing.   I disagree with another reviewer who said the filling was too cinnamony.  It was fine.  The dough was pretty easy to make and came together really nicely.

text:
Another 5 stars. This is a great recipe. I would double the frosting but then again I don't put all the sugar in it, so it's not as sweet, and that means I get less frosting out of the recipe. Many people mentioned a problem with the filling running out -- if you just let them sit til they're completely cool, the filling condenses and soaks back into the bottoms so you taste it in every bite anyway. You don't need to turn the pan over or anything, just be patient :) Thanks for sharing, to me these are better than Cinnamonster or Cinnabon.

text:
this is soooooo the best cinnamon bun recipe ever! i have made it twice before, and i am making them again tomorrow. for these cinnamon buns to really taste like a cinnabon you have to double the cinnamon mixture. (i know, you are all prabably thinking that this recipe is already unhealthy enough, and there is plenty of sugar,so why add more?, well if you have had a cinnabon before you know the crazy amount of cinnamon they add to it, the cinnamon literly oozes out of the cinnamon bun.) I have also heard that if you add a packet of vanilla pudding mix to the dough it makes the bread part of the cinnamon bun taste exactly like a cinnabon.

7699934
Display Name:
scottandtiffany

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've baked a lot of things and never had such a problem as I did with this recipe.  I followed it to the T, using Margarine AND butter where it is noted in the recipe.  As an avid pizza maker, I am familiar with how dough should feel, rise, etc. as well as how much flour to add to get the right consistency.  This dough was really dense, very heavy, and didn't rise more than 15%.  I've handled a lot of dough and this one already was raising a few flags as I kneaded it.  My yeast was good because I've been baking all week with the same jar, using the same temp water.  The dough seemed so dense that it was if I was suffocating the yeast, which I'm sure isn't possible but that's the impression I got.  After barely getting a rise from the dough after 2 sessions, bake time wasn't any more rewarding.  I have an oven that runs hot, and after 15 minutes (per recipe) they were still extremely gooey inside.  I baked them on the center rack.  After another 5 minutes they were still gooey, with hardly a change in texture at all!  So I moved them to the bottom rack and added an additional 10 minutes @ 350F, which seemed like overkill but I was determined to make this dough set up.  10 minutes later, after a total of 30 minutes of baking time (recipe calls for 15), they were STILL GOOEY!  40 min @ 400, still gooey.  The story continues!  They never baked properly.  I bake a lot of stuff, and with this many problems I'm giving up on this butter/sugar-loaded recipe for good.

text:
This recipe is great!  Definitely not a Cinnabon (not even close) but they are very good.  When I am too lazy to make my family recipe I use this one, and it is 2nd to best.  Some tips: When the cinnamon rolls are rising, heat your oven to about 110 degrees, then open the oven door and put the cinnamon rolls in to rise.  By the way, I make this by hand.  In the filling, add more butter.  Follow what another reviewer said and flip it over when it is done baking, because YES the filling does come out.  Thanks!

text:
Cinnabon is using danish dough which is a three fold method incorporating butter. When they make the buns they roll out a piece of danish dough, spread it again with butter and brown sugar (might even be some cinnamon mixed in-been a while since I've had one), then they are baked and topped with drifond or 10x icing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fantastic but I did very slightly alter them.  I added about a teaspoon of cinnamon to the dough in the bread machine and made about 1.5 times the filling recipe, blending together the cinnamon sugar WITH the butter before spreading on the rolled dough (a bit of a messy process but trust me...).  They were taking a long time to rise, so after 40 minutes, I put them into a cold oven, set to 375F.  When the oven reached temperature, I baked for 18 minutes - the results were perfect: big, slightly doughy (underbaked like cinnabon), ooey, gooey cinnamon buns!!

text:
I made this recipe as is except for a few changes.  I made the dough in the bread machine then cut the rolls up and put in the pan overnight to be baked the next day.  When they finished cooking I flipped the hot pan over onto a jelly roll pan and let the drippings run down over the rolls for few minutes.  I flipped back then frosted.  I omitted the cream cheese  as I have made it before with and my kids said the frosting was too rich.  Everyone enjoyed them very much.  Good recipe!!

Those of you that say that these are too sweet, you clearly haven't had a Cinnabon before (or Cinnaroll since I am from Canada).  These are the things that will make the heart attacks that we have worth it.  I had one hot right out of the oven, and it tasted exactly like a Cinnaroll, but I found that I enjoyed it even more when it had been sitting out for a couple of hours (covered in Saran wrap).

text:
Warning!  Do not share these unless you want to be continually making them or you are one of those people who have no problem saying, "No. I'm sorry I don't have time."  My son loved them so much he shared with his teenage friends and I ended up losing two weeks of my life after making them for parents and teachers and the senior trip!  They really are that good!  The only difference between these and Cinnabon is the type of cinnamon.  Regular cinnamon is a litte stronger.  As for sprinkling or spreading the cinnamon mixture I found that buttering and sprinkling was much easier than mixing it all and spreading it.

text:
I have tried and tried for YEARS to make homemade cinnamon rolls. For some reason, I always had a lot of trouble getting them to come out to my satisfaction. The very first time I tried this recipe, they came out terrific! Not only that, but I was able to repeat my initial success, never even using a bread machine. The only other thing I did differently was to combine the brown sugar, cinnamon & butter filling together prior to spreading it all on the dough instead of each item separately. Seemed easier and more uniform to me that way and worked well. Very labor intensive and time consuming but well worth the effort!

text:
These have gotten rave reviews!  They were super easy to put together and very user-friendly.  I did make a couple small changes.  I made half cinnamon rolls and half peanut butter rolls.  I mixed the butter into the brown sugar and cinnamon mixture, as some reviewers suggested, and was pleased with the results.  I also only used a simple confectioner's sugar glaze for the rolls since I am out of cream cheese.  

For the peanut butter rolls, I simply replaced cinnamon with 2 tablespoons of peanut butter as the filling, and made the peanut butter glaze here for the topping
Great recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5149230.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are better than Cinnabon.  Double the brown sugar, cinnamon, and butter that you spread on the dough, and double the icing, for really gooey cinnamon rolls.  

DO NOT mix the brown sugar, cinnamon and butter together and then spread on the dough as someone suggested.  I tried this, and the brown sugar didn't caramelize; the caramelizing of the brown sugar is what makes them gooey.  Spread the butter and then sprinkle the brown sugar and cinnamon mixture over it as the recipe says to.

Also, as another reviewer stated, flipping the rolls over after you take them out of the oven is another key to gooey cinnamon rolls.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made two batches of these for the first time yesterday and they were sooo good! My husband brought them to work and they were gone in seconds and everyone loved them.  

I put my ingredients in our bread maker in the order of liquids-dry-then yeast. I pressed the dough/pasta cycle and just let it work it's magic.

Make sure you roll out the dough very even.  I hear people saying to dump them out and let all the gooeyness run back into them. I let ours sit in the pan and rise for about 1 hour or until they were almost as high as the pan before baking. I think sitting them for 30minutes wouldn't be near enough time. My turn out so most and big there is no room for the goo to run out.

I also added raisins and crushed walnuts to mine when sprinkling on the brownsugar and cinnamon.

I make them all the time and people tell me they are the best rolls they have ever had

text:
this was a amazing cinnamon roll recipe! i made this for breakfast when my aunt was here and she said," these cinnamon rolls have an X- factor. indescribably good." 
this was a great recipes but i did make some changes. i put 1 and a 1/2 cup regular flour and the rest wheat flour. because of that they made them doughy in the inside and crispy on the outside. i also combined the cinnamon, brown sugar, and  butter all together in a bowl and used a batter spatula to spread it a round the dough so each part of the dough would be covered in the mixture. i have made this recipes 3 times and i always end up burning them, so this time i decided to put them in for a bout 8-10 minuets and they turned out perfect! thanks for the recipe!

text:
Truely a 5 star recipe. Did not need to alter any of the amounts or ingredients. First time making cinnamon rolls, and they turned out PERFECT! Very much like a cinnabon. One tip. To keep the filing from running out, you can take the end and sort of make a flap to close off the bottom om the cinnamon roll. Filing stayed in and turned out great! Takes a while to make, but SO worth it!

excellent recipe. didn't use my bread maker, just used my kitchenaid to mix/knead and rise as normally would any breads. definitely recommend using bread flour rather than all purpose, there is a noticeable difference in the results! i used white sugar rather than brown sugar for the filling and enjoyed the results, no filling draining to the bottom of the pan. used my own carmel frosting rather than the recipe included here.

text:
Absolutely amazing!  Made them the night before and covered them with plastic wrap and stuck them in the fridge overnight.  I let them sit out for about 30 minutes before putting them in a pre-heated oven (350) for 25 minutes.  A little too much icing for my liking though and I did bump up the cream cheese to about 5 or 6 oz for a more cream cheesy and less sugary taste.  My husband ate 3 in a row!  This one's a keeper!

Outstanding recipe! I made a maple frosting instead of the cream cheese...since i didn't have any cream cheese on hand.  MAPLE FROSTING:   2 cups Powdered Sugar  2 teaspoons Maple syrup   1/4 cups Milk   2 tbs Melted Butter   3 tbs Coffee  pinch of Salt Just throw everything together in a bowl and mix until thick but pourable.

text:
A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!!  This has been in my recipe box for over a year and only now got around to making them.  Cut sugar back to 1/3 c. and substituted 3/4 c. of the flour for whole wheat.  Baked in a glass dish @ 400F as directed and 3-4 minutes after removing from oven, inverted a metal cookie pan over top.  Then turned them upside down for about 10 minutes to let the filling redistribute.  Then turned the glass baking dish back right side up and iced them.  I can't tell you how perfect the texture was.  My family devoured them.

These were a big hit for a family Thanksgiving breakfast!  I used butter in place of the margarine and followed another reviewer's hint to turn the rolls upside down before frosting. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks for sharing this recipe Marsha! :) These are fantastic and I recommend that anyone who is "on the fence" about making these give it a try!   Like many others, I made these without a bread machine (have one, but like to do it by hand). I have made these twice now and have read many other's tips/modifications. I follow the recipe as written, and I really encourage everyone to line the pan bottom with wax paper, double the frosting, and bake at 350 (i have tried 20 and 25 mins... 20 leaves them just a little under baked for me).    I haven't noticed it in the reviews I have read, but if you are going to frost them in the pan you baked in, let them cool just a little while, cut them apart, and THEN frost.   These disappear quickly! Enjoy!

Absolutely amazing! Did follow some great suggestions: Didn't use a bread machine, just used my mixer with dough hook. Let the yeast dissolve in the warm milk...then let it rise in a 200 degree oven (turned oven off right away when I put it in to rise), added the cinnamon mix to the butter and finally cooked about 2 min less than recommended. These were truly, truly amazing. Thanks to all those people who made these recommendations before me...  I didn't need to double the icing. Will make plenty of more times.

text:
As suggested by another reviewer I made the entire 8oz container or frosting and used the frosting ingredients measurments as suggested by the reviewer. I also used aluminum foil and greased it so cleanup would be easier. Believe it or not it was difficult to roll the dough and not have the filling squeeze out. I mixed the sugar,cinnimon, and butter together then spread onto the dough. But I was so proud of my rolls. I have never made anything like this before and I really felt proud of the end result. My rolls may not have been rolled so nice and tight but it really didnt matter since the frosting makes them look pretty anyway. And I found that the rolls that were rolled a little loose cooked better on the inside, they weren't as "doughy" as the one or two that I did roll tightly. Splenda brown and white sugars were used as well as Smart Balance butter to save on calories.

text:
Wow, were these good!  I proofed a package of active dry yeast with 1/4 cup sugar and the milk heated to 110 degrees.  Then I added the remainder of the dough ingredients and mixed with the dough hook in my stand mixer.  I finished kneading a little bit by hand.  Then I put it in a greased glass bowl covered loosely with greased plastic wrap.  I put it in the oven that I had preheated to 200 degrees and turned off for 1 hour.  I did as another user suggested and mixed the butter with the brown sugar and cinnamon.  Then I just spread this on the dough.  My husband talked me into cutting them into just 8 rolls.  They were huge - just like real Cinnabons.  I made them the night before, covered and refridgerated, pulled them right out of the fridge in the morning and popped them in a cold oven that I then set to heat to 350 degreees.  In about 25 minutes, they were brown on top.  (My oven does cook a little hot.)  They were outstanding.  My husband thought the dough could have been a little richer to be just like a Cinnabon but the cinnamon filling and icing were right on.

text:
These turned out quite well.  The dough was easily streched out and rolled well.  After cutting the rolls, I seperated them out on a cookie sheet and put them in the freezer.  After they froze, I placed them in plastic bags.  Now whenever I want cinnamon rolls, I take a couple out the night before and put them in the fridge.  In the morning, take them out of the fridge and place them on the counter under a warm towel for 30 minutes.  Pop them in the oven and you'll never know they were frozen!

Display Name:
ALIA_26

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm new to using a breadmaker and have always had issues rolling out anything for baking. I can tell you, the dough came out perfect in the dough machine and I didn't have to adjust a thing. I did add 2 Tbsp of Wheat Gluten to ensure a good rise, and it had a beautiful rise. I will admit I had troubles rolling up my log (due to lack of experience). I did melt the butter for the filling and added some of the cinnamon/sugar mix to form a paste. I wish had had made a paste of all of it as it would have been easier for me to roll then cut without some of the filling falling out. I did roll the pin across the filling to help push it further down into the dough, but it was still a little too loose. Again, all lack of experience. In the end, the rolls came out great. I baked at 325 in a convection oven for 25 minutes and covered with foil a little after halfway through baking to prevent overbrowning. Came out perfect. I used another recipe for frosting: 1/2 cup butter, 4 oz cream cheese, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract (beat well) and add 1 1/2 cups powdered sugar, beat until light and fluffy. I smeared half the mixture on the hot rolls right out of the oven and saved the other half for "extra" as the first smear is supposed to melt over the hot rolls. I refrigerated over night, popped them in a cold oven at 200 degrees for 12 minutes or so, then turned up to 325 for 25 minutes (using the foil after about 15 minutes to cover and prevent over browning). Great recipe. Thanks !!! Yummy

country:
None
text:
I made these the day before baking, storing in refrigerator at the point they were ready to bake, allowing to get back to room temp prior to baking.  Were they as good as the real thing? NO, they were much better because the dough was cooked through and fluffy.  I did not get any gooey filling on the bottom of the pan so no need to turn pan over.  I used crisco for the dough, don't own a breadmaker so I dissolved the sugar in the milk, warmed to 125 degrees and then allowed the yeast to sit in that for 10 minutes.  I took other's suggestion and warmed oven to 200, turned off and then allowed dough to rise for 1 hour.  I also combined the butter, brown sugar, and cinnamon together for spreading but it was too thick so I warmed that mixture in the microwave for 20 seconds and it was perfect.

text:
I made the dough TWO TIMES & BOTH times the dough DIDN'T RISE. After investigating everything I did I think I microwaved the milk TOO LONG; it should not be bubbling, it should be WARM to the touch, NOT HOT; my stupid mistake. I did some more research & found Sandra Lee's recipe on FoodTV, which uses a frozen white bread loaf for the dough; THAT WAS A GOD SENT! I mixed the brown sugar, butter, & cinnamon together, which worked great. I used about 5-6 ounces of cream cheese & added a bit more sugar & vanilla... PERFECT! I greased a glass pie pan & placed the rolls in until they expanded. (PLACE ON A COVERED COOKIE SHEET, the juices spilt & smelled like I was baking burnt marshmellows!) Baked at 350 for 27 minutes. SOOO good!

text:
I make these on a very regular basis. It is always expected when the kids visit that I have these on hand, and both family and friends that don't bake, request I make them for them. I now keep a batch in the freezer at all times, and keep a batch of frosting (easily made in the food processor) in the frig. We pop them in the microwave for about 30-40 seconds, frost them, then pop them back in for another 30 seconds. They taste fresh baked and are enjoyed by all. I do take them out of the oven about 90 seconds earlier than I would if I wasn't freezing. I can't tell you how long they last in the freezer, because at my house we fly through them faster than they could ever go bad. :) Marsha, thank you so much, from myself, my husband, family, and friends, for sharing this recipe.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/222789.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a solid five star recipe. I have made it over and over and it is consistently outstanding. No one can resist - even those who aren't huge Cinnamon roll eaters. Beware that it is a huge sugar rush if your eaters have any blood sugar issues you may need to modify or have them skip it altogether. The bread machine recipe is perfect every time. You can freeze these for several weeks with no impact on quality at all. I use small bowls and then put self-sticking wrap on them so that people can microwave them. They make great gifts during the Holidays. Bring them to work for a special continental breakfast. Don't count on baking these in a few quick minutes - these take time - and depending upon weather may take longer than indicated. I also found that temperature affects the dough more than with recipes such as bread. Well worth the time and effort.

text:
I've made this recipe twice now, without a bread machine, and had excellent results.  I found the dough easy to work with and BOY are they good.  I did use melted butter instead of Margarine (I never buy margarine).  My co-workers hate me now whenever I make them because they can't resist having a half of one here, a little piece there.  They come out fine if you make them the night before and keep them in the fridge for the next morning.  30 seconds in the microwave or a couple minutes in a toaster oven does the trick.  They're even great cold!  I didn't have a 9x13" dish available so I just used a Jelly Roll pan and they were fine.  I didn't find the cinnamon at all overwhelming as some reviewers seemed to.  A great recipe!
Review:

country:
None
text:
Fabulous recipe!   Some notes not in the recipe that I got from reviews: I made it in a glass dish, with dark brown sugar, placed the larger rolls towards the outside of the dish before baking and inverted the rolls onto a serving platter directly after they came out of the oven. This was easily done by placing the serving dish directly on top of the pan and flipping both over at once.   I then iced them and chose to alter the recipe a bit by raising the amount of cream cheese by one ounce and cutting back on the amount of powdered sugar very slightly. This turned out wonderfully.   I do regret listening to another reviewer and cooking longer than 15 minutes. That was not necessary in my case, as they turned out less soft and squishy than I like cinnamon rolls. I will stick to the original time and temp in the future.   I will lessen the amount of cinnamon from 2 1/2 T. to 2 T. next time, as the cinnamon that I buy is very intense.   I will definitely make this amazing recipe again and thanks so much to the original poster!

The brand of cinnamon you use can make the difference between 4 star & 5 star ratings.  Not all cinnamons are equal.  I buy CINNABON brand cinnamon and use it for my extra special recipes.  The taste difference between cheap and quality cinnamon is noticeable.  Don't believe me?  Try making the same recipe twice: with "generic" and any high quality (from Madagascar) product.  Your taste buds will adore you FOREVER!

text:
I have to say that this is the best yet cinnamon roll recipe that I have ever made. Honestly, it is the closest thing I think that anyone will ever get to a cinnabon, short of stealing the recipe. The eggs and milk in the bread mixture create a more rich crust for the cinnamon rolls, and making it in a bread machine takes the work out of kneading the bread. So far, the several times that I have made it, the dough is perfictly consistent, and then easy to roll out. The brown sugar and cinnamon add a hugely rich caramel-like effect when the rolls are baking. Using brown sugar, in my opinion, is a better choice for sugar in regard to making a more rich cinnamon roll filling. Like others, I agree with turning the pan upside-down directly after baking, as it allows the filling to coat the roll and reintegrate itself. This recipe gets an A+!

country:
None
text:
Great recipe, I made it by hand.  To make by hand, I heated the milk to 110-115 degrees and added the melted butter, and sugar in a large bowl, then wisked in the yeast and let proof for about 10 minutes.  Then I scrambled the eggs with the salt and gently wisked in the yeast mixture.  I added flour about half a cup at a time, and followed through with the rest of the recipe.  They turned out great!  To make them seem more like the real Cinnabons, I made them into 8 rolls and put them in a 9X13inch pans and cooked them at 375 for 18 minutes.  Thank you for sharing the recipe!

text:
Not sure what happened with this recipe.  First the dough wouldn't rise, then I had to let the individual rolls sit out over night and they had barely risen at all.  They subsequently were dry and rather heavy.  The were still okay out of the oven, but the cut and bake kind I had been making seemed so much better.  I still have extra ingredients so I might try them again and see if they come out better.  Anyone have any suggestions? On the up side my husband and 6 year old son both really liked them, little man even went back for seconds but my 4 year old only ate half of hers.
-----------------------------------------

                Update!!!

After my second attempt at this recipe I can honestly say they are wonderful!  The second time I made sure the milk was not too hot before adding the yeast, secondly I made sure and followed the directions on here for turning out the dough which has to do with strectching it, folding it in on itself, and restreching it over and over, which helps it rise,  and BOY DID IT EVER RISE!!!  I turned it out and did the 'strech' thing before I rolled and cut the cinnamon buns out.  they rose about 3x (possibally 4x) the original size.  They came out soft, chewy and simply wonderful.  I sent the left over 8 to work with my sister in law and husband, and by the time he got back to the shop there was only one left.  I think that consitutes a success!  For those who have these turn out abysimal the first time, definately try them again and see if

userID:
2386038
Display Name:
ajsmom0513
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I have ever made homemade cinnamon rolls, and let me tell you , this was time-consuming...BUT SO WORTH IT!! I will never buy cinnamon rolls again, these are 100 times better than any cinnamon roll i have ever had! Not difficult to make, and so moist and delicious when they come out of the oven. I don't have a bread machine so i went with a reviewers suggestion and dissolved a 7g packet of active yeast with 1 cup of warm milk and 1/4 cup sugar. I then added the rest of the ingredients, leaving the flour for last, and kneaded the dough by hand. Left it in the warm oven that i had turned on to 200 degrees and shut off immediately after the dough went in. Added the butter and brown sugar/cinn mixture to the flattened dough, rolled it up the long way, cut them into 12 pieces and let them rise for about 25 minutes in a 9x13 baking dish. Popped them in the oven on 400 degrees for 15 minutes and they were perfect! The only change I made was that i realized i didn't have any cream cheese so i added about 3 tablespoons of milk to the icing ingredients and it was delicious! Next time will def make sure i have cream cheese in the fridge so it will be even better. Thanks for a fantastic recipe, I wish i could give this 10 stars!

After reading the reviews, I had to find out what the hype was all about.  Well, let me tell you.
Amazing.  Soft.  Gooey.  These bun things smelled so nice, directly after frosting them, I ate the middle first.  The only thing I tweaked was I added a little bit of vanilla to the dough.  The recipe is great, everyone has his or her personal preference about frosting.  I'm all about the middle section of a cinnamon roll and this recipe has it down from ingredients to the oven time.  And, if you know your oven, then you're good to go.  My husband LOVED these rolls and was sad when they were all gone.  The only thing I did not like was waiting for them to be ready to eat.  Patience is a virtue with these rolls and they are worth the wait.

These are great!  I agree with doubling the frosting, because I like loads of frosting.  After looking at the many, many pictures of this recipe, I do have one suggestion.  Make sure to spread the frosting on while the rolls are still hot.  This makes the frosting melt down around the sides and into the spirals of the rolls, making them extra ooey-gooey-good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since I do not have a breadmaker I used the  suggestions on how to make them without the breadmaker and they turned out beautifully.  I even doubled the recipe and there were no problems.  

If you are going to double I suggest doing it twice or mixing in 2 separate containers because it's not easy for all of the yeast to dissolve in the milk if you do it all at once.  And the dough will rise better the first time is rises if there is not so much dough.  

Also be sure to add your yeast slowly into the milk and continuously stir.  I made the mistake of adding all of the yeast and then trying to stir the milk and I ended up with yeast stuck to the spoon and to the bottom of the bowl and not at all dissolved.  I ended up having to redo this part, adding the yeast slowly and it worked out just wonderfully. 

Everyone loved them and have been begging for me to make them again!  I hope you try!

userID:
804707
Display Name:
FLIESE
isPro:

city:

country:

text:
I have made these 4 times now and have played with the recipe some each time. I made them as the recipe says for some friends and they loved them. I made another version for my family that was lower sugar and fat, as well as whole grain. I accidentally made them without eggs once too (oops). I use my mixer to make the dough, as I don't have a bread machine.

Following the recipe as written, the cinnamon rolls are fantastic. There is plenty of frosting (I don't know what other reviewers were thinking saying it was too little) and the rolls are huge- almost too much to eat in a sitting- but oh, so worth it.

Making them slightly healthier, I tried with 100% whole wheat and found them to be too heavy. Using one cup of AP flour did the trick, though (the other 3.5 cups as WW). I also used 1/4 cup sugar and 1/4 cup Splenda in the dough- and that works well. I used butter in the dough and frosting, but used Smart Balance Light Buttery Spread in the filling, which also worked well. In place of the brown sugar, I used Splenda mixed with a table spoon of molasses and the cinnamon. This resulted in no gooey filling, but the flavor was there. For the frosting, I used Splenda, butter and fat free cream cheese. It was a lot runnier than the one made with sugar and full-fat cream cheese, but, again, the flavor was good. Skipping the eggs pretty much resulted in a flat, tough dough.

My family prefers the healthier version, but we tend to limit sugar and get headaches from the full-sugar on

text:
I reviewed many recipes before making. I too, like others didn't have a bread machine to use so I kneaded by hand for 10-15 minutes, and actually my kids enjoyed helping with this part.  I recommend using butter instead of margarine like another reviewer mentioned. I proofed the yeast and by this method what I did was warm milk to 110 degrees, then dissolved 2 tbsp. of the sugar in it, and then added the yeast and stirred till dissovled too. I put in the oven that had been pre-warmed to 170 and shot off to raise quicker the first time. I softened the butter in microwave ( not melted) and then added the cinnamon and sugar and then put on the rolled out dough.  I did 1 1/2 times the cinnamon, brown sugar and butter mixture like someone else mentioned. I put the rolls in the fridge the night before I made them and then put them in a prewarmed oven of 170 degrees to raise faster for my serving of them. I still took longer then I thought it would- maybe 1 hour. I doubled the frosting but was to much. I may 1 1/2 times it next time. I baked at 375 for maybe 20 minutes but was to long. They weren't burnt but just alittle more done then I liked. Maybe will try 350 next time. Very good. My family loved them. They are rich-- hard to eat more then 1 at one sitting.

text:
What a yummy cinnamon roll!  Very moist and just the right amount of cinnamon and frosting too.  I made a mistake when mixing the filling, I mixed all of the ingredients together and when I realized my mistake (having trouble blending ingredients), I warmed it up in the microwave to soften up the butter more, it made a nice paste!  I did notice that the bottom of my pan didn't have alot of filling on it, so I do think that it helped the filling to stay in the roll better and will mix it that way again in the future!  I made these in two 8x8 disposable pans (gave one away) and had plenty of frosting for both pans.  The ends pieces that didn't have filling in, I just smeared butter on them, than sprinkle brown sugar and cinnamon on and they came out just like the others.

text:
I'm only giving it a 4/5 because the recipe itself is rather unspecific.  I did as another poster suggested, and used Dry Active Yeast, and proofed it in the milk with 2 tbsp of the sugar.  Then left it for about 5 minutes.  When it got frothy, then I mixed in the eggs and butter (I didn't have margarine).  Then the sugar, salt and flour.  And though it doesn't seem like all the flour will get mixed it, it will once you take it out of the bowl and knead it with your hands for a few minutes.

Otherwise, I followed the recipe as is.  Though next time I'll buy confectioner's sugar.  I tried to make my own (1 cup = 1 cup granulated sugar + 1 tsp cornstarch), but I may not have left it in the blender long enough, since the icing turned out sort of gritty.

text:
This is an awesome recipe.  The dough was really easy to work with - probably the easiest dough I've ever rolled out.  I took the advice on baking from other reviewers and baked at 350 for about 22 min and they were PERFECT.  The ONLY thing I would mention is if you don't like cream cheese, the icing has a distinct cream cheese flavor.  I might try a different icing next time or just cut down on the cream cheese and use more butter or maybe a non-flavored shortining like Crisco.  Edit:  Here's the perfect icing:
7 Tbs Butter (softened)
2 oz Cream Cheese (softened)
1.5 C powdered sugar
1/2 tsp Vanilla
1/4 tsp salt
Whip until smooth and fluffy.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this four stars only because my husband liked them a lot. I goofed and used self rising flour instead of bread flour. The second time I made it, it was MUCH better of course because I used the bread flour. I couldn't find 8grm packs of dry active yeast, only 7grm packs, so I used the 7grm pack and dissolved it in the warm milk. Be careful to make milk warm and not hot as this will destroy the yeast. I used my kitchenaid bread hook to mix the dough, finished it with my hands. I think the cooking time is actually too long or too high or something. Real Cinnabons are almost doughy in the middle, not quite done. These came out baked through and almost crusty; I didn't like that at all. I did not find the cinnamon sugar mixture to be too much, in fact, I might make more of it next time. As for frosting -- I am a frosting gal; the more the better. However, doubling this icing made so much that my rolls are  now literally drowning in it and I didn't even use it all. I will make this recipe again and try to perfect it with my changes.

These are amazing. I really do suggest reading the reviews before you make them, because as someone else suggested, mixing the cinnamon and sugar with the melted margarine really makes a difference (it doesn't drip to the bottom, and you can tell if you've spread it evenly).

text:
GREAT!  I made these and came to realize they are very similar to Alton Brown's Overnight Cinnamon Rolls.  The ingredients are very similar.  I am glad I made these.  It gave me a few ideas on how to make cinnamon rolls differently.  For example, my recipe I normally use you need buttermilk.  This recipe uses regular milk.  I like the butter in the icing.  Alton's recipe does not have butter in the icing.  That is a few things I take from this recipe for next time!  Also, I prefer to bake the cinnamon rolls @ 350 for 30 minutes instead of the 15 minutes @ 400.  They come out better.  Sometimes, slower is better! :o)

Fabulous.  I don't have a bread machine, so I mixed the dough like a traditional bread dough (proofed the yeast in the milk, added the eggs, butter, flour, etc) let it rise for an hour before rolling it out, and followed the recipe exactly after that and these were the best tasting cinnamon rolls I've had in a long time, (Not counting my mother's of course)  I even have a friend who can't stop nagging me to make them for her! country:
None
text:
I made these without a bread machine, and halved the recipe.  I added the yeast to the warm milk, mixed everything together but the flour, and then incorporated that and needed until it was smooth and elastic.  I also let it rise, rolled it out into buns, and put it in the fridge overnight.  In the morning, I let it sit out for an hour or so and then baked.  They were delicious.  Definitely listen to the baking time if you want it to still be a bit dough-y, like a cinnabon is.  I baked mine a bit longer and that is the only thing I would change if I made them again.  The icing was amazing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the third cinnamon roll recipe I have tried and this one is by far the best.  I combined this recipe with another cinnabon knock off and used 1 egg, 1/2 cup butter instead of 1/3 cup margarine, 1 Tbsp. vital wheat gluten and 1 tsp. vanilla in the dough.  I also made this without a bread machine and it did not rise as much as I thought it would.  Check the freshness of your instant yeast.  I used a rolling pin to press the cinnamon/sugar mixture down onto the dough.  I baked these at 350 for 25 minutes and they were perfect, not doughy.  I doubled the frosting mixture because I did not want to waste the other half of my cream cheese but found that I had to much icing.  I took the cinnamon rolls out of the pan right when they were done and put the frosting all down the sides.  Bottom line--THESE WERE DELICIOUS!!  This recipe is a keeper.

I'll be honest and say baking this was a real pain for me, but it wasn't the recipe's fault.  I didn't read enough of the reviewers' suggestions, so it wasn't as easy as I thought.  I don't have a bread machine, so I used the suggestions, and my dough didn't seem to rise as much as I thought it would.  The mixture for inside the buns spilled out the side as I rolled the dough!  It made a big mess, but everything was well worth it.  These were delicious, and I will attempt them many more times!  Suggestion: Definitely put the cream cheese topping on as soon as it comes out of the oven.  It's scrumptious!

text:
The first time I made this it was a disaster!  Came out hard as a rock and didn't rise at all.  I knew it was my fault and not the recipes... my guess is that I killed the yeast.  Not wanting it to defeat me, I decided to follow the recipe down to the letter... minus the breadmachine.  I even looked up how to properly make bread... I dont do breads.  Used a thermometer, used the oven to regulate the temperature... it was great!  I was sooo excited when it actually doubled in size.  I'm going to make this again and try 3 different things... 1. rise, fridge, bake in the morning.  2.  Rise, Freeze, thaw, bake. 3.  Freeze, thaw/rise, bake.  Can you tell I'm not very good at this yeast thing?  :)  Oh, double the icing.... it's yummy.

text:
OMG!!!  Best cinnamon buns ever.

I altered only two things...  Changed the cream cheese for mascarpone cheese (that's what I had in my fridge) and I put the cinnamon, brown sugar and butter in a processer and created a cinnamon, sugar paste to spread on the dough (it is much more uniform that way and I saw a how it's made show for cinnabons where that is how they are made).

I highly recommend making these a little more luxirous by using the mascarpone cheese.  YUM!!

text:
YUMMY!  I used the recipe for Amish White Bread (from this site) for the dough and just followed the recipe from there.  The filling and the icing are GREAT!  If you don't have time to make the dough - using store bought frozen dough along with this recipe would STILL impress your guest/co-workers/family.   
I prepared the night before so when we awoke  all I had to do was put the pan in the oven.  Also, right after baking I inverted the buns into another pan to get all the yummy gooey stuff to pour over the buns.

Mmmmm!  I brought these to work and people were fighting over them.  Thanks to all who suggested doubling the frosting.  It was out of this world.  I followed the recipe exactly except I used to 9" rounds to bake, added about 1 c. of chopped pecans to the filling and also added a splash of lemon juice to the frosting to bring out the tang of the cream cheese.  I've never tried the original but if it's anything like this one, it's got to be good.  The only problem was they came out a little dry, but with the frosting it wasn't very noticable. Thank you Marsha!

text:
about 10 minutes out of the oven, 4 rolls are gone!it's fantastic!i did some changes (probably,you can try it too!)...a)i put in 2 types of flour.4 cups of bread flour,1/2 cup of all purpose flour.b)i mixed the yeast (i put in 1 tsp only) with an extra 1/4 cup of warm milk and let it rise for abt 30 minutes.c)reduce the sugar to 1/2 cup.d)added 1 tbspn of bread/dough softener.e)mix some raisins and pecans with the brown sugar.TIPS:i sprinkle/spray a bit of water before putting the rolls in the oven so that the top wont be dry n hard.i had an extra rolls that can't be fit in the baking pan.so i put them in the muffin tray.and it looks cool!spiral on top but muffin-shaped below!i'll definitely bake more cinnamon rolls!!

text:
I had a favorite recipe for cinammon rolls, but tried these based on the outstanding reviews. These are definitely in a league of their own! Big, rich, soft, and delicious, with an incredibly creamy icing. The brown sugar and large amount of cinnamon in the filling really make these standout. Definitely use a shiny, not dark-coated pan, as the outside will be too dark before the center ones are cooked. Truly amazing rolls!

text:
These are awesome.  Not a lot of effort, but worth the time it does take.  I use my kitchenaid mixer.  When making the filling I found that if I use a whole stick of butter softened and mix the sugar and cinnamon in with the mixture and spread it out on the rolled out dough it is SO much easier!! Works great.

I made some the other day.  A double batch.  FIrst of all, I didn't use all of the filling.    I will use all of the filling from now on.  But I made them smaller, so I could fit 12 in a disposable aluminum rectangular cake pan.  I did not double the icing because I always have leftovers, but I ran out.... so if you make them smaller like i did, i would recommend doubling the icing as well.  but btw, they are just as good with or without the icing. i brought a pan to my MOPS, and sent a pan with my husband.  they were GONE!  and bob came home with requests for more.  apparently they are willing to pay for me to make them.  I could put Cinnabon out of business.  WELL!  Imagine if I had used all of the filling! LOL!  This is a keeper.  Thanks  for sharing this recipe with us.

text:
I've found this recipe years ago, but haven't really had the opportunity to bake it since then. Since we're having a Christmas potluck today, I decided this recipe would be perfect, as cinnamon rolls/buns are unknown in Belgium.
They looked so great in the pan I couldn't keep myself from eating one for breakfast (I baked them yesterday afternoon), and I gotta say they're super!
I didn't use the suggested frosting, as I was afraid it would be too rich for breakfast, but I drizzled a simple frosting made of 1 cup confectioner's sugar and 2 Tb milk on the buns, and they are still great.
These should be absolutely out of this world when fresh out of the oven!

text:
Believe it or not this recipe is also great in a Low sugar version I created!  Use "Splenda" blend instead of sugar, and use "Splenda" granular in the frosting.  Great for Diabetic exchanges.  You do need the blend so the bread will rise properly (sugar is needed to activate the yeast).  Then you can use one cup of "Splenda Granular" and 1/4 cup of "Log Cabin" syrup to create the (1 cup of brown sugar)  these turn out wonderful!  Great news, update!:  Splenda now has their own Brown Sugar Blend! I have used it an it's wonderful! So you can either use the "Log Cabin" Or now the "Splenda Brown Sugar Blend". for this recipe!

wonderful, but pay careful attention and make sure you roll out the dough to 16x21.  The reason is that if the rolls aren't exactly the right size, they will come out doughy.  You may also want to increase the cooking time by 5 minutes.

None
text:
Excellent, excellent recipe. Using the bread machine to make the dough saved a lot of work, and gave me perfect dough. My aim was to make soft moist cinnamon rolls as most of the ones I've tried are dry and hard, even after reheating. These turned out wonderful and are absolutely perfect served fresh, straight out of the oven. You can't skimp on the butter if you want the rolls to be moist. I also skipped the icing as I prefer my rolls plain. This recipe made 24 good sized rolls. (I stretched out the roll before cutting into 1 inch widths.) I'd imagine if there were only 12 they'd be too massive for me. Packing them reasonably tight is important so they don't unfurl.

text:
This recipe was absolutely fantastic!  When I took the dough out of the breadmaker, I was quite surprised to find that the dough was the most silkiest and smoothest dough I had ever felt or seen.  The plan was to make these just for my son's school bake sale, but we ended up eating a few.  Now a few days later I'm making them again for my husband for dessert.  Terrific!  TIP:  put all of your liquid ingredients in the breadmaker first, but make sure that the water isn't too warm since the egg will cook itself.  Than sift your dry ingredients together and throw those in on top of the liquid.  make a hole in the middle of the dry ingredients and add your yeast.  Easy and Wonderful!

text:
WOW.  These definitely lived up to the reviews I read.  I made the whole thing by hand and they turned out quite well.  The scent filled the whole place, mmmm.  Dental floss definitely works well in slicing the buns.  They were a little gooey in the middle but I guess I will leave them in the oven a bit longer next time.  And don't be stingy with the butter - the more butter on the inside, the more gooey the filling is!  A great recipe for a bake sale.  Oh, and one more comment, they are definitely too rich to eat more than one at a time!  I got sick this morning eating so many.  ;)  Thanks for the fabulous recipe!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Second time making this and just now getting around to writing a review about them. These are delicious and super easy to do without the bread machine. The first time I made them I used All Purpose flour because I didn't have any bread flour and instead of the 2 eggs I substituted 6T of egg whites because...again I didn't have any eggs. Well They turned out okay, I was actually amazed that they still turned out as well as they did. Today I made them again following the recipe exactly except I didn't bake them right away(I left them in the fridge overnight and popped them in the oven this morning at 350 on conventional bake it took about 13 minutes to turn golden brown) definitely recommend the bread flour, it just has the consistency that you need for cinnamon rolls. The All purpose flour ones were just too soft and had a weird flavor to them.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-08-19T03:16:08.29
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
5263381
Display Name:
remittancegirl
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6012549.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe, but it's tricky if you're not using a bread machine and I don't have one. A couple of things really matter. Don't use bread flour. I did and they came out dry and more fibrous than when I used plain flour. Definitely foam the yeast in the milk first. Add the flour to the wet ingredients a cup full at a time. Depending on humidity, I've used anything from between 3.5 to 4 cups of flour. The dough should be a little sticky when you turn it out. Knead for about 10 mins to get the gluten moving, but not longer or the rolls end up tough. Let it rise until, when you stick two fingers into the center and pull them out, the hollow stays. Don't depend on time, just be patient. The finger jabbing trick is the best way of all to tell when it's risen enough. I do the same trick as another commenter - mixing the filling of butter, spice (I add a bit more cinnamon and a tiny bit of ground cloves) and brown sugar into a paste and spreading it on the rolled out dough. It is a LOT easier than the brushing and sprinkling. Finally, I add raisins on top of the filling. I just like hitting the chewy bits.
I've used this same recipe about 10 times now and kind of hit my stride with it.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-06-16T09:47:34.44
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
3249528
Display Name:
Jenykell
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/286477.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, so these are the real deal.  I do have a few tips though, which is why I gave them a four.  The first time I made them, the buns were too big for a 9x13 pan, so I put the over flow (two rolls) in a 8x8 pan.  I used glass pyrex baking dishes.  The two that were in the 8x8 where absolutely to DIE FOR!  BUT the rest of them were not even mildly done in the middle.  Quite disheartening after three hours of baking...  So I actually put them back in the oven, and it kinda sorta salvaged the ones on the outside.  But I made them again today for father's day brunch and used a roasting pan, and made sure to leave space between each roll.  I also lowered the temp to 350 and cooked for about 25-30 minutes.  Worked much better.  The first time I made these I doubled the frosting, but had about 1/4 left over so I used a cookie scoop and froze individual dollups and added those to the single recipe today and it was the perfect amount.  Also, just a note, my family is fairly gullotenous, and well, frankly, these are huge.  Really, a roll is too much for one person unless that is ALL you are eating.  Next time, I will split this into two batches, and make the rolls smaller.  Then freeze 1/2 or even 3/4 and that way I can pop them in the oven if the mood strikes without having 3 hours of prep time.  Frosting doesn't need lemon, perfect the way it is.  Good tip to turn the pan upside down and let the goo soak back to the top.  Yum!  Great recipe thanks so much!

text:
I made these for the very first time today, it took a bit of effort ( no breadmaker and just a hand held mixer with dough attachment), but OMG!!! SO worth it. Having read many of the earlier reviews (particularly, the one about how to make them without a breadmaker), I decided to double all the ingredients and make two batches. I actually used my crockpot (on the lowest setting) to raise the dough, and used a hot oven ...switched off before putting them in, to raise them again for 30mins). The only slight changes I made to this fantastic recipe, were:
I increased the amount of cinnamon by around 50%, and also increased the amount of frosting...just my own personal preference and tastebuds, but WOW! Fantastic recipe, definitely a keeper, thank you for sharing this recipe...I loved it SO much that I decided to write a review (which I never do). I had friends round for dinner and they loved these...my husband showered me with compliments, my home smelled like a cinnabon shop ( Heaven :) for me). I became addicted to these in the States, and have long lamented the lack of Cinnabons in Ireland. Thankfully, my craving is now satisfied, just have to pace myself to not make these more than once a month, ....too addictive! Finally, a real Cinnabon clone!

text:
A favorite whereever I take them-- it seems someone always asks for seconds after the whole dish is already gone.  Sometimes I double the batch and add an extra packet of yeast to the dough to ensure the dough rises properly.  I also substitute REAL butter for the margarine.  Be sure to pour the icing over the buns as soon as they come out of the oven so that they are as close to the gooey texture of an authentic Cinnabon.  Be prepared to add an extra workout or two to your week if you make these--they are irresistible!
