photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/180775.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolute WOW! These are a must make. I will pass on some tips that I picked up here - they make the best cinnamon rolls I have ever had! I do not even miss the fact that we don't have a Cinnabon in my town. Follow each of these tips for perfect deliciousness:

* 1/2 a pack of vanilla pudding instant mix into the flour

*turn the oven down to 350, cook for about 20 min

*double the filling mix for extra gooey yumminess

*mix the butter, cinnamon, and brown sugar together in a bowl, then spread  onto the dough

*invert the rolls onto another pan as soon as they come out so that all of said gooey yumminess drips down into the rolls

*slather half the frosting on as soon as they come out of the oven, and five minutes later, slather the rest (my family LOVES frosting, so I doubled this too - it was more than enough, I still have some left over)

I used round cake tins to make mine and then inverted them onto a glass dish. Make sure you oil the pan good and they will just come right out. These make a LOT - I had plenty left for the weekend. I cannot reiterate just how delicious these are - my husband is not a fan of sweets, and he was licking his plate with his finger! These should be a go to recipe for everyone. Again, this is a must make.

text:
Awesome!  I haven't had a cinnabon in a long time, but this is pretty much what I remember them being like, and it's sooooo good!

Now, I have to be honest, it took me over three hours from start to finish to make these.  I've never really made my own bread but I have a lot of baking experience.  I didn't factor in the time for kneading the dough since I don't have a bread machine.  Also, my dough wasn't really rising much so I let it go a little longer and put it in my oven after warming it up just a bit and then turning it off.  I rolled the dough out on flowered wax paper, but I guess I didn't use enough flour and my dough stuck to it and I had to very carefully peel it off.  Speaking of rolling out the dough, it took a lot of rolling for me to get it to the specified size.  All that being said, I think it was worth it, just make sure you allow time for these random things you don't predict will happen :)

text:
This is a very satisfactory recipe, the second egg is a good idea. I use butter instead of margarine. If you slather the log rolled dough with butter, they will not stick to each other. The premium cinnamons in the market shine in this recipe. Also for a epicurious flair,  thin stripes of molasses plus drunken raisins  and orange zest added before rolling up will dazzle your frieds. The same for the addition of Mexican vanilla in the dough, too.  Always bake on parchment paper for quick cleanup. Nutmeg in the dough may please people too.

text:
This was my first time making cinnamon rolls from scratch and they turned out perfectly! I don't have a bread machine so I used the 7oz yeast packet instead of bread machine yeast and took the advice of several reviews and dissolved the sugar in the warm milk and then added the yeast, waited several minutes, then added the rest. I used a glass 9X13 and will say they came out huge! They could have cooked a little longer or as my husband suggested make them a little smaller because the center of a few was slightly doughy but awesome. I used the buttercream icing recipe from this site as my staple icing on everything. Will make them MANY times again. Thanks!!

userID:

Display Name:
mmhmm

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never had a Cinnabon, so I can't compare, but these cinnamon rolls were the best I ever had! I was scared because I've never made any recipe with yeast that wasn't disgusting, but these came out perfect making the dough in my new bread machine. The only issue I had was telling the temperature of the milk without a thermometer. I tested it against my wrist, figuring that if I'm 98.6 degrees, 110 would feel a bit warmer. I guess I wasn't far off! I was afraid to use the full amount of cinnamon, so I decreased it a little, but the full amount would have been fine. I mixed the melted butter, brown sugar and cinnamon all together before spreading on the dough. It was difficult to spread, but I didn't have the problem of the filling running out during baking. This definitely is neither a fast nor easy recipe, but the result is totally worth it.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, I was extremely sceptical while I was making this because it seemed that my bread machine didn't mix the ingredients properly. I took it out of the machine before the first rise and added more milk and kneaded it to try to mix the ingredients in better. I put it back in and noticed that it really didn't rise much which made me even more convinced it was going to turn out horrible. I was about to take the dough and toss it to start a new batch but decided not to. So GLAD I didn't. They were delicious! Super soft  and chewy with good airyness to the dough. My last attempt at cinnamon rolls was TERRIBLE. So terrible I took one bite and threw the rest out. This was the exact opposite. I did also flip them  over after baking. When I was rolling out the dough it was very elastic which made it somewhat hard to roll it out enough to use all the cinnamon sugar. The only thing I will do differently next time is to check on the dough during the mixing and use all the cinnamon mixture. Definetely a keeper recipe!

wow.  my bread maker's dough cycle apparently doesn't mix the ingredients, just pretends to, I used half whole wheat b/c I ran out of white, I only had 1c of pow sugar, and these were still ammaaaaazing.  I actually liked the depth that the whole wheat added.  I was expecting them to be dense, but the texture was still really good.  I think I'm going to stick with the whole wheat version for future batches. Only 1c of sug in the icing turned out to be a good thing.  I was going to supplement with granulated to taste, but after adding the pow, it didn't need anymore.  These also reheat very well. (in the toaster oven, don't think the microwave would do very well)

I am famous among family for these cinnamon rolls.  This recipe nails the taste, texture and appearance of a true "Cinnabon" roll.  Imperative to use brown sugar and lots of high quality cinnamon.  I use my rolling pin to roll over and further imbed the brown sugar and cinnamon into the dough before I roll it up.  Beautiful when rolled up tight.  I have made these to this stage and then frozen.  I put them in my refrigerator overnight to thaw and out on the counter about an hour before baking.  GREAT!!!

Made these for Christmas morning, they were a huge hit.  I used some of the tips from other reviews. text:
I've made these twice now and I guess it's time to add my own praise to the 4500+ positive reviews!  

These are the ultimate cinnamon roll!  Great texture, great size, perfect amount of sweetness, and really?  Is there anything better than a fresh from the oven, homemade cinnamon roll?!  

I did adapt this recipe to be made using a KitchenAid mixer as I don't have a bread machine.  It's not hard at all to do it without a bread machine.  

I made these up to the baking point on Christmas Eve and we baked them off and ate them on Christmas morning.  After putting the rolls in the pan I covered them with plastic wrap and put them in the fridge.  I pulled them out and set them on the counter 30mins-1hr before I wanted to bake them and then baked them for 20-25mins at 350 (the first time I made these I baked for 15mins at 400 as the recipe calls for and they didn't bake evenly, definitely go with the lower temp!  I did take 1/2 a star away for this as my rolls were under baked in the middle the first time I made them because of this.).  

The only other change I made was to change the proportions of the cream cheese frosting a bit.  The first time I made the rolls I made the frosting as written and didn't love it.  I much preferred  the frosting I made this time (I took another 1/2 a star off because of this) where I used 4oz of cream cheese rather than 3oz.  

And don't forget to flip the pan over after it comes out!  Other than those two things this recipe is perfection!

text:
Delicious! I made these in my bread machine, putting in all the liquid ingredients first and then layering the dry, yeast last. It worked great. I prepared the rolls and put them in 2 8" square pans as another reviewer suggested. Then I put covered them and put them in the fridge overnight. The next morning I cooked them as directed. Unfortunately, thought they browned, they were all raw on the sides that touched. I had to separate them (3 to a pan instead of 6) and bake them some more. They came out okay. The second time I tried this, I only put 4 in the square pans and when I pulled them out of the fridge I put them in a cold oven then set it for 350, then set the timer for 25 min. I added 2 more min. just to be sure and they turned out great this time.  So... these are wonderful cinnamon buns but I recommend you leave adequate space in your pan for them to bake properly and adjust the heat and cooking time if you will be refrigerating them before baking.

country:
None
text:
These are wonderful & amazing. There are a few problems I've found with the recipes for breadmakers.

You have to use bread machine yeast. The other one being that the recipe comes out great IF you bring the liquids used (water, milk or whatever) to the temperature recommended in the yeast bottle instead of what the recipe calls for. I think between 120°F -130°F the bread maker's yeast gets activated otherwise there won't be the required heat to make things rise. Also if your butter is a bit on the cold, it will bring the temp of the liquids down if a bit too high hot & at the same time get warmed up.

That's just my machine though. It doesn't preheat the ingredients. 

I didn't have the cream cheese & my frosting was a bit too buttery but it was still awesome. The best part is that I saved like $12 & I had all the ingredients in my pantry & they didn't have that bitter taste that all the frozen pastries & dough have (*cough Pillsbury cough*).

I am never buying cinnamon rolls at the store again. Unless I'm at the mall & there's a stand without a line...

This is a great cinnamon roll recipe!  I doubled the recipe and made them pretty big.  They are extremely gooey inside and pretty darn close to a Cinnabon. I think this is a great cinnabon clone recipe but I do recommend mixing the cinnamon,butter and brown sugar together before spreading on the dough like another poster suggested. I also refrigerated mine overnight and baked it in the morning. Like another poster suggested I didn't set it out to rise I just put it in a cold oven at 350 and baked for 25 min. They turned out great. This will be my go to recipe for now on.

text:
Not quite a cinnabon, but close enough that I will make these instead of spending $5 for a roll at the airport. In response to many people's comments about the filling running out. I actually combined the brown sugar, cinnamon, and butter together so it made a paste. Then I spread the paste over the dough. This kept everything inside the roll for the most part and I didn't have to add any extra ingredient to the filling.

text:
This is a pretty standard recipe.  I would say in response to Jennifer Woodward's post about 'flipping the pan' as soon as they are done baking...  adding a little bit of flour to the filling also alleviates the runniness and helps the cinnamon and sugar stick to the inside of the rolls.  Unfortunately, I don't have an exact measurement, I just eyeball it by dusting the surface through a fine sifter.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Made these this morning and they were fantastic.  Upon the suggestion of others I made the rolls last night and refrigerated them, put them in a cold oven set to 350 degrees and baked for 30 minutes.  I inverted them onto a plate right away to let the filling drip back in, frosted while warm, and they were fantastic.  It is a great option for a morning with company because it only takes 30 minutes to bake in the morning and you can spend less time in the kitchen and more time with your guests.  My neighbor even came over this morning to check them out when he smelled the cinnamon coming from the kitchen!  I was actually out of vanilla so I used 1/2 tsp of hazelnut rum and that worked out fantastic.  It added a little nutty flavor to the frosting.  I know I will be prepping these again the night before Thanksgiving to bake up Thanksgiving morning when I have a house full of people to feed!

text:
I followed the mixer directions, didn't change a thing in the recipe and they were AWESOME!!  I followed the advice to flip the pan, which I kept flipped for 15-20 minutes.

After I rolled it all up, I lengthened the roll to about 26 inches just by gently stretching then cut into 16 portions which fit perfectly in the 9x13 pan.

I doubled the icing and there was still half left after a generous topping! 

Next time I will experiment by adding a bit more butter when rolled out and 50% more sugar/cinnamon filling.

Overall, this is a keeper!

text:
So yummy! They ARE a little harder than the 'real' things, but then again, I imagine that's the lack of science-project-type ingredients, so I can forgive that. Every time I make these, people absolutely swoon over them. And yes, I definitely make sure to use both margarine and butter where called for, and a little grated orange zest in the icing takes it to another level altogether!. This recipe is now my go-to recipe for special breakfasts (birthdays, Christmas, etc) because I make it all in advance up to the rising stage, then cover in Saran Wrap / cling film and leave in the fridge overnight. Whether taken out for half an hour before baking or put straight into the oven as it warms up, they are fantastic. I can't say enough how yummy these are!

text:
Excellent Cinnamon rolls. Will definately use this one again. Followed the recipe except to add raisins and a pinch of cloves to the filling. I baked 4 rolls right away, refrigerated 4 rolls overnight to bake the next morning, and froze four rolls to bake a few days later. The first 4 rolls came out great, even without icing. The overnight rolls came out even better, I guess the filling had time to really 'gel' together. The refrigerated batch didn't rise as well as the first batch, and after 30 min. out on the counter without rising I gave in and proofed them in the oven (still did not rise as much as first batch). Topped these with the icing and toasted pecans. Excellent even thought they were smaller than the first batch. The frozen batch I thawed overnight in the fridge and then proofed the next morning. Didn't rise as well as either previous batch and when baked the dough was a little tougher than the other batches, but still very good.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2011-07-01T19:07:22.217
helpfulCount:
3

7253793

Tammy Gowans

text:
Good cinnamon roles...not Cinnabon, but just as good (and a little bigger) than the ones you buy in a can and bake. Maybe it was my oven, but 400 degrees at 15 minutes made mine way too dark, teetering on overdone. For the next batch, I turned the oven down to 375, baked them for 11 minutes and they came out perfect. It was a fun project with our kids, but next time I'll buy the ones in a can. Less mess!

text:
This was a great recipe.  My husband and kids loved it.  I followed the recipe for the dough exactly except for the margarine.  I only use butter.   For the icing, I doubled it based on some reviews.  I did not need to use all of it though.  I think next time I will increase by about 50% instead.  I baked it at 400 degrees as directed, and it came out perfectly because I had it on the bottom rack. They did not overbrown at all.  In fact, I think next time I may let it bake a few minutes longer to get them a little more golden.  With a bread maker, there was no work.  The dough was easy to roll out, the filling stayed perfectly, so easy... I cannot believe I never tried cinnamom rolls before today!

text:
This is so cliche but I would give this 10 stars if I could.  I honestly didn't believe it would be good enough.  I love Cinnabon.  They just are that good.  I made all 12 cinnamon buns in one 9x13 pan.  Then I froze 6 of them, two at a time in storage containers.  They were fabulous that morning of course.  But what I was really surprised at was how good they were when we heated the frozen ones.  They tasted more like the real thing than the fresh ones!  So taste alone make these fabulous.  They also were easier to make than I thought.  I mixed them in my bread machine and then rolled the dough out and shaped them the night before.  After taking them out to come to room temperature in the morning, the rose and baked beautifully in the oven.

6617120
Display Name:
Fenchurch042

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a bit underwhelming considering all the rave reviews, but it was pretty decent.  The bread itself is no different from my family's Finnish pulla recipe, except for using a bread machine.  I had to make many alterations due to a) not having a bread machine; and b) living at 8600' in a country where there's no such thing as "bread flour" and "all-purpose flour" is just cheap, bleached stuff.  The yeast did NOT rise at all directly in the warm milk, in fact it clumped into a hard cake.  Three times, and two separate batches of yeast.  To fix this, I proofed the yeast in 1/2 c of water with sugar, then added another half cup of warm milk.  For some reason, 4 1/2 cups of flour wasn't nearly enough.  To get the dough workable, I needed 6 cups, then another 1 or 2 to knead for 10 min.  Finally, I added cardamom (to give it the pulla flavour).  As for baking, I know this is entirely due to the altitude, but 400 degrees for 15 min left the tops dark and the middles raw, so next time, it'll be 375 or lower for 20 min.  And maybe making smaller rolls (more like the cinnabon minis).  Flavour-wise, 5 stars!  Ease of altering and making at altitude, 3 stars but I'm sure this would be an entirely different story if I had been able to make it exactly as written.

I haven't had a Cinnabon in probably 10 years, so I can't say whether this is a clone, however, I was very happy with this recipe!  I left them a little too long and they got a little too dark on the bottom for my taste (not a fan of the slightly burnt sugar flavor), but the rest of the roll was still soft and gooey and perfect!  They are best the first day, but even a few days later, if you zap them in the microwave, they're great.

text:
This has been my go-to recipe for a few years now, and I'm just getting around to reviewing it!  I follow the freezing instructions included in the reviews and give them every year at Christmastime! They're always a HIT! 

One addition: With the frosting, I like to freeze it in "packets." I evenly space spoonfuls on a piece of freezer Press & Seal wrap. Then top with another piece and seal around the frosting. Freeze it and you have packets of frosting you can cut apart and use anytime! Great if you freeze the rolls individually!  

Awesome recipe and I will continue to make and give them year after year!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome! I used the make without bread machine method of dissolving about 2 and 1/4 tsp of active dry yeast in the warm milk before adding all the other ingredients in my kitchenaid. after kneaded well with the dough hook i covered it and put it in the 200degree turned off oven for a hour. I then turned on to a floured mat and covered for another 10mins. Then rolled it out as instructed in the directions.followed the ingredients for the roll perfectly! I placed them in the baking dish on parchment paper and sprayed it for good measure. Placed it in the fridge overnight and left it covered with a towel on the oven in the morning while it preheated to 350. Baked for about 25 mins I would say. On the frosting I used 4oz's of cream cheese because thats what I had left over from another recipe and used the same amount sugar and other ingredients. I did turn it out on a baking sheet lined with tinfoil for easy clean up and dripped all of the goodness on top of it. I then used a rubber spatula to spread the cream cheese over the top. So Yummy!

text:
These rolls are as close to a Cinnabon can be! The brown sugar and cinnamon make the filling nice and gooey. I followed the recipe's ingredients list exactly, but not the directions. I used my Kitchenaid to mix and pre-knead the dough, then kneaded it by hand and let it rise until doubled. Filled and sliced and put into pan in the fridge until next morning; left at room temp about 30 mins and then baked. The rolls came out great; definitely made for a great breakfast and not much work in the morning. Thanks, Marsha!

This is one of those recipes that you automatically expect to be a big hit. I must say that this was a big miss for us. Too wet, too sweet, too gooey. I guess everyone else likes their cinnamon rolls different than we do. This won't be a repeat in our house.

text:
These were so easy and turned out perfect!  I made in the bread machine as stated. Per other reviewers I mixed the cinnamon and sugar together with the butter to form a spreadable paste.  After cutting I let rise for about an hour and then covered with buttered plastic wrap and put in the refrigerator until the next morning.  I took out about 30 minutes before baking and baked at 350 for 20 minutes.  They turned out perfect! Will definitely be making again.

text:
Very disappointing!  I love cinnabon and this is definately not a clone.  Followed the recipe exactly.  Didn't rise very much (and my oven has a proof setting so I know that wasn't me and yeast was tested prior to using and is fine) too much flour and way too much sugar in the filling, very very sweet.  Dough too dense and even tough.  I've made many sweet rolls and have many many cinnabon in my life and these are nothing like them at all.  If you want good cinnamon rolls just make a sweet dough, roll out and spread with butter sprinkle with cinnamon & sugar, rise, bake and put icing on top don't bother with this recipe.

text:
These are excellent. very 'doughy' if that is what you like, which we do...I used my Kitchen Aid mixer to knead the dough, it was so easy. My family loved these rolls. I honestly do not think they are 'like' Cinnabon to a "T", but they are delicious in their own right. The frosting IMO was not what I expected, but it could have been my own mistake, don't get me wrong, it was still yummy, I just felt it was missing something I cannot put my finger on.  Over all, a really good cinnamon roll. Oh yeah, I left it in my oven over night to rise, and I got a great sized cinnamon roll for baking. I was planning on turning them over after baking (as other reviewers advised), so as to utilize the butter/sugar drippings to their best, but my husband beat me to getting these puppies out of the oven, and the kids cut into them right then and there. There was NO complaining from them about the gooey goodness ending up at the bottom of the pan...I don't think they even noticed. These are at their prime straight from the oven....but the next day they still were gloriously gooey and tender, not dry like I expected.

Very good- better even still the next day. The frosting was... a little too cream-cheesy... it's why I didn't give it 5*'s. It needs tweaking. i just pulled a batch of these out of the oven a little bit ago---oh my goodness! they are so yummy! my husband said they're the best hes ever had. they dont taste exactly like cinnabon, but they are close. i actually like them better, cinnabon is a little too rich for me. i used my breadmaker for the dough and it worked great. i didnt have bread flour so i subbed all purpose. to compensate i added about 1/4 cup more, as one reviewer suggested. they are really easy to make, but the dough process takes a long time, so keep that in mind! i will definetly be making these again. thank you for this amazing recipe!

I tweaked these just a little to make TURTLE CINNAMON ROLLS and added some chocolate chips and pecans when I rolled it up.  In lieu of cream cheese frosting, I topped them with caramel (1/2 cube butter, 2 T Karo Syrup, 1/2 C brown sugar and a dash of salt- all boiled to soft ball stage.  stir in 1/8 t baking soda and 1/4 t vanilla)  SO AMAZING!!!

I've been making these since I found the recipe about two years ago.  Everyone I have ever made them for has loved them.  They are THE BEST cinnamon rolls!!  The only change I've made to them is in the filling:  I use 1/2 c butter instead of 1/3, 1 1/2 c brown sugar, and 3 tbsp cinnamon.  I usually roll them into a longer skinnier log, so that I get more and smaller rolls.  I've never had any problem with the filling running out.  They are perfect every time.

text:
As I gazed at this rendition of a Cinnabon on my screen, I was transported back to the first time that I succumbed to the original decadent delight.  Perhaps your experience was similar and just as wonderful!  Some years back, I was passing through a local mall and the smell alone just sucked me in.  I hadn't a chance against this sugary "icon of cinnamon indulgence", and was of course completely in awe of the experience.  In marveling at the thought of creating my own, along with a bit of gentle encouragement from my girlfriend, I ventured forth.  Obviously, I had very high expectations of these gooey "Clones", and must say that I was not let down in the least.  As my depth of experience and comfort lies in cooking versus baking, I followed the recipe exactly as written.  My girlfriend polished off a lone bun, but I somehow coerced myself into a second after making short work (too short) of my first.  We have three teens in the house, and the eldest (17) sucked down three of them.  Two warm from the oven, and another on the sly once mom went to work.  The buns were off limits to the other two as they had already imbibed in an afternoon junk-food affair at the movies.  I must say that I've yet to find a recipe to be as stand-alone "perfect" as this, and as I conclude I'm hearing the early morning shuffle of the boys through the kitchen, and it occurs to me that I'm unlikely to ever again see the surviving "six in the pan" that I so carefully wrapped up late last night.

text:
These are wonderful!  The time is way too long for us though.  So the night before, we fully made them all the way through letting them rise as if they were about to go in the oven.  Then we put a lid on the 9x13 and put them in the fridge.  Next morning when we got up all we had to do was make the icing and bake them for the 20 minutes (on 375).  This way made breakfast a lot quicker.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SOOOO yummy! I've made these more than 10 times and others agree they definitely are CLONES of cinnabuns (if you combine these most common suggestions by reviewers):
1. Cut down sugar in dough to 1/3 cup sugar
2. Cream 1/2 cup SOFTENED butter with brown sugar and cinnamon (1 1/2 tablespoon is plenty and not overwhelming for cinnamon). These ratios will allow a perfectly spreadable mixture for your buns. Use all of it and you will get just enough drippings (see #4)
3. Bake at 350 for 25 minutes to avoid "doughy" buns in the middle.
4. Invert the pan into a pan of the same size and any gooey drippings will drip back into the buns. This works IDEALLY if you line the bottom of your pan with a buttered piece of wax paper.
5. When they are still warm, spread just a bit of the frosting. It will melt and sink into the gaps. When buns cool enough not to melt frosting, add more.
ENJOY!!! They'll still be warm :)

text:
I have made this recipe several times over the past year and everyone in my family and extended family absolutely loves them. I do not have a bread machine so I make them by hand as others have mentioned. I also use a 50-50 mixture of white and whole wheat flour.   The recipe does make 12 huge rolls - too big for me. What I do now is roll the dough out as directed in a 16X21 inch rectangle. After adding the filling, I cut the dough in half lengthwise and roll two long logs, one towards me and the other away from me. I cut each log into 12 rolls and set 9 of them in a 9X9 pan and 15 of them in a 9X13 pan. I raise and bake as further directed in the recipe. These rolls are a better serving size for my diet and still so yummy!

text:
Just finished making these, and they turned out PERFECT! The only changes I made were adding less butter (watching my diet) I used about 1 stick of butter total. When rolling them up, instead of putting the butter on the dough first; I mixed the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together and spread it on the dough. This worked out WONDERFUL. I ended up almost tripling the icing on accident (I didn't realize the recipe calls for 3 oz of cream cheese and accidentally used the whole 8 oz!) but it ended up being the perfect amount, we like to have tons of extra icing :) My dad says they are better than cinnabon. I will definitely be making these again!

I've tried cinnamon rolls before, but never had as good of luck as I did with these. I didn't have a bread machine, so I took the suggestion of another reviewer and set the oven to warm, then turned it off and set the rolls in there for about an hour. After letting them rise, I put them in the fridge overnight and baked them the next morning. When I started making the frosting, I realized I didn't have any confectioner's sugar, so I used the recipe on this site for Whipped Cream Cheese Frosting. It was a nice, lighter alternative to the usual thicker cream cheese frosting.

text:
awesome recipe! easy to follow.. only difference is like others I proofed the yeast with warm milk and 1/4 tsp sugar until foamy..added eggs, sugar, salt..then slowly added flour.. in my kitchenaid.. I then switched to my dough hook and continued kneading..once it came together I kneaded by hand.. let the dough rise in a lightly oiled bowl for 1 hour..I then rolled the dough out into a 16X21 inch rectangle..put on the topping..rolled it up - suggestion: dental floss works very well to cut up your rolls! let rolls rise again for 30 mins..baked for 20 mins - oven was at 350..delicious!!

text:
I made this as written sans the bread flour as I  did not have any and ended up using AP in lieu and they still came out amazing!!  My daughter said that they were better than the ones at the mall or grocery store.  I plan on getting a thermometer so that I can get the correct temperature correct for the milk and I will hunt down bread flour and try it again...I am sure that will make them even more wonderful!!  I made this by hand as I do not have a bread machine and it was simple and straight forward.  Thank you for sharing this!!  UPDATE: I made these again today and thought I would share the non-bread machine way for those with the time and patience to do it. Sifted 4 1/2 c bread flour, leaving 1/2 cup on the side. Added bread machine yeast, flour and sugar, stirred to mix all the dry ingredients, and set aside in a separate bowl.  Melted the butter and the milk and let cool to 125 on a instant read thermometer. Meanwhile in a large bowl I whisked the eggs and added the milk and butter mixture.  With a heavy spoon or spatula I mixed the  dry ingredients with the wet 1 cup at a time.   Sprinkle part of the 1/2 c. reserved flour onto your work surface, turn dough onto the floured surface and begin kneading, incorporating the remaining flour and you knead 5-10 minutes till soft and silky.  Butter a large bowl, place dough into the bowl, turn to coat, cover and place in a warm area till doubled in bulk.  Turn dough onto a floured work surface and let rest 10 minutes. The proc

OMG I would give these 10 STARS!!! if I could! These are the best things I have ever tasted!!!! They are so good you will cry when they're gone!! Literally! I know we did! I always used to make homemade cinnamon buns but always did a biscuit type dough, so they were quite different and well these blew those away. I found one thing helpful for the people who said the middle ones didn't cook, well I put the smaller end pieces in the middle and the bigger middle pieces on the outside so they cooked beautifully, and I did 350 degrees for 20-25 minutes instead of 400 for 15 min.. Hope this helps, oh and next time I think I'll use a bigger pan than a 9x13 as mine busted out and over and needed more room. I want to make these everyday....I could literally eat the whole pan. A big THANK YOU to the person that posted this recipe and I think I'm in love with you!!! LOL Please everyone make these....don't even think twice about it...just do it!

userID:
3372597
Display Name:
Kyra
isPro:
False
followersCount:

47

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/150803.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are simply fabulous. The buns were simply perfect! Soft, scrumptious, mouth watering flavor!  I don't own a bread machine, so here's how I did it: I warmed up the milk to 115F or 45C & mixed in 2 1/2 teaspoons of active dry yeast & 2 tbsp. sugar from the cup of sugar the recipe called for. Then I let it rest for about 10 minutes, until it got creamy. Since I don't like using hydrogenated fats such as margarine, but knowing that butter won't give the dough that extra fluffiness, I used lard instead. I added the lard & the 2 eggs and used a whisk to mix them in properly. Then I added the rest of the sugar and continued whisking for a minute or two. I like to add the flour 1/2 cup at a time in case I need to make adjustments to the qty I use & by feeling the dough (it must feel elastic and smooth, slightly sticky) I ended up using only 4 cups of ap flour. I formed a tight ball, oiled a big bowl and put my dough in it face down, then turning it back up, so that all the dough was perfectly coated with oil, covered it and let it raise in a warm place until doubled (@ one hour) I took the dough out of the bowl, gently deflated it and rolled it out on a lightly floured counter. It rolled out beautifully, pretty thin and it did not stick to the counter. I followed the rest of the recipe exactly. Roll the dough pretty tight so the filling doesn't fall out when cutting. I used a sharp knife to cut the buns.

amazing recipe. it really is just like a cinnabon and considering how many i have consumed in my lifetime... i can tell u... i know what the cinnabon tastes like and this recipe is perfect... althooo i did make alterations to fit my needs and here they are:  I do not have a bread machine so i also dissolved my yeast in my sugar/milk mixture. I kept everything else the same except i did double the cream cheese frosting recipe. It is almost necessary to double the frosting because it is very delicious, not overly sweet, and perfectly compliments the cinnabon. Oh and i did make these the night before, so putting them in the fridge overnight is perfectly fine. I put them in the oven while it was preheating along with the regular cook time. Maybe it is just my oven but when i took it out of the oven after 20 minutes, it was undercooked. Me being careless, had already spread a lot of the frosting on before i realized this. So i just popped it back in the oven for ten more minutes. It still turned out perfect! even the frosting was still delicious. so apparently this is a recipe even i cannot mess up!

text:
i made this recipe a few times and made some changes.  we didn't use bread flour, and used all purpose flour...we substituted a cup of whole wheat flour, which gave it a more wholesome texture.  i found that using all white flour made it very dinner-roll-esque.  to deepen the flavour, we added a little more butter a dash of cloves and nutmeg to the cinnamon filling.  i am a huge fan of cream cheese flavour, so we added an 8oz package of cream cheese...and it was super!!!  definitely add some of the icing when they come out of the oven, and add some more before serving.

text:
YUM, these are so delicious! I cut down the flour by 1/4 cup the second time I made them, and the dough was perfect consistency with that minor adjustment.  My kids prefer the small "cinnabites" so i rolled the dough to 1/2" thickness and spread butter and brown sugar/cinnamon mixture on both sides. Used a pizza cutter to cut the dough into 1/2" cubes and put them on a greased cookie sheet and let rise before baking 15 minutes at 375. Drizzled frosting over the pieces and served them in a cup, just like at the mall. They were a BIG hit!

text:
Made this recipe today. I didn't have margarine, so I used butter in the dough. I proofed the yeast by putting the total amount of yeast in 1/4 warm water with one tablespoon of sugar. I let it sit for around 10 minutes until bubbly.  Since I used butter, the extra 1/4 cup water made up for the fact that margarine has a higher water content than butter.  I added one teaspoon of  vanilla to the liquid in the bread machine.   Once done, I turned the dough out onto floured wax paper. Trust me when I say use LOTS of flour when rolling it out. I thought I'd used enough but the wax paper still stuck to the dough.   The dough took a little longer to roll out than I had expected. I made a mistake by using only 1/2 cup butter to spread on the rectangle of dough. I will be much better with the 1/3 cup the recipe called for. I left 1/2 inch along the long edge unbuttered to seal the roll.  After sprinkling on the sugar/cinnamon mixture (leaving the 1/2 inch edge unsugared), I used a rolling pin to pat down the mixture. the helped keep the sugar and cinnamon from falling out. I rolled it up starting with the long end, like a jelly roll, and it made around 3  layers. I sealed the unsugared edge. Then I cut off the uneven ends to make the end rolls uniform.  I sliced them with a knife  about 1 inch wide, and put them cut side down in a parchment lined 8 x 4 pan, four to a pan. After letting them rise I baked at 350 for around 17 minutes. There was no issue of the filling running out, but t
Review:

text:
My sister has a wonderful cinnamon roll recipe that she won't share.  I set out to find a good recipe, and this recipe is better than my sister's!  So, if you're reading this Lynette-I don't need your recipe anymore-this one beats yours! ;)

I don't have a bread machine so I used other reviewer's advice on how to make this without a bread machine.  I also made them the night before and put them in the fridge just before letting them rise the last time.  I just pulled them out the next morning and put them in a cold oven, turned it to 350 degrees, and baked for 25 minutes.  Next time I will probably place them in 2 8X8 pans or 2 8" round pans to give them more room to expand and for more even baking.  In my 9X13 pan, the outer buns browned and baked well while the inner buns had some doughie spots.  

I made no changes to the recipe and it came out delicious.

text:
i have never made cinnamon rolls before. i'm not good at all at making dough either, so when i got my breadmaker a couple of months ago, this is a recipe i had to try. i started this afternoon with the dough, in the breadmachine, started having probs with rising, or so i thought, turned out okay, but lots of worrying and posting to AR for help, and i got excellent help by the way. okay, rolled them out, doubled the recipe for the filling, rolled them up, cut them, (i ended up with 16 pieces), left four out to rise, and froze the rest. well the four didn't really rise, as the recipe called for. the recipe said "until they double in size. they may have quartered in size, so i was quite worried about this as well. i also didn't pack them in tight in the pan. my pan was an 8x8 with the four rolls packed in the middle, so when i took them out of the oven, the outsides were a dark brown (not burned). i spread some of the icing on top right away as some reviewer suggested to make them softer. and a few min. later put the rest on. OMG. they were AWESOME. i suprised myself! my son even loves me again (he's typical moody 17 yr old) he ate two. the dough in the middle is sooooo soft and tender, just like the real deals. these are easy, after all the trouble i thought they were. i worried for nothing it seems. however, i do wonder how to get the filling a little more gooeyer/syrupy like. as it tends to get hard once they're cooled and this is soooo not a complaint! cuz it's soooo yummy,

text:
This was the first time I've ever made homemade cinnamon rolls. They where very easy to make. It asks for two room temp. eggs, I can be impatient so I looked up a quick way. Place your egg [in the shell] in warm water for two min. Wipe off. feel it, if it seems cool still, place it in warm water one more time for two min. It seemed to work,no one got sick either [for the egg police]. I made two batches. I was very trusting of the reviews.So I sent them off with my husband to work. He works construction, the guys loved them, one man said "they where the best he's ever had, and he's had a lot of cinnamon rolls". I thought that was really nice. My husband was very happy. So was I. Thank you for a terrific recipe.

As for others saying that they unrolled in the oven, you should put them somewhat close together so when they cook, they will all come together and stick.

text:
Exceptional! I doubled the recipe and made them for my sunday school class. I had two bread machines going at once.  I cut the rising time by about 10 minutes before sticking them in the oven, didn't seem to effect them any. The only thing I changed was I used butter and only 1 1/2 Tbsp cinnamon.  I used a pastry cutter to cut the butter into the sugar and cinnamon mixture. After brushing the dough with butter I added the cinnamon and sugar mixture.  I didn't have a problem at all with the filling falling out.
Update:  I made these rolls again and they were outstanding I made them the night before and let them set out for about 45 min. the next morning.  Didn't seem to change anything.  They did bake about 10 min. longer.

text:
Absolutely fantastic. A hint for substituting all purpose flour for baking flour: make sure to add extra gluten so it will stand up to the oven. 

Here's how: 

Make a simpel dough from 1 cup of whole wheat flour and a little water. Rinse the dough under a trickling stream of water for about two minutes, until you have only gluten (Wash out all of the starch).  This should leave you about two tablespoons of gluten, which I added to the dough before kneading. It came out absolutely perfect, even without baking flour!

Wow - these were delicious, esp. this last time. I think the key to a great cinnamon roll is to make darn sure you don't overbake them!!! So I guess it's mostly about personal preference and knowing your oven.  :)

This recipe has gotten rave reviews from anyone I've ever served them to.  I have made these about a dozen times and they have been excellent every time.

I do use Saigon cinnamon that I get at the grocery store or Costco instead of regular cinnamon...as it really makes them taste more like Cinnabon.

I also use the recipe for Amish White Bread from this site submitted by "Peg" instead of the bread recipe for these rolls.  I make the dough in my bread machine.  I have a child that is allergic to eggs...so a recipe without eggs is helpful for us.  I haven't tried them with this bread recipe.

My husband and kids love when I make these.

Absolutely fantastic! I haven't had a Cinnabon in a long while, but this tasted perfect to me. And the icing was divine! The only things I did differently were: I didn't have margarine, so I used butter; I mixed the butter, cinnamon, and brown sugar together and then spread it on the dough; and I put parchment paper in the bottom of my glass baking dish. I often use parchment when baking breads - cleanup is so so so much easier and you don't need to grease pans if the recipe suggests it.

text:
Fabulous recipe!
I'm a first time cinnamon roll baker, and so I didn't heat the milk enough, added the salt to early and didn't knead the dough enough, all of which meant that the dough didn't rise enough and only yielded 8 rolls.
I also followed the advice of the user who suggested 350 degrees for 20 minutes and they came out undercooked. 
However they were still fabulous, and my roommates loved them as well. (The frosting is to die for!)
This is a recipe is a keeper, and I will definitely make it again, this time following the original recipe and baking at 400 degrees, and I may increase the baking time if needed.

this recipe is as awesome as everyone else says it is! i followed the advice of others and was able to make this without a breadmaker. i lined my baking dish with parchment paper and butter - they didn't stick at all! i baked mine at 350 for 25 minutes (20 min they weren't golden brown yet). i like that these come out perfect the first time you ever make them!

text:
My work friends beg me for these!  I just can't keep up with the demand!  The last batch (two dozen) were eaten in under 15 minutes!  Everyone said that I should open up a cinnamon bun business.  These can be made the night before.  After placing them in the pans, refrigerate them until about two hours before baking.  Take them out and let them rise before popping in the oven.  Double the cream cheese icing recipe and apply while the buns are warm.  The buns taste best when served warm with vanilla ice cream.

text:
Not that this recipe needs another great review, but these are excellent! I did everything that the recipe said, the only issue I had was on the rising time (but that isn't the recipes fault). Mine took almost 2 hours to rise the first time and the second time was about 45 minutes.  I know some had said it called for too much sugar/cinnamon, but i thought i might need a LITTLE bit more. I did not double the frosting and it was perfect.  If you haven't tried these you need to.  I will be making these many times over! Thanks for the great recipe!!! *I did make a paste out of the butter brown sugar and cinnamon, made it look nicer and stayed in the rolls better!

I was craving Cinnabon cinnamon buns but don't live anywhere near one, so I figured I could probably find a recipe somewhere, and here it is!  These are sooooooooo yummy!  My sisters-in-law were all envious!  A lot of work, but definitly worth it.  Double the icing!
I make the dough by hand, use instructions from Mother's cinnamon rolls.
When tripling the recipe, do not triple salt, use three packets of yeast.
Use hand mixer for icing.
15 minutes is too long in the oven.

text:
very good! if you want to make them overnight, place rolls in freezer/fridge before the 2nd rise (after you have cut them and placed in pan). In the morning, just pull them out, let rise in a warm place for about 40 minutes and bake.
I agree with the other reviews - DON'T cut down on the cinnamon/brown sugar - it's perfect.  I substitute 1/4 C white sugar and 3/4 brown sugar for 1 C brown sugar and add a bit of vanilla to the butter and it seems to have a little more flavor.

country:
None
text:
YUMO!!!  The only things I would change for next time would be to use a knife and cut the corners to right angles... rather than rounded... b/c this makes it hard when you roll it up... I mean you kind of lose a little of the cinnamon buns since the dough isn't the same length on both sides... I still used mine, but those ones came out harder than the other ones b/c they were mainly dough.  Anyway... the other thing I did do was I cut the dough in more than 12 slices.  The slices with 12 were WAY too big.  I basically cut the roll in half in the middle, then I cut each of those in half at the middle, and so on until I felt the rolls were a good size.  I didn't have any trouble with losing the goo either... I made extra icing b/c we love that part, but I shouldn't have... the recipe calls for the right amount, so next time I won't double it!  This was delicious and I plan on making them again!  Thanks for the recipe!

All I can say is Oh Wow!  This is the first time I have made these - I stumbled onto the recipe as a new user of the site and decided to give them a try.  I took onboard some of the comments made by others, I used half bread flour and half plain flour, I used the warm oven idea to help them rise and I baked them at 375degF. country:
None
text:
These were fantastic...just as good if not better than Cinnabon's!  I don't do alot with bread/yeast and I don't have a bread machine but I followed some suggestions and used one 7 oz packet of dry yeast which I dissolved in the warm milk and then followed the recipe.  (I kneaded it a little bit...not quite sure how long to knead for.)  I did let it rise in the preheated oven which worked well.
I think next time, I will combine the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon and spread it on so it all stays in there.  I rolled the dough from the long side and cut into 13 pieces.  I would probably cut them smaller for mini's as they were the size of the acutal cinnabon.
I would also bake at 350 because the tops got very brown quickly and I was afraid it the dough would still be raw in the middle so I baked them a little longer.  
AND...I would definitely mad a double batch of icing as we love that!  (I might even try the canned cream cheese icing)

text:
Very Yummy and my house smells oh so good!!

I used Splenda Brown Sugar and instead of sprinkling it on the butter, I mixed the the butter, sugar and cinnamon together and spread it on.  This made it so the mixture stayed in the bun versus oozing out into the pan.

The Splenda Brown sugar tastes good...I only used it because I was out of regular.  Pro to that is it is half the calories so I don't feel as bad eating these things!

text:
These are so delicious!  I made them for Christmas breakfast and everyone LOVED them.  I was a bit worried because the dough didn't rise much in the time I had before needing to bake them (about an hour) but they turned out perfect anyway.  I loved the frosting too, tastes like it came from Cinnabon for sure!!  Try this, you'll love it!  
UPDATE:  I made these for the second time today and I did as a few suggested, after I took them out of the oven I turned them over onto a cookie sheet to let the cinnamon/brown sugar filling redistribute through each roll.  I was planning to flip them back again to frost them but they came out of the pan and the bottoms lookes so juicy and perfect to I left them flipped over and iced the bottoms with the frosting.  This made them TO DIE FOR!!!  They were great before but even better this way, and they looked gorgeous too!!  Hope this tip helps anyone who has had a problem with the filling dripping out of the rolls to the pan.  Try it, it really works great!

country:
None
text:
The key to this is using fast rising yeast.I used regualr yeast and it really di not rise as well. I let it rise for 30 minutes in a warm oven. I made sure to cover the bowl with a cloth so it can rise.(make sure the oven isnt too hot so your bowl wont melt! I do not have a bread machine. But I found this recipe to be easy without one.   I also use a bit of melted butter after the rolls rise, I brush onto the rolls. Then I sprinkle a bit more of cinnamon on it. I also make sure when making the dough I put cinnamon in that too.  If your a cinnamon lover, then add some of the cinnamon in the icing as well. It taste SOOO good. I am going to have to make another batch!  This is still not a cinnabon, but it is a really good recipe. These rolls only last about two days or less. YUMMY!!

text:
I first want to start off by saying... I hate cinnamon rolls. Yeah, I'm a weirdo. I simply made these for fun (even though I honestly don't like the smell of sweet baking pastries). When they came out of the oven looking so beautiful, I decided to give them a try. For the first time in my life, I've enjoyed eating a few bites of a cinnamon roll! I will definately make these again (not for myself, but others).

I couldn't find bread machine yeast, so I bought packets of Active Yeast. I used a packet and it worked! I used my bread machine simply for kneeding. I followed the suggestion to put the oven at 200, turn it off, and let the dough rise that way. It worked PERFECTLY (I've never made bread products before out of the bread machine). I also didn't end up using all of the brown sugar mixture. After I cut the dough into rolls, I used the oven again to help those rise. They baked for 15 minutes and turned out perfectly! I HIGHLY recommend this recipe.

text:
WOW!!!! These are by far the best cinnamon rolls I've had.  My kids ate them up, too.  Plus, they're homemade and I know exactly what's in them. They are easy even without a bread machine and they came out fluffy and delicious! I'll definately make these again soon! Thanks for sharing. UPDATE: I HAVE MADE THESE SEVERAL TIMES SINCE I FOUND THEM. I'VE LEARNED, HOWEVER, THEY DO TURN OUT DOUGHY, ESPECIALLY IF I BAKE THEM IN A CAKE PAN. TO CORRECT THIS, I TURN TEMP DOWN TO 325-350 DEGREES. IT TAKES A LITTLE LONGER, BUT THEY ALWAYS TURN OUT DONE...NOT DOUGHY. THEY ALSO BAKE UP WELL IN A COUPLE OF PIE PANS.

I had to make these lowfat/lower calorie for my husband who is on a diet but craving cinnamon buns and I was leery about how they would come out. But wow!! Even with the changes they are so good. And my 16 year told me there is no way they are healthier, because they taste so fattening. I substituted egg beaters for the eggs, light butter spread for the regular stuff, Slenda sugar blends for regular sugar and brown sugar, and fat free cream cheese for the regular stuff. Other than making those changes, I followed the recipe. They are sooo yummy. And I don't feel so bad now eating them.

text:
I know there are already so many positive reviews but had to add my two thumbs up, my kids two thumbs up and my neighbors who I shared half the batch with's thumbs up!  

I rolled from the long side and cut with dental floss every two inches. I ended up with 13 rolls.  I used parchment paper on the bottom of the pan and when they were done turned them over onto a differnt pan (sprayed a little bit with spam) and let all the yummy goo drip back onto the tops.  Then I flipped them back into the first pan and iced.  I didn't use the icing recipe here as I had no cream cheese but I used a very simple one and it was delicious.  3 cups powdered sugar, 3 tbs milk, 1 tbs vanilla and mix.  Add more milk to get the consistency you desire.  WOW is all I can say. : ) The family came a running when they were done.

text:
I did't have a bread machine and so followed the advice of others and proofed yeast and then put the dry ingredients in one bowl and the wet in another. once the yeast was ready i mixed it with the wet ingredients then made a well in the flour and then mixed   everything until it was homogenous. then i let it rise for 1 hour and 20 minutes. and followed the rest of the recipe as written. this is a very delicious recipe. i might ease down on the sugar because if you are sensitive to sweet things this will have you twitching for the next few hours. i can't imagine adding more sugar, syrups, or corn syrup for that matter. for me it's borderline sickeningly sweet...but otherwise delicious!

GREAT STUFF!
To make these rolls a little more "gooey" inside I added some brown sugar and cinnamon to the top of each roll and a small bit of butter. text:
Oh my gosh these were delicious!  I made them for a group of friends that were moving and they were gobbled up.  I don't have a bread machine so I just mixed it in my kitchenaid then let it rise for an hour in a warm oven like someone had suggested.  I wouldn't preheat the oven to 200 degrees though.  I took the bowl out of the oven after an hour and it was still so hot that I had to use a hot pad!  It sort of cooked the top of the dough it was so hot.  Next time I'll set the temp. around 150 degrees, turn it off, then see if it's still too hot before I put my dough in there to rise.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy (yet sinful) and easy to make using breadmachine.
Still turn out great despite using All Purpose Flour and Quickrise Instant yeast (increase to 3 tsp)instead as that's what I have.
Thanks for suggesting using Dental floss and lining pan with greased waxpaper.  It certainly helped to avoid squishing the dough while cutting and avoid the mess after baking while making it also easy to remove the dough/roll from the pan.  Also found my dough rise very well when placed in preheated oven.  
I had to decrease the oven temp and time to 335F x 15min to avoid burning the bun - that's likely b/c my buns were smaller (made 20).  

Would make this recipe again but will have to ensure I start earlier so I don't go to bed at 3am again.  Took me 4 1/2 hours total (2h breadmachine and 2h rise).

Next time, will try refridgerating my rolls and bake next day but not sure of the steps.  
Not sure whether I should let my rolls double in size first before refridgerating??

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/42008.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe many times since it was posted. I found that if you heat the milk for a minute in the microwave, it is just the right temperature to melt the softened butter. I use only 4 cups of bread flour, but other than that I don't change the recipe. I baked a batch of these cinnamon rolls on Thursday, and they went so quickly that I had to make another batch on Friday. I think the quantity of frosting depends on what you like. My teenage daughter thought that the regular amount of frosting was too much, I thought it was just right. It is my favorite recipe, and a lot of people ask for it. The bread machine helps make the recipe a lot easier than doing it by hand.

text:
I love this recipe!  it comes out perfectly everytime and I am a true novice when it comes to baking...I don't have a bread machine or a mixer, so i did it all by hand: I proofed the yeast with the white sugar for 10 minutes (I did NOT use the rapid rise).  I then mixed in the dry ingredients and set it aside and let it rise for about an hour.  I then rolled it out per the instructions and then let it double in size for another hour.  You won't regret the time you put into this!!!

text:
I've made a lot of cinnamon rolls looking for something that comes close to cinnabon, and this is the closest I've found. The frosting is a dead on match, and the rolls are very close when they are still warm. The dough was very easy to work with although it sounded like it may have been a little hard on the machine. My bread machine is pretty low end though, so that could be the problem. These rolls are best while warm but if you have leftovers, make sure you put them in something airtight (tin foil was a bad idea. They were hard the next morning). Thanks for the great recipe! I'll be using this one a lot!

text:
A good cinnamon roll recipe but not a great Cinnabon clone -perhaps because differences exist between ovens and I didn't follow this perfectly....only closely. The texture is good out of the oven however as they cool they quickly get tough and the brown sugar turns to candy. The cinnamon swirl needs to remain more fluidlike. The icing recipe is not replicating that used by Cinnabon. The cream cheese is too rich. Cinnabon's icing is lighter and milder. This is a good cinnamon roll recipe but some adjustment needs to prevent them from turning to bricks once they cool.

text:
was a little hesitant when the dough came out really tough, but I made the rolls almost to the recipe, I don't have a bread machine but made the dough by hand. My butter was also too hard and I over melted it in the microwave.  I think I rolled them the wrong way, the longer side, but once they baked they filled in width wise to match their hieght (make sence?) anyways, they came out amazingly close to cinnabon's, although maybe its just me getting older, but they seemed REALLY sweet, It has been about 10 years since I had the origanal though! In all I gave this 5 stars, they were easy to make and came out great! will make again, but will try making mini ones instead of large ones.
Thanks for a great recipe!!!!!!!!!! EDIT: I make these all the time; I line a pan with parchment, put the rolls in the pan and freeze right away. ( skipping a second rise) I take them out the night before and thaw overnight in the fridge, place pan in cold oven, then turn on the oven, they rise as the oven warms and then bake till golden. They aren't as good after freezing but I love having them on hand! The frosting freezes great as well. Thank you again for. A great recipe!!

text:
Ok, I tried this again after leaving a bad review because the rolls were still doughy inside and overcooked outside with the Temp and Cooking time. This time, I decreased the T to 350, and raised the cooking time to 25 mn. Baked in muffin cups --> Delicious. Baked in pan --> still raw. Not as much as the 1st time though. So, if you cooker longer at a lower temp, and give them plenty of room to expand, they'll be awesome. Or else, they'll be raw and a disaster. And that was with 2 different ovens, one old and one brand new.

Display Name:
Allyson Hester

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6596835.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!! This recipe is delicious! I followed a few other reviewers' suggestions, and here are the changes I made. The recipe tasted just fine using low fat butter/margarine and low fat cream cheese.  I baked the rolls in a 13x9 glass dish with 6 in each dish at 350 for 23 minutes.  I also set the dishes on the lower rack of my oven.  I used my bread machine, measured and greased the wax paper, and rolled the dough out as close as I could get to 16x21.  Roll the dough as tight as possible and they will hold together just fine.  I placed the shaped rolls in the fridge and covered overnight. This morning I let them sit out for half an hour and then baked them uncovered. When they were lightly browned, I loosened them with a spatula and turned the dish over, letting the rolls fall out upside down. This kept the gooey stuff on top of the rolls. I also doubled the frosting. MMM!  Absolutely heavenly!  I can't wait until next time my work has a breakfast! Ally

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It tasted pretty good, but the bun is not as soft and chewy like the Cinnabon I've tasted (perhaps I over cooked the bun).  You can make ahead with this recipe and store in freezer: after cutting the roll into 12 pieces, individually wrap them in plastic and place in zip lock storage bag and leave in freezer.  To serve:  about 10 hours before serving (or the night before) take them out and unwrap from plastic and leave in cold oven to thraw.  Be sure to put them in an non stick container (silicone bakeware the best) and give enough room for them to rise the second time before cooking at 350 degree oven.

text:
These take a long time to make, but they taste exactly like Cinnabon cinnamon rolls.  I split the dough into two equal pieces, rolled out each and made 2 dozen "Mini bons" that I included in treat baskets that I gave out for Christmas presents.  People have been begging me to make more ever since!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe!  It's easy and fairly fast, though not as fast as stated here when using the dough cycle on my bread machine.

I increased the filling ingredients to 1-1/2 cups of brown sugar, 5 tbsp of cinnamon, and 1 stick of butter.  Additionally I added 3/4 cup of chopped walnuts.  I hate those cinnamon rolls that have skimpy fillings!  

When slicing the rolls, I sliced them thinner so that I ended up with 18 rolls instead of the 12 listed here.   They still rose very high, almost to the level of the pan!  Also, even though I did grease my pans as directed, they were a mess cleaning up because of the melted brown sugar.  Next time I will use parchment paper or silpat to line my pans.

With the increased amount of filling and the nuts added, these rolls came out perfect for our family!   They were filled with a decadent sticky, nutty, brown sugary goodness and sweet enough they were wonderful even without the  icing on them.

I will definitely use this recipe again, but will experiment using different fillings for some fun variations.

THE BEST BY FAR!  THIS IS A STANDARD RECIPIE FOR OUR HOUSE.  I USE IT FOR CINNAMON AND DINNER ROLLS.  WHEN I MAKE A BATCH OF THE DOUGH, I MEASURE OUT ADDITIONAL DRY INGREDIENTS TO PUT INTO ZIP BAGS.  THAT WAY WHEN I WANT TO MAKE MORE, I JUST PUT IT IN MY MIXER AND ADD THE LIQUIDS AND YEAST.  WORKS GREAT.

text:
Fabulous recipe! A new favorite for our family! For those who have a pasta machine, we placed sections of the dough on the #3 setting and ran it through for a more even consistency than a rolling pin.  We also used a pizza cutter to make nice uniform edges and made slicing dough easier.  We made miniature cinnamon rolls which was a hit for the kids!  Reminded them of a certain drive-thru restaurants version...however much more delicious! Yielded about 20 mini cinni rolls.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are so good I've already made them twice. They're 98% the same as Cinnabon and the difference is is that these are better. Much better in fact. They don't have the nasty trans/cheap fat aftertaste the others have and they reheat much nicer than the originals without leaving grease on your plate or having the icing seperate. These are SO much better! I made two changes. The recipe calls for margarine in the dough and I used butter instead and I changed the cooking time to 20 minutes at 350 degrees. Also, they're even better with rasins. Soak the rasins in really hot water for about half an hour, drain and then sprinkle over the cinnamon mixture before rolling up.

text:
These cinnamon rolls are incredible!  They are so close the real thing at $4 a piece, it's worth the time and effort to make them.  The first time I made them, I had used old yeast and all purpose flour, and they didn't rise and the filling fell out, but they were still really good.  The second time I made them, I used bread flour and just bought yeast, and they got huge, and the filling stayed inside the rolls, yummmm!  Thanks for the recipe Marsha!

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  By far the best cinnamon rolls I have made.  I did not have a bread machine, but followed the advice of other reviews and let the dough rise in the oven.  It works perfectly.  The only change I would suggest is to cut back a little on the amount of butter for the filling. Thanks for sharing.

text:
WoW!  I am the world's biggest cinnamon roll fan and ALWAYS got just Cinnabons (no other cinnamon roll compared!)  Not any more!!!  These are out of this world.  I baked half of them today and are saving the rest for tomorrow, for fresh cinnamon rolls in the morning.  Thank you so much for sharing such a terrific recipe!
P.S. What a great gift idea ... make the rolls up until the baking point and refrigerate (or freeze, depending on how long until gift-giving), and make the frosting.  Then put 6 or so unbaked rolls in a box, put the frosting in a little jar inside of the box, and write out baking instructions on a card and put on top of the box.  I used a small department store box and lined the inside with wax paper.  It looks adorable and what a great gift!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to become a member so I could comment on this great recipe.  I'm new to making breads and the Amish White Bread from this site was all I had done up to this point.  I followed this recipe precisely and it came out perfectly.  I was very impressed and so were those who ate it.  I've made it three times now all by hand -- no machine whatsoever.  A few hints for those, like me, who are new to working with dough:
Use wax paper between the rolling pin and dough to roll quickly.
If kneading by hand, highly active yeast and regular yeast both worked for me.
Line pan with wax paper for easy cleaning.
Drizzle icing carefully over evenly spaced rolls  (and not on the pan) or else make a bit more icing.
Thanks Marsha for a great recipe!

text:
Just like the Cinnabon rolls at the mall! My family loves these rolls and I'll definitely make them again. Only caveat: for the icing, don't beat until fluffy, but simply stir, the ingredients together, making sure cream cheese and butter are softened to room temperature. Stirring makes it more like icing than frosting and, therefore, more like the icing on Cinnabons.

text:
Very good! I did the cinnamon sugar part different mixing melted butter, light brown sugar, and cinnamon together and spread that on the dough. I then sprinkled some regular cinnamon sugar mix on tip of the rolls before placing in the oven (I luuuuuuv cinnamon!). Since I had no cream cheese I made a simple icing of butter, powdered sugar, and vanilla. So good!
**Added Note** I use the dough part of this recipe for dinner rolls all the time now. They are fantastic!

text:
I've altered this recipe to make it VEGAN and it's amazing! Use water instead of milk or your favorite milk replacer like soy milk. Also, Earth Balance instead of traditional butter, 1/2 cup of applesauce instead of eggs and Tofutti cream cheese instead of regular cream cheese. Best vegan cinnamon rolls I've ever had!

None
text:
This recipe is awesome! I will definitely make it again. There were some helpful reviews that I used. 1) I combined the brown sugar, cinnamon, and butter to make the spread. 2) I made the cinnamon rolls the night before and stored them in the glass baking pan (covered with plastic wrap). Then I put them in the oven the next morning. They turned out great, just needed a couple extra minutes of baking time. 
It was a tad on the sweet side so it went really well with tea and coffee. The next time I make them I think I will reduce the sugar a little for the cinnamon spread and icing and see how that turns out.
Thanks for the recipe, its awesome!

text:
I absolutely loooooveeee this recipe! Every time I've made them everyone was really impressed.
I didn't add the icing cause I feel like it's a little over-the-top sweet, but that just comes down to personal preference. :)
The only negative point is that it takes a while to make but it's totally worth it. (Plus most of the time you're waiting for the dough, so you can do other things meanwhile.)
Also, they dry up quite quickly, so keep them inside a plastic bag or something, either way it isn't much of a problem anyways since everyone eats them so fast ^_^
Definite, no doubt, 5 stars, I'd give it 6 if I could.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly as written, and it was wonderful. Light and fluffy, sweet and flavorful. When I pulled the dough out of the bread machine, I wanted to lay on it like a pillow; it was so smooth and airy. I made it a second time the next day and made some changes to suit our family's taste. We don't like our rolls quite so sweet, although my friends who ate it as written raved about it! This time, I used only 1/4 cup sugar in the dough, and I used half the frosting. I also prepared in the night before and cooked it the next morning. For our family, this slightly less sweet variation was perfection, although it was awesome to begin with. I highly recommend this recipe.

First, I am only giving it 3 stars because they did not cook all the way through at 400 for 15 minutes. The middle roll was still very very doughy. Not sure if I need to increase the time and reduce the temp next time - but I will make these again.
Otherwise, the end rolls and tops were beautiful, and very tasty!!! The dough rose beautifully and the (cooked) pastry was not hard or brick like (as stated by other reviewers. I did use a bread machine, and did let them rise again in the pan.

text:
I have made this recipe several times and everyone loves it. My husband, friends, coworkers all rave about these. I used butter instead of margarine. I usually make these the night before and put them in the fridge. I do this right after putting them in the 9x11 pan (no need to let it sit 30 more min). Then I put the pan in a cold oven and heat the oven to 350 degrees. Let it cook for 25-30 min.

I'm rating the recipe based on the dough and frosting. I used a different filling. I did what one of the other posters said for making it without a bread machine. I have a kitchen aid stand mixer! I used all purpose flour instead of bread flour. I accidentally put the melted butter in my dough... Oops!!! It still came out delicious, chewy, doughy, goodness! I could have gotten about 20 rolls but the dough started to dry too much and was difficult to roll out. The frosting!!!!! OMG! I will use that one all the time! I doubled it so I have a bunch left over in my fridge! Yum

text:
The women in my family have tried a LOT of cinnamon roll recipes over the years. I first tried this recipe for Easter about 4 years ago, and I'm happy to report we haven't tried any other recipes since. This is THE one. I use butter instead of margarine, and regular white flour instead of bread flour. If you don't have a bread machine (I don't), be sure to read the "Most Helpful Positive Review" from 2004, which explains how to make it without a bread machine!

text:
Holy cow are these good! I don't have a bread machine so I followed the following advice from ANDYTAMI..."Dissolve the yeast in the warm milk in a large bowl. Mix in the sugar, margarine, salt, and eggs. Add flour and mix well. Knead the dough into a large ball, using your hands dusted lightly with flour. Put in a bowl, cover and let rise in a warm place about 1 hour, or until doubled in size. Then pick up with rolling out the dough." This was very helpful and the rolls turned out delicious! I used butter instead of margarine because I always buy butter. Very very good!! Thanks for this keeper recipe!

text:
Great recipe! Very little hands-on time. I put the ingredients in my bread machine, turned it on the dough setting and left for about 1 1/2 hrs. When I came home, the dough was ready to roll out. Following a review, I refrigerated the buns overnight. This morning I put them in a cold oven, then turned it on 400. They were done in approx. 25 mins. I immediately turned them out onto a cookie sheet so the filling could run down over them. They turned out perfect! These are scrumptious with or without icing! My family loved them. Great for busy moms. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Incredible.  That awesome middle bite is exactly as delicious as a Cinnabon.  I messed up and added the cinnamon and butter that was supposed to go in the middle in to the dough (which I made in my Kitchenaid mixer).  To compensate I used less sugar, butter and cinnamon in the middle.  They still came out amazing.  The icing is delectable too.  This is one of those things that I can't believe came out of my kitchen.  Will definitely be making it on holidays and special occasions in the future.  Thanks for sharing!!!
Update:
Made these with 2 1/2 cups oat flour and 2 white, 1/2 cup ground flax seed, and subbed nonfat Greek yogurt for half of the butter to try to make them a little more nutritious, and they were just as good.

text:
Living in Italy, I really can't complain about the food. But.. there are those days when I REALLY miss a good cinnamon roll or a Real freshly made doughnut and there are no chance to have them here. For this reason I kept on trying cinnamon rolls recipes ( doughnuts are more difficult because of the frying). Until now. Ok, This is the one. I read the recipe and many reviews, then I decide to make it just as stated originally. Those were just PERFECT! We were having a little BD party for my youngest just turned 2, and these rolls were gone in 5 minutes. I cut them using a piece of kitchen cord, like somebody told me to do, and made them big, then I let them rest in the baking sheet - on a silpat- ( too many-too big for the pan stated) for a couple of hours because I had other cakes in the oven. They grew.. perfectly. didn't fall apart. they were PERFECT! 15 minutes and were golden, fully cooked but still SOFT just like a cinnabon... for truly perfect cloning I have to work on the glaze, but even if I felt them little differing from the cinnabon, I can't understand the difference because these ARE SO GOOD!!!!!

text:
This makes great cinnamon rolls, but make sure the bottoms are done.  I cooked at 400 degrees for 15 min, and the tops were brown, but the bottoms weren't done.  (It might be because I used a glass pan.)  They were still stretchy dough on the bottom halves.  I will cook them at 350 degrees for 20-30 min next time.  It's strange, but even though they were doughy, they disappeared within minutes.  I didn't even get one at the party I took them to.~  Thanks, Marsha!

Fan-Freaking-Tastic!

A-Ma-Zing!!!!

None
text:
This is such an easy recipe and so delicious.  I make my dough in my kitchen aid mixer and then let it rise for 45 minutes.  Then, I follow the recipe starting with #2.  I made it the first time with the cream cheese icing which was delicious but way too sweet for us.  So, now I make a glaze and drizzle it over the top.  The glaze consists of 1 c powdered sugar, 3 tbsp heavy cream, 1 tsp vanilla or almond extract.  With the glaze, they are even better!!!!

Yummy :) The cinnamon-sugar mixture did end up running a little, I tried the whole turning over thing and that did help a tiny bit, but then all of the brown sugar glazed over the top of the buns and kind of made them look messy. I easily scooped up the excess mixture with a spoons and placed it on top of the rolls making sure to get most of it on the inside. Everybody loved these and said they were better than the ones at Cinnabon. Makes plenty of frosting, so don't be greedy ;) Thank you, Marsha for this recipe. These are awesome.

text:
Very disappointed. It may not be the recipes fault however. There are 4,652 reviews as I write this. I was trying to avoid the 3+ hours wait time for what I have been dreaming of for some time. I either do not comfortably know how to make basic bread dough or realize now that the use of the bread machine would have perhaps made this oops proof. I tried following the top rated reviews on not using the machine. The dough came out dry and never fully rose. I combined the cinn, sugar and butter and spread the now paste onto the dough. Rolled, cut and baked for 20 mins. Though they smell yummy and are gooey, they never got much bigger than they started. I've extended the cook time 4 more mins, then 3 more mins...they have gotten a little bigger but I am worried about a bitter or burnt taste from the filling being over cooked. I may try to remake these with the machine, but for now, extremely disappointed. ALSO, no one mentioned successfully cutting the recipe in half due to a possible size issue in the bread machine from 4+C up flour. All my basic dough recipes in the machine book state 2ish cups... concern?
