text:
tastes awesome! .. to start with the dough, mixed and kneaded it with my own hands, took 2 hrs to raise, didn't double, however that didnt really matter as the Cinnabons turned out PERFECT! as other reviewers suggested, i did cook it at a lower temperature than suggested and for a longer time. Used sour cream for the frosting (very nice, creamy, and thin, unlike cream cheese would be!) but its the matter of preference. I would suggest cutting the dough spread and roll each bun separately, what's the trick? cutting the dough into triangles, it would prevent the center from popping out :) just an option!
ohh, i ve made 24 smaller buns rather than 12 large.. in any case, wonderful recipe! thank you! its a gold mine for the Cinnabon addict who lives in a place where there's no Cinnabon branch :)))

Flavor of the inside was perfect and this recipe is so easy.  I had wanted to make cinnamon rolls for awhile, but was concerned about how difficult they were, with this recipe, it was simple!

text:
Currently my favorite cinnamon bun recipe. It's easy to make. (I don't use the breadmachine version, but make my own dough.) I love the filling. With this amount of brown sugar, it's a mix of crunchy and "juicy" when you bite into the bun. The icing is very good and easy to make. I just love it. Family and friends love it. A couple of things: 1. I have to bake for just about 38 minutes at 350 degrees. I have to continue to adjust temp. I also weigh my flour for consistency of outcome. 3 cups equals about 1 lbs.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous... once I made it a couple of times and changed a few things! I use my bosch (don't have a bread machine) to mix the dough in, and found myself with only active dry yeast, so I added just a pinch more yeast, and about 1/8 tsp cinnamon to the actual dough, with closer to 4 cups of flour (I add it a little at a time and stop when the dough starts pulling away from the sides of the mixing bowl) and had to let it raise longer. I also found the cinnamon for the filling was way too much. I cut it down to just under 2 tablespoons, as well as used a whole stick of butter to spread on the rolled out dough. I also pulled them out once they just start to turn golden rather than golden brown, otherwise they seemed overdone.

text:
Easy recipe ingredient wise. Not very good though. I'm not sure if I did something wrong, but I followed the directions exactly and the rolls came out to yeasty flavor wise. Also, the rolling directions weren't very clear. I had to look up elsewhere which direction I had to roll them. The filling didn't stay in the rolls (maybe I didn't roll tight enough??) and there wasn't very much flavor. There's also no way all those rolls would fit into a 9x13 casserole..... All this being said, I have never made cinnamon rolls before or used a bread machine, so it's quite possibly operator error! I will be trying this again. *I did find the frosting quite tasty, but it's kinda hard to screw that up! Hahaha*

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't say I have ever had a Cinnabon cinnamon roll, but why bother when you can make these? These are my new go-to overnight cinnamon roll. I did not use a bread machine, and froze them for a weekend in wine country with the girls.  I thawed them in a cooler on the way, then overnight in the fridge.  Put them in a cold oven set to 400 and baked for 15 mins.  They could have used a touch more baking time although the tops were brown enough.  The bottoms were a bit doughy (oh yum, I say, but some people might not like that). I also didn't frost them. Fresh cinnamon rolls and no need to get up early.  It's a win win!!

I made these again today for Easter morning tomorrow. They are very easy to make and simply delicious.  My oven runs hot so I used a lower temp and shorter cooking time.  I used the recipe for the frosting again as well.  I do wonder how they'd be with a simple frosting and not cream cheese.  Whatever frosting you choose the rolls are delicious, soft and pillowy. 


Original review. The buns are in the oven and it smells so great in my house. This was very simple, I followed directions to a T, and they look fabulous. I'll add when I taste, but I think these are going to be a hit!
Made these a 2nd time and I dropped the cinnamon down to 2 Tablespoons and added a sprinkle of cardamom to the brown sugar mixture. The first time I made as written and it was just a tad too much cinnamon flavor for us. But this is a wonderful recipe.

text:
Yum yum yum! I made a double batch and we have had them everyday this week. The cooking time needs a little tweaking, i prefer my cinnamon bun to be a little gooey in the center. I read the reviews and someone suggested mixing the cinnamon and brown sugar and butter together instead of sprinkling the cinnamon on the sugar butter mix. I had no problems with the filling draining out. I also made a double batch of frosting. I found that anymore than the regular portion was too much, and i have a serious sweet tooth.

text:
A smashing hit - everyone loved them, best cinnamon roll recipe I've made. They turned out tender but not doughy.

Changes: I lined the pan with parchment paper when I baked the rolls to keep the filling from baking onto the pan. That worked well.

Also, I changed the frosting recipe slightly - I used an entire 8 oz pkg of cream cheese and doubled the rest of the ingredients. The frosting was sweet but not overly so, with a nice hint of cream cheese.

text:
This is an excellent cinnamon roll recipe! I took some to work and was complimented on them the whole day. I did follow the recipe quite closely, though didn't wait until the oven was preheated and my bake time turned into 25-30 minutes, as the dough was still too raw when i tried them at 15 and 20 min. Also, the rolls in the glass dish cooked faster than the silicone dish. 
Don't skimp on the butter for the filling and make the amount of icing listed. That seemed to be about right (unless you like to drown your cinnamon roll in sugar glaze).

Display Name:
Kelly's Kitchen Creation
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/597455.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Incredible flavor and they really do taste and look like Cinnabon!  This is the third cinnamon roll recipe I've cooked in the past couple of months and this is my favorite.  I do have a warning though.  I am using a temporary oven (portable convection oven from Costco in Taiwan) and baked them in a glass 9x13 pan and they were doughy and raw on the bottoms (sadly) and a little brown on top.  I much prefer baking cinnamon rolls on a silicon pan and thought I'd try a new way.  Big mistake! Now I need to throw them away or just eat the top halves, which we probably will since the "done parts" are so good.  I cannot wait to get back to my own ovens.  I baked them at 204 C and not on convection.  Next time, I'll avoid using a glass pan and put them on the lowest rack in the oven.  Great recipe--just a user error made them less than perfect.

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  I've never made these before and they are divine.  The buns didn't rise after they were cut.  The recipe states they should in 30 minutes and mine didn't at all.  I put them in the oven and they then were about 1.5 times their original size.  Awesome recipe.  I couldn't even wait for them to cool before the whole family dug in.  I was lucky to pull my hands away before there were pulling them apart.  The icing is exactly like the stores in the mall.  Now a favourite of mine!!

I tried again with flour bread, bread machine yeast and what a difference!  double the size compared to my first 2 batches with all purpose flour and quick rise yeast!

AMAZING! I couldn't believe it.. they really did taste like Cinnabon's but even better. I made the recipe with my Kitchenaid Mixer, adding the rapid rise yeast in with 3 cups flour and then poured in the milk and eggs. text:
I've made this many times and it's always a hit.  Very easy to make the night before and bake in the morning so they're fresh from the oven for breakfast.  I've had to limit them to very special occasions only or I's be making them once a week I'm sure!  One tip, I melt the butter and spread it on with a pastry brush then sprinkle cinnamon and brown sugar on and press it down with the back of a tablespoon.  Seems to help keep the filling inside when baking.

userID:
662202
Display Name:
JENNELLEN

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, these are deadly!  In a good way :)  I followed the recipe exactly, just adjusted the baking time/temp slightly (375 for 20 min. and they were just right; also immediately turned out onto some wax paper and let all the goo run out of the pan on top of the buns.) I did have some trouble getting my buns to rise in the pan pre-baking.  Ended up sitting them on top of my preheated oven, where it was nice and warm, for just over an hour.  They did rise a wee bit, but not nearly double.  Pretty sure this was due to my mistake of having the milk too hot and killing my yeast.  I was worried they would end up hard due to this problem, but they actually turned out fairly soft, and not dry at all.  Lots of yummy cinnamon sugar oozing out.  The icing tastes delish; love the cream cheese.  I did find it was not necessary to use quite so much icing as the recipe calls for though.  So all in all, even with my little problem with lack of rising, they were still super yum.  I will give these another go for sure.

Made these Christmas Eve for Christmas morning. I used my Kitchenaid and followed the recipe almost exactly using all purpose flour and butter. These were delicious. text:
Very sweet roll, I've never had a Cinnabon, but these were really good!   I made the rolls and put them in round baking pans(found at dollar store.)   Each pan held 6 rolls. I then froze the rolls and made up the frosting and froze that as well.  When I want to eat them, I thaw rolls on countertop for 7 to 8 hours, until doubled then bake for 20-25 minutes at 350 degrees.  I also have made a whole pan and put in the frig overnight to raise, then baked at 350 for 20 -25 minutes.

Here are the 2 things I've discovered after making these a few times:  1) You can use warm water instead of milk 2) You can mix up all the ingredients and put rolls in pan at night in fridge and wake up and bake!  It's best to bring the rolls to room temp again and then pop in the oven.  This saves time in the morning!

text:
This recipe was fantastic! The best homemade cinnamon bun recipe I have tried yet! For me though, the dough was VERY dry, I had to add more moisture to it..I'm not sure if I added too much flour (my 4 year old daughter was helping me) or maybe my milk wasnt warm enough? or maybe it was because my eggs were straight out of the fridge? not sure..but..I added 1/4c milk to the dough after it was mixed, and another 1/3c margarine. I think next time I will use regular salted butter. It rose great, and tastes FANTASTIC!! I only made half the recipe (the rest of the dough is in the fridge for tomorrow) and used the icing as is except for only 3/4c conf sugar. sooooo yummy!!! Thank y'all for this recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
excellent recipe, just takes a while to make.  I did not make this in the bread machine, I just proofed the yeast in warm milk and then added all the ingredients into the kitchen aid mixer with the dough hook and kneaded for 6 minutes.  I let it rise until double and followed the rest of the recipe.  I will make this again but will try other suggestions about making this the night before and then bake in the morning.
Update: I made the dough and put it in the freezer, the day before I wanted to bake them, I pulled them out of the freezer and left them in the fridge overnight.  The next morning, I let them sit for about 1 1/2 hours and then baked normally and they came out great.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very easy to make. I put the dough ingredients in my bread machine and let it knead the dough. Then I rolled it out on my cutting board (the dough was pretty sticky) and spread on the butter and then sprinkled the brown sugar/cinnamon. I would use a little less brown sugar mixture because these was a lot of it! Then I rolled it up and cut it and placed the slices in a 9 by 13 inch pan. I had a few extra slices so I put those in a smaller dish. I refrigerated overnight and baked them in the morning. The inside of the roll was gooey and they were delicious! Will definatly make these again. Thanks!

text:
This is the BEST cinnamon roll recipe!! I've made them many times and I have a nagging feeling that it's not good for my health- or weight! I usually use less oil and half milk, half HOT water. (then you don't have to heat the milk) I also add vanilla to the dough, it adds a nice flavor. For the frosting I use more cream cheese and less butter as well as adding milk to make it more glaze-like. All in all, a GREAT recipe!

text:
I just finished making these.  I am only giving them a four star, because they weren't completely done at 15 minutes, as posted.  The inside rolls are completely doughy, which is disappointing.  The taste if FANTASTIC, but the recipe needs to be modified to bake for 20 minutes.  The tops were nice and brown, but the insides were really doughy.  We are going to try to freeze the inside ones and then bake them in the microwave to finish dough.  Also, I used all butter and no margarine, and I would also recommend this.  Margarine has a very high water content, which isn't conducive to most recipes.

delicious. time consuming (even with my trusty kitchen-aid!), but worth it. tasted almost like a cinnabon, i think with a little more tweaking it would be exact! the center of the cinnabon is my favorite, where its really soft and gooey. i think ill bake these just a couple of minutes less so the outer portion of the roll isnt hard. i melted the butter and spread that over the dough, then sprinkled the cinnamon sugar mixture over that and had no problems with it running out during baking. i might even double the cinnamon sugar mixture next time! for a rare treat, im going all the way! :)

text:
I'm rating this recipe for what it would have been, had I actually followed it. Not to say that mine weren't good, but i'm surprised they even worked at all. I decided to make these on a whim for mothers day, because my mom was out of town and it would surprise her when she got back. I started making it, only to realize that there was no way I was going to have time, since I had to work at 4 and didn't start making these until 1:30. So, I took the dough out of the bread machine before it was done rising, didn't wait the 10 minutes to let it rise after taking it out, didn't wait 30 minutes after rolling them to let them rise, and just popped them in the oven. Needless to say, they were nowhere near done after 15 minutes. So I put them in for another 15 and still, not done. By that time I had to leave and I left a note for my mom saying to put them in for 10 minutes when she got home to let them finish baking. She did this, and somehow, they were STILL good. I also used all purpose flour and regular quick rise yeast. I'm baffled at how well these worked. I thought I would definitely have to throw the whole batch out. Next time though, I will definitely stick to the recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
cmac

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Took a total of almost 4 hours doing it without a bread machine. Here were my results: The way I managed the dough- Used dough hook on my stand mixer. Mixed fine, didn't know it'd be so elastic, very different than most doughs i've worked with. To allow the bread to rise I set my oven to 170 and put the dough in there. It made it rise very quickly. Took roughly half an hour.  Icing: I didn't use the recipe for the icing from here. I found another recipe which sounded more like the original. I was correct. It tasted very similar, though still not the right texture, someone said it could be thicker if you used fondant sugar. The other recipe used margarine and also included lemon juice. Makes sense considering the the frosting of the real cinnabon has that flavoring.   Overall the cinnamon roll tasted okay, but it wasn't a cinnabon by any stretch of the imagination. The breading was almost gross. Not the right texture at all. These were slightly airy, and not very strong, where as the cinnabon brand is very strong and dense. So I don't know what to say, I spent so long working on these, sure it was a bit of fun but it was overall very disappointing and became a waist of money. If i do this again I will certainly edit the recipe to include more cream cheese and less butter on the frosting, also figure some way out to make the dough more dense.

text:
I've made these quite a few times now and have been asked several times over to keep making them.  They are SO delicious!  I like to bring these to work and have always followed the recipe up until the rising part.  I would cut them up, line them in the dish and refrigerate them.  Then, get up in the morning, microwave some water to boiling while I preheated the oven, pour the boiling water into a pan and place that in the oven, turn the oven off and stick the rolls in to proof while I get ready for work.  Works every time!

text:
Well lets just say the tons of 5 star ratings don't lie! One thing I must warn you about is: make sure you use the right kind of yeast!  I didn't know bread machine yeast existed so I used active dry the first time I made these, and they tasted great but had more of the texture of dinner rolls.  Bread machine yeast made all the difference.  I too do not have a bread machine so I followed the basic steps for the good old fashioned way that many have already given the tips for here, so ty.  Turning the oven on and then off was a brilliant idea, especially in the middle of winter when there is not a single spot in this house that is warm.  The last thing is, I forgot to get cream cheese this time so I opted to use Special Buttercream Frosting for this, just added less sugar and it was actually pretty tasty!  My husband, 11 month old and neighbors just loved these.  Fantastic recipe, thank you so much!

text:
I didn't have a bread machine, so I used other reviewers suggestions and put the yeast into some warm milk and mixed all the stuff in. I also turned the oven to 200F and then turned it off before letting the dough rise. My dough got HUGE. More than doubled in size. Then when I rolled it out I ended up getting, like, 20 rolls. I, like others, mixed the butter with the cinnamon and brown sugar, and since my oven gets hot, I baked at 350 for 10 minutes and they -still- came out hard and crusty on the outside (it's my oven -- it's done this before) so with the rest of the batch I'll be sure to make sure they come out of the oven sooner.  However, even with that self-inflicted issue, these were still DELICIOUS, particularly in the center. I'm not sure what people mean by too much cinnamon -- there didn't seem to be enough for me and my roommate! And my roommate--she normally hates EVERYTHING, but she went back for seconds.

text:
I've made these as written a couple of times now.  Today I tried a new variation:  Orange Cranberry.  Omit the cinnamon and brown sugar.  Cream softened butter with  1/2 cup white sugar and 2-3 tbsp orange zest.  Sprinkle with 1/3 cup finely chopped walnuts and 1/2 cup dried cranberries.  Roll up and bake as usual.  For the frosting I used Orange Cream Cheese Frosting from this site.

text:
A SUPER recipe!  I followed another reviewers instructions for making them without a bread machine, and they came out beautifully.  My one suggestion: Instead of spreading the butter on the dough and then sprinkling on the cinnamon sugar, cream the butter, sugar, and cinnamon together, and then spread the mixture over the dough.  I find that it makes rolling and cutting the rolls much easier.

text:
WOW!!!  I don't have a bread machine and wish I had read more of the tips in the reviews but once these came out of the oven I wasn't sorry for the time involved in making them!  They taste delicious and almost identical to Cinnabon.  Next time I'll refrigerate them overnight and bake in the morning so that we can have this for Christmas breakfast.  For those without a bread machine, be sure to preheat your oven to 200 degrees, turn it off and then put the covered bowl in for an hour to let it rise.  This will save a lot of headache on babysitting the dough.  Also, don't use too much flour when rolling so that you don't get that taste when they're done.

Delish!  With over 3,000 reviews, what more can I add?  Well, this space cadet accidentally added the cinnamon to the dough mix! Five stars even with my goof!  I think I'll make it the same way next time.

userID:
2662511
Display Name:
ChrisAnna
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cannot rave enough about these awesome cinnamon rolls!  They are a little time-consuming to make but WELL worth the effort.  Easy to make, hard to hide :)  I've been making these almost as long as the recipe has been on allrecipies!  Even when I forgot to let them rise before I baked them, they were great.  Be prepared to make a double batch if you take these rolls to work- they go fast.  I've only changed a few things.  I've always used butter instead of margarine.  If I'm making them for work or a bake sale- I roll them a little thinner, and nearly double the cinnamon filling.  (This will make enough to fill a disposable roasting pan.)  For the last few batches, I covered the rolls with foil when they were done, layered towels to fill up the extra space, and then flipped them while they were cooling.  Flip them back before completely cool- the extra filling seeps into all the little nooks and crannies- yum!  I haven't tried freezing them.  I have made them the day before and then put them in the fridge overnight.  Be sure to let them warm and rise a bit if you do this.   If you don't have a bread machine the recipe still works.  Mix and knead well but gently.  Be sure to let the dough rise in a warm spot- such as on top of a warm oven.  The magic of a bread machine is that it warms a little during the cycle so the dough rises well.  If your dough isn't rising, it needs to be warmer.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.  It's the ultimate cinnamon roll!

text:
Cinnamon rolls are our xmas breakfast tradition, thought I would try a homemade version for the first time.  First of all, I haven't actually eaten these yet.  I was experimenting with making the day before and going to make the icing in the morning then eat (just too much work for xmas morning).  Well, wish I had read the reviews.  I actually baked mine and wish I had put them in the frig as others have successfully done.  I think mine will be fine though.  Wanted to give my input also:  Do lower the temp some and/or cook for less time.. mine got a little too brown on top.  Also, took much longer to get the rise both times.  First one in the machine took an extra hour I would say......to double in size and fill my pan.  Second rise took at least an hour also (after cut and in pan) But, as I am now reading, I would have just put them in the frig for morning at this point.  One really good tip I just learned from  my MIL:  using thread to cut them.  Just place thread under the roll and cross the thread on the top and pull (like the first step to tying your shoe) until it totally cuts off the roll.  Worked amazing!!!! Enjoy!  I know we will and now I have a good plan for xmas morning!

text:
UPDATE: MADE MY FROZEN ROLLS THIS PAST WKEND . TOOK OUT OF THE FREEZER & INTO  THE FRIDGE LAST NITE & ALLOWED TO REST WHILE OVEN WAS PREHEATING. BAKED AS I DID LAST TIME. EXCELLENT!!! OK, here's the deal. I've been eyeing this recipe for a while, but was too timid to try it! If u use a bread machine or KitchenAid & follow other's sugg. for rising (in fridge) overnite, these are EASY to assemble!!! I pretty much followed Marsha's direct. w/ just a few ch. 1) subbed (unsalted) butter for marg. & used fast rise yeast (intended for BM use - needed an entire 1/4 oz. pkg. + a tad of another). 2) warmed my milk in the micro. (used an infared therm. from Sears Auto to test temp. - works like a charm!). 3) allowed butter & eggs to come to rm. temp. (VERY impt.!); for the eggs, soak in warm H2O for a few min. 4) used the dough cycle on my BM (1.5 hr. + 10 min. to rest). I placed a (cut) roll in ea. of 6 greased jumbo muffin cups, covered w/ plastic wrap & let rise overnite. I placed the remaining rolls in a greased, disposable pie pan, covered w/ foil & froze. This AM, I took my rolls out of the fridge, placed them on my stove for a 1/2 hr. (while preheating) & then baked at 350 for 25 min. Although I like the muffin tin idea, I don't think I will try it again. My rolls were hard around the edges (and VERY dk.!). Oh well! Other than not liking the frosting (I'll keep searching...) & the muffin idea, these were EXCELLENT! I can't WAIT to thaw the ones in the freezer! Tx. for sharing. :)

country:
None
text:
These turned out gorgeous.  I changed it to 9 instead of 12 but still got 11 buns.  They raised enormously, so I think a bigger pan is warranted.  I cut each bun to 1 1/4 inches and when cooked they were a good 3 inches high or more.  The only things I would change, now that I've made them, is to increase the brown sugar in the filling & decrease the cinnamon, then start watching after 12 minutes as mine were fully cooked by then.  They would have been overdone by 15 minutes.  Mind you, all oven are different.  I don't care for cream cheese icing, so I just did a glace of icing sugar, butter, vanilla & milk.  I liked the suggestion to turn them out of pan immediately when they come out of the oven to keep the filling in.  I highly recommend this recipe if you want the greatest cinnamon buns in the world.

I love cinnamon rolls. These are very good. Love the frosting. I lowered the fat and calories by subbing smart balance for the margarine (margarine has a TON of trans fats) I used egg beaters instead of egg and neufchatel cheese instead of cream cheese for the frosting. I also left out all the salt. I never understood why people put salt in sweet treats. I've heard it is supposed to enhance the sweet flavor, but I can't tell the difference and I try to watch the sodium intake.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6823763.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making these for years! I do not find that having some of the gooey cinnamon filling leak out of the bottom a problem. It is very easy to scoop or spoon up and put on top of the roll. It does NOT stick to the pan. In fact it is one of the wonderful pluses to making your own cinnamon rolls, to be able to easily scrap the hardened pieces of cinnamon goodness from the bottom of the pan once cooled! It's an extra treat to pick at! If you flip the rolls over so the bottom is now the top it does not make for a very pretty cinnamon roll. I have never used bread flour and they have come out perfect using all-purpose. (I am very interested in trying the bread flour as a comparison.) I have never let them rise before baking and they have always risen just perfectly in the oven. However, the recipe I have calls for 10 minutes vs 15 in the oven. I sometimes need to leave them in an extra minute. If most of you recall the actual Cinnabons do have a somewhat gooey center. The dough is just barely cooked in the center. I remember buying one at the mall and bringing it home to do a side-by-side comparison and the center was somewhat gooey, cooked but just barely, very soft. Excellent recipe, a must try!

text:
Phenomenal.  I was worried about mixing raw eggs with warm milk (and making scrambled eggs in the bread machine) but I slowly mixed the eggs with the melted butter and then put it in the warm milk.  Also, I used others reviews and put the cinnamon rolls into the dish, covering & refridgerating overnight, then sticking into a cold oven & setting the oven at 350, and leaving them for 30 minutes.  I also flipped the cinnamon rolls upside down on a sheet to serve so all the delicious "goo" at the bottom of the rolls could fall down and evenly distribute.  They came out perfectly, everyone was so impressed.  The consistency of the dough is soft all the way through, with no hard edges or raw centers.  I love this recipe!

userID:

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Marsha, Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. I've made this many a times for my office and for my husband's office. I'd come home with an empty pan each time and so does my husband. Who resists cinnamon rolls, right? The original recipe yields 12 very huge rolls. The first time I made it, a couple of guys in my husband's office were such wusses of eating one cinnamon roll alone because it was too big so they split the roll. LOL! That's how big it was!!! I have been able to make 18 rolls out of the recipe to make it go further. I do not have a bread maker so I prepared the dough manually as suggested by another poster. The type of flour one should use is definitely bread flour because of the high gluten content. After having made the cinnamon rolls a few times, I started to add currants and chopped walnuts to the cinnamon sugar mixture. I also make half of my batch with the cream cheese glaze and half with just the regular glaze for those who do not like cream cheese.  The rolls keeps in the freezer quite nicely as well. I just carefully wrap each roll in Glad Press and Seal then put the wrapped rolls in freezer bags. When I want one, I'd put in on the counter to thaw for 15 minutes or so. Then pop it in the microwave on medium for 30-45 seconds and VOILA!! I save money making my own as well as having portion control. Next time when I make these, I shall use other types of fillings such as fruits. Again, thank you for sharing!

Well the old man was on a roll tonight and made my first batch of cinnamon rolls and only screwed up once! Mixed up the dough in the Kitchen aid and let it double in size and punched it down, rolled it out and then couldn't figure out why I had so much if the filling??!! I'll try the correct method once before doing the cream cheese in the filling trick again though!

text:
Yummy! The taste was really like a real Cinnabon! I loved it. I had a few problems with mine because I did not read the reviews from those who have made them before. I did not use bread flour, or a bread maker. Also I used heavy cream instead of warm milk. The yeast took a very long time to dissolve into the heavy cream (I'm thinking milk would have been better but we never drink milk so I opted for a small carton of heavy cream-really wished milk came in tiny cartons) I used my fingers to incorporate the yeast into the cream/ which was really helpful. My dough did not raise as much as I wanted it to-next time i will use the proper flour and try letting it raise in a warm oven-method.   I added tons of cinnamon to the brown sugar. It was really delicious! My only problem with the filling is that it was not gooey like I wanted. Next time I think I will mix the filling with a bit of cream cheese, oil, and butter.   I really loved this recipe, and my comments were only meant for those who are novice bakers like myself :)   Yummy 5stars!

These were delicious!  First time I've ever cooked anything with yeast.  I've always been nervous about baking with yeast.  I don't own a breadmaker but per several reviews I managed my way through it without one.  My dough didn't rise to double in size by any means, but I'm assuming it's my lack of experience working with yeast that caused this. Either way, it did rise somewhat and after rolling the dough with cinnimon mixture (i mixed all together before spreading on the dough) I let them sit awhile on top of the warm stove and they rose quite a bit more.  End result was great.  These did not last long at my house and I will most certainly make them again.  Hopefully I'll begin to get more acustomed to using yeast and can try more breads ect.  Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe

I tried to keep to the recipe as written, but used only butter, (I don't use margerine), made without a bread machine, and made 1 1/2 times the icing. Very Good Highly Recommended.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfectly delicious in every way!  I did make a couple of changes though. I DID NOT USE A BREAD MACHINE. I was having trouble getting my yeast to activate and so I took a tip from my dinner rolls recipe.  Instead of using 1 c. milk, I heated 1/2 c. milk and 1/2 c. water in the microwave for 45 seconds.  Then I dissolved the sugar and then added the yeast.  It activated just right.  Then I followed the directions. I did mix the butter, sugar and cinnamon together and spread it out over the dough.  I had no problem with the mixture dripping out.  In fact, when I tried to turn the pan upside down, my rolls almost fell out!  So, this recipe will be my #1 cinnamon roll recipe.  Can't wait to bake these for Christmas morning!

My daughter and I made these this weekend and they were sooo good!  I have a bread machine but have never used it, thought about getting it out for this recipe but at the last minute decided not to.  We doubled the recipe so my daughter could make hers and I could make mine.  We had to knead the dough about 10 minutes.   I drizzled my frosting on and she doubled the frosting and spread it on hers.  But, both ways were totally wonderful and everybody loved them.  The only way you could go wrong is not making enough, lol.

This makes having them ready in the morning a lot easier.  They are too good to pass up.  Not cinnabon...BETTER because I didn't have to take out a small loan to have a pan full!

text:
I made these for the office and they didn't last an hour!  The only thing I would alter is the amount of time the dough spent in the bread machine.  When the dough is completely mixed, I would take it out and put it in a covered bowl on top of a heating pad or a warm oven.  I just think the dough cycle on my machine was too long and made the dough a little tough.  Otherwise, a perfect recipe!!

We all agreed on this rating...five stars all around! I made this recipe one day in advance, covered in saran and refrigerated it. I also made the frosting the day before, covered in saran and refrigerated it. In the morning, I took both the rolls and the frosting out while I preheated the oven. I baked at 350 for 30 minutes. It was absolutely delicious. I'd never made my own cinnamon rolls before and this was surprisingly easy. And there's no comparison to the ones you buy in the tubes at the store. It will be hard to buy those again now that we've tried these. Will definitely make this again!

Display Name:
Jennifer Schisler Bess
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2397193.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Last time I made the recipe as written and it was good. However, after reading other members' reviews, I made a few alterations this time, with TERRIFIC results that I prefer to the original. I increased the filling by about 50% (used 1.5 cups brown sugar, 3.5T cinnamon, and 1/2 cup butter). I combined the melted butter, cinnamon, and sugar, and didn't have any trouble with filling falling out. I increased the filling, mostly so that I wouldn't have leftover cream cheese. I used 8oz cream cheese, 1/2 cup butter, 3 cups confectioners sugar, 1.5 teaspoons vanilla, 1/4 teaspoon salt, and about 5T milk. I divided it into 4...used 1/4 and froze 3/4 in 3 ziplocks. Lastly, I made 24 cinnamon rolls, which were plenty big. I baked them at 350 for about 20 minutes. At 400 degrees, I had trouble with the tops browning before the rolls were all the way cooked. YUM! By far, the best cinnamon rolls I have ever made.

text:
Ooey, gooey, cinnamon-y deliciousness! These turned out perfectly. They are a very soft 'breadlike' bun, and the dough (with only 4 c. flour) is a charm to work with. Made without a bread machine, I only had to knead for about 5 minutes and didn't even have to flour the counter to roll out. Really, I cannot express how lovely a dough this creates. There was too much frosting for my tastes - I would have preferred more of a light drizzle. What I got was a -very- generous smearing. In the future, I will make half the icing, to suit my own tastes. I will definitely be making these again, and I don't repeat recipes very often. Thank you!

text:
When I made these the dough rose significantly. So instead of using the entire batch for cinnamon rolls I split the dough and used about 3/4 for cinnamon rolls and 1/4 for dinner rolls. Maybe I put in too much yeast? Didn't really measure that. I let them sit for awhile and they rose like crazy again. when I had placed them in the pan there was still a little space left at the end but once they cooked it definitely filled in. I cheated and used a can of cream cheese frosting for mine. I also added peanuts and raisins. I can never get my hubby to eat cinnamon rolls when we are out or when I purchase them but he loved these. Definitely saving this recipe forever.

I have a really great cinnamon roll recipe already but was excited to try this one.  I am sorry but I was a bit disappointed.  The dough was really tough...the rolls turned out more crisp than soft...and adding salt to the frosting??  What??  I may try this one again...only leaving out some of the flour for a softer dough...and cooking at 350* for a longer amount of time...and absolutely no salt in the frosting (yuck)...then I will add to this review :) 05/04/09:  I tried these again only this time I sifted the flour into the measuring cup making the dough softer and not as tough...then I used only 1/2 c. melted butter combined 2/3 C. brown sugar and 2 Tbs cinnamon...then I cooked at 350* until barely golden...then frosted while still warm...much better the second time around!!!  YUMMMM!! Changed rating from 2 star to 4 star

text:
So delicious! Buttered wax paper is a must for the bottom of the pan. If you're having a hard time rolling out the dough to the right size, let it set for a minute or so then come back and the dough will have relaxed. Also, if you refrigerate it, cover it well. The tops of my rolls were a wee bit crunchy from exposure but other than that, AMAZING! Next time I'm going to add some cinnamon to the dough :)

text:
Okay, I don´t know why I procrastinated so long for making this. It took me about 3 hours rising time included but it was totally worth it. I followed the recipe exactly, also added ground clove and I cannot even begin to say how great they are. I made them by hand and it wasn´t so hard to make. I also used wheat flour and they took between 15 and 20 mins to be done. You cannot die without trying this, you will be the hit of every party from now on. Oh, another good tip is when you let it rise: Boil a pot of water and put it on the bottom rack of the turned off oven and the dough on the top rack for it to rise in a warm and moist place. Superb!!

text:
This was the 4th cinnamon roll recipe I have tried off of this site, and I have to say this is the best dough. It seems a little tough when it comes out of the bread machine, but once it is finished it has a very nice texture. As for the filling, I used the remainder of the stick of butter from the 1/3 cup, plus 1 stick, 2 TBSP cinnamon, and 2 tsp of vanilla all mixed together and spread on the dough. It was wonderful!! These also heat up nicely with just 45 seconds in the microwave.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are dangerously delicious!! I used my brilliant stand mixer for mixing (dissolving yeast in 115°  warm milk with a little of the sugar first) and unsalted butter instead of margarine. Proofed in warm oven (that had been heated to 200°  then turned OFF) with damp (and clean obviously) dish towel o'er bowl o' dough. Took about an hour to double. Assembled as directed. Upon removal of baked rolls from oven, be sure to flip them immediately to a serving pan/plate. When it comes to the frosting... don't mess around: use an 8oz pkg of cream cheese and double the other ingredients. Also, if you have a disposable latex or nitrile glove... you can frost them to perfection with your hands. AND! Since I'm not to keen on waking up at oh-dark-thirty to bake, assembly happened the evening before. In my groggy morning stupor, these go directly from fridge to oven (not even bothering to preheat)... perfect! Prepare to be loved!!

text:
I've tried a lot of cinnamon roll recipes and this by far is the best one with a little tweek here and there. The filling does run during cooking and I tried flipping it over as one had said to do, and it worked. But on accident, I found something that worked even better. The first 15 minutes were cooked at a low heat of 295 degrees and then cranked up to 370 degrees for 6 minutes. The filling held togther in the roll and it came out perfect. Another thing I wanted to comment on was the way the dough turns out beautifuly and is so easy to work with. I'm going to try different fillings. Thank you for sharing this recipe.

country:

text:
I had never made cinnamon rolls before trying this recipe. I was under the impression they were hard to make, and although it was a time consuming process (3 hours start to finsh, though a large majority of that was waiting for the dough to rise), but it really was not difficult. I ended up using over half whole wheat flour because I ran out of white. I prefer to use all whole wheat flour, but didn't want to push it on my first try with cinnamon rolls. I'm glad I ran out, though, because they turned out great with the whole wheat addition. I will definitely try all whole wheat next time. I made the dough in my bread machine. Added the ingredients into the machine on the dough cycle, pressed start, and let it do it's thing for 90 minutes (that included mixing and rising). I did not do the icing, and am glad I didn't. They were great without. My husband and kids have been begging for them ever since! I'll definitely have to make them again!

I thought these cinnamon rolls were easy to make, and the results were so professional that my hubby, who wasn't home when I made them, expressed doubt that I had made them myself. (As in, "did you REALLY make these yourself?") They came together quickly - I used the 'dough' setting on my bread machine. I followed the recipe exactly. Quantities were perfect. It made a dozen big, gooey rolls that, once rise time was allowed for, baked quickly! The biggest part of the time allowance is in rise time. Actual making/dough handling time is quite minimal. A great snow-day treat for the kids.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/172399.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe truly is fabulous! For those of us looking out on the healthy side (or trying!), think about cutting the dough in half once you remove it from the bread machine. Roll each half separately and coat with cinnamon/sugar as directed, using half the mixture for each rolled half of dough. Bake about 2-3 minutes less. This results in twice as many cinna"mini" rolls! Plus, you won't feel so guilty when you want to eat two...which will almost certainly be the case. :o) Enjoy!

None
text:
My first attempt at homemade cinnamon rolls...EXCELLENT!  I did not use a bread machine.  I used 1 packet yeast. I warmed the milk and butter in the microwave then combined it with the dry ingredients.  Mixed with a hand mixer just until combined, then kneaded for about 5 minutes on a floured surface.  Heated oven to 200 degrees, turned off and let rise for 1 hour, then followed recipe.  After I took them out of the oven, I flipped them onto a piece of parchment paper.  Looking forward to making them again!

text:
These are amazing! I can't stop making them... or eating them!  I have received so many compliments and requests already. My recommendations are: cut back a little on the cream cheese and add a little extra butter & powdered sugar if you don't like the flavor of a rich cream cheese icing.  Also, mix the butter with the cin. sugar mixture so it sticks to the dough easier.

text:
I can't believe this!  I have tried about 35 recipes involving yeast. I'm serious. I am NOT exaggerating. I kept trying different recipes because my yeast would not rise, no matter what I tried. With this cinnabon recipe, I decided to try yeast one more time. This recipe used milk, instead of water, and guess what happened? The dough was bubbling so much, that it almost came out of my glass mixing bowl. I was ecstatic!  It was great. The cinnamon rolls turned out wonderfully sweet, and they were so light. I am planning on using the same basic dough for yeast rolls.  I would just leave out the cinnamon and so much sugar. (Just a thought!)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy flavour but definitely a decadent "treat" for special occassions only as it was quite filling and rich!!  Made this for Christmas Brunch and actually overbaked them since I had cut out 21 rolls instead of 12 (duhhh - but it was late & I was tired) and did not realize my error until they had already baked for 15 mins.  This made them hard around the edges so to remedy this, I sprinkled some water on the buns with my finger tips and put them in the microwave covered for 1 minute.  This also works for warming rolls straight from the fridge (30 secs/roll - add 10 secs for each additional roll).  I found the frosting to be a bit pasty, not smooth like what you get from Cinnabon so I added a touch of milk and that helped.

Oh my goodness--what a treat!  My husband honestly did not believe that I had made these from scratch.  (He's taking the pan into work so he won't eat them all himself;) )  
I did add a teaspoon of vanilla to the dough before making it, and when it came time for the butter and cinnamon filling, I simmered the butter and sugar together so it became more of a paste and did not drain out of the rolls after cooking.  I also added some chopped spiced nuts before rolling up.
Thank you for a wonderful recipe to work with.  I will definitely make these again.....I'm seeing chocolate chips in the next filling, maybe a caramel butterscotch flavor another time :)
Blessings!

text:
The flavor of this recipe was outstanding.  The filling, the bread itself, and the icing were all top notch.  However, I made my rolls in 9x9" pans, and there is no possible way to cook them completely if you're cooking them at 400*F for only 15 minutes.  I found that I had to turn the heat down to 350*F and cook them for at least 45 min. to get the center to raise/cook and not burn the outer rolls.  
This recipe is definitely a keeper

text:
These were amazing! I've never had Cinnabon, so I don't know how they compare, but these were great! I made them for a brunch with some of my girlfriends and everyone loved them! Made the dough the night before in the breadmachine and with my mom's help, assembled them and put the pan in the fridge overnight, covered with plastic wrap sprayed with nonstick spray. I took them out of the fridge the next morning and let them sit for a couple hours before baking them. They didn't rise at all before I put them in the oven, so I was a little concerned. But they turned out perfectly! I didn't have any cream cheese, so for icing I mixed powdered sugar and vanilla caramel flavored non-dairy creamer until it was spreadable. Very sweet, but verrry good! Will definitely make these again!
Review:

5

country:
None
text:
I make smaller Cinnamon rolls when I make these, making twice as many, then freeze half.  My kids can't eat a monster-sized cinnamon roll, and although I can, I shouldn't!  I also make the frosting ahead and then freeze glbs in individual plastic wrap.  That way I can just bring out as many as I need after they bake.  Often, my son doesn't want any frosting.  Or sometimes I frost with a simple sugar glaze (1 cup powder sugar, 1 TB milk, 1 tsp. vanilla).  Obviously, this topping is not as rich.  But like I said, I have frozen cream cheese frosting for anyone who prefers the rich stuff.

I don't exactly follow the recipe verbatim.  I add a little vanilla to the dough mix, follow the directions till baking time, then I bake for about 13 minutes vs the 18.  I also do not follow the directions for the icing.  I use about 1/2 c REAL BUTTER, 6 tsp vanilla, 1 1/2 packages of cream cheese, and just start dumping in the powdered sugar until its the right taste for me.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't actually eaten these yet, they are in the final rise.  I've been letting them rise in the fridge as another reviewer suggested and it's been working out well.  With the first rise, I let it spend the last 10 - 15 minutes in a warm oven to make sure it had risen thoroughly, and I'll set the pan on the stove while the oven is preheating before baking for the same reason.  I also mixed the butter, cinnamon, and sugar together and spread it on the dough.  I halved the recipe to make 12 mini-buns.  I made the full amount of frosting, though.  When making the frosting (which I've tasted and is so rich and delicious, almost too much), I added only 1 cup of sugar.  For texture and sweetness, it really didn't need anymore, and I think the richness of the butter and cream cheese comes through better this way.  I am looking forward to eating them tonight.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These do taste like the Cinnabon cinnamon rolls that you get at the mall.  However, you have to bake them just right.  I made these in 2 batches.  The first batch, I let cook until they were golden brown as the recipe states.  They were dry and the sugar that came out of the cinnamon rolls at the bottom hardened.  I made the second batch and took them out right before they browned.  I cut into one to make sure they were cooked all the way through.  They were perfect this way!  Also, I did not use my bread machine.  For those of you that do you use the bread machine, it takes about 3 hours to rise.

text:
These are really really good!  I halved the recipe and ended up with 12 reasonable sized rolls so the original recipe must make HUUUGE rolls!  For the filling I melted the butter and added a tsp of vanilla and spread that over the top and then sprinkled over the cinnamon sugar - I also added a couple of pinches of mixed spice to the filling.  I also halved the frosting recipe and added a few drops of lemon juice.  I warmed the frosting in the microwave and only ended up using half of it.  I love these so much I think I am going to make a full batch (but cut into 24 rolls) tomorrow and treat everyone at work on monday with yummy cinnamon rolls for morning tea.

text:
Very good cinnamon rolls, but I agree with the other reviewer that the cooking temp and time is way off. 400 degree oven is way to hot of an oven and the time to cook them is too short. Mine were done on the outside, perfectly, but still doughy inside. I had to stick them back in the oven and cook them longer. Next time I will use a oven at 350 or 300 and just cook them longer. Also I really think the brown sugar/cinnamon mix was too much! I didnt even use all mine. Otherwise, pretty darn good!

i gave this recipe two tries, both bombed. i don't understand all the raving about it, they are just plain cinnamon rolls, nothing special in my opinion. the first time i made them i used white sugar w/ cinnamon because i was out of brown sugar, and a plain sugar glaze as i was out of cream cheese, i baked according to the directions and they were doughy in the center. the second time i made them, i used the brown sugar according to directions, the only changes i made from original recipe was in the baking time, an extra 5 minutes, and the frosting, i used orange extract instead of vanilla, a personal taste prefrence. i will definatly not make these again, will go back to my favorite cinnamon roll recipe.

None
text:
All I can say is WOW!  This REALLY tastes like a Cinnabon!  I cheated a bit, and these were even more simple to make.  I used three, 1 lb. loaves of frozen bread dough, thawed.  I increased the butter to 1/2 cup, and the brown sugar and cinanmon increased accordingly.  I mixed the butter and sugar together to form a "paste" which I spread on the dough.  Since the bread dough was shaped into loaves, I rolled each one up with 1/3 of the sugar/butter mixture.  The total amt came to about 1 9x13 pan and 1 8x8 square pan of rolls.  I also doubled the amt of frosting, because we like it gooey and sweet.  This was a GREAT recipe, and the prepared dough tasted just the like the way it's supposed to.  YUM!!!!!!!!!

text:
These always turn out great! I don't use a bread machine so i make a few changes. I dissolve the sugar in the warm milk and then proof the yeast(I just use regular yeast.) Then I add everything except the eggs and butter. I mix those in before the last cup of flour. I let it rise in a warm place for an hour and then punch it down and roll them out. Then I follow the recipe exactly! Thanks for the wonderful recipe.

text:
Definitely NOT a cinnabon, but a good cinnamon roll. I followed the recipe exactly and here are the problems I ran into: The brown sugar did not fully cook and was still grainy when eating the cinnamon roll, there was not a lot of "goo", and it was super duper sugary sweet. Here are the changes I will most likely make next time: I will cook it at a slower temperature, longer to try and cook all the brown sugar; I will blend a little white sugar and brown sugar instead of just plain brown sugar; and I will add a little more butter to the top of the cinnamon rolls.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-03-18T10:09:58.53
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
1488433
Display Name:
lilamonster
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
72
favoritesCount:
1003
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/105216.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were great, and really easy if you use frozen bread loaf from the groccery store. I read other reviews before I started, and used the following hints: mix the butter and cinnamon/sugar to make a spread. It gets pretty soft, and I cut them thin (store loaf makes 9 thin, not 12 huge), so I used a spatula to transfer them to the pan. I planned to flip them onto a sheet pan after they cooked, so I used the hint to put a thin layer of melted butter in the bottom of the pan and then greased the sides. Grease the corners WELL - that's the only place they stuck once flipped. Let the pan sit on top to let all of the goo run for a few minutes! I let mine rise in a pre-warmed, shut OFF oven (200 degrees) oven with the pan of water, and it still took an hour. I also lowered the cooking temp. to 350 and added 5+ min. so they weren't as 'crusty'. For the frosting, I used 1/2 cup less confectioners sugar, as I am not a frosting person, and it was nice and cream-cheesy, not as sweet. I put a little on top of each, and then set out the rest so people could frost them to suit their own taste. The changes I followed only affected the cooking/presentation, not the flavor, and these were truely awsome. If you skip the dough-making, these are SUPER easy, with BIG, BIG taste for surprisingly little effort! Thanks for the great recipe - my mom is already planning the next batch for Easter Brunch!!

Like this needs another review, but, if there is anyone reading this with a 3 yr old like mine, this needs to be said:  Not only are these as good or maybe better than Cinnabon, MY 3yo ATE THEM! You know, Jean's West, Orange Julius, stop to peg my jeans, buy socks to match my shirt to go with my sparkling white Keds, go to the bathroom to get my hair bigger, then finish it all off with a big, fat,  Cinnabon!  Good times, good times.
Thanks for the memories!

These are, sorry, _were_ great! I dind't do any frosting and they were still great! They had a little cinnamon-caramel sauce underneath after baking. Display Name:
Kate

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Unbelievably good!  These are easily the best cinnamon rolls I've ever had.  I make them in my food processor, first I proof the yeast in 1/4 cup of the milk with a teaspoon of the sugar.  Then I put the flour, salt, and remaining sugar in the work bowl.  Start the processor and while running add the melted butter, the eggs, remaining milk, and finally the yeast mixture.  Allow the dough to come together and be kneaded by the dough hook until elastic and then I proceed as the directions say.  I've made these three times in one week so far.  There is PLENTY of icing for my taste, I can't imagine needing to double it!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-01-21T17:40:18.05
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
2383734
Display Name:
{ s.a.r.a.h }
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
101
favoritesCount:
83
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are PERFECT.  I used my KitchenAid with the dough hook instead of a bread machine, allowing the yeast to bloom in the warm milk and sugar for 10 minutes first.  Like many suggested, I heated the oven to 200 degrees then turned it off, letting the dough rise in an oiled bowl for an hour.  My dough was very sticky, so I floured my counter and rolling pin generously.  I just melted margarine and used a pastry brush to spread it across the dough once rolled out, then sprinkled the cinnamon/sugar mixture.  I rolled from the long side, cut 12 rolls at 1.5 inches, and cooked them 25 minutes at 350 degrees.  I also used all margarine instead of butter, just because it was what I had on hand, and everything came out great.  A lot of time and some trouble, but definitely well worth it!

country:
None
text:
Wow! What a cinnamon bun! I think that the result was well worth the three hour wait. The dough has a perfect flavor, not bland, like I find many other cinnamon bun doughs to have. I found myself having too much brown sugar/cinnamon mixture, so just before the buns were put in the oven, I added a spoonful of brown sugar/cinnamon on top. Perfect! Like many other reviewers, I flipped the buns over so that the cinnamon coating would run over the rest of the bun.
I found myself also having too much icing, but in this case, that was not a bad thing. This icing is perfect!

Thanks so much for sharing such a great recipe. I definitely be making these again!

text:
I just made these for my family this afternoon, and they are delicious!  I didn't use a bread machine, just did it the old-fashioned way.  I only used a 7 oz. package of yeast.  Also, I didn't have the bread flour because the cashier at Walmart must have not put it in my cart because she was too busy talking to my toddler.  I used all-purpose flour, and they turned out fine.  Probably could have used a tad bit more flour, but I just added a little more when I rolled them out.  I only used about 2 tbsps. of butter on the dough instead of the 1/3 cup.  Just seemed like a lot of butter to me, but I guess that's what makes them really 'gooey'.  Taste just fine to me the way they turned out!  If they dry out too fast, I'll probably use the 1/3 cup butter called for the next time I make this recipe.

text:
Another raving review...These are fantastic!  I did NOT use a bread machine.  I dissolved a T. yeast in the warm milk and added the rest of the ingredients.  This dough is fabulous to work with, supple and not sticky.  After the first rise and rolling/cutting the rolls, I put them in the fridge overnight. I let them sit in a slightly warm oven for over an hour, then baked as directed.  I wish I could eat without worrying about calories, because I would eat a half dozen of these no problem.  The best cinnamon rolls I've ever had.  Hands down.  I don't see the need to even try other recipes.

text:
Egg allergy here, but these were fantastic with 1/2 c. vanilla yogurt substituted for the eggs. You'd never know the eggs were left out!  I also used melted butter in the dough instead of margarine because our food needs to be Feingold-safe as well as egg-free.  After removing the dough from the bread machine, I had to let it rise more in a warm oven to get it to double.  My ingredients may not have been close enough to room temp. when I began.  I followed some others' suggestions and made these the night before. They didn't rise at all in the fridge, so I popped them in a barely warm over for about 30 min. then preheated with them still in there and baked at 350 for about 2o min. until done.  They seemed a bit gooey so after I served the first two, I propped up the pan to let the goo run to the side.  I'll probably adjust the cinn./sugar mixture next time I make them.  Can't wait to have more!

text:
These are fantastic, I will make them again and again. I actually didnt have confectioners sugar, and had to use real sugar instead. If this happens to you, just use 1 cup sugar and dont worry that it is a bit gritty, because once you put it on the buns it melts right in and I didnt notice the icing being gritty anymore.

Another tip! I use dental floss to cut the rolled up dough into buns. Works way better than a knife.

Ok, so I have been dying to try this recipe for a while now, but with my kids schedules, I haven't found 3 hours to do so. Well, Football season was finally over, so i decided to make it for a treat tonight. I timed it so it would be ready after dinner. Well, I timed wrong, and we were in the middle of dinner when it was done. Let me tell you, I have never seen my son eat so fast so he could be the first one to try it. So while we were still eating dinner, he dug into the first one, the boy looked like he was going to melt with deliciousness (if that is even a word) I said, so it looks like you like it, and he just said, oh, this is sooo good. I asked if it was worth the 3 hours and he said ohhhh yeaaaaaa! What I did differant was as some others had done, I cut the butter in with the brown sugar and cinnamin instead of spreading it (the butter) on the dough. I then spread the mixture onto the dough. Also for the icing, I used 5oz instead of 3oz of cream cheese, as I am a cream cheese fanatic, ohhhh was it good! I will definately make sure I have all ingrediants on hand for when I have a spare 3 hours...magnifite!!!

Display Name:

city:

country:
None
text:
My first review on these was in 2007(original review below). I have been making this recipe since, on Christmas eve (today reason for my re-review). I don't change the dough at all and put in my bread machine. My sugar mixture I add walnuts/pecans. I cut the dough with a string/waxed dental floss to avoid smooshing. I also cut the dough about 3-4 inches and press down slightly in pan to widen out for bigger rolls. I cover and put in fridge over night. When the kids wake us up I preheat the oven and pull out the rolls placing them on top of oven to rise for about 30 minutes or so. After baked I flip them out onto a large cutting board for the drippings to cool on top of rolls. Please keep in mind the middles are still baking. Love this recipe thank you again for sharing.
(Original review 2007) Wow what can I say these were amazing. The only changes I made from the original recipe were reducing my heat to 350 degrees and cooking for 20 minutes. Also instead of spreading my icing I put it in a sandwich bag and cut the corner of the bag making zig zags over the top of the rolls. Just a tip, let the rolls sit for about 10 - 15 minutes before serving. The rolls are still cooking in the center after coming out of the oven. The center will be googy and undone if served right out of the oven. If you are unsure about this recipe, don't be.

text:
*Drool* Awesome recipe! I make this frequently, and have noticed that I can interchangeably use hot water instead of milk. And I tend to add white sugar to the cinnamon and brown sugar mix (makes it a bit more gooey). I also recommend using an all purpose flour. Makes it nicer to handle. Enjoy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are very good. I've made one batch exactly as written, but I also made a batch with 2 c. of whole wheat flour (the other 2 1/2 white flour), Splenda instead of sugar, and fat-free cream cheese. They were also very delicious. Thanks for an amazing recipe. 
I turned them over after baking to allow the cinnamon to coat the buns as a previous reviewer suggested. I would also recommend doing that. 
Another helpful suggestion would be to use a pizza cutter to cut the dough into your 12 strips. I cut the dough in half, then in half again. Then those four sections I cut into thirds. This made nice, proportional rolls.
I received tons of praise when serving these and everybody wanted and got the recipe and I also referred them to this site because it rocks.

text:
Delicious!  I have made this twice and my second batch was the best one yet.  Do put the entire brown sugar mix onto your dough.  I made the mistake on my first batch of not including the entire brown sugar mix and it didn't have enough gooey middle stuff.  I also turned them upside for 5 minutes after it came out of the oven to help redistribute the leaked out gooey stuff back onto the rolls.

text:
These are great!!  I've made it twice now, both times with a breadmaker.  However, once I made them exactly as the recipe called and they came out beautifully.  The next time, I made them and let them rise, then covered and placed in the fridge until the morning.  Took them out while letting the oven preheat and baked as usual.  Again, came out beautiful.  Will be making again and again.  They are super easy and use items I usually already have on hand.  One note to consider... both times I made them, they rose so much that I ended up pulling a few out onto another pan, so there would be enough room.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These taste exactly like a cinnabon!!!  That is the overall opinion in our house.  They don't look just like them but the taste is dead on. I did this all by hand and followed others reviews instructions. A few things I did that worked really well was the dough rising in a warm oven, and I greased the surface to roll the dough instead of floured, it rolled out beautifully and really helped the cinnamon rolls "seal" and keep from unrolling in the pan. I changed the frosting slightly and it was perfect: 4 oz cream cheese, 5 T. butter, 1 3/4 cups powdered sugar, same amount of vanilla and salt, and 1 T. milk. Also very important, 350 degrees for 30 minutes=perfection!! My family and friends think these are to die for and I totally agree!!!

text:
I have followed the review as I was not using the bread machine and reduced the yeast. It did not rise enough, it was like eating a toasted dough. so STICK TO THE ORIGINAL RECIPE even if you are not using a bread machine.
I will be trying again.
I recommend mixing butter and cinnamon mixture then spread on the dough, instead of butter first and sprinkling the cinnamon sugar.
Less messy, and it gets rolled inside the dough without losing half of them!

text:
Wonderful!!! I had never made cinnamon rolls before I made these and they turned out perfect! Absolutely delicious! Mine didn't seem to be dry, but I added a lot of icing on top. If you're afraid they'll be to dry after reading other reviews, add half a pack of dry instant vanilla pudding after you put the flour in your bread machine, that should help. These were the best cinnamon rolls I've ever had!!!

text:
Wow!!!  I was doubtful that it could be possible to make anything close to what you can buy and wow!! First, I pulled out my bread maker that I had not used for the past 4 years and when the result of putting in all the ingredients was a beautiful lump of warm dough, I was starting to get more optimistic.  Rolling out the dough was a bit tricky since the dough was so elastic!  After baking it, I was so pleasantly surprised at the end result!  How professional and delicious it all looked.  I shared half a dozen with my neighbors and I got two calls from different family members telling me just how awesome they were, in fact better than the ones that are made at the malls.  My two daughters also wolfed down their cinnamon buns for a snack this afternoon.  Finally, I just sat down after tying up all the loose ends of the day and I am enjoying my first taste.  I am very happy to be enjoying fresh, HOMEMADE cinnamon buns!  Thanks for sharing this awesome recipe as it will be made in my kitchen many times over!

These were amazing!  This recipe made about 14 large perfect cinnamon rolls. The only thing I didn't like about this recipe was that it didn't specify which ingredients were going into the dough, filling, or icing. text:
Fantastic!  The first try came out a little hard and dry (combo of a little too much flour and cooked just a little bit too long) but I've made them twice since then, just making sure to measure flour properly and WATCH them as they cook to be sure I grab them before they become too dark, and they've come out perfect!  I followed a previous reviewers tips on how to make these without a bread machine.  And I also had difficulty proofing the yeast but the recipe still works.  Don't pass this recipe up just because you don't have a machine.  It's a good thing these take a little while to make otherwise I'd be making them all the time!  Thanks for a great recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It turned out quite well considering that I didn't use a breadmaker. I have an aversion to using recipes with yeast but this one was easy. I followed the suggestion of one reviewer who put the milk, sugar and yeast together first, and I used 1C of butter for the filling and an extra 1C of brown sugar also. The icing part is SO NOT Cinnabon! Theirs is much lighter in texture. For that, I used about 2/3C heavy cream and 1/2 C soften butter with sugar to taste and whipped it up. Much better. You will have extra filling & icing if you do all this and it will be more than enough for an extra batch or two. Perfect to make when guests are staying for several days.

text:
AWESOME!  These were the best!  My husband has been asking me to make his grandma's cinnimon rolls, and I still hadn't gotten the recipe, but decided to try this instead.  I've now been asked to make these more often!  I did 1 1/2 times the frosting, which was about right.  I took some reviewer's advice and did the dough in my breadmachine the night before, filled and cut them and then left them in the fridge overnight.  I should have let them rise again in the morning, but I just put them straight in the oven and they were still rather large and good.  But next time I'll probably wait 1/2 hour before putting them in the oven in the morning.  Thanks for the amazing recipe!

The 4.5 cups of flour made a really stiff dough for me. It didn't rise well at all and as a result, didn't have that wonderfully light, melt-in-your-mouth  cinnabon texture. It did taste good. I will try again and watch the dough more closely. I'll go for something a   bit more loose. I have to watch all my breads like that, so I should know better. I will try again :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe every year for my co-workers, typically 4-6 dozen.  Everyone raves about them.  One thing I do differently than the recipe calls for is I buy square aluminum cake pans rather than using a 9" x 13" pan, and stagger 6 rolls in the pan.  I find when I use a 9" x 13", the center rolls never get completely done, and while I like the gooey doughy center rolls typically, in a 9" x 13", it's just too much.  It's too bad I can't find 9" x 6.5" pans to bake them in.  That would be perfect!

text:
These had a delicious flavor - the brown sugar and cinnamon combination is fantastic, as is the icing, but I had a problem with the cooking time. The rolls were golden on the outside, but the inside of some of the rolls was uncooked and very doughy. Next time I'll make more rolls at a slightly smaller size or else cover them with foil towards the end of the baking time and bake a bit longer. I can see how these would be addictive!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls turned out beautifully! I made them without any icing, since I didn't have cream cheese available - good thing that my husband didn't really want icing anyway! The rolls turned out golden brown, light and puffy, perfect amount of moisture, and excellent flavour. I cut the recipe in half - all ingredients halfed as written - to make 6 large spiral rolls. My bread machine was set on the 'sweet dough' cycle for kneading. So simple to make and easy cleanup - doesn't create a mess in the kitchen. I plan to use this recipe again and again - next time, I'd like to try them with the icing.

This recipe is INCREDIBLE.  Seriously, I can't think of anything better for breakfast than one of these fresh out of the oven.  Yum. text:
These are, without a doubt, THE BEST homemade cinnamon rolls! I have made them several times now and they disappear as fast as I make them. Very easy to make and with just the basics that I always have on hand. The only thing I do different is to melt a container's worth of vanilla frosting (such as Duncan Hines or Betty Crocker) and then pour it over the top of the cinnamon rolls while they're still hot from the oven. Mmmmmmm.....so good!!! Also, I occasionally add raisins to them (I usually sprinkle them over the top of the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture before rolling the dough).

text:
YUM!  These were absolutely delicious.  I don't have a bread machine or a stand mixer, so I kneaded this by hand and it was just fine.  I only let the dough rise for 1/2 hour, and then another 1/2 hour after I placed the rolls in the baking pan, and they turned out great.  I had plenty of the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture left over so I would make 1/2 or 3/4 as much next time.  They are amazing right out of the oven & still very good after reheating.

text:
SO GOOD!!, close to  being a  "Clone of a Cinnabon". I like to add vanilla ex to the dough, and I use the "Cream Cheese Frosting II" recipe to top these.  I make this completely by hand and is always worth the effort. I make the dough and roll them, then allow them to sit in the fridge over night. This eliminate any yeasty taste. The morning of, I let them sit for about 30 mins, then bake them at 350 util golden. This is a fantastic Thanksgiving or Christmas breakfast.. In fact, both my kids and husband always want this as their birthday breakfast..

All the  other ones I have found have been too intimidating and looked too time consuming.  This recipe couldn't have been easier!  I took the advise of others and made my rolls the night before, put them in the refrigerator and baked them the next morning. I also baked them at a lower temp. They were so good I couldn't beleive I made them! I will never buy cinnamon rolls from the store again. I am so happy to finally have a cinnamon roll recipe I can make over and over again! text:
I didn't think these were all that great.  Too much cinnamon left a yucky taste.  Also, dough was tough when baked.  The Better Homes and Garden's "Goof-Proof Cinnamon Rolls" I have been making for over 10 years are much better.  They are lighter and have a better porportion of cinnamon to brown sugar.  Also, didn't care for the cream cheese in the frosting.  Maybe that's how cinnabon makes them but it's not that great.  My recipe is fabulous and much better: 16 oz. powdered sugar, 1/3 cup melted butter, 1 tsp. vanilla and 1/4 cup evaporated milk.  This is a super creamy frosting.  Try it and you'll see it's much better.

I like this recipe. I have never made a cinnamon roll in my life and feel that I did pretty well. Next time though I will roll the dough a little thinner. Some of the rolls that were sliced near the middle ended up being too thick and had a little doughy taste, but that is only because of my technique not the recipe. I didnt use a bread machine. Can anyone describe the best way to make this not using the bread machine? also make more icing than the recipe calls for.

text:
Yes....indeed these are a delectable treat. Raves from friends and co-workers alike. BUT, watch out. Like some other reviewers, I too found that 15 minutes at 400 F was not going to cut it. I ended up turing the oven down to 350 F and letting them go another 10 minutes. But I suppose it all depends on how thick you cut them and also how evenly your oven distributes heat. Overall, very good and worth a try.

country:
None
text:
NON BREAD MAKER METHOD:
We don’t have a bread machine so I just made it the way I would with any other bread recipe. 

I put the sugar, milk and yeast into a 4 cup measuring cup to dissolve and put 3 1/2 cups of flour and the salt in the mixing bowl. I mixed together the melted butter and the eggs in a small dish and when the yeast liquid was ready to add to the premixed salt and flour mixture, I also added the egg and butter mixture into he bowl. I added 1/2 cup of flour at a time once everything was mixed well until I had a nice soft dough.

Note** I used regular all purpose flour rather than bread flour

Well it was a clean sweep across the judges... Exactly like a cinnabon!!! Great Recipe was loved by all

text:
Made this the night before using instant yeast...Combined dry ingredients (including yeast packet). Mixed melted butter with milk, and heated until 110 degrees, and then mixed into dry ingredients.
Used my kitchen aid mixer dough hook to knead 10 minutes. Did Step 3, and then covered tightly with plastic and put into the fridge.
Next morning took out of the fridge for about 1/2 hour and then followed Step 4.
They rose like crazy in the oven!
FANTASTIC!!!!!

Display Name:
AliveNCooking

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/205292.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe for the roll is very good as is (even though the instructions are not great). But the frosting recipe wasn't very good and I had to get another one elsewhere. I used a bread maker on the dough cycle, adding ingredients in this order: butter, milk, eggs, sugar, salt, flour, then yeast. After the dough cycle finished, I set up the bread maker on the manual cycle set to "rise." After it finished the rise cycle, I floured a counter lightly, put the dough on it, and rolled it into a rectangle. I spread the butter on with a spatula (leaving clean 1/2" on each long end), sprinkled on the brown sugar and cinnamon (combined first), and then sprinkled on 1/2 cup of raisins. I rolled it up tight, wetting the 1/2" on the long side with water so that it would stick to the roll. I cut them in 1" slices. Then I let them rise for a second time.
