text:
So good!  Rave reviews from my whole family.  I made it almost exactly as the recipe -- but I have a milk allergic child.   I replaced butter with dairy-free margarine.  I replaced the milk with 1/2 cup of warm water to dissolve the yeast, and used extra margarine to make up some of the richness.  I would have used a milk substitute, but all I had was vanilla flavored almond milk and I didn't want to add the vanilla taste to it.   I also could not add the cream cheese to the frosting - so not quite as cinnabon like  for us, but still yummy!

The instructions aren't very clear. So stop at the flour for the bread maker. The next three ingredients, the 1/3 cup of butter, Brown sugar and Cinnamon all happen to be for inside the roll and the last ingredients is for the icing.  FYI

text:
Ohhhhh these were SO good!!! I made them as our Christmas morning breakfast, and have decided it will be our tradition, and can only hope I can wait that long to make and eat them again!  

I was happy to discover that a) you can make and freeze them, and simply defrost in the microwave till warm and gooey (this I did for my experimental batch!) and b) you can make them ahead up to the point of proofing after rolling and cutting:   placing in the fridge overnight, then proof next morning for 30 mins in an oven preheated to 200 degrees but then turned off, then bake as per instructions (this I did for the Christmas batch). 

So, so good!!!

I absolutely love this recipe as is, but for a change of pace I turned these into Mexican chocolate rolls by adding 1 T of Cocoa powder into the filling. With over 2K reviews, I'm not sure anyone will ever read this!  I decided I wanted to make these and got started, only to find that I only had AP flour, active dry yeast, not enough milk.  You get the picture...substituted like crazy.  Had about 1/2 a cup of milk left and used fat-free half & half for the rest of the milk, used all-purpose flour, and used regular active dry yeast.  Still came out absolutely delicious!  My husband is on his second as I type this.  Can't wait to try it with the ingredients, as written.  So good!

None
text:
We had these for Christmas breakfast and they were very good!!  I don't have a bread machine, but I used the dough hook on my stand mixer and it worked great!  I used ideas from others - put in warm oven to rise for an hour, mix softened butter, brown sugar and cinnamon all together & press mixture via rolling pin into dough, invert onto parchment paper immediately after baking, put 1/2 frosting on right away (melty goodness in all the layers), then put rest of frosting on after a few minutes.  YUMMY!!

text:
These cinnamon buns were amazing and tasted very similar to Cinnabon. I do not have a bread machine or a KA so I warmed the milk and then dissolved the yeast in the milk, and then proceeded to add all of the rest of the ingredients. Also when it came time to add the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture, I added about 3/4 of the mixture to the dough, then I went over the dough with the rolling pin, before adding the remaining 1/4 mixture. I think this helped keep all of brown cinnamon from leaking out.
Review:
Rating:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were phenomenal!!   I followed the recipe to a tee, with the exception of making them without the bread maker.   I did however, follow some other viewers suggestions and rolled the sugar and cinnamon into the butter (about 3 sweeps of the rolling pin) then made sure the roll was snug.   After letting them rest/raise for 30 minutes, I put them in a preheated, 350 degree oven, for exactly 20 minutes (not the 400 for 15 that was in the recipe) and then immediately turned them over onto a new pan and placed half the frosting on them.  They were perfect!  No issues of the butter/sugar running out into the baking pan and very little was even on the wax paper that lined it - not even enough to scrape off.  They tasted exactly like Cinnabon and my husband ate 2 of them as soon as I could slop frosting on them!  I did remove them at exactly 20 minutes - even though they looked questionably gooey.  They were not raw, and any longer would have caused them to lose some of the ooey-gooey that makes them desirable.  If you like dry cinnamon rolls - these are NOT for you!!  I will be making these again to share with neighbors and family, with no changes to the recipe or process.  Amazing!!

text:
This is absolutely delicious. I made this for my co-workers to test before making them for my family's Christmas Day party. Everyone loved it. I make 2 batches for my family, one with pecans and one without. We had to hide some because my family kept coming back for more!! I agree with another reviewer, only use half the icing while they are still hot and the other half once they've cooled down some. If you allow them to sit overnight after you have cut them before baking they will get bigger so if you do that I would suggest cutting them smaller. I did that and it allowed me to have almost double the rolls for one batch. If you add nuts like I tried, I would suggest adding them when you put the cinnamon mixture, that way you can roll the nuts inside as well or maybe mixing it into the icing. Just a suggestion though.. Overall really great recipe. Thanks for sharing!! It is now apart of my stash. LOl

text:
Just made this today; super like but I made changes hence the four stars. For the spread: used 1/4 c melted butter,  1/2 c packed brown sugar, 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 c  chopped walnuts and rolled out the dough thinner that I made 16 pieces (I cut into 1-inch rolls)! For the icing: used 3/4 cup white sugar and thinned it with 1/3 c 2% milk because I found the original recipe very, very thick. I am having this right now with coffee. So good!

madfly43

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like to read the most helpful reviews and try to combine the suggestions. I pretty much followed mcatherwood's and it came out wonderfully. We don't have a bread machine. I dissolved a 1/4 oz. packet of Fleischmann's Active Dry yeast in 1/4 c. warm water. The dough came out really sticky, (I might just dissolve it in the milk as others suggested next time) but we kept dusting with flour to keep off our hands and knead into a ball. I followed mcatherwood's suggestion about placing the ball in the warmed oven. I followed Jamie's suggestion to mix the cinnamon/sugar with the butter then spread. I combined mcatherwood and Jamie's suggestion by using a glass 9x13 pan lined with greased (with shortening) wax paper. I baked for 22 min. at 350 degrees ('til the top browned). I took it out and flipped it as JENNIFER WOODARD suggested. When I took my first bite, I was a little worried that the middle didn't cook all the way 'cuz it was gooey, but it was gooey in a fantastic way. And as it cooled, it dried out a bit. Oh and when they say 3 oz. package of cream cheese, I used a regular 8 oz. package.

None
country:
None
text:
These are mighty fine!  Make sure to pack the rolls pretty close together, so when they raise they do it "into" each other.  This gives you nice golden tops without too much drying.  In addition, I think these are best cooked right after preparation.  You can certainly put them in the fridge and cook the next day, but they will take a good deal of time to rise and if you put them on something warm to speed it up, some of the butter will melt and fall to the bottom and can saturate the rolls as they cook.

None
text:
Made this recipe for the first time today and it's really good. It was a little too cinnamon-y for my tastes, next time I'll cut the cinnamon down from 2.5 tablespoons to 2 tablespoons, that ought to be just about perfect. Even without a bread machine, just working the dough by hand the texture wonderful. If you have trouble with the filling running out I think that's probably caused by under-proofing the dough. After you roll out and cut into the individual pieces let the dough go through a second rise in the baking dish before you bake. That ought to squeeze the rolls together enough to keep the filling in place.

userID:
3804983
Display Name:
Vicky Ferrell Field
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2618091.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this in my bread machine and it was super easy.  I followed some reviews and wish I had followed others.  Suggestions I followed: 1) Spread the softened butter on the rolled out dough, sprinkle with cinnamon and sugar (I then smeared it all together with a spatula so it looked like a brown sugary paste).  2) Bake at 350 on a lower rack in the oven for 25 minutes.  3) Add a touch of lemon to the frosting - wish I hadn't followed this one.  The cream cheese made the frosting tangy enough. 4) Invert the rolls after baking and then use a spatula to respread the gooiness in the bottom of the pan. Wished I had added a touch of vanilla to the frosting.  Revisions I WISHED I had followed (read them as I was baking the rolls).  1) Make sure the rolls are rolled TIGHTLY.  Pinch the dough together. 2) Leave a small space in between each roll to allow them to rise fully.  I actually made 16 rolls and they were all touching before the rise.  3) Bake in large muffin tins so the rolls are more round instead of square.... this was the first time I've ever made homemade cinnamon rolls and I've never had a "cinnabon".  They were tasty, but not as moist and gooey as I would have liked.  I'm sure this will improve with more experience in using this recipe and tweaking to my personal preferences and I will DEFINITELY be repeating this recipe :)

text:
All I gotta say is wow!  Only stupid thing I did was baked them for 20 minutes instead of 15.  They were so big I thought it needed longer.  Nope...stick to the 15 minutes.  They weren't badly burned but I like mine light brown.  I think I might add a little cinnamon to the dough mixture though next time.  I know its on the inside but I think it would be better if incorporated throughout the dough.  I didn't have cream cheese for the frosting.  I melted 1 tb of butter and added it to 2 cups of powdered sugar and 3-4 tablespoons of french vanilla creamer.  That turned out awesome!  This is not my first time making cinnamon rolls but my first in my bread machine.  They turned out wonderful.  I might add pecans or something like that next time to dress them up a bit.  Thanks for the recipe.  Turned out great.  It's VERY important to make sure your eggs and butter are room temperature.  Make sure the milk is warm too.

text:
I've made this recipe twice now and both times were a complete success!  I don't have the bread machine, so I used a packet of the active dry yeast and dissolved it in warm milk (as others suggested), which worked out perfectly.  My only adjustment was to add the butter to the cinnamon/brown sugar mixture and then to spread it onto the rolled out dough, which was by accident the first time, but I didn't have any issues with the ingredients coming out of the rolls.  I also doubled the icing recipe as my family loves the extra icing.  Great recipe...I will continue to use this one for sure!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-01-22T13:32:25.31
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
5132361
Display Name:
reidster
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
6
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use a stand-mixer and make with a few modifications. Dissolve the yeast and sugar in 1/2 cup warm water. Then mix in 1/2 cup warm milk, 1/2 cup melted butter, and two slightly beaten eggs. Now mix in two cups ALL-PURPOSE flour. Switch to a dough hook, add remaining AP flour and 1 1/2 tsp salt. Knead at least ten minutes. Then let rise until doubled. 
Roll dough out to 16"x 21", completely cover the dough with melted butter, THEN spread the sugar mixture out evenly. DO NOT ever mix the butter and sugar/cinnamon together. Now roll the dough so you have a 21" wide log, NOT 16"! Do NOT pinch-together/seal the seam. Your rolls will cork-screw up, rather than spread outwards as they rise. Place the dough on a well-floured surface. Cut the log in half using DENTAL FLOSS, not a knife. Do this by sliding the floss underneath the log, crossing over the top, then pulling in opposite directions to neatly slice the dough. Cut each half in half again, then each quarter into thirds. Place the 12 rolls into a well greased 9" x 13" baking dish. Ones with a high straight up-and-down edges work best. Cover and let rise until they at least completely fill the dish. Be patient! Now bake in a 350 degree oven 25 - 30 minutes. I hope this helps.

text:
I tried this recipe, using Andytami's process for making the dough (since I don't have a bread machine) and Jennifer Woodard's suggestion for after they're done. There's a reason that these are the most helpful review!

I also had to use whipped cream cheese since I was fresh outta the normal stuff (about 28 tbs to simulate an 8oz package and I similarly used dbdcook's modifications to the icing for the 8oz, (2/3 c butter, 4 c powdered sugar, 1-1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/3 tsp salt) minus the salt). I mixed the butter and cinnamon sugar together to make it easier to spread.

I made 16 out of this recipe and had SO MUCH FROSTING LEFT OVER I DIDN'T KNOW WHAT TO DO WITH IT. Definitely didn't need to double+ that part of the recipe, I dunno what other folks were doing with it!

They're really yummy, though! Easy to make, too; might have a new favorite for breakfast. Freeze some and then just make one in the morning? Yes please! I might actually eat, then!

text:
These are just okay for me. I think they were too big for a 9x13 pan (I rolled from the short end but the video says to roll from the long end. I watched it after I made them but that was the only thing I did different than the video. I think they would have risen better if they had more room between them. They won't come out big and fluffy like the picture in a 13 x 9 pan. After looking at other pictures it doesn't look like very many come out big and fluffy. Also, 400 was too hot (I have a temperature guage in my oven so it was the correct temperature. They cooked too fast and were very brown on top but still doughy in the middle. If I try these again I will lower the temperature and spread them out over two pans maybe to give them more room. I also didn't find the filling very gooey (which I like). Overall, these were just okay for me. I didn't try the icing as I like my buns without.

text:
Oh my God!!!  These are amazing!!  Made them for Christmas morning. What a treat, as they turned out absolutely perfect.  I followed the recipe exactly and put the ingredients in the bread maker Christmas Eve before going to bed.  I set the timer so it would be done kneading and rising by 7am. When I woke up I went right to step 2 which the kids helped with. That's the fun part, rolling and cutting the dough!  The icing is just right with the perfect amount of cream cheese.  I am always watching my weight but I didn't cut back on any of the ingredients.  I did not want to mess with perfection and it paid off!  I added a few pecans to one side of the pan so we had 4 with nuts and the rest without.  Just make sure to under cook them a little. If the tops turn golden brown, chances are the bottoms (which will be the new tops) will be too well done.  At least that's how my family likes them, a little more undercooked than overlooked.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really Good.  I added a 1/2 of a 3.5 oz package of vanilla pudding mix and 2 tbsp of additional water to the dough cycle.  For all other ingredients, I put in the exact measurements and items called for.  Once the dough was ready to put the cinnamon/sugar/butter combo on, I mixed these together first, then spread on top of the dough.  When the rolls came out of the oven, I did as a few other reviewers suggested, and put tinfoil on top of the pan and inverted the pan upside-down so that the "filling" could run back onto the buns - worked great.  The frosting is spot on and so good.  Turned out really yummy.

text:
This recipe is amazing for the bread machine. I have a magic chef. Don't know if it matters. Anyway the one thing I would recommend is to use a baking stone. Coat it with the butter flavor crisco beforehand. They slide right off and they don't burn on the bottom as easily. And remember the darker the stone the better. It means it's seasoned. Never use soap to clean it. Its just like cast iron, you shouldn't use soap on them.

I did bake mine for about 4 extra minutes as they didn't seem quite brown enough.  That was just perfect at 19 minutes total.  This definitely deserves all the 5 star reviews.

text:
If you love Cinnabon you are going to hate these because they are just as good! I made mine in my bread maker. I ended up having to add about a 1/4 cup of flour to the recipe because the dough was too damp. I also made the rolls and placed them raw into the fridge and followed the example another baker had followed and baked them off in a 350 degree oven for 25 minutes (place the rolls into the oven while its cold). I cannot wait to make these again and again.

text:
Just made these a few hours ago as a surprise Birthday breakfast for my boyfriend. Absolutely amazing! It's just the two of us so i halved the recipe to make six. I prepared the dough by hand since i wasn't sure if such a small batch would work in my bread machine. When i cut the roll the six pieces were still too big so i cut it into 12 pieces instead. I know these are supposed to mimic a cinnabon, which are enormous, but i was fine settling with just copying the taste. This also cut the calories per serving in half which is nice. Very very good, would not change a thing and will definitely make again.

text:
HEAVENLY! I made without the icing.  The dough tastes like my mother's sweet bread which I adore.  I just finished my first batch of these cinnamon buns and ate three right away! Best recipe for dough.  I softened my butter too much; it melted. So, I added the sugar & cinnamon and spread it on the dough. I also followed someone's tip and turned them out of the pan shortly after removing from the oven.

text:
These are excellent, but never never NEVER use margarine when you're baking.  So, in the dough, use 1/3 cup real salted or unsalted butter.  

I didn't have cream cheese, so I just made a powdered sugar glaze.  

Kind of seems unfair to rate a recipe when you make alterations, but they were delicious.  Probably would have rated 4 stars if margarine were used in the dough.

text:
SOOOOOOOOO good!!!! I didn't have any brown sugar so i addes about 2 TBSP to 1 cup of granulated sugar. I also didn't have any cream cheese so I substituted sour cream for the cream cheese. I cooked mine for about 15 minutes, took them out of the oven and let rest for about 5 minutes or so. I then turned the pan upside down onto a serving dish to get all the good stuff out of the bottom of the pan then frosted!! They were delish. Will def make again and again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Even with over 4000 reviews, I thought I'd add mine.  These are not quite like Cinnabons, but they were definitely worth cheating on my diet!  I don't have a bread machine, and without reading the reviews I kind of wing'd it.  I used a stand mixer, and let it rise in a warm oven, took about 1.5 hrs.  the 2nd rise, I let it rise for 35 mins.  Then baked at 350 for 22 mins.  Came out perfect!  I did not use the cream cheese frosting, I made a regular glaze, I didn't measure anything, just a huge cup of powdered sugar and then slowly poured in a little milk at a time till the consistency I liked.  Will definitely be making this again.

text:
Used the advice in several reviews and doubled the icing - I wish I hadn't.  Way too sweet for my husband and I. If you love sweet and sugar, double icing; if not, make as is. These were delicious and I will make again. 
* I made this again and cut the sugar in the icing by a third. I also only added a small dab to each roll and let others add icing as they needed. Those who added icing did so sparingly. Next time I will cut the whole icing recipe down to half along with the sugar. I also only used two Tbsp butter and the icing was still fine.

text:
I have been making these for years! I usually use 3 TBS of cinnamon in the roll AND to make it easier, get the frozen bread loaves, I use Rhodes. Thaw the loaf for an hour on the counter or until totally thawed. Then roll it out and proceed with resipe. It wont roll out as large as the scratch recipe but is just as good and saves time! I also add chopped pecans to the filling if I have them and some cinnamon the the frosting! Yummers!!

Display Name:
wendybird82

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/739571.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Don't plan on looking further. These rolls are heaven. I didn't have 'bread' flour. I used all purpose flour about an extra 1/2 cup and added about a tsp of baking soda (not sure it that made a difference or not) They rose HIGH and the texture was fantastic.  I don't have a bread machine and I used my Kitchen Aid with a bread hook. I placed all the wet ingrediants first, but not the butter. I added the flour, and the melted butter towards the end. I let it run for 5-10 minutes on low. It was a lot of work for my mixer and I kneaded another minute or two by hand. I let rise 1hr in my warm oven (preheated to 200 and turned off) I wrapped in cling wrap and refrigerated overnight. Baked at 350 for 25 minutes. PERFECTION.

Display Name:
amy
isPro:

192

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe.  As other reviewers mentioned, I prepared it in a 2 day process.  If your'e serving it for breakfast, it is much easier to prepare the buns the night before.  Once I got to the point where I placed the buns in the pan, I covered them up and put them in the fridge.  I also prepared the icing the night before and put it in a separate container in the fridge.  The next morning, I cooked buns at 350 degrees for 30-40 minutes.  I put the icing container on top of the stove.  The stove wasn't on, but the heat from the oven warmed it up.  So when the bun were done, I poured the icing on.  It worked perfectly.  The only cream cheese I could find was fat free, but it was great that way.

text:
So I'm an electrician alright. I struggled to get the dough to rise. I don't have a bread machine and I think I used the wrong yeast because I struggled to get the dough to rise. After a little research I boiled some water, popped the pan in the oven with my dough, and got my dough to rise. This is my first real bread baking experience and even I couldn't make these turn out bad. Amazing texture and flavor. My wife even commented that these are the best homemade cinnamon rolls she's ever tasted. I'm very encouraged to keep trying this recipe and maybe even get a mixer. They might not be Clone of a Cinnabon but that's a sweet name nonetheless.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had made these for the first time a couple of night ago and here I am again making another batch, the first batch turned out amazing, I added a little more cinnamon like some had suggested but I didn't need to turn over the pan to recoat at all, I figure if you roll the dough up tight enough to begin with turning them over was unnecessary for me and I followed the recipe to a "T". I also used my kitchen aid mixer instead of a bread machine, I let it knead for about 4 min, and did a light knead before I placed the dough in a bowl lightly brushed with oil, I have a proof setting on my oven so I let it proof for an hour then rolled it out and assembled and cut then let it sit for 20 min in the oven again to proof a bit more then took it out while the oven preheated to 350 then baked for the suggested time...I will definitely be baking these cinnabons over and over again...hope this helped...thx for the great recipe...

These are great! I didn't make them in a bread machine. I just dumped everything together in a stand mixer and used the hook to knead the dough for a few minutes, then let it rise. I'm keeping this recipe and making it again soon.

country:
None
text:
These are incredible!!! my husband had 3 of them in a row, right out of the oven! Here is a tip to make them FAT FREE (courtesy of my sister in law): substitute apple sauce for butter; whenever the recipe calls for butter, subtitute 1/2 that amount for apple sauce (ie. 1 cup of butter= 1/2 cup applesauce). Also, when rolling out the dough, instead of spreading butter all over it, spray some PAM (nonstick cooking spray on the dough). You would never know they were fat free, they are truly incredible!!

text:
Absolutely divine.  So good that I had a friend pay for me to come from DC to Pittsburg so I could make these for his friends after they challenged his assertions about how good they are.    One thing that I found helpful is to increase the amount of cinnamon in the filling-- this makes it stick a bit better and gets you closer to the way real cinnabons are. Otherwise the filling tends to run right out to the bottom.

text:
The only thing i didnt like about this was the frosting. It was way too sweet and not tart enough to taste like the real thing. I even doubled the cream cheese to try to cut the sweetness but it didnt help.. On a second run, i used an 8 oz block of cream cheese with only 1 cup of powdered sugar plus the rest of the icing ingredients as written in the recipe and it was much closer to the icing served on the rolls at cinnabon. i would suggest to  the sugar a little at a time and taste as you go, stopping once you get to the right consistency and flavor for your taste prefrence. Aside from that, the rolls were spot on!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are wonderful!  The first time I made these, I made the mistake of punching down the dough and letting it rise again.  Oops.  However, they still came out wonderful.  The second time I made these, the texture was much better because I didn't punch it down and let it rise again.  I followed the directions the second time regarding rising.  They're great with or without frosting; they're great with or without nuts (walnuts or pecans).  We love these!  I'm going to use this recipe to make cinnamon bread, too.    Outstanding!  Simply, outstanding!  Very minor changes that I made: I used a glass dish; I added a tablespoon of Gluten to the bread part; I doubled the amount of cinnamon (it needs a bite or zing); I doubled the amount of the filling; I made the paste mixture for the filling; I added a teaspoon of vanilla to the filling; I used olive oil instead of butter (but butter works) in the bread part, not the filling part.  

USE DARK BROWN SUGAR!
USE GLASS BAKING DISH!
BAKE AT 350 FOR 20 TO 25 MINUTES!
DBL FILLING
DBL FROSTING (OR NOT)
ADD EXTRA CINNAMON FOR A BITE

text:
These were Amazing.  I followed the other reviews for making this in a Stand mixer since I don't have a bread machine.  The only problem I had was that 15 minutes was not enough time in the oven.  The buns looked golden brown but they where still doughy on the inside so I had to bake them an extra 15-20 minutes after they were iced.  The icing recipe makes more then enough.  One tip is to follow the proofing directions on the package of yeast.  I also let my dough rise in a 200 degree oven that was turned off and then let them sit in the fridge overnight.  These should be called 'Better then Cinnabon' because not only are they easy to make but they save you a ton of money :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous cinnamon rolls. I do not have a bread machine so I made these by hand. I found out that I needed a bit more flour than was called for in the recipe. I followed the recipe exactly and the only addition I made was to add grated orange peel to the dough. I wanted an orange cinnamon bun and used this site's orange cream cheese frosting, which was delicious. I followed the advice and put the dough in a warmed oven to rise (I only warmed to 100 degrees for a few seconds and that was enough to make the dough double in size; I did not want to kill the yeast with too much heat). I also made the paste out of the butter, sugar,and cinnamon and added 1 TBSP of flour to the paste and had no trouble with the filling coming out. Some of the cooks have complained about the buns getting too hard, but as soon as mine came out of the oven, I tented them with a piece of foil and left the foil on for fifteen minutes then frosted the warm rolls. It is several hours later and the rolls are still soft and yummy. This is a wonderful recipe and deserves more stars than 5!

text:
AMAZING! I've never made any type of bread before so I was pleased when I tasted this. I don't have a bread machine so I did it all by hand. This does take a big part of the day but that's only because you have to let it rise a few times. I did mix the cinnamon/sugar with the butter and spread it on the dough. I didn't have to flip the pan over afterwards...maybe it was because I mixed the sugar and butter? I also put the dough in a 200 degree oven shut off for an hour covered to rise like other people have mentioned and it worked well. I doubled the icing but I didn't need the extra...the icing is SO sweet...a little goes a long way. This is a great recipie and I will definitely make it again when I have the time!

text:
This recipe turned out great, even though I did it a little differently.  I loved that the dough was made in the bread machine.  I put the ingredients in and it made the dough while I went grocery shopping.  It was easy to put together after I took it out of the bread machine and rolled  and cut the rolls.  At this point, I did it a little differently.  They were suppose to rise 30 minutes and then bake.  It was late and I needed to go to bed, so I covered the pan and put them in the frig.  When I got up the next morning, I laid them out on the counter for abour 30 minutes then put them in the oven with the light on and a bowl of hot steaming water and they rose perfectly.  It did take longer than the 30 minutes it would have taken had i not put them in the frig, but they turned out well anyway.  I let them rise about and hour and forty five minutes in all.  They tasted great and they were not that hard to make.  I recommend this recipe and would make it again.

I made these to send with my husband to work, but only half of them made it there! They are some of the best cinnamon rolls I have ever had!   I loved the icing, but my husband likes more of a glaze than actual icing on his cinnamon rolls. It was more of a glaze as he liked, and more of it "soaked in" the rolls. But I thought they were amazing without any tweaking!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these by hand as I don't have a bread machine. I first dissolved the yeast in the warm milk and a little bit of sugar. For the dough, since I don't use margarine, I used butter. I mixed the butter, salt and eggs then mixed that with the milk/yeast and finally mixed in the flour. While the dough was rising I mixed the softened butter, brown sugar and cinnamon into a paste and then spread that on the rolled dough for an even coating. I then baked as the directions indicated. For me cooking for 15 minutes at 400 wasn't enough, they weren't cooked all the way through and had to put them back in the oven, which I turned off, for about 10 more minutes. I had no issues with the filling running so there was no need to flip the pan over. Overall the taste was okay. It certainly wasn't what I was looking for. I found the brown sugar taste to be too overpowering and the cinnamon didn't come through enough. Between the batter, the filling and the icing there was too strong of a butter flavor and it made me feel sick afterward. With some tweaking these could be great, but then it wouldn't be the same recipe.

good stuff. I had to seal the bottoms so they dont lick. They burn easily. I took someone's advise and froze 4 rolls. I will never froze them again, but I will defiantly bake them fresh.

userID:
674114
Display Name:
The Bunny Chef
isPro:

85

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls are great!  I don't have a bread machine so made the dough in my Kitchenaid mixer.  Let the yeast (1 .25 oz packet equals about 2 1/2 t) proof in the warm milk with about 2 T of the sugar for 10 minutes, stirred in the melted butter (but cooled slightly so it wouldn't kill the yeast or cook the eggs), eggs, the rest of the sugar, and the salt.  Dumped in 3 cups of the flour, mixed it up with the dough hook (I'll actually try the flat beater for the first 3 C flour next time so it gets mixed up faster, then switch to the dough hook), then added enough additional flour so that the dough still stuck to my finger a little when I touched it (this results in a soft dough that is perfect for cinnamon rolls).  Let it knead on the second from lowest speed for 8 minutes, then continued with the recipe as stated, rolling the dough out on 2 pieces of lightly floured waxed paper that I overlapped slightly and taped the bottom of :)  My only changes were that I only used 1 1/2 T cinnamon (I was nervous of 2 1/2 T even though I love it), accidentally left out the salt in the frosting and only used 1/4 t of vanilla.  I'm VERY pleased with the outcome of both the rolls and the frosting!  It only needs a couple of tweaks to be perfect- for example, next time I'm going to try mixing together the softened butter, sugar and cinnamon, then spread it on the dough rectangle so it's neater and easier to distribute perfectly.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I have made these twice now and they are wonderful... they really do taste like they were bought from a professional bakery. I also didn't have any trouble burning or icing running to the bottom, but I also cut back on the sugar/butter because I can only imagine how fattening these are! My only complaints are that after about 6 hours, even wrapped tightly, these start getting very dry and hard and are pretty much rocks by the next day, so they're almost impossible to save. I even tried freezing them and they were okay immediately after heating back up, but then back to rock. Also, the margarine gives them a very processed taste, and I have cut it back as well with no bad results. Thanks!

text:
I wanted this to come out 5 stars so bad I even tried twice!   Ok, here's what happened, I don't have a bread machine, so I followed the other suggestions and made it myself, I also allowed it to sit overnight in the fridge and then put them in a cold oven at 350*, here's where I think I went wrong. After 30 min, they didn't look brown and the inside looked too gooey so I turned off the over and allowed them to sit in there for several more minutes. This was my mistake because both times this happened and both times they were too done. I guess I might try again because this is such a highly rated recipe I want to experience the ooey gooey goodness that everyone claims comes from this recipe but it migh just be one of those things you have to perfect. Also flipping the cinnamon rolls over right out of the oven was probably one of the saving graces because it does coat the rolls agains with all the good stuff. If I try again I will either follow the instructions for baking exactly or take them out when they look too gooey and see what happens then.   My advice is read the other reviews and don't bake too long even if they don't look browned.

userID:
4479891
Display Name:
JHolt
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/392761.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Try melting the butter, adding the brown sugar and cinnamon mixture then spreading on the rolled out dough. I use a spatula to smear it around, works so much better than dry ingredients dropping everywhere (maybe I am just a messy cook?).  Also I cut the dough with a pizza slicer into 1 1/2 inch by 8 inch strips and roll individually not the whole dental floss gig..that never has worked for me (again maybe I am just a bad cook). Also I use a KITCHEN AID MIXER on the STIR level with a dough hook to mix it. I do use the bread machine (SAF instant yeast) with flour then add the milk in as the first step. Then let it rest for 10 minutes then add the rest of the ingredients (already combined in a separate bowl) and mix until the dough looks sticky and butter/sugar mix is distributed. (Sticky dough good, beat down tough dough bad)  I use two 9 x 13 casserole pans and put 12 in each  lined with wax paper so as soon as they come out I flip them onto a wax paper lined cookie sheet and peel of the wax paper (easy clean up). Make sure to roll the dough out thin enough (I like 1/4 inch) or else when it does its second rise you get really big rolls that pop the centers out as they cook. These are DELICIOUS!!! But if you are not good at making dough, practice! You need to let it rise enough to get the light airy soft texture that makes the Cinnabon famous. Also I like the Whipped Cream Cheese Frosting from this site better..the one listed is ordinary, not spectacular like Cinnabon.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls were so good.  I don't have a bread machine, so I substituted an 8 gram pack of dry active yeast for the bread machine yeast. Then kneaded the dough by hand.  The first time I made them, the dough tasted wonderful, but the rolls were too dense.   So, the second time I made them I decided to let the dough rise twice--once in the bowl, and after punching it down, rolling out and assembling the rolls, I let it/them rise again.  Because I like lots of filling, I increased the butter and sugar that I spread on the sheet of rolled out dough. If you do this, be careful not to put in too much, so that filling doesn't end up sticking to the bottom of the pan.  These were some of the best cinnamon rolls that I have ever eaten. For Real!

text:
Yum!! Great recipe and pretty easy, I thought.  I made mine dairy free for my son, substituting rice milk for the milk and vegan soy butter for the margarine and they taste just like any other cinnamon bun I've had.  I made the frosting as the recipe said to and made a separate one of soy butter, confectioner's sugar, and vanilla for my son.  The cream cheese frosting was good, but I might try to find one that I like a little more (I thought the cream cheese taste was a little strong).  Overall though, I'll make this one again and again!  Thank you so much!

The rolls were swimming and I had to scrap most of the excess icing off.  They were still a hit because they are just too darn yummy. Next time I'll use the amount of icing the recipe calls for.  What a great recipe, thanks!!!!
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4757232
Display Name:
pettyak
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe. I've made it many times but have made the following changes: 1. I used 1/2 a cup of water and 1/2 c of milk, instead of the full 1 cup of milk. I use the water at 110 degrees and add the yeast to it with a big pinch of sugar, mix the yeast in thoroughly, NO chunks, and let it froth. I heat the milk as directed in the recipe. I find that doing this, the dough rises better.  2. I NEVER use the full amount of flour the recipe calls for. I gradually add the flour until the dough creates a ball, but still sticks slightly to your fingers.  Knead until elastic.  3. I let the dough proof until it truly is DOUBLED.  This may vary in time depending on where you live/ temp.  4. I create a caramel glaze to go on the bottom of the baking pan, in place of having a frosting (which can be too rich). You simply melt 1/2 c butter. Whisk in 1/2 c brown sugar until fully combined. Pour into baking pan and spread evenly. Roll up the dough with the softened butter and cinn. sugar mixture, and cut into 12 pieces.  Space evenly on pan.  Let proof until they just start touching. Bake. I suggest placing foil on the bottom of your oven; the glaze can make a mess.  5.  Once golden, remove the cinn rolls from oven, and invert the rolls onto another surface to let the glaze ooze back into the rolls.  **always warm before eating, its better this way!

This is one of the BEST recipes for cinnamon rolls I've made. I've never written a review but I had to make an exception for this recipe. Thanks to the first 2 reviews listed I followed the suggestions. I made the dough in my mixer. The only thing I will do different next time is decrease the amount of sugar in the dough to 1/3 C. I live in the SW so I'll chill my filling a bit and cut using non-flavored floss a little faster next time to avoid the filling from seeping out. My husband loved it. Will definitely make again. Thanks marsha!

text:
fabulous cinnamon roll recipe that everyone will rave about. I didn't use bread flour and they still turned out perfectly. Mine were a little too doughy in the center so next time I will bake them a couple more minutes. I was afraid they would be overdone because they were very golden on top, but they weren't.  I also flipped them over onto a serving tray and then iced them. This is definitely the way to go. The golden tops (now bottoms) soften by being on the bottom and the gooey bottoms (now tops) mix with the frosting and create deliciousness!

text:
Very sweet and moist.  I recommend using about 1T less butter in the bread batter and a full teaspoon of vanilla in the frosting (this will make the frosting a bit more flavorful and smooth.  When making the brown sugar filling the amounts in this recipe created way more filling than necessary and caused much of the filling to run out of the cinnabon, so I would suggest easing up on the butter by a tablespoon or two in order to keep it a bit thicker but still just as sweet and rich.

text:
I tried this recipe because I have been looking for a good recipe for cinnamon rolls.  Every recipe I tried before this the bread was always off either by being to hard or not tasting good.  The bread for this recipe was exactly what I was looking for.  It is soft and has a good flavor.  However I did change the filling to 1/2 cup of butter and 3 tsp of cinnamon.  When they are done baking turn the pan upside down on a jelly roll pan for about five minutes and the filling stays put.  They got a lot of rave reviews from all the people I baked them for.  Thank you.  hvirch.

text:
Quite tasty; not as gooey as a "cinnabon" (even by inverting & adding more brown sugar & cinn to filling) but ok by me:)  For more "goo," probably just need to add more butter, brown sugar, & cinnamon to filling.  Let rise in warm oven then just turn oven on to bake while they're in there to ease things up a bit.  To get eggs fresh from the fridge to room temp quick, just make the milk a bit warmer than needed- just be sure not too hot to kill yeast!  Used butter in lieu of marg.  Yum!

text:
Made these 5 or 6 times already and they are AWESOME!!!!! Thanks for this super easy and show-stopping recipie. I used the breadmaker and make an extra batch of icing as someone else suggested. I freeze the icing and use it for the next batch of buns. The texture is different, but just needs a drop or two of milk and to be wipped up, then it's as good as new. The buns have yet made it to the freezer - they're gone too fast! I have made the buns all up the night before and then cooked them the next day. They take a little longer to rise, but have worked out just as good. HINT: Don't over cook them or they won't taste like Cinnabon buns...but still are very good anyway! LOVE THIS RECIPIE!!

text:
These turned out very good.  I did not use my bread maker..used my stand mixer.  I proofed my yeast with the warm milk and 1 tsb of the sugar. I put all the ingrdients in the mixer except the flour and mixed with flat paddle.  I added the flour until a dough started to form and then put my dough hook on and mixed at 2 for 2 minutes.  I did not use "BREAD" flour, I used "ALL PURPOSE" flour and added 3 TBS of vital wheat glutin.  This turned out very good!  I will make again but double the recipe as it is time consuming.

userID:
683514
Display Name:
giggletush
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/254158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG... THESE WERE FANTASTIC!!! It deserves 10 stars!!! And I'm a HUGE Cinnabon fan! My husband was scrapping his plate to get every last bit of the cinnamon goo, he doesn't even do that w/ cinnabons. I used the exact ingredients the recipe called for but I didn't use a bread machine. It was easy to make using my kitchenaid mixer. I added the sugar and milk and stirred to dissolve than added the yeast and let proof, about 5 mins. Than I added the melted butter and eggs and mixed while adding the salt and flour, one cup at a time, till well blended. Than I used my Kitchenaid dough hook and mixed on low for about 7 mins to knead. I put the dough in a bowl, covered w/ a damp cloth and I put that in my oven (oven was off) and I let that rise for about an hour. I also took the suggestion to mixed the butter, cinnamon and sugar before adding to the rolled out dough, I just pressed the mixture into the dough before I rolled it up. I used dental floss to cut the rolls which worked PERFECTLY! I drive 45 mins to get my Cinnabon "fix" a couple of times a year and I actually think I like these better. The dough has a nice sweetness to it, cinnamon mixture was perfectly gooey and tasted devine, the cream cheese frosting I could of eaten all by itself and it wasn't as filling/heavy as a cinnabon is. My kids and husband told me that I HAVE to make these more often! These are Definatly my new favorite dessert! THANKS!!!

text:
This recipe is fabulous! I made dough by hand, other than that followed recipe exactly. This is the best cinnamon roll I have ever had! I did make 15 rolls from the dough.....really big rolls! I used two pans, placing 9 in one and 6 in the other to give the rolls room to rise and spread. Worked perfectly. Also I Iet the rolls rise overnight in my refridgerator and baked in the morning. I recommend letting the rolls sit for about 5 minutes before inverting the pan. Let rolls sit for another 5 minutes before putting the pan right side up. Then frost. I used disposable pans so I didn't have any clean-up. Thank you for a wonderful and easy recipe. This is my go-to recipe from now on!

text:
I have made this recipe many times now & it never fails me. I get proofed dough from my local grocery store so it makes these super simple. I've found if you melt the butter and use it to mix the brown sugar and cinnamon in a paste then spread on dough your mix will stay in place. Also take the time to make your own frosting. The few minutes it takes to mix as directed here is WAY better than buying from the tub.  My husband says these are not a clone of cinnabon they are better!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these last Saturday for my family.  My dad love cinnamon rolls and he said these were the best he'd ever tasted; even better than cinnabon (he thinks theirs are a bit too sweet).  I added a little extra butter on the top of the rolls when I got them in the pan and I also used all purpose flour instead of the bread flour.  I think I ended up using betweem 5 1/4 to 5 1/2 c flour total.  Came out fantastically...Don't forget to flip the pan!!!  I almost didn't and then realized that i could just use a cookie sheet to flip them on to and did it.  Everyone was out and about wanting one.  Tasted fantastic (and the frosting tastes just like the stuff from cinnabon) and even gave the house a nice smell; if only for a night.  Considering making these once a month or on special occasions.  Loved them and thanks for the recipe.

These are perfect cinnamin rolls. so easy with the bread machine too. I poked toothpicks through the individual rolls before placing them on the baking sheet to rise then bake. This prevents them from unrolling as they rise and bake. Also, the frosting recipe needs to be doubled. It only frosted 10 out of the 12 rolls.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUMMY!!! My family loves these, we live in AK and not a cinnabon anywehere around us. I have made 2 times now both times I followed someones review to make the night ahead all the way to the point of them of putting them in the pan to rise and than I cover them with plastic wrap and put in the fridge overnight. In the morning I put them in straight from the fridge to the oven THAN start preheating and baking. Mine finish in about 20 minutes though, I keep a eye on them. I double the frosting cause I love frostng. Double makes to much but I save it for next time in the freezer. As soon as the come out of the over I turn over to get them out of the pan and turn over again so they are on their bottoms. That way they get out of the pan and still have their filling. Loved them! Will ALWAYS make these as my cinnamon rolls!

text:
I made these cinnamon rolls last night, and despite operator error these turned out great!  I did tweak it by using only 4 cups flour (2 c. bread flour & 2 c. ap flour), and reduced the sugar in the dough to 1/4 c.  My hubby does not like cream cheese frosting so used a basic powedered sugar icing which I added a tablespoon or so of maple syrup.  Baked 6 and froze 6.  Turned out awesome-great with a cup of coffee for a mid-morning snack.

text:
I've made this a couple of times now, and it always gets many compliments, even though I've never made it with the frosting. I found that the rolls were too sweet for my liking, so I cut down the sugar by about 1/4 cup and added 3 tbsp of cinnamon powder instead of 2.5.  Do remember that it is important you roll the dough tightly to prevent the filling from leaking out as much as possible. Also, a nice idea for beautifully shaped rolls is to let them rise in a muffin cup, so it rises nice and round. Enjoy!

text:
Amazing!  I substituted 2 cups AP flour and 2.5 cups whole wheat flour for the bread flour.  I used a sifter to evenly coat the buttered dough surface, and they came out great!  I'm not usually good with anything involving yeast, but this was a success the first time around (I had a bread machine to help).  For the second rising after the buns are assembled, I heated the oven to 200*F and turned it off as per another reviewer's suggestion.  True to its title, this recipe *is* a clone!  I live alone and can't eat 12 by myself, but there will be some very lucky clerks at the 24/7 convenience store tonight!

Janene

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/101873.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to make these two times. the first batch weren't as good as the second. The second batch I added 1 more tsp. of yeast as it didn't seem to proof well enough with just 2 1/2. I didn't use a bread machine; just regular flour and yeast. I proofed it and then put the dough in a warming dwarer at 100 degrees to proof. The dough rose beautifully! I also added a small box of vanilla pudding (that's the secret to my grandma's cinnamon rolls which I have made for years.  I ended up putting 1/2 T. more cinnamon in the filling mix as well for a more cinnamon than sugar flavor.  Also, added 1/2 c. powdered sugar to the icing to make it a little sweeter.  This isn't a low-fat recipe but let's be honest, if you are looking for low fat, cinnamon rolls aren't the recipe to make!! :)

text:
Superb cinnamon rolls!  Very close to Cinnabon in my opinion.  My husband and I loved them.  This is will be a new tradition in my house.  Like many others, I don't have a bread machine and made them by hand.  For the filling, I mixed the brown sugar, cinnamon, and butter together before spreading the mixture on to the dough.  I had no problems with it dripping out of the rolls after baking and did not need to invert the pan when done.  Thank you, Marsha, for a great recipe!

text:
This recipe is amazing!  My family was eating them as fast as they came out of the oven!  I added some more cinnamon to the recipe because we love the taste.  Otherwise I changed very little.  I also made the dough without a machine.  I mixed all the ingredients then slowly added the flour.  I kneaded the dough for about 8-10 minutes, then let it rise for an hour.  Also, after they have cooked, if you take a spatula and flip the cinnabon off the pan, you can keep much of the brown sugar mixture on the cinnabon and off the cookie sheet.

text:
I made this without a bread machine.  I added a regular packet of yeast to the milk and let it sit for about 10 minutes before mixing the first batch of ingredients.  I let the dough sit in the microwave oven for about 3.5 hours to double in size.  I mixed the butter, brown sugar, and cinnamin together like other reviewers.  Next time I'll do butter alone then sprinkle the topping.  The bread kept pulling out of shape while trying to spead evenly.  Doubled in size withing 30 minutes and was slightly under baked in 15 minutes but I use a convection oven.  At first I thought their wasn't enough frosting but it was plenty when eating it!  My husband thought it was too much.  We loved the flavor though, I ate two and felt a little sick afterwards.  I'll freeze extras and hopefully they'll still taste good.

text:
I made this last night following the advice of other reviewers.  I did not have bread flour, so I used 1.5 cups wheat flour and 3 cups plain flour.  I do not have a bread maker. I warmed the oven to 200 degrees, turned it off, and let the dough sit in it.  Make sure you space them apart on the baking pan.  mine were spread about 2 inches apart and touched after they had risen the second time.  They turned out HUGE! My teenage brother who eats everything in sight was only able to eat one of them.  I will definitely make these again.
Review:

userID:
2066507
Display Name:
Mary F
isPro:

followersCount:

43
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/129062.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!!!  These rolls were surprisingly easy (with a bread machine) and so divine.  My only problem was rolling out the dough; it kept shrinking- which happens to me all the time.  Like other reviewers suggested, I softened the butter to mix with the cinnamon and brown sugar for easier spreading.  I baked them in a glass pan and redrizzled their juices on them.  I used 4 oz of cream cheese because I love the tang of it.  I baked at 350 for over 20 minutes.  Will definitely make again, these are so simple in the morning if you let them rise shaped in their covered pans.  I just have to make sure there are enough people around to eat them!  And to tumbleweedbarngirl- bread flour is fairly easy to find.  It is not from a specialty store and should be available at your local Walmart.  I wouldnt use all purpose, bread flour gives it an elasticity, etc more like bread.

text:
These were amazing! My whole family thought they tasted even better than Cinnabon. These are actually quite flexible. I accidentally peeled too many apples for an apple pie and decided to put those in here. The result? To die for gooey cinnamony apple pie in a cinnamon roll. Another way to add your own flare is to (once done, or the next day after it is baked) you can actually brush the bottom of the roll with melted butter and dip it in cinnamon sugar, microwave it, toast it a bit, and you get the perfect sticky buns. Just a thought. These were amazing though!

This recipe was ridicously good BUT I had to make this recipe twice. The first time I baked the rolls at 400 F and after 5 minutes they were completely burnt (like black and starting to smoke, it was REALLY bad). So the 2nd time, I baked them at 350 F for 20 minutes and they were perfect. I would recommend this recipe to everyone!

text:
Simply delicious! The only thing I found was the buns were really heavy and dense making them by hand so I only used 4 cups of flour (used all purpose unbleached flour) and they came out lighter. That was my only change, however either way, the taste was heavenly!!! Cinnabon has nothing on these homemade yummies! Thanks Marsha! **UPDATE** I now make these in my bread maker still using the changes I made earlier and they come out sooooo light and fluffy!! Simply divine!!

text:
I was scared to make these because I had simply never tried before. I did use my bread machine. Dough was a wonderful soft smooth mixture. I followed the recipe exactly. No problems. Once the rolls were sliced and placed in the pan for the last 30 minute rise, they didnt double like the recipe suggested. So, I left them for about 45 minutes and then couldnt wait any longer to put them in the oven. They baked up wonderful. Taste wonderful. Great recipe. Fun to make if you have some time on a weekend.

text:
I let these sit in the fridge overnite and then cooked them at 400 like someone else suggested.  However, they were not completly done inside.  If I had let them come to room temp. FIRST then it would have worked, but my kids were too hungry to wait!  I am putting them back in the oven(covered)and will see how this turns out since I already have the frosting on them! :(  Also, the last time I made these they seemed a bit dry in the middle.  So I melted the butter that goes in the filling and this seemed to help for some reason.  One more thing:  I didn't have all bread flour so I used just about half and half and the dough was still great!

text:
My husband and co-workers raved about these and my husband wants me to make another batch already. I skipped the butter in the frosting and reduced the amount of powdered sugar and was able to cut back a little on the filling. I made 20 good sized rolls, if you are worried about the calories that will help. I will try adding raisins and pecans to the filling on my next batch. I loved these because they are super soft throughout and my old recipe was always tough on top. Thanks for sharing the great recipe!

text:
These are WONDERFUL!  I did what others suggested and turned them out and left them upside-down for a few mins so that the filling is even, and the smell that wafts up and hits you when you peel the baking paper off the bottom of them is DIVINE!  I always line pans with baking paper for these sorts of things as well as for cakes and cookies. I also put the frosting into a plastic sauce/ketchup bottle and zig-zag it over the top, it looks better than when I try to do that with a spoon. Even though people around me know I can cook, they are always surprised when they see that I've baked these, and then they taste them...Mmmmmmm.  I haven't made them for a while, but I'm thinking of them and can't come up with the right words to describe how fantastic they are as the thought of them is impairing my ability to access anymore words than I have used to write this review!!  They're sooo good, give them a go.  Thanks for the recipe!

These are excellent and the best cinnamon rolls I've ever had.  I heeded some earlier advice to use a glass 9x13 pan and transfer them to a cooling rack immediately after taking them out of the oven (parchment paper made that really easy). I will definitely make these again.  Thanks!

text:
I've made these many times as the recipe was written.  Tried 2 suggestions on yesterday's batch - mixing the butter/sugar/cinnamon ingrediants together before spreading on the dough, and baking at 350 for 30 min instead of 400 degrees.  I have to say, they turned out much better.  The filling was a much more carmelized, and I didn't have trouble with the outside buns getting really dark while the inside ones were barely cooked.  I'm making these changes permanent!  This recipe is also great with raisins added to the dough.

text:
Clone of a RAW Cinnabon perhaps!  15 minutes at 400 degrees is not adequate to bake these.  They were baked on the outside, mostly raw dough on the inside. NO, there is nothing wrong with my oven temp. Unfortunately we realized after frosting that they were severely under cooked.  Tried baking longer but the center would not setup.  They probably would bake better at a lower temp for more time.  Also, they were ultra sweet (too much sugar) and cinnamony (only used 2T.) Frosting is awesome however.  Recipe could be tweaked, but not worth the labor intensive work. Kids say they prefer the Pillsbury kind - say no more.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1072476
Display Name:
Tara S
isPro:

followersCount:
0

28
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is well deserving of all five stars.  These are absolutely heavenly!!!!   I don't have a bread machine so I proofed my yeast and kneaded in my stand mixer & by hand.  I put the warm milk in the mixing bowl, dissolved in the yeast packet.  I added about a tablespoon of the 1/4 cup of sugar to the yeast & milk and let that sit for about 10 minutes.  Then I added in the other dough ingredients.    For the filling, I mixed the soft butter, brown sugar & cinnamon all together and I rubbed it on the rolled out dough using my fingers.    I made these the dough the night before & cooked in the morning for breakfast.  Once I rolled the dough & sliced the individual rolls, I placed them in the baking dish, covered with plastic wrap and put it in the fridge.  In the morning, I put them in the cold oven, turned the oven to 350 and set the timer for 30 mins.  I took them out & they were perfect.  PERFECT!!!  I made the icing while they were cooking and slathered the icing on the hot rolls and they turned out wonderfully! I will be making these again & again.

country:
None
text:
EASY!! Even my youngest son helped! I never made cinnamon buns before (last week was the first time I made bread from scratch), Didn't use a bread machine instead I kneaded the dough for 8 minutes with the kitchen aid mixer.I followed other reviewers advice by letting the dough rise in the oven by turning oven on to 100 degrees and then turning it off,The only other thing I did different was sweeten the icing by using a little more butter,vanilla and confectioners sugar to suit the taste buds of my youngest son,( The cinnamon bun expert). I froze eight of them and put the other four in the refrigerator over night, In the morning I baked them at 350 for 25 minutes.I would definitely recommend this recipe it truly is a clone of a Cinnabon.

text:
I've been making this recipe for the past couple of years, and everyone I make it for just loves them!    I followed the advice for making without the bread machine, and  it is still a very fast recipe- so easy!!  The tip about flipping them out of the pan and turning them upside down as soon as them come from the oven is key.  That way, all of the  cinnamon mixture stays within the buns, rather than pooling on the bottom.  The best cinnamon rolls  I've ever made!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Truly the best I've ever tasted.  I have made this recipe a few times now and my husband can't stop eating them.  Now I make a batch and freeze half right away.  I also took the advise of another review to divide the icing and freeze wrapped in small portions.  Makes it easy when you are re heating one at a time.  This way if you want more icing you always have.  I mixed my dough in the breadmaker, when done I remove and let rise, then roll out and follow the rest of the recipe.  Once they are cut and lined up in the pan let double in size before putting in oven.  I put in oven at 350 for just about 30 mins.  They come out much better (not guey in the center) but light fluffy and oozing with the melting of cinnamon and brown sugar. I let sit for a few minutes then spread on the icing and let it melt over.  The icing recipe is enough to lightly spread and save some for freezing. These are better then CINNABON bar far! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I made these for Valentines Day breakfast!  Yummy!!  I took advice from another reviewer and made these the night before and put them in the greased pyrex dish in the fridge.  Took them out in the morning and popped them in the oven.  I also mixed the butter, brownsugar and cinnamon together it was much easier to spread on the dough- I added a 1/2 cup of chopped walnuts which were excellent- my husband and son loved them!  They do need to be cooked for more than 15 mintues more like 20-25 mins.They started to get brown quickly so I tented them with foil to keep them a golden brown and from getting too dark!  I will definately make these again- fun to make with my son who is 3 years old!!

text:
How can i possibly say anything more about this fantastic recipe? I followed another reviewers suggestion to cook on a pizza stone and it worked great. The bottom stayed soft and light. Just leave space between each one on the stone to allow for the second rising. The twelve rolls covered the entire stone when they were done rising. I was afraid that some of the cinnamon mixture may drip off the stone while baking so i covered the lower oven rack with tin foil and it did drip but just barely. I also mixed the butter in with the cinnamon/sugar as others did but next time i won't because i found it difficult to spread. It kind of clumped. I have never had a cinnabon but these are sooooo good!

text:
OHHH MYYYY GOOSSHH!  To die for and tastes just like Cinnabon.  I also did not have a bread machine so I used a packet of the quick rise yeast dissolved in warm milk with the sugar (let set for 5 min. and foamy).  I also added Vital Wheat Gluten to accomodate for not having bread flour (1 Tbls per cup of All-Purpose) which I think made a huge difference in the texture.  I also added about 1/2 cup whole grain pastry flour since I like to sneak in whole wheat when I can and couldn't even tell the difference.  This recipe is so awesome!!

text:
Very good cinnamon buns.  I didn't use a bread machine, I used my KitchenAid mixer with dough hook attachment.  Worked extremely well.  I used 2 active yeast packets instead of the bread yeast that the recipe called for.  Made the dough, left it rise for 1 hour in my warmed oven. Rolled it out and cut it into slices.  Baked at 350 for 19 minutes.  I flipped the pan into another 9X13 like the one reviewer did, to prevent the cinnamon mixture from running out.  Worked well.  Then I used a double batch of the glaze/icing on top.  Very good, time consuming to make, but well worth it.

Display Name:
Taunte Sara

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/170166.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was very pleased with how soft the dough stayed even a day or two later. I always have trouble with my sweet rolls drying out so this dough recipe will definately stay in my files for other uses. I don't have a bread machine and used the quick-rising yeast version by hand. I mixed the butter, sugar and cinnamon together as suggested in another review and found it worked very well. I would maybe increase the sugar by 1/4 cup and the butter as well but decrease the cinnamon! I used 1 1/2 Tbsp but it was still a little too strong. Since I use a high-grade cinnamon I may bring it down to only 1/2 Tbsp or 1 at the most next time. The strength of the cinnamon will depend on the brand you use. Regular in-store brands are not as strong. Watkins, Pampered Chef and Epicure Selections are all more potent and you don't need to use as much.

text:
My only tip--they seemed much better when the icing was fully melted.  When I made them I let them cool a bit before spreading the icing, and they just didn't taste right.  However, we had lots of leftovers and after I heated them in the microwave and the icing was fully melted, they tasted much better.  Personally, I thought they got better each time--ie. they make great leftovers!

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe at least 6 times.  I follow the recipe exactly.  They always come out absolutely perfect.  Everybody is always so impressed by them!  This is truly a 5 star recipe!  I was going to make these again because my family loves them so much but I ran out of brown sugar!  I replaced the brown sugar with white sugar and the cinnamon with orange zest.  Oooh these are yummy too!  I also added a small amount maybe a few tbs. of orange juice to the frosting and this was a great variation to this recipe!  Also, as another person mentioned while rating, I don't have much problem with the filling ever leaking out either and I also think it's because I roll the dough until it's about 7 turns.  I do this by kinda stretching it a little while rolling and then paying extra attention to the ends, making sure they don't get too distorted looking.  The end rolls are never perfect.  I suggest eating them yourself... a little sample for the cook!

text:
Oh my goodness! This is the best recipe I have tried in years. It really tastes like cinnabon. Even better in my opinion.
I cut the recipe in half. (I didn
't need so much, and have a small bread machine.) I made 8 rolls instead of 6, to fit a long oblong pan I have. 
     I mixed it in an old bread machine on the "manual" cycle, then turned off the machine and let it double in size. 
      I didn't have bread flour so I used all purpose flour, with 1/4 c of whole wheat flour. 
      The buttery creamcheese frosting is to die for. 
       Thank you for posting

text:
Believe all of the reviews!  I followed others who didn't use a bread maker.  I proofed the yeast in 1/2 cup milk for 10 minutes.  I then added the remaining milk and other ingredients and used my Kitchenaid to knead.  Also, if rising takes a long time, use a glass bowl, not melamine or plastic.  I tried a few times with both and it was always faster for me with a glass bowl. Enjoy, you will love these!

text:
These were excellent (though not the same as a Cinnabon). I made these on Christmas Eve for our family to have on Christmas morning. We just warmed them in the microwave, and they were perfect. What I love about this recipe is the dough itself (often, it's the icing &/or filling that MAKES the bun). But the dough in this recipe is rich and flavorful. These are "substantial" buns - filling and very satifying. I would not double the icing recipe (I did and there was just too much left over), but I would make a recipe and a half. Also, I followed the instructions from another reviewer to make these by hand, and it worked perfectly. I will be using this recipe for cinnamon buns from now on. Thank you!

You can put these buns in the fridge overnight, and then pop them in the oven the next morning.  Also, my oven gets too hot on the bottom, so I put my baking pan on top of another one so that I had double insulation on the bottom and they baked perfectly!  I'm trying them this morning with some raisins mixed in with the dough, like a raisin bread cinnabon.  Sounds yummy, we'll have to see!  Super great recipe!! I'm so glad it was shared.

Perfect! Followed the recipe ingredients exactly. I kneaded the dough myself and let it rise, rolled it into cinnamon rolls and left it in the fridge overnight. Took them out in the morning to rise and baked! Perfecto! I doubled the icing recipe but found my guests liked them plain almost as well. I did line my baking pan with parchment paper and inverted the rolls onto a serving platter after baking. Will definitely make again and again.

text:
I'm sure this recipe doesn't need another 5 star rating, but it sure deserves it!  I've made this for our Christmas morning breakfast for the last 3 years and it's definitely become a tradition.  Since the bread machine does all the hard work, it's a pretty easy recipe.  I actually do all the steps up to the baking step the night before, and let the rolls rise in the pan overnight - then just pop into the oven first thing in the morning and you have restaurant quality cinnamon rolls.  One day, I would like to play with adding some flavoring to the frosting, maybe some orange liquor in lieu of vanilla extract...

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So perfect!  I don't have a bread machine, so I used my 30-year-old Sunbeam.  I put a dash of the sugar into the milk to proof the yeast.  When I mix the dough, I add all the sugar, two cups of the flour, and the salt to the wet mixture; I mix it thoroughly before I add the rest of the flour.  I use AP flour, dry active yeast in the same proportions as the recipe calls for.  When I roll them out, I flour my granite countertop; I rub about 1/2 teaspoon of flour on wax paper to roll them out on top.  Works like a charm.  This time I made them yesterday afternoon, refrigerated the dough, and baked them this morning.  Next time I'll try a lower temp and longer cooking time.  But no matter what I've done to these, they always turn out great.  Thanks for the recipe!  EDIT 5/10/15  I wrote that review a long time ago!  Now I prepare the dough in my Kitchenaid, and I roll them out on Silpat or parchment.  Baking them at 375 for 23 minutes gives me a perfect cinnamon roll!

text:
Delicious! Gets lots of raves from adults and children alike. Two recommendations for improvement though. If you're making the rolls by hand (not in a bread machine), don't put in all 4 1/2 cups of flour right away. Put in 3, then add a little at a time until you get the dough the way you like it. Otherwise, I think it's too dry. Also, the recipe calls for a little too much cinnamon for my taste.

Oh and by the way some folks had said that they had trouble with the dough rising. When you have a sweet rich dough like this it can delay rising. Just give it a little extra time if need be. Thanks for sharing this great recipe!

text:
These were AWESOME!! I, too, had trouble with the dough rising, even put a desk lamp over the pan to give it alittle more warmth. Rolled it out and finished making the rolls and they, too, didn't raise as I thought they would. Baked them anyway, and they rose beautifully. My family loved them. This was my first attempt at cinnamon rolls, and I think I might have had the milk too warm for the yeast which may have caused the dough not to rise that much. Will make again because they were delicious. (Only thing I did differently was I didn't have any cream cheese for the icing, and just used butter, powdered sugar and added orange extract instead of vanilla...it was alittle thick so I added a Tbs or two of milk to make it easier to spread on rolls.) Thanks for sharing......
Revised 12-12-08...Made a second time, put the dough into the oven with my oven light on...was a warmer place to let dough rise, and it rose beautifully, even rolled out easier. Baked rolls were very light and soft...this is a real keeper...Thank You!!

city:

country:
None
text:
First, for the "high altitude" reviewer: I live in Colorado and never have a problem by following three rules: 1. Always use self rising flour, 2. Always use quick acting yeast, 3. Always let dough rise in a fairly warm oven. These did fine for me however 400 degrees was too hot for my oven. 350 degrees worked much better. The filling leaks out the bottom so be sure to invert your pan after taking them out of the oven. My rolls were done even in the middle and very tasty. I always use more filling than what any cinnamon roll recipe calls and I did here, too. My 14 yr. old says she still likes the recipe I usually use better, but these were good. The frosting is great but very rich and sweet.

text:
Wow! This is a wonderful recipe! I have to first start by saying that I am not a baker, I actually don't really like to bake so just the fact that these turned out at all is saying a lot about this recipe, I have had a ton of baking disasters. I do not have a bread machine so I scoured the reviews for helpful tips on making this with my kitchen aid stand mixer. I have to say these were not nearly as difficult as I had anticipated, the longest part is waiting for the dough to rise. I made these while my family was out of town for the weekend and when they came home these fresh, homemade cinnamon rolls were waiting for them. My husband tasted them and said "No way you made these, you went to Cinnabon and bought them" ! The kids loved them, I wish I had doubled the recipe because they were quickly devoured. Thanks so much for a great recipe, if I can make it and have it turn out, it is practically fool proof!

text:
OMG!!! These are so good, my family loves them. It took me a few try to get them right cause i don't have a bread machine and i really never made dough before. For the filling I put 2 cups of brown sugar and 4tbsp of cinnamon so that its more gooie. Instead of greasing the pan I melt 1/3 cup of butter in a pan and add half cup of ice cream and half cup of brown sugar. Bring to boil for 2 min. Pour the mixture on buttom of baking pan and put rolls on top. Cook it at 375 til they turn golden brown. The ice cream mixture give them a really good flavor. This recipe is a keeper!!

city:

country:

text:
WOW.  I am NOT a good cook, but I was THUROUGHLY impressed with this recipe and how it turned out.  My husband usually compliments me on my cooking (no matter how bad it is) but with this recipe, he wouldn't stop saying how much he loved it.  I was a bit concerned when it seemed the cinnabons didn't rise too much after I rolled them out and spread the cinnamon sugar, but I was thrilled when I opened the oven 15 minutes later and my apartment smelled just like the cinnabon store at the mall!  :)  We've decided to make this a traditional "special occasion" breakfast, and my husband says, "Isn't EVERY day a special occasion??"  THANKS FOR THIS RECIPE!  Gooey-ness note:  The one issue I have had with this recipe is that the rolls toward the center of the pan never seem to bake very well, resulting in OVERLY gooey cinnamon rolls which I don't mind, but some of my guests have not been thrilled with.  To combat this problem (and still get delightful results) I now divide the rolls into enough pans so that there is space around each roll so that the oven air gets around every roll and everything is more evenly baked.  It doesn't look as pretty coming out of the oven, but they are more satisfactory to my dough-hating friends.  :)

text:
This was my first attempt at homemade cinnamon rolls.  I followed the recipe, except for the filling.  I combined the butter with the brown sugar and cinnamon and spread it on the dough.  It was a little tricky to spread, but I saw all the comments that the goo melted to the bottom of the dish.  By combining the butter with the brown sugar and cinnamon, I had NO GOO on the bottom of my pan and they taste wonderful.  They are pretty rich so I can only eat a few bites but I will make them again.

text:
This was really good.  I would not call it a "clone of Cinnabon".  Cinnabon buns are gooey, these are not gooey, but still very delicious.  Dough is perfect, cinnamon amount is just right. I used the tip of flipping them upside down after pulling them from the oven, which is a great tip to redistribute the filling.  Best recipe I have used, but not a Cinnabon.
