text:
I tried this recipe and totally loved it.  I did it all in the mixer then took the dough and finished kneading it.  Used the dough rise setting on my oven it took a while to come up but boy what a great sweet dough.  Would use this for cinnamon bread for toast.  Okay, the icing - it is a WINNER!!  I have tried alot of cinnamon bun recipes, but this topped every one of them will use this a thousand times.  It did take some kneading, and some time to rise but what a recipe. I might let it rise overnight in the fridge and bake off in the morning for hot rolls.  They keep well and warm well in the mircrowave.  Try it you will like it.

text:
I chose this recipe because of the number of reviews and the 5* rating; I am a bit disappointed.  They were no more trouble to make than any other cinnamon roll.  But after 15 min. of cooking at 400 they were very brown.  I touched them and thought they felt rather soft, but any more cooking and they would have been burned.  Turns out they were RAW in the middle!  IF I ever make them again, I will lower the temp. and cook them longer!  Also, they were way too big.  I will probably make them into 20-24 rolls next time.

text:
My husband demands I make this recipe for the rest of our lives! My Sunday School went bonkers over it! This is one of those recipes that makes you look like a way better cook than you actually are! 
I used a glass pan as suggested in the reviews. I only had 15 minutes to let it rise the second time but it still turned out great! I combined the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together before spreading on the dough as suggested in another review but I had trouble getting it to spread easily. The consistency of the filling in the baked rolls turned out perfect. So maybe a little work on the front end makes it better in the end result.

Thanks for the recipe!!!

text:
These were good and fairly easy to make with the bread machine.  Not that this recipe needed another five-star rating, but I might as well add mine to the bunch.  I did take the advise of others and use a metal pan, I actually used an air-bake cake pan. I use air-bake cookie sheets on almost all of my cookies and everything thing I make with them seem to come out great.  Many people don't like them, but I couldn't live without them.  I think next time I will either roll the dough out a little thinner or use just a little bit less cinnamon and brown sugar.  Thanks!

text:
Absolutely fantastic recipe! When these are made on a weekend morning at my house, the pan is gone before noon! If you're short on time (or inclination) to make the dough from scratch, I found that using three (1 lb.) loaves of frozen white dough will yield great results. Simply thaw the dough in its package in the refrigerator overnight (10-12 hours) and roll out as usual the next morning.

Excellent.  However, I'm only giving 4 stars because the sugar filling hardened as the rolls cooled, and left some crunchy sugar bits that my husband didn't like.  Also, there was realy no need to double the frosting, as some suggested.  THe original amount would have been plenty.  I doubled it, and have about half left over.  Overall, an outstanding cinnamon bun recipe.

These take a long time, but they're definitely worth it. 
I think they need to be baked a bit longer than the recipe says to, though. The ones in the center of my pan were very doughy. If I make them again, I'll definitely add another 15 minutes or so of oven time. 
I used "whole wheat white" flour instead of regular white, and it tasted great.

text:
What a great recipe. I did what other suggested and I inverted them onto a jelly roll pan and let them sit for about 20 minutes and then frosted them. My husband is a frosting freek so we doubled the frosting and they were fabulous. I just used regular yeast in my bread machine and it worked great. I set my convection oven for 350 and I watched them for 15 minutes so they wouldn't burn and they came out great. The first time I made them I wasen't paying attention and they got pretty brown on top. But by turning them over and then frosting them no one could tell. My husband asked me to make them again tonight so I did and they turned out great. THANK YOU!

Made these last night and they turned out great.  Changed the cooking temp and time to 350 for 25 minutes.  Thinned the frosting with a couple tablespoons of half and half, otherwise no changes.  As another reviewer stated, the dough came together beautifully.  I rolled them up nice and tight. Will definitely make again. FANTASTIC RECIPE!!

text:
Cooking temperature was way too warm. At 400 after 15 minutes the edges were very dark and all, I mean all of the insides were not cooked. I did not realize this until they were all iced. Put them back in the oven, icing and all and it took another 20 minutes to get them all cooked. I RECOMMEND A 350 OVEN OR LOWER. The dough however was amazing, the best I've worked with. I'm going to definitely try it once more in a few weeks. Just with a cooler oven.

Loved it,loved it,loved it!!!This is Outstanding!  Rushed home yesterday to start baking the rolls.  I followed the recipe to the letter except for the yeast, at which I used the Fleismann fast-rising (acting?) yeast-  didn't think it would make any difference.  I did the Glaze/topping and it has a fantastic consistency I've ever seen!  It's wonderful when you spread it all over the rolls.  The only thing that made me doubt was the "15 minute" cooking time- which is a little too short for me- I baked it for a few more minutes, 7-8 minutes.  The whole house smelled so good at 10:45pm!! text:
I added raisins and I didn't melt the butter...I spread it over the whole rectangle.  

When I tried using a knife to cut the sections, they got squished.  So, I used a long piece of dental floss.  (unused, of course!)  I slid it underneath the roll, brought up both ends and then crisscrossed until the section had been cut through.  

I will be making these again!!  thank you!!

text:
I tried this recipe out last night.WOW!!!!These came out absolutely yummy.Soft,moist,gooey and my home smelled of cinnamon and dough.I used 4 cups instead of 4 1/2 cups of flour and added two teaspoons of vanilla extract in the dough,i also added 3 tablespoons ground cinnamon instead of 2.I also baked my buns for 20 minutes till they're lightly golden brown.I didn't make the frosting that this recipe comes with,but made one of my own:3 tbs.milk,2 tbs.instant vanilla pudding mix,1/2 cup white sugar and 1 1/2 tbs.butter.Boil all together till the mixture is bubbly and spread over cinnabons.Yummy,rich and gooey!!!!!!This is a keeper,i'm not gonna try another cinnabol recipe again,i've found the perfect one!

text:
Scrumptious. I made these in the bread maker, then overnighted the rolls in the fridge. I didn't want to heat the kitchen up too quickly so put both pans of rolls on a heating pad to rise. Baked at 350 for 20 minutes. I didn't have cream cheese but if you add around a Tab. or so of lemon juice, it will give it the right amount of tang. My daughter ate SIX of these cinnamon buns on Easter morning! Thanks for the great recipe.

Fantastic! I mixed the brown sugar, butter and cinnamon together and put it into the microware for 10 sec to make it soft and easy to spread on the dough.  I just do half of the portion but roll it to 8X12 inch and cut 12 mini size cinnamon.  One of the review b4 said it is more soft if bake it 175C 20mins, so I follow her suggestion.  Because my family don't like sweet~~~so next time I will try to decrease the portion of butter and brown sugar.

Really good! Mine separated though and the filling mostly came out. prob something I did wrong. Regardless it tasted declicious. I did 1/2 w/ cinnamon sugar and the other half w/ cinnamon/sugar/pecans & cranberries. Delicious!

2/2010: Update: I made this again and used softened butter but not too soft and mixed it w/ sugar/cinnamon like others suggested. I also baked about 20 minutes on 350. Next time I might do more of the butter/sugar mixture. Delicious! and this time the butter/sugar mixture did not leak out.

country:
None
text:
Before I made these.. I read all the reviews...well, most of them. I thought" could that really be that good?" I made them last night. YES! They really are THAT good!!! I can not believe how great they are. Better that what you get in the store without all the chemicals and preservatives they use for commercial production. I didn't have a bread machine, so I made them by hand. Dissolved the yeast in the milk first. The trick about preheating the oven to 200 degrees then turning off, really worked well. Great idea! They definitely are better than cinnabon's. I made my own frosting with cream cheese( always make my own anyway, I have a peanut allergy son.)So I can't vouch for the icing in the recipe, but I did bake them for 20 minutes at 375. Perfect. Also, if you don't turn them over to let the sugar run down, you will get this great base of sugar on the bottom of the roll. Yum!!!!  (if you like that sort of thing!) If you are hesitant at all about this recipe...forget it...this really is the BEST one out there!!

Oh my holy goodness.  This was the best recipe ever.  I made them the night before and put them in the fridge over night.  In the morning I let them rise for about 45 minutes (we got impatient, it was Christmas morning), then baked.  They were incredible.  I mixed the brown sugar/cinnamon/margarine together and it spread very nicely with a spatula (I also let it sit out to get to room temp).  At any rate, this was incredible- I'm making them again this weekend for company- these were actually BETTER than Cinnabon's- they weren't so sticky sweet, and a little more spicy.

text:
I have made this recipe twice now.  The first time I put them in a disposable 9x13 pan then put them in the freezer.  I took them with me on vacation to bake there.  They did take a while to defrost and then rise, but they were awesome!  I just made them again for my husband to take to the musicians at our church and they were awesome again.  This time I put them in the fridge for a few hours and then left them out overnight to rise.  I baked them in the morning and they were perfect.  I always add extra cream cheese to the frosting since I like the cream cheese flavor more then the icing sugar flavor.  These are really easy to make and everyone always raves about how good they are.

I made these without a breadmaker. country:
None
text:
Even if your dough isn't perfect these rolls will still taste great.  I used 2 frozen whole wheat loaves to make these.  I followed the directions on the bread loaf bag to defrost and work with the dough.  After I rolled out the dough and cut off the excess I still had about 15 rolls, although they weren't huge. (which is a good thing, as these are so sweet and rich, more than one almost makes you sick)  I followed other reviewers and used more cinnamon, about 4 Tablespoons, and after I baked these I put them on a plate and poured the excess cinnamon goo over the top.  The recipe for the icing makes plenty, had I doubled it I would have thrown the rest out.  Excellent, but definitely a recipe I'll save for once or twice a year, as they are so very sweet!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you for this recipe!  I absolutely love Cinnabon's!  It had been part of my Christmas morning tradition for many years.  I moved this year and suddenly found that the nearest Cinnabun shop was an hour and a half away. After reading many of the reviews, I made the following revisions:  I allowed the dough to rise twice before rolling it out so that it would be fluffy and light.  I also did not melt the butter with the cinnamon mixture but spread the butter on top of the rolled out dough and sprinkled the sugar and cinnamon afterwards.  It took approx. 18 minutes to cook.  They were perfect, just like the freshly made ones in the malls.  The icing was slightly different, not as much cream cheese flavoring but this could easily be adjusted.  Overall, quite a hit and I am glad that I still can continue my Christmas holiday tradition.

country:
None
text:
Tastes just like a cinnabon! We made this Christmas eve, and put them on wax paper on a baking tray in the fridge. We let them sit out for an hour in the morning, and then baked them and iced them. I messed up slightly when making the filling, as I just mixed the melted butter right in with the brown sugar and cinnamon mixture, then spread it on with a frosting spreader, rather than brushing it on first. It actually worked out better, since it made it much easier to roll up- the sugar didn't fall out the sides at all and stayed in place better. I think I'll do that next time as well. This is our new Christmas tradition!

text:
Very good! We used Whole wheat flour so they turned out a little dryer and less sweet then a true Cinnabon.

The second time we made them we upped the milk an extra 1/4c to help the whole wheat not be so dry. We also used Splenda in lue of the sugar and a full cup of the new Splenda Brown sugar in place of the regular brown sugar so my diabetic father could eat some as well for Christams and I think the Splenda version was even better!

We also did not have bread machine so we used the dry active yeast suggestion and it turned out beautiful! Everyone was impressed we made it!

Display Name:
Jo Sais Bohannon-Grant

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5234618.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for the first time yesterday and did have some problems. The first batch of dough did not rise and I had to throw it out. I have no idea why. The second batch rose correctly. As one reviewer suggested, I premixed the filling materials in one bowl, but then  it was lumpy and dry and wouldn't spread evenly. I had to soften the mixture in the microwave so it would spread evenly on the dough. I had trouble getting the dough off the wax paper as I was rolling it up, so remember to put enough flour under the dough. The roll made enough cut pieces to fit perfectly in a 9 x 13 pan, which I cooked at 350 for 22 minutes. I then inverted them on a plate. Half were gone within the hour! I did expect them to be gooey-er than they  were, more like a real cinnabon. There was no runny sweetness on the bottom of the pan, but we didn't mind.  My family  actually preferred these to the real thing!

text:
The claim that this recipe is a clone of a Cinnabon, is absolutely true! I had a very difficult time getting the dough to rise, but after several hours of patience and working with different temperatures, if finally did. The only change I would recommend is to make a little extra frosting (maybe 1 1/2 the amounts the recipe calls for) Also, did not have a problem with cinnamon mixture running out of the buns - maybe they just need to be rolled fairly snug. Thanks for this amazing recipe - well worth the work!!!

I have been a long time user of All Recipes but this is the recipe that made me take the time to write my first review!  In one word, AMAZING!  Cinnamon bun recipes can be hit or miss but this one is spot on.  The dough was a beautiful consistency to work with, practically no sticking at all, easy to shape. text:
Absolutely amazingly worth the work! I didn't have the right pan so I used a large spring-form pan for some and a large glass baking pan which had rounded corners - I won't use this type of pan again since the outside rolls were cooked and golden and the inside weren't (however, even undercooked were delicious!) I also wanted to try this recipe so badly  and I didn't have a rolling pin but I just stretched as best as I could; would be much easier with a good marble rolling pin (I asked my  Mom to let me have hers specifically for this recipe!) Oh yes, I did mix the butter, cinnamon and brown sugar all together and spread it on instead of sprinkling.

userID:
2546582
Display Name:
GraceisGone
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
1446
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4545417.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for my boyfriend and his brothers and they raved about it.  Even his picky younger brother fell in love with the soft roll and amazing frosting.  I used a bread machine but let the dough rise in the oven.  Heat your oven to 200 degress and turn it off and place the dough in a greased bowl and cover with a moist towel.  Leave for about an hour to double in size.  I followed previous advice and added 1/4 granulated sugar to the filling and increased the butter and cinnamon as well for ample filling.  I lined my baking pan with a sheet of parchment paper to make removal easier.  I let them rise again in the oven for about a half hour.  Baking the rolls at 350 degrees for 20-25 minutes produced wonderfully golden moist buns.  I had no need to double the frosting recipe.  My boyfriend wants to know when I can make it again and says "You were wrong.  It's better then a Cinnabon"  You can't beat that!!!

text:
Awesome!  I did take some of the suggestions and cook them at 350 for 22 minutes, and they were perfectly cooked and just golden brown.  Pay attention to the frosting--the cream cheese amount is only 3 ounces (a small cream cheese package)--not the traditional 8 oz package that I usually buy.  It probably would have been good either way, but I caught that just as I was about to throw the whole thing in.

I followed the advice of some previous reviews and baked them at 350F for 20 minutes, and also flipped the pan over onto a tray after they were done, to allow the yummy filling to ooze back over them.  If you are looking for a good cinnamon roll recipe don't skip this one, it will definitely be my cinnamon roll recipe from now on!!

text:
This recipe was my first attempt at cinnamon rolls.  They were great!--the first time!  I made them again today but my dough didn't rise as it should.  The first time I dissolved the yeast in the milk and added the sugar to the yeast/milk mixture, then proofed it.  This time I dissolved the yeast in just milk and proofed it before adding it to the sugar, egg, salt, etc. mixture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, and very well received by everyone!

My tip is to make sure the butter for the filling is softened (microwave for no longer than 10 seconds for butter that isn't frozen) and not melted.  I used melted butter for my first batch and when I rolled the dough, it kind of squeezed out the sides making quite a (delicious) mess!

I made the dough the day before and let it 2nd rise overnight in the fridge (per other's recommendation's) and that turned out great!  I made the frosting the day before as well and it was quite good.

I made these cinnabons for the first time on Easter morning. I followed the recipe exactly, but my first batch of six buns came out burnt after only 12 minutes of being into the oven. dateLastModified:
2006-11-11T15:44:09.147
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1596502
Display Name:
Cheri
isPro:
False
followersCount:
53
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
61
favoritesCount:
1908
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/159756.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husbands favorite cinnamon roll recipe... I have tried many that he has never quite been satisfied with... but this one he looks forward to eating every time... I half the recipe and make it in a 8x8 pan... then for the frosting I add 3 Tbsp of cream cheese. A 3 oz pckg of cream cheese is equal to 6 Tbsp. One 8 oz pkg. of cream cheese is 1 cup, which is 16 Tbsp.. (each 1/4 cup is 4 Tbsp) so an easy way to measure it is score the block in half... and then in half again... then you have 4-1/4 cup portions... the if you need Tbsps... just score those 1/4 cup portions into 4. This also works for the 1/2 cup cubes of margarine or butter.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-10-09T09:20:12.263
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
23208
Display Name:

text:
I made these last night and the dough did not rise quickly like so many of you have said.  Even let it sit in the oven all night and it still needed to rise more; hence, the dough was real tough and the finished rolls were tough.  I like to think that I am a good baker, (I make homemade breads and rolls all the time!)so I started on another batch this morning,and this dough is still not rising and seems real heavy and tough!  I don't have a bread machine, but carefully followed the advice of previous reviews.  I even tested the temperature of the milk before adding the yeast.  I would like to know if anyone else has the same problem.  My own cinnamon roll recipe dough is much softer and rises nicely.  I really would like to adapt to this recipe because I can see where they could definitely taste like cinnabons, but don't know what else to do. Any help out there?

userID:
1844555
Display Name:
Dawn
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
54
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These buns were very good and addictive.  I had to bring the rest to work so I wouldn't eat anymore.  I do think these buns are very sweet.  I will not use as much brown sugar the next time.  For a lower cal bun you could omit the icing; I think that is the killer.  

I think some people may have had problems with the buns not rising or turning out because when I followed the recipe and added ingredients to the bread machine I added the liquid stuff first then the flour and as I am putting the salt on top I thought...hmmm...if the yeast gets in contact with the salt it won't rise, I mixed in in best I could with the flour and sugar.  So I suggest mixing the salt in with the water first.  
Also I will need about 20 min next time to cook buns all the way through.  The middle ones were a tad doughy.
I have made cinnimon buns in the past and it was an all day event this recipe is great because it is only about 1 hour in the kitchen and your done.  I will always let my bread machine do all the dirty work from now on.

5

text:
Dangerously addicitng--especially if you are pregnant and have a lull in morning sickness! :-) I tried this recipe twice. The first time the rolls in the middle of the pan were a tad doughy and all of them rose up HUGE, so the second time I cut 16 pieces instead, squeezed them into the pan and didn't rise them as long. Much better! After baking I transferred them to a cookie sheet and broke them apart to allow the icing to run down the sides. Fabulous!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy way to make cinnamon rolls. I've made them many times "kneeding by hand" and it's work! The breadmachine takes the hard work out of it, and they come out great! I followed the recipe closely, but I did use another reviewer's "overnight" in the fridge idea. I just followed the steps to get them in the 9x13 pan and then covered them and put them in the fridge. The next morning I let them sit out for 30 minutes and then put them in a 200 degree oven for a few minutes and then cooked them in a convection oven at 350 degrees for 20 minutes. They're excellent!

I made these exactly as written, and they were excellent. I did double the frosting mix, per other reviews, and ended up with over half of it leftover, so I don't think the frosting needs doubled. country:
None
text:
These were wonderful.  I made them sticky buns by melting 1c. brown sugar, 1/2 c. butter and 2T. light corn syrup in the bottom of the pan before the final rising step.  They tasted great, but I had to bake them a little longer to get the center rolls done.  In the future, I will put them on a jelly roll pan and spread them out a little bit so they bake more evenly.
Review:

text:
All the great reviews are right, these are terrific.  I added raisins to the sugar mixture and will make again this way.  I followed another reviewer's advice and mixed the sugar, butter, and cinnamon together and spread on the rolled dough. It was not easy to spread out the mixture, but I do think it helped keep the cinnamon and sugar from leaking out the ends of the rolls.  Don't worry if you can't spread out the mixture very evenly.  When the rolls cook the mixture spreads out.

None
text:
I made these for breakfast a few days ago for my full extended family. Everyone LOVED them - my uncle even said they were the best cinnamon rolls he'd ever had. The only things I'd change - double the frosting, and use margarine in it (or less butter) because otherwise it tastes very strongly of butter; mix the cinnamon, sugar, and butter for the middle together before spreading them on the dough so it doesn't all melt out; and cook them an extra five minutes at 350 degrees instead of 400. They come out just perfectly this way!

text:
Like a previous reviewer I tried this recipe with my Kitchenaid mixer. Other than that I followed the recipe exactly. I was pretty nervous when the dough wasnt rising, but figured since I had spent the money on the ingredience I should bake them anyway. Imagine my surprise when after 25 minutes of cooking I found 12 deliciously plumped up fluffy rolls! 
Next time, rather than squishing them together in a 9x13 I will spread them out on a cookie sheet to allow each one to rise and brown evenly on all sides.
I gave this recipe 5 stars because my husband ate three rolls as fast as I could get the glaze on them. However, after all the great reviews I expected some kind of earth shattering taste but turns out for me  they were really just eh...cinnamon rolls.

text:
This recipe is amazing. The Cinnabons are delicious! Everyone who has tried them loves them.

I found two small adjustments I prefer on this recipe, however. The frosting was a little to cream-cheesy for my taste, so I added more confectioner's sugar to make it sweeter. Also, one day I had no light brown sugar, so I used dark brown sugar with more cinnamon. Also, with more cinnamon, the cream-cheesier frosting nicely balanced it all out.

Excellent recipe!

These are absolutely fabulous! Since I have a older Black and Decker Bread Machine thatI received in 1995, my machine could not handle the 4 1/2 cups flour, therefore I had to scale it down to a yield of 8, but managed to bake 12 at the end.  I had to try this recipe three times before it worked on my dough machine. Just a note for you cooks out there that have a older machine. This recipe is worth investing a new bread maker.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

I made this for my Sunday School class this morning and I got TONS of "Wows!!" Lots of people asked for the recipe claiming these cinnamon rolls were JUST like the CINNABONS!! And the icing ROCKED! I followed the recipe to the "t" however I opted to mix all ingredients together in a bowl (making sure the eggs are room temp and the milk is at least 110 degrees)instead of using a bread machine. It's true the dough puts up a fight at first, but hang in there and it will eventually give when rolling it out!  My kids LOVED helping and the cinnamon rolls were simply BEAUTIFUL!  Time consuming, yep, but WELL worth it!

text:
This recipe was AWSOME! I took the advice of another reviewer and melted the butter and combined it with the brown sugar and cinnamin and brushed it on to the dough, it came out GREAT! I also sifted the flour into the bread machine and the dough came out very silky. At first I saw some reviews about cinnamon rolls III and I tried that recipe first, but it was way too sweet, so I tried this one and it was just what I was looking for. I don't think I have found one that was this close to a cinnabon so I'm going to stay with this one.

Display Name:
LUVJEZUZ

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
FIVE stars just isn't enough for these!!!  One week ago, my husband and I ate a Cinnabon, and when my husband tried these, he said "OH MY GOSH, that is EXACTLY like a Cinnabon!!"  It's true, and these are extremely awesome.  My mom said, "Those aren't Cinnabons, they're better!" I've made other "clone" recipes before, but this one truely is the same thing.  

I don't have a "bread maker," but instead a mixer that has dough hooks, and that's how I made them.  I used fast rise yeast, and combined it with the dry ingredients.  I mixed (separately from the dry ingredients) the melted butter with the warm milk, then I put in the eggs, and added all that to the dry ingredients.  The dough hooks worked great; I "kneaded" with those for 6 minutes.

I sprayed a large glass bowl with cooking spray, and let it rise in a heated oven (I put it on the "warm" setting).
One thing that was strange for me was that it took so long to rise, both times.  Don't know why...anyway, I will surely make these again and again and again!

text:
These were excellent -- taste just like the Cinnabon ones.  The only issue that came up was that my husband said he tasted something "bitter" in a couple of bites.  So, I'm guessing that some of the cinnamon didn't get mixed real well w/ the sugar and butter.  It seemed like an awful lot of cinnamon/sugar mixture, so just make sure it's mixed well and that there's plenty of butter all over the dough.  They're awesome!

text:
These were great! Couple things-although the cinnamon roll itself didn't taste exactly like Cinnabon, the frosting was a dead on hit! I had a small problem with all the cinnamon/sugar mixture running down to the bottom of the cinnamon roll, so the inside wasn't as gooey and cinnamon/sugary as I hoped. I think I just need to roll the dough tighter, and I could cut back on the butter a tad. I did have to add a little more cinnamon sugar mixture. They were a huge hit, and will be my forever cinnamon roll recipe!

By far my best recipe find ever!!  If you are a Cinnabon junkie, you will LOVE this recipe.  I took the advice to turn down heat & cook 20 min & they came out perfect. My advice -  make sure you buy the big bags of flour, brown sugar & confectioners sugar, because I am already ready to make my 3rd batch, and I have run out of supplies!!

I didn't use bread machine yeast, I used regular quick rise Fleischmans yeast and it still came out good! I will use the yeast it calls for next time and see the difference.. Thanks MARSHA!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely scrumptious! I was a little leery of this recipe, considering that I don't have a bread machine. Plus, the last batch of cinn. rolls I made (using another recipe) were a total flop. Well, I decided to take the risk, and I'm so glad I did! These cinnamon rolls really do taste like Cinnabon's! I was a little worried when mine didn't appear to have "doubled" either time, but they eventually puffed up in the oven, and tasted delicious, too. And there was no need to double the icing; I had plenty to spare. Only change I would recommend: 3/4 c. brown sugar works fine, but when you dust the dough rectangle, leave a little margin around the edges. Otherwise, it's kind of tricky getting the edge of the rolled dough to stick to the cinnamon-y side (i.e. my "rounds" kept unravelling).

Display Name:
CHEVVY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ooh la la. Delicious!! The cinnabons rose to the occasion (they doubled in size twice) and were SCRUMPTIOUS. I don't  have a bread machine so used my mixie- but it didn't seem to make any difference. They were yummy. Followed the recipe to the T- there's no need to double the icing, I ended up with more than needed.  I rolled the dough a little thinner and made 18 rolls instead of  12. If you use a clear plastic sheet lined counter, it will be less sticky when rolling the dough. Also placed the cinnabons to bake on a wire rack lined with wax paper (placed in the baking pan), as the first batch got overbrowned and hard when they were dirrectly put on the baking pan.  The tip about using dental floss to cut the dough was very useful. For those of you who didn't get good results the first time, try again- like I did. My first attempt  at making them was a disaster - my fault. I think the proportions I used were wrong. Thanks Marsha.

text:
I've made this recipe numerous times and it it fabulous. The only problem I encountered was that the tops were overdone while the middle was doughy. (Many of the other reviewers have reported this same problem) I made a double batch last night and I believe I have solved the problem. I baked the rolls at 350 instead of 400 and extended the baking time to  22 minutes. THE WERE PERFECT. I have already noted the change on my copy of the recipe.

I've already reviewed this recipe (it's totally fabulous!), but in response to Ellen who wanted to know how many WW points one bun is, it's 12 in the entire bun and 6 for half. (I know the halving sounds like a no-brainer, but sometimes with WW you have to watch out how you halve and double points!)  Good luck!

text:
Made this a few times already. The only thing I do differently is make actual frosting for these instead of glaze. I do so by upping the icing sugar to 4 cups total and it is spread onto the buns when completely cooled. These freeze very well, frosting already on and all. No need to make them in the bread machine. My stand mixer with the hook does all the hard work.

text:
I've made this recipe without a breadmaker and with a breadmaker. It is SO much better with a breadmaker (day and night difference in the dough).  I made the recipe exactly as written except I did add extra cinnamon / sugar to the inside and extra frosting on top. I also added a little extra cream cheese and milk to the frosting to thin it out. This is one of the easiest recipes I have made because I just put the ingredients in the breadmaker and pushed the dough button, which saved a lot of time and energy. I think they taste exactly like Cinnabon's rolls.

text:
Puffy. Soft. Gooey. Everything you want in a cinnamon bun! I have prepared these the day ahead with great results. I make the dough, form the rolls, and place them in my greased pan, but cover and refrigerate them overnight. They still rise fine. I take them out and let them rest at least 30 minutes before baking.  I also make the dough with buttermilk and 00 or pasty flour (personal preference) and they are just divine!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
They were delicious! I adjusted the recipe for 6 servings, and poured a little bit of warm heavy cream over the top before baking, but other than that I followed the recipe as written. I don't have a bread machine so this is what I did: combine warm milk with the yeast and let it sit for about 10 minutes. Then I added the margarine (melted but cooled,) and egg to the milk mixture and lightly mixed them all together. Then I combined all the dry ingredients (for the dough) together and mixed them well. I then added the wet ingredients and combined everything well. I put it in the mixer for about 7 minutes then followed the directions from there. The recipe was a bit vague, so I had to go through before I began, and color coded the different ingredients for the different components. For example, I highlighted the dough ingredients with blue, the filling with orange, and the frosting with yellow. This really helped me. It was my first time making cinnamon rolls, so if I can do it you can too! They tasted very similar to Cinnabon.

text:
Worst Recipe ever, I am surprised that All recipes even published it.  It is like a recipe that Raymond’s mom (Marie) would give to Raymond’s wife (Debra) with a lot of the details missing.

 The main issue is with the directions;
First issue:  Step 1.  Says “Place ingredients in pan of bread machine”.  However, it does not tell you what ingredients to place in the pan of the bread machine.

Second issue:  The Prep time reads 20 Minutes and step 1 says “Select dough cycle, press Start”.  My dough cycle ran for 1 hour and 40 minutes, so how is the Prep time 20 Minutes?

Third issue:  Step 4.  Says to beat ¼ cup of butter, confectioners sugar, vanilla extract and salt.  Well, the ingredients did not list, confectioners’ sugar or vanilla extract and I had already used the salt in the dough.

Marsha Fernandez needs to change her name to Marie Barone if she is going to leave out so many details.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved these cinnamon rolls! I have made them twice in as many weeks. The first time I mixed the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together as one reviewer suggested and this was not nearly easy as sprinkling the brown sugar cinnamon mixture over the butter. I then used the rolling pin to press it down as another reviewer suggested and this was a great idea! The first time I made it they were a bit thicker than the second time and I preferred them rolled a little bit thinner and cut not so thick. Just my personal preference. However because they were thinner they did come out a little dryer so the next time I will not bake them for quite so long. Since this second batch was cut into thinner cinnamon rolls I have a small pan that I am freezing. A reviewer said that this works just fine so I’m anxious to see how that goes. I love the icing given in this recipe but my family prefers just the confectioner sugar icing. I didn’t see the need to turn the pan of rolls over and they weren’t so gooey that they stuck. I highly recommend using parchment paper!!!

text:
These were amazing!  It took about 2 1/2 -3 hours to make from start to finish.  I was a little bummed that it took that long (and I used the "quick" dough course on my bread maker).  It sort of makes it hard to make them for breakfast unless you can do it the evening before and just bake that next morning or if you get up at 4 or 5 am to get started.  I'll have to read some other reviews and see if that is possible.  (Yep, just saw what others do - so I will definitely do these ahead of time so I have something amazing for breakfast next time).  I was impressed with how easy it was to make them in my bread machine (I know many say they always make it by hand, but this was so easy, why do that if you don't have to?).  I followed the recipe exactly - although I did cook it for a few extra minutes because the tops didn't look golden brown yet.  I did not have a big problem with the cinnamon mixture falling out of the buns.  That may be because we left about an inch not buttered along all of the edges before we sprinkled on the cinnamon/sugar mixture.  Everyone in my family enjoyed them.  We are looking forward to leftovers tomorrow morning! I do plan on making this again sometime (maybe when our kids have a bunch of friends sleep over)!

Truly awesome just as the recipe is written. The bread is tender and the rolls are filled with gooey cinnamon-ness. The dough was a little difficult to work with, a little dry and not the typical airy, stretchy bread dough I’m used too. Nonetheless, the rolls raised well and they are delicious! Nothing special about the recipe, but I marked it down because of the way it's organized.  The ingredients need to be separated into: dough, filling, and frosting.  Anyone who is a novice cook would have to read through the entire recipe and figure out what goes where - I'm an experienced baker and I ended up putting the butter (which was listed as margarine) in with the dough mixture!

text:
Amazing recipe....amazing. I made a few changes based on other reviews. First, we dont have a bread machine. So I just dissolved the yeast in warm milk and then combined with salt, sugar, eggs and butter. Then added to flour. Preheated oven to 200 and then turned it off.  Placed dough in the oven covered with a damp paper towel. For the filling, I combined the ingredients before spreading it on. For baking, I place rolls on parchment paper. No stick, filling didnt leak out. I would suggest doubling the icing recipe. It makes enough but more would would be better.

These are THE best rolls I’ve ever made but change two things. I use a Chinese cinnamon. Makes a difference. Second....on the icing...use a 1:1 ratio of butter and cream cheese. I use 1 8oz cream cheese, 1 stick butter, 1 1/2 teas lemon juice and 2-2 1/2 cups powdered sugar. Trust me.l..

text:
Made this with AP flour instead since bread flour is so expensive. Also used a cream cheese frosting. And I don’t have a bread machine so made it by hand/kitchenaid. (Other reviews have instructions) Turned out delicious! I gave a family half of a dozen and the mom ate them all! Haha. They are absolutely addicting. I saw a few reviews saying that the filling dropped out with baking and that didn’t happen to me, just make sure you get a nice tight roll. Also, I have tried a bench knife, a serrated knife, and dental floss and the floss worked the best to cut without squishing them. Just make sure it’s not flavored!

text:
Absolutely delicious!! We all love having cinnamon buns on saturdays. Now thanks to these, I no longer will be buying the can!  First time I made these I cut them in the 12 pieces. came out beautiful and fluffy, but were just too big! So made them again and cut them yielding 20- Perfect size! Froze them and divided each bag into having 10. First time eating them from freezing was just as delicious. Took out what I wanted for the next day and let dethaw in the fridge (spray cooking pan before hand). Let them rise in the cold oven while preheating and then baked for 350 for about 25 minutes. Yum yum yum. These are easy, just time consuming, so I love I can make some batches throughout the week and just freeze into ready to go portions. 

I never can seem to roll the dough right on the ends. I get beutiful rolls, except for the first and last, they are very tiny! So I Have been freezing the "tiny" ones for when me and the husband want to snack on cinnamon rolls late at night!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are delicious! I made the recipe as is without any changes. I did use a KA mixer for the dough and then the frosting. I dissolved the sugar in the bowl before adding the yeast and mixing in all of the required wet ingredients. Used the dough mixing attachment and added 1 cup of flour at a time until it was complete. Once complete I transferred to a lightly oiled bowl and allowed to rise for 1 hour. I mixed all of the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together before spreading on the dough and using a rolling pin to press the mixture into the dough. As another reviewer mentioned, I left some bare spot on the dough so it would be dough to dough when sealing shut. I also wiped a little bit of water on the edge of the dough to ensure it stuck together. Once the rolls were cut, I placed them in a 9x13 glass baking dish with parchment paper on the bottom and allowed them to sit for 20 minutes. Then cooked them for the 15 minutes referenced, in the future I would probably cook them an additional 5 minutes as some of the middle rolls have some gooey spots that seem under cooked. Once they were complete I used half of the frosting immediately to coat all of the rolls and allow it to melt down into them. Then after a few minutes of cooling I drizzled the remaining frosting on all of the rolls.

These are delicious, I can’t keep them around the house! The first time I made it exactly as directions instructed. The second time I changed a few things, when making brown sugar mixture for spread I mixed brown sugar, butter and cinnamon together in bowl, added a teaspoon of vanilla and then spread it on. Much easier! And I sometimes add raisins to the recipe. I also changed the temperature at which you bake them to 350 for approximately 20-25 minutes 400 degrees was drying them out.

I would cut the roll filling down to 1 1/2 cups of brown sugar and 2 teaspoons of cinnamon. I have the biggest sweet tooth I know of, and these were too sweet for me. I love cinnamon as well but 2 1/2 tablespoons was too much. 

If you don’t have cream cheese, any basic icing recipe with some vanilla, butter and confectioners sugar will do just fine. 

I do not own a bread machine. Instead I used a stand mixer and let it proof an hour before rolling it out and they came out very large and fluffy!

LKK6211

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I follow the suggestion for not using a bread machine. I've been making this recipe for 4 or 5 years now, and I always get rave reviews.  I'm baffled at some of the comments indicating the rolls had no flavor or came out like bricks. My rolls come out perfect every time.  It does take longer to rise than the recipe indicates unless I use the bread proof setting on my oven (really a factor of the temp in my home).  I use that setting if I'm in a hurry. Be sure to follow the directions on the temp of the milk. Too warm and you'll kill your yeast which would cause the rolls not to rise.  Too cool and you'll have trouble getting the yeast to dissolve. I always test my temp before adding the yeast. Delicious cinnamon rolls!

1. Use the bread merchine pizza dough option, after done, leave in the pan until the size doubled. 
2. Dough, reduce sugar to 1/4 cup
3. Filling :1 loose cup of brown sugar and 1 TBSP cinnamon powder
4. Topping, 1/2 cup of powder sugar instead of 1 1/2  cup
5. 375 f  for 15 mins

This is my first  time making these awesome cinnamon rolls. My first time using the Cuisinart bread machine that I'd purchased back in December 2016.  My family is very finicky but they all love these! I am making 2nd batch now to save it in the freezer.  I used coconut oil instead of butter and you can't taste it after it is baked.  I have read most of the reviews and I agreed that bread flour is a must instead of AP flour, because the texture is chewy yet light, like the original Cinnabon.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made no changes to the ingredients, but I mixed the dough last night in my breadmaker, then put it in a greased bowl, covered it with plastic wrap, and refrigerated the dough until morning. It did rise in the fridge overnight , but stayed within the bowl. In the morning, I let it warm up on the counter for about 10 minutes or so before proceeding with the rest of the instructions of rolling out the dough... making them into cinnamon rolls. They turned out beautifully, and they were DELICIOUS! Because I was able to use my breadmaker and have the dough ready for the morning, it took no time at all to make these for breakfast.  Definitely a keeper!!

text:
Made this recipe years ago and forgot to save it.  I made a bunch of these for a family reunion and froze the buns after assembling the dough and cinnamon mixture and cutting them.  I then thawed them overnight in the fridge and baked fresh in the morning.   They were a HUGE hit and also were literally huge in size.  The cinnamon filling has so much more flavor than store bought cinnamon buns.  It's honestly a lot of work but for a special occasion they are so worth it.

text:
This recipe is not only spot on for a Cinnabon clone, it is even better. I have made them three times in less than a week.  I make them as minis instead of full size.  Divide the brown sugar and cinnamon in half, cut the dough in half and roll out to a 21 x 8 rectangle. Spread half of the butter/margarine over the dough. Spread half of the brown sugar and cinnamon. Complete as indicated by the recipe and repeat with the other half of dough. They will bake the same as the full size ones but are great for a party or just for less calories! I did increase the frosting recipe by 1 1/2 times so I guess I didn't really cut the calories! The dough bakes up nice and chewy because of the bread flour, which is what I have been looking for for years! Thank you, Marsha. Great, great recipe.
Review:

5

gggogetta

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks to AndyTami I made these today w/o a breadmaker. I used buttermilk because it was what I had on hand, also used real butter.  This is not a quick recipe but it was very easy, it has two separate rise times some people might have overlooked. 

I warmed my buttermilk to 120° and let it sit with the yeast for 10 minutes then I mixed it with the other ingredients before adding the flour. I hand kneaded my dough then let it rest in a oiled bowl for an hour. After that, rolled it out and cut them then let them rise for ANOTHER 30 minutes. I had to bake mines for 21 minutes, since they were still kinda soft and white after 15 minutes. 

They came out really big and soft even after cooling, tasty but not quite cinnabon tasty. This was my first time making cinnamon buns, thanks for and easy first tasty time.
Review:

text:
Made two batches... when it said to add all ingredients to he bread maker, I did, literally. This was a mistake. I had never made cinnamon rolls before, and the recipe was not divided to show which ingredients were for the roll batter, the filling and the Frosting. Because of this, I added more than I should have before catching myself. I cooked it anyway in muffin cups   The kids liked it, but it really was terrible. I made the second dough in my bread maker immediately following the first, but because I only had one egg, I halved the recipe (for the most part). I kept the filling and frosting at full volume (so doubled if I had made it as stated in the recipe). THEY TURNED OUT AMAZING!!!! If I could make them daily I would. Definitely worth the time. Oh, I didn't warm any of my ingredients because my bread maker does it for me.i also baked it at 359 for 20 min as others recommended and they were baked in a round cake pan.

14684508
Display Name:
Lauren Pennington
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1690457.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Turned out amazing! I was intimidated to make it, but you really do not need any culinary experience. You also don't need a bread machine. There is a comment below that explains what to do. Let your yeast activate in the warm milk and then after you see bubbles/foam, add the other ingredients in to start forming your dough. NEVER use HOT MILK to active your yeast. Scalding milk (or any liquid for that matter) will kill your yeast. When you are finished making the dough and want to let it rise, I like to microwave water until it boils and quickly remove it and shut the door to trap the moisture in. Then I place the covered bowl with my dough inside the microwave. Again do this quickly because the whole purpose is to keep warmth and moisture in the microwave.
Review:
Rating:
2

text:
Made  almost as written, but did not use bread machine, mixed by hand, as I find that gives me better control of the dough and how much flour needs to be added.  Had to change the frosting for my lactose intolerant kiddos.  Used Toffutti Cream Cheese instead.  Delicious, light and fluffly.  I made the night before, after first rising and rolling into rolls.  Covered with suran wrap and then placed in warming oven.  They rose perfectly.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/78562.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for Christmas Eve breakfast, and I was a little nervous because I had never made cinnamon rolls before. These were so easy. I don't have a bread machine so I just dissolved 2 1/4 tsp yeast in the warm milk in my mixer until foamy, and added everything else to mix, then  allowed to rise as a ball once, punched down, formed into rolls in a baking pan and placed in the fridge until the next morning when I took them out while the oven was preheating and baked as directed. Very delicious! Next time I would divide into two batches and freeze one for another time. I got about 14 rolls out of one batch.

text:
These were delicious and with some slight tweaks they will be perfect. I made this according to the recipe. The only change I made was mixing the butter with the brown sugar and cinnamon to spread on the dough. That was not a good idea. I ended up with a crumbled filling instead of gooey goodness. I love cinnamon but this was too much even for me. Next time I will add pecans and raisins. I also decreased the powdered sugar by 1/4 cup and increased cream cheese by an ounce. It was a good choice since I think it would have been too sweet otherwise.

Fantastic recipe... I actually rolled my dough out a little too thin in some areas, but it turned out very well actually. I read some reviews that they wanted that extra goo type thing, and before I baked mine, I made a little "goo" for the top. I used 1/4 cup butter, some brown sugar and a little cinnamon just so it stays moist. I will definitely be making these again, but next time leave more room in between my cinnarolls :)

country:
None
text:
I pretty much only used the brown sugar and cinnamon amounts from this recipe, then did everything else differently.

I used frozen dinner rolls.
1. Put them in a greased (canola oil) muffin pan and let them rise in the oven for 1hr.

2. Mixed the cinnamon and brown sugar, flattened the roll and added a scoop of the sugar mix to the center and closed the dough and putting it back in the muffin pan.

3. Spray the top of the dought with nonstick spray and sprinkle the leftover sugar mix on top.

4. Put back in the oven rise for 15-30min.

5. Bake for 15min and serve!
Review:

5

text:
Oh...my.....stars!!! This is incredible!!! I've made them 5 times in a week and a half haha. My family and neighbors love them! It is so easy. I'll never buy a cinnamon roll again, no joke. 
I used siagon cinnamon for the for the first time, and I'll never go back to "regular" cinnamon at least when it comes to baking. It elevated the quality and flavor a lot then when I've used cassia or ceylon cinnamon. Please make these! You won't be disappointed, unless you seriously messed it up. ;)  I can't wait for the next family gathering for an excuse to make them again. The frosting is delicious. I've wanted a good cream cheese frosting for other items and I will take their recipe and apply it to other recipes. The texture was perfect and the flavor was spot-on. I would even use a little bit less frosting on the cinnamon rolls next time.

userID:
17265067
Display Name:
Melissa Frick Minick
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4083323.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious. I didn't use a bread maker... 1 put 7g yeast with warm milk in my mixing bowl, whisked and let sit for 10 min till frothy. Added sugar,  egg, salt, butter. Whisked together. Attached my dough hook. Slowly add flour and kneeded on low for several minutes till fully encorporated. Dough was elastic and lightly sticky, but not like glue. Turned out dough into a bowl coated with cooking spray. Added a bit of spray to the top of the dough. Covered the bowl with plastic wrap covered in cooking spray.  Put dough in bowl in the oven for 1 hour to rise. Oven was off. I used my trick of boiling water ahead of time in a pot, and putting the pot in the over with my dough. The steam helps to rise. After an hour, turned dough out onto lightly floured surface. Rolled with pin into rectangle.  Brushed softened but not melted butter to dough surface. Sprinkle brown sugar and cinnamon. Brush evenly. Added chopped pecans and raisins to dough surface. Rolled. Cut into pieces.  Put pieces into glass pan covered in cooking spray. Cover pan with plastic wrap with cooking spray. Put back into oven with boiled water pot. Let rise another 30 min. Take out of oven. Preheat 350. Pop in oven for 20-25 min. Top with frosting. Yummy
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-02-17T08:37:50.01

text:
AMAZING! I've just made it twice...first time I put them in the fridge after rolling the dough and baked it in the morning, by turning on the oven and placing them in to warm up as the oven warmed (as per a reviewers suggestion)..the middle ones did not bake...def need more of a warm up time or double the bake time.
Second time I baked them right away, all 12, for 20 mins, could've used an extra 5mins.
I also used cold out of the fridge eggs,  all purpose flour measured as recipe called for, and milk heated for half a minute. The first time i used shortening and second time i used butter....both ways tasted amazing! Also I flipped them right away on to parchment paper, and then put them back in the baking pan to let the goo ooze in..yum! icing is amazingly delicious.
These were delicious! and I will try to master the over night fridge technique. AMAZING recipe! thank you!!!
How many times have i said amazing and delicious?! haha Because they are!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Usually the bread maker directions tell you to put wet ingredients in first, then all dry except yeast, then make a well or hole in the middle of the dry just big enough to put yeast in. I always use fast rising yeast. FYI one of the yeast packets equal 2.5 tsp. Dividing the recipe is confusing. I figured out that the 1/3 cup butter, cinnamon, and brown sugar were the filling and then the rest are cream cheese frosting. Good outcome though. We love the rolls and I love how easy it is to walk away and let my bread machine do the work. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This recipe is really amazing.  The salt ratio is wrong as it is written.  Essentially I doubled the salt content as written and that came out perfect.  Also - use a thermometer to watch the temp and pull them out at 180 degrees.  They'll hit 190-195 sitting in the pan. That way, the muffins are nice and soft - just barely cooked.

text:
amazing! I did as another said .."Someone wanted to know how to make this without a bread machine, here is how. Dissolve the yeast in the warm milk in a large bowl. Mix in the sugar, margarine, salt, and eggs. Add flour and mix well. Knead the dough into a large ball, using your hands dusted lightly with flour. Put in a bowl, cover and let rise in a warm place about 1 hour, or until doubled in size. Then pick up with rolling out the dough." Also let sit in fridge over night and baked at 350 for 20-25 mins the next morning. (for dough to rise: Warm oven-preheated to 200, then turned oven off and let dough rise.)

Also, I mixed the butter with cinnamon sugar before spreading on dough.

text:
I've made these twice now and what I've found was to change it to 8 servings instead of 12 still using just 1 large egg and let it rise 3 times in total.  When I don't have any cream cheese I use maple syrup instead for the glaze. I don't have a bread maker so I just add all the first ingredients and add the yeast last letting it sit for a minute before mixing it with a mixer for about 4 minutes. This is a great recipe as is but I like to tweak things to put a personal touch

country:
None
text:
I used stand mixer instead of bread machine; softened butter instead of melted margarine; instant yeast instead of active yeast; room temperature milk instead of warm milk. I had long rise time. My first rise is at least 1.5 hour longer. I also only used half of the brown sugar in filling which already gave me enough sweet. As suggested by some reviewers, be remembered to leave 1/4" margin at the far side in spreading for better dough-dough sealing; roll it from the long side and from middle to edge; cut using dental floss and cool upside down for the drippings to coat back the rolls. Next time I shall try 4 tsp instant yeast and 1 Tsp cinnamon.

text:
I made these rolls and the rolls seemed tough. After reading others reviews I made the dough in my bread machine. I did as one reviewer suggested, I mixed the brown sugar, cinnamon, and butter together first before spreading it onto the dough. I put my rolls on parchment so if the sugar mixture leaked out I could turn the rolls upside down. Maybe I went wrong by following s reviewer that rolled and cut my rolls then placing them in the fridge overnight. I placed them in a cold oven and let them bake 20 min. They rose just fine and looked great. As another reviewer said to put some icing on them while warm to keep them moist and then icing them with the remainder of the icing later. The dough just seemed tough. I told my husband, make sure you nuke them before you eat them so they will be soft.  Could it be how they are kneaded in the bread machine? Overnighting the rolls in the fridge? Or just the dough recipe? The rolls still tasted good, but truly I was disappointed.  Maybe it's just me, the baker? Any suggestions would be appreciated!

None
text:
Fantastic! My family and I devoured them. Then I realized I forgot to put the icing on! Never in my life did I think I could make cinnamon rolls this good. I didn't even need a bread machine. I dissolved the yeast and sugar in the warm milk. I incorporated the other ingredients, kneaded it, then let it proof until double in size. Then I picked up at the rolling out step. Once I had them all together, I put them in the fridge overnight. The next morning, I placed them in a cold oven with a shallow pan of boiling water underneath for about 20 min for the second rise. Then, I took everything out and preheated the oven. I baked at 400 for 20 min.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! I veganized it by subbing with: almond milk; Earth Balance spread (the soy free one); flax "egg" (1 Tb ground flax + 2 1/2 Tb water = 1 "egg").
I also kneaded the dough for a total of 15 minutes (I took breaks, haha), since I don't own a bread machine. Yummy, gooey, perfect. I might add more cinnamon next time, though. For the frosting I just used Tofutti "cream cheese" (the one with hydrogenated oils, since I read it tastes better and is thicker than the one made without hydrogenated oils: I know, I know, its unhealthy) with some powdered sugar. Yummy, as well.
These cinnamon rolls freeze well (the dough), and so does the frosting (as another reviewer mentioned). Excellent for popping into the toaster oven (set on warm to let them rise). 
Keeper recipe. You'll be pleased with the results. :)

text:
This review is a 5 star when making a few minor adjustments . I made it about 15 times and around the 5th time of making them i decided to bake them at 350 for 25 min. This is the best!!!  They are more fluffy and soft, and not as over baked. Also for even more tender cinnamon rolls allow the rolls to bake for 10 min, take them out and pour about a tablespoon of heavy whipping cream on each cinnamon roll and put it back in the oven for the last 15 min of baking. This will definitely turn your cinnamon roll into a Cinnabon roll. No regrets I only make it this way from now on. Mmmmm I have some in my fridge waiting for me :)

I would give 5 stars for what I actually made, which was not this recipe exactly, but it was my starting point. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Decided to try this out, and switch it up from my normal recipe. This was overall tasty. I made my dough in a stand up mixer with dough hook attachment..and then kneaded it by hand for about 8 minutes. I used a quick rise yeast so i just set it aside for 10 minutes while i got the filling ready. Rolled it, filled it, and shaped the dough in a greased dish. Covered it really tightly and put in the fridge overnight.(i wanted fresh buns for breakfast) I pulled the buns out about an hour before baking..then put them in a cold oven and baked away. These were good, not great..the dough is missing something for me.. (maybe vanilla )We don't have Cinnabon here in Canada so i wasnt sure what to compare to, other that the regular recipe i use. I am happy i finally tried this...and so glad that these can be made night before with positive results.
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:
2015-08-29T13:13:33.993

text:
I had to make a few alterations because this recipe was a last minute thing. I used all purpose flour instead of bread flour and instant yeast instead of the bread yeast. I just kneaded it by hand and put it in a greased bowl to rise. After that I just rolled it out and added the butter/sugar/cinnamon as per the recipe. After that I put it in a pan put it (covered) in the fridge until time to bake (I was making them as a dessert and I still had a few hours before I needed them). When time to bake rolled around, I uncovered them and followed baking directions. Perfectly risen and golden

country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls are delicious. I didn't give this recipe 5 stars because I do think it was necessary to change a few things from the original recipe. I didn't think it was very much like a cinnabon but they are still good. 
I like my filling plentiful. In order to achieve that I used more butter, cinnamon, and sugar. I doubled the amount called for in the recipe. I suggest rolling the dough pretty thin. (I found that the Cinnabon rolls have a thinner dough that is rolled up more) The baking time is pretty accurate but always double check rolls. (never open the oven unless they are done or you will lose the necessary heat) 
I have made these cinnamon rolls numerous times and always change it up by adding something else. Try pecans next time around.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
0
userID:
7310564
Display Name:
tmistyd
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
117
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As is this recipe is a solid 3, but the bones of the recipe are good. With a few changes it's easily a 5, hence my 4 star review.

I make the dough portion of the recipe exactly as is except I substitute butter for the margarine.. We don't use margarine in our house and I find it really odd when a recipe calls for both butter and margarine considering most households choose one or the other and rarely use both. 

The filling is good but doesn't make near enough so I double it. These are cinnamon rolls, not health food. If they're going to be bad for you don't skimp on the good part. Now where I majorly differ from the recipe is I don't spread the butter and then sprinkle with the cinnamon sugar. Instead I combine them together then kind of massage the entire mixture onto the rolled dough. I find this keeps the filling from leaking out of the rolls better. It also more evenly distributes the flavor. 

Per the suggestion of other reviewers I bake the rolls for 20 minutes at 350 so they don't over brown. 

Finally, the icing... I accidentally misread the recipe the first time around and used a full 8oz package of cream cheese. I've never even seen 3oz packages at my grocery store. I do everything else as written then throw it all in the microwave for about 30 seconds to make it more liquidy. This makes more of a cinnabon textured paste/icing rather than the drizzly stuff pictured. Cinnabon glops their icing on, so I will continue to use a full 8oz package of cream cheese.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-01-04T08:29:04.633

This was soooooo much work and the end result was too dry and had the faint unpleasant taste of yeast. They did look beautiful and I didn't have the problem of leaking filling even though I never turned the pan upside down like people recommended. But the best part of the Cinnabon is the soft moist gooey innards and this did not have that at all. Just dry cinnamon-sugary bread. And I didn't skimp on the butter!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for my family over the weekend, and it was a big hit !! so some changes i made to the recipe: I wanted to keep it dairy free so i changed the milk to soy milk, and butter to margarine. I didnt have bread flour, so I just used regular all purpose, and it came out perfectly fine. I also didnt use a bread machine, followed the instructions from one of the comments. For the butter to spread on the dough once rolled, 1/3 cup in my opinion was wayyyy too much, so I just used however much I needed to lightly spread on. As for the cinnamon filling, it made just enough to cover the dough, I thought it could have used more. For the frosting, I made a simple glaze from confectioners sugar, soy milk and vanilla. All in all was great, and I will definitely make it again !!!!!!!!!

This recipe was good, but I overcooked it because it didn't brown the way suggested and by the time it did brown, all the cinnamon sugar had melted out the bottom and both bottom and top were hard as stale bread. My oven is 3 months old and a perfect tempature, so I know it was not that. Next time (and I will try it again using the exact timing) I will brush the top with egg yolk wash before baking. text:
It was a good recipe in all, but I don't think it's worth the time and effort to make a dozen cinnamon rolls. The recipe also doesn't specify what 'ingredients' to put in the bread machine. You put the first section (up until the first space) into the bread machine. The second section is for the 'cinnamon-sugar' mix, and the third is for the topping. It was OK, but I am more satisfied with the ones you can just drive to your local baker and get.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I chose this recipe mainly because I had a bread maker that was gathering dust in my kitchen (I usually make my bread by hand) and was feeling rather lazy on this Sunday.  This recipe is, in short, amazing.  I followed it exactly and took the advice of another reviewer, flipping the pan over for about 10 minutes as soon as they were done to let the filling run back over the rolls.  This results in filling that comes up and over the top of the roll just a bit, making it extra good!  I thought the frosting was good as well.  This recipe is a keeper and I'll definitely be using this one in the future.  There's nothing like cinnamon rolls with the bread maker doing half the work for you.

But I thought they were amazing, BUT then I tried Cinnamon rolls III... And they were infinitely lighter and softer and fluffier.but I kept this frosting, as this was perfect to me, and theirs seemed too high on the cheese. So I'll use their dough and this frosting and my own filling.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was fantastic! I brought this to a bridal shower and everyone raved about it, the bride-to-be was even complimenting them in my thank you card! I took other reviewer's advice and flipped the pan so that all the drippings soaked back into the cinnamon buns rather than sticking to the pan. Also, if you're looking for more of a true cinnabon icing add in 1-2 tbsp of fresh lemon juice and you'll get that little bit of zing that this icing recipe is missing. You should be wipping the icing for at least 12 minutes to get the right texture. I will definitely be making these again.

text:
This is a VERY good recipe....very easy with breadmaker. A special note if you plan on doubling this recipe (by hand making): Do NOT put 2 dozen rolls in a large pan to cook.  The cinnamon rolls will NOT get done and there will be no way to salvage the undercooked middle ones.  (Believe me, I tried.) It's better to stick to using 2 9x13s.  :)

text:
Perfect cinnamon rolls!  My guys loved them!  I had self rising flour and omitted the salt and I had instant yeast. I added a teaspoon of surgar to the yeast with 1/4 cup warm milk and let it set for 10 minutes. I too do not have a bread machine and making them by hand was no problem. I also liked the tip of setting a bowl of hot water in the warm oven to help them rise. Thank you all.

This recipe is pretty good, but i think that this could be a lot better. I had made these a couple of times, and 2/3 times it came out of the oven undone. For one batch I put it in the oven for 2 more minutes, so they wouldn't scorch. Unfortunately, the rolls came out burned, and the baking pan came out oily. I actually saw the bottom of the cinnamon rolls, and I saw a coat of brown sugar and cinnamon on the bottom. The overall taste of them is ok, but I think that this recipe could use a little more work. Next time I make cinnamon rolls, I'm making a faster, less troubling recipe.

I have to agree with some of the other reviews and say that my only complaint is that they came out slightly more dense than I wanted to. Cooking at 400 for 15 minutes didn't get the rolls done, yet they were very brown.  Next time, I will try 350 for 20 minutes or more.  Doubling frosting like others suggested made too much, may be 1 1/2 frosting recipe.  The rolls and frosting were wonderful & I will definitely try again.  I also removed from pan right away as suggested and had no problems with my filling oozing out.  I wasn't thinking and mixed the butter in with the brown sugar and cinnamon and just had to sprinkle on dough, but maybe this is what kept all of the good stuff from oozing out!

text:
These came out awesome!!  I am currently on mat leave and trying to get more into baking.  Was looking for a good cinnamon roll recipe and found this great one!  Followed the recipe (using the recommended non-breadmaker method) exactly.  One thing extra I did (which was the only good thing I got from a previous recipe I tried) was I added pecans, melted butter and some of the cinnamon/sugar mixture to the bottom of the pan.  When the rolls were done, I flipped the pan over onto a platter and the gooey goodness was the topping for the rolls.  Soooo yummy, but probably not the healthiest.  Thank you for this recipe...this is now my go to dessert special!!

text:
The hardest part was rolling out the dough (wants to spring back). I had to put some muscle into it. If you include rising time, the prep time is closer to two hours. The rolls are very big. I made 1" cuts and I managed to squeeze out about sixteen rolls. I used a second pan. The frosting needs a good whiping, so pour on the power. I think they're better than cinnabon. Rich, moist, bubbling with cinnamon sugar and very yummy. A special family weekend treat.

text:
I tried out this recipe for the first time yesterday (Thanksgiving Day). I used my Zojirushi Bread Maker on the dough setting. When I took out the dough, it was exactly like the video! Perfect texture! Not sticky, or too dry, it rolled out easily. For more space on the counter for rolling, I just used sections of waxed paper. 

After following the recipe exactly, I baked them in a glazed stoneware pan, (I have found that stoneware prevents the bottoms from overcooking when baking) and was actually quite astounded that the finished rolls really DID taste and look just like my favorite Cinnabons! My family absolutely loved them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Definitely delicious. My friends raved about it. I figured 6K folks couldn't be wrong. I tried the suggestion of one person to combine the butter/cinn/sugar & spread it all at once onto the dough. I found that it was a little too dry & that was a real pain to do, but I managed. I think I may opt for the original method next time. I love raisins in my rolls, so I also sprinkled 1/2c of raisins in before I rolled them up. I bet pecans would be delicious too. Last mod I made was I followed the recommendation to bake at 350F for 20-25 mins instead of 400F. One thing I had trouble with is trying to roll out a rectangle! The dough simply doesn't form corners well, so when I rolled it up to cut it, the ones on the very end were not uniform w/ the rest, but they were still tasty. Very good recipe. (although one could argue that it is difficult to make a bad version of fresh dough laden w/ cinn/sugar & covered in sugar/cream cheese!) :D

This is the best recipes for cinnamon buns that I've run into.   Having such a wonderful success, the frozen frosting won't last long.

Ok, this is awesome. I don't have a bread machine so I followed what everyone else said to do, and it worked. I brought them to work and everyone said they were amazing. I have to agree! I found that 1/3c of butter was not enough to cover the rolls so I had to add a little more, and next time I would probably use a little more brown sugar/cinnamon mixture, too. It was barely enough to coat the dough. They were extremely delicious and I will definitely make them again. The frosting is soooooooooooooo good too. It tastes exactly like Cinnabon!!!

userID:
5912271
Display Name:
Rani Ness
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
200
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5831998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous. Needed a snack for my son's leadership team meeting. He wanted cinnamon rolls, but I'd lost my best recipe. Decided to try these.  Amazingly glad we did. Never used brown sugar in the filling before. It's obvious now, but it's new to us. My husband was on his way to get butter for our 'practice run' when I we ran out of time, so used oil in the dough (won't use margarine for health reasons). Pleased with oil, though butter would probably taste better. Did use butter for the filling. Did add a touch of flour a couple of times while kneading the dough. When the dough only barely clung to the top, but cleaned the sides, I stopped adding flour. The dough was amazingly easy to handle, so I wondered if it would be tough, but not at all. Placed formed rolls in a glass casserole sprayed with Baker's Joy. When tops were nicely browned, the bottom wasn't browned at all, so I covered the rolls with foil until the bottoms were just a touch golden. The results? Incredlble! / Made another batch now using oil, half whole wheat, & sucanat (raw sugar). Also used sucanat in the filling. Stopped adding milk when tacky to the touch. Will make white rolls most of the time when sharing for special occasions with others, but we all really enjoyed the half-whole-wheat rolls.  They were gone in no time.  Being healthier, I'm sure that's what we'll continue to do most of the time. Good for dinner rolls too. //  Will try whole wheat without any white, but using some gluten, later in the weak.

These were very easy to make, especially considering how good they are!  The dough is extremely forgiving, and rolls out beautifully.  I baked for 17 minutes to get the wonderfully browned rolls the way I wanted them.  Slightly crunchy on the outside, but nice and chewy on the inside.  The icing is amazing, and I am not ashamed to admit I licked the beaters clean!  Thank you- I will be making these often this fall and winter :)

These are incredible.  Everyone loved them.  The only change I made, was I added about 1/2 tbsp of milk to the frosting.  I found that it was too thick, not turning into frosting.  The milk made it just right.

2nd time making these now in 3 days....I didn't have room temperature eggs, so I zapped them in the microwave for 20 seconds, still in the shell.  Worked like a charm!

text:
This was my first attempt at cinnamon rolls and they were great. Very simple using the bread machine. The only thing is, it took a long time for the rolls to double in size. I had to let them sit over an hour. Probably because I am in Iowa in March and it is cold here. Also, I baked them for 15 min as the recipe stated, but it was a bit too long. They were very dark on top. I should have watched them closer, but once I added the frosting, you couldn't tell. They tasted great. The frosting is SOOO yummy!
