city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My experience with Cinnamon Rolls was limited to ones that come in a can from the refrigerated section of the store... until now.  I recently inherited my mother's bread machine and decided to try this recipe out as it's been languishing in my recipe box forever.  I followed the dough directions exactly, but did add in 1 tsp of vanilla extract as some other reviewers suggested.  The filling is excellent as is - no changes needed!  I'm not a fan of cream cheese icing (I know... something must be wrong with me), so instead I used a simple confectioners sugar/milk mixture with a little vanilla extract for a glaze.  These really are amazing!  Very flavorful and gooey when eaten warm.  I will definitely be making these again... no more canned rolls for us!

text:
I made these for Christmas morning breakfast.  I made them 2 days ahead and popped them in the fridge for a slow rise. Then baked them on Christmas moning.  They were delicious!  The frosting was so good!  I didn't have bread flour, so I used all-purpose.  I also used regular yeast, and did not use a bread machine.   I will definitely make these again!

text:
I tried this recipe 3 times this month and each time turned out differently is the only reason I didn't give it a 5 star review. The first time the dough didn't rise at all. The second time, it barely rose at all but I continued to make the rolls and they tasted great but were the size of the ones you buy in the roll at the grocery store. The dough the second time was gorgeous though! Perfect texture and not too wet or dry. Today was the third time and it was a wet mess. I had to add a ton of extra flour. The icing is wonderful. They are a wonderful roll. Oh, and I'm making my by hand and not in a bread machine. Thanks for sharing!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1234624.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took a shortcut because I was too impatient to make the dough. Bridgeford Dough was on sale at my grocery store so I picked up a package (3 loaves included).  I used the ingredients specified for all three loaves combined. I let the rolls defrost in the fridge - this made them triple in size. My husband forgot to add butter to the insides of our last batch. In a pinch I grabbed butter and placed 1/2T atop each roll. These actually made them taste so much better. This made a sauce accumulate at the bottom of the baking dish.  Immediately after baking, I flipped the rolls upside down so that the sauce would flow down the sides so all sides are coated.  I doubled the cream cheese sauce and added it to the buns right after they came out of the oven and flipped the buns.  Awesome....going to make more tomorrow night. :)

userID:
1554570
Display Name:
the4taals
isPro:
False
followersCount:
116
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
704
favoritesCount:
38
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3158466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I scaled to 8 servings as 3 cups of flour works best for my bread machine. This is what I use: 1 cup milk, 2 eggs, 3 tbsps butter, 1 tsp Butery Sweet Dough baking emulsion, 3/4 tsp salt, 1/3 cup vanilla sugar, 1 tbsp yeast, 1 tbsp vital gluten flour, and 3 cups all purpose flour. I rolled out to 12x24 inches, topped with 1/4 cup butter melted and 1 cup brown sugar and 2 tbsps cinnamon combined. Cut into 12 rolls, 2 inches each. Preheat oven to 400, when I put the rolls in I reduce to 350, bake for 30 minutes, turning and covering with foil halfway through. Frosting 2 oz each cream cheese and butter beaten, add 1 tsp lemon juice and 1 cup icing sugar. Very good and house smells delish!

text:
Great recipe! The only change I made was I added a little milk to the frosting to make it more pourable. I usually place the rolls covered in the fridge overnight after the second rising and bake the next morning and store the leftovers in the fridge, heating them in the microwave when needed. They are still delicious even after a day or two in the fridge. Definitely give these a try-they are worth it.

text:
Excellent recipe.  The dough is very rich, and makes for a dense, and yet, fluffy cinnamon roll.  I usually double the butter/cinnamon/sugar for the middle of rolls, but there is no need for this recipe - there is plenty of filling to make the middle of these rolls yummy and flavorful.  There is a LOT of cinnamon - which I really liked, but I wouldn't add anymore.  I will absolutely make these again.

text:
This recipe was so delicious!!! I had a little bit of trouble when I was making the dough because I don't have a bread machine. I actually don't think I did this right, but I just added a packet of active dry yeast to the warm milk and let it set...which it didn't do very well. The dough only rose by about 1/3 of its original size, but I kneaded it down and let it rise after I put in the filling and cut it, and it did ok! I got rave reviews! DELICIOUS

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cinnamon rolls were absolutely fabulous. Like many other cooks on here, I do not have a bread machine (hopefully will get one for Christmas), so I was grateful to find the substitutions for making this without the bread machine.  Everything else, I followed to the T. The rolls came out delicious. While they do not taste just like Cinnabon, they are close. If you really want to get these closer to Cinnabon, I would add even more cinnamon and brown sugar and probably made the rolls a bit bigger in themselves by rolling them up on the short side and making 6 of them in a 9 x 9 pan. But, doing them this way was fine. Some cooks said it was too much cinnamon/sugar mix, but if you love cinnamon, you could add even more and be OK. Thanks for the recipe! I will make these again very soon, when my waistline recovers from this batch .

text:
My sister and I made these, following the alternate instructions for people without bread machines, and they came out *exactly* like the cinnabons sold at the mall. Also, we followed another commenter's suggestion to flip the cinnabons after they were taken out of the oven so that the gooey insides wouldn't sink to the bottom. Oh, and baking the cinnabons for only 15 minutes yielded an underdone batch for us; popping them in the microwave for an additional 30 seconds helped.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the best cinnamon rolls ever. I myself don't eat treats like this but I actually had a full one.They are especially good with this frosting: Caramel Frosting 1 stick butter, 1 cup brown sugar, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/4 cup milk, 1 tsp vanilla, 2 1/2 cup powdered sugar. Melt butter in a saucepan over low heat. Blend in brown sugar, and salt. Cook on low for 2 minutes, stirring constantly. Add milk. Remove from heat and add vanilla. Let cool then add powdered sugar. :)

text:
I made these exactly as directed, with the exception of all purpose flour instead of bread flour. They turned out great! I didn't have problems with the filling seeping out, they are perfect. Do they taste like Cinnabon? I don't really think so, but they are still the best that I have ever made... It's good if you're going to be around the house all evening to work on them. They don't take an unreasonable amount of time, but you have to be available to do little bits and pieces of the process over several hours! We will definitely make these again!

I made them exactly as the recipe called for, except that I did the dough by hand instead of bread machine. I personally prefer a sweeter dough for my cinnamon rolls, but this was excellent. I will probably try them with a little more sugar in the dough next time, and a little less in the filling. The frosting was awesome. It was the best cinnamon roll frosting I have made. That is the one thing my family commented on more than anything else about this recipe. All of them want me to make this again.

userID:

Display Name:
jerseysmom
isPro:

12

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are amazing!  It was my first time making cinnamon rolls from scratch, but they turned out really yummy!  A couple of suggestions for others making this....after you put the rolls in the pan, let them rise for an hour so they get nice and big. Also, double the icing....what the recipe calls for is not enough. After making these a couple of times I HIGHLY recommend using a glass dish, they came out perfectly (in a metal dish they didn't bake evenly). Delicious!!
Review:
Rating:

This recipe is awesome! Just like those from Cinnabon. I followed most part of the recipe, except for the amount of sugar used in filling , I ended only using 2/3 of the amount it calls for. Also, for the frosing, I used 20g less.  It came out great. I refridgerated the cinnabon before baking. I think it would be better if I let it sit at the counter for an hour before baking, so it will give a better rise for the roll.

text:
#1 MOST IMPORTANT TIP!!!!!: make a full batch of frosting by using the whole 8 oz cube of cream cheese: 2/3 c butter, 3+3/4 c powdered sugar, 1+1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/3 tsp salt. the frosting is the BEST part and trust me, you'll be glaaad there's plenty to go around! I used all purpose flour and they came out perrrfectly. Also used the tips on how to do it without a bread machine.

text:
This recipe is fantastic! After the first time I made this I changed it slightly. My bread machine seems to let the dough rise more than necessary so I halved the dough once it was ready to roll out. The two smaller rolls are easier to handle and then the recipe turns out smaller, more reasonable proportions. The rolls also stay nice and soft longer than other recipes.

text:
Really yummy cinnamon rolls.  The only thing is when I pulled them out of the oven they still seemed doughy and not done.  I had already iced them as the top looked brown, but decided to put them back in to let the bottom finish cooking.  I put foil over them so the icing wouldn't burn.  Let them cook a little longer (5 - 7 mins) and then pulled them out a second time.  Gooey, yummy, sweet treats.  I couldn't imagine eating more than one in a setting.  I think I will freeze the rest and save them for a gathering we're having this weekend.

userID:
3711932
Display Name:
Brenda
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cannot believe how EASY it was to make these cinnamon rolls using the bread machine.  My eggs weren't at room temperature and I didn't measure the milk's temperature, but there is no sign that those 2 factors had any negative effect.  I did follow one reviewer's advice to mix melted butter, brown sugar and cinnamon together and spread over the dough.  It wasn't a spreading consistency and was impossible to get evenly spread, but the end result was fine and it didn't run out into the bottom of the pan using this method.  I did not use wax paper in the bottom of the pan or flip them out as soon as they were done.  I left them in the pan for several hours and they came right out.  I don't know for sure if this is because of using the melted butter/sugar mix or not, but I had no problems in this area whatsoever like some other reviewers have had.  This was my first attempt at cinnamon rolls and I'm hooked.  I've never had a Cinabon, but if this is what they taste like, they're great.  I have had Grands cinnamon rolls with cream cheese icing, which I love and I would put these in the same gooey, texture category as a Grands...minus the "canned" taste.  I also thought the amount of butter/sugar was perfect and the amount of icing was perfect also.  The only thing I don't like is that by using the bread machine, I'm limited to making a batch of 12 rolls.  SUPER RECIPE!!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-02-07T11:52:28.6
helpfulCount:
0

text:
My family loved the bread portion but preferred the filling & topping from my bread maker recipe book.  Filling: 1/2 Cup butter, 1/3 Cup sugar, 3 Tablespoons cinnamon. Melt butter, combine all, spread on rolled out dough.  Topping: 3/4 Cup butter, 1 1/2 Cup light brown sugar. We don't use the cream cheese.

I guess the only difference I had was that there was no way my rolls were fitting in a 9x13 pan.  I put 5 rolls in 8x8 pan, and 6 rolls in an 8x12 pan.  They fit just right.  I was a little curious about the 400 degrees and 15 min cooking.  When I ate a roll right out of the oven it was a little doughy/gooey, but I like them that way!!  Tasted amazing!!  But, as the rolls sat a few hours until we ate them for supper the doughy-ness was gone and they were still very soft and delicious.  I say this for those who may, or may not, like that doughy type of roll.  Very, very good rolls.  I plan to try out the "soft, moist, and gooey cinnamon roll" recipe to see which I like better.  I will absolutely make this again.

OMG, my family LOVES this recipe!  Delicious!  I don't have a bread machine, so I mix the dough in my stand mixer, about 5 min., until the dough clings to the hook.  I had to add a little extra flour to keep the dough from sticking.  These rolls are huge!  I  make 24 smaller rolls and freeze half of them to bake later.

text:
Awesome.  I'm not a fan of preparing bread dough, but when I saw this receipe I had to try it.  Our Christmas tradition has always been to have cinnamon rolls on Christmas morning but I've used Pillsbery canned.  I will never do that again, these will be our new Christmas tradition.  I followed the receipe exactly as it's written, prepared them the day before, then put them in the frig.  I took them out and let them sit for 30 minutes, then put them in a warm oven (about 150 degrees) for another 30 minutes.  Then I cranked up the temp to start the cooking process.  They came out perfect.

I can't believe how great these are. I followed directions, but added a lot more (5oz) cream cheese to the frosting. Also, I melted 1/4c of butter in a saucepan and stirred in 1/4c brown sugar until it was dissolved and poured it over the rolls after they were done baking to add extra goo. Also, as other suggested, lowered temp to 350 and baked about 20-25 mins.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect dough for sweet rolls.  I used real butter instead of margarine, since I had it on hand and knew the rolls wouldn't need to last.  The only change I made to the filling was that I added 1 c of chopped toasted pecans and mixed the filling ingredients together. I then sprinkled that filling over the dough and rolled it in. The filling stayed put - no drips.  Also pre-made these rolls and kept them in the fridge overnight.  I brought them out for about 30 min before baking.  They weren't fully risen, as one other reviewer noted, but rose perfectly in the oven.    Light and tasty - definitely to be eaten right away.

text:
I followed the directions that ANDYTAMI left, since I don't have a bread machine.  I preheated my oven to 200 degrees and then TURNED THE OVEN OFF so  the dough could rise and that worked great.  The only thing I changed was I baked at 350 degrees for 15 minutes.  These were TO DIE FOR.  Only problem I had was after forming them into the rolls, they didn't rise much the second time around, but they turned out beautifully.  WILL BE MAKING AGAIN!

text:
So delicious!  My husband had 2 right out of the oven.  Very tasty.  This recipe was easy to make, I enjoyed it a lot.  I didn't have a bread mixer, so I took the advice of one of the reviewers and made the dough by hand, and it turned out fabulous!  I didn't have 2 eggs and so I had to substitute one of the eggs with 3 Tbs. of mayonnaise.  The end product turned out delicious.  The frosting really made it taste like the cinnabons at the mall.  Love it!  I will be making it again.

country:
None
text:
These were good, I went a little lighter on the cinnamon and thought it was good (more like 1 1/2 tablespoons.)  I followed the directions except I let them sit in the fridge overnight, then in the morning sat them out 20 minutes then into the oven at 350 for a little longer.  They came out looking beautiful and very tasty.  I've been looking for the perfect cinnamon roll recipe.  I thought these were similar to the cinnabons - but like the cinnabons very sweet, cinnamony, and heavy heavy heavy.  If I try this recipe again I will let the dough rise longer in an effort to get a lighter roll, and also use less filling.  They were really good though.  :)  Between me, my husband, and my two young boys the whole pan lasted under 2 days!

5 stars AS IS - but if your in a hurry you can make with biscuits -quick and easy- I rolled the biscuits into a snake then flatten to 3/4" to 1" wide X around 12" long-covered with butter and cinnamon mix -bake to desired doneness -I like mine a little crispy- then I warm up the frosting and drizzle it over the top - Excellent- took me about 45 minutes total

text:
Superb!  Do need to make sure to bake the full time, as the first time I made them they were a bit doughy for my taste (everyone else said they were fine, though!)  Edit: 1st time I made this I used my bread machine, which has since broken.  Made these last night without one and they turned out superb again :)  I ran out of white flour and used 1 cup of wheat, used less butter for the filling (another ingredient I didn't have enough of!) and they still are absolutely amazing!  Also, took another reviewers suggestion and baked them at 350 for 20 minutes- they cooked better that way then the first time.

text:
I love this recipe. I make the dough in my bread machine and then do as previous reviewers have suggested--I prepare the dough and roll and let it rise overnight. Next morning, I pop it in the oven and house wakes up to a delicious aroma!
 I have substituted up to one cup of whole wheat flour, and have used almond milk instead of regular milk. But since this is not a low cal, healthy  recipe to begin with, I usually just indulge myself and make it as is. The recipe really does live up to it's name-took this to a recent brunch and everyone thought I picked them up at Cinnabon! Delicious! Thanks for sharing.

text:
EXCELLENT. Never actually had a cinnabon so I don't know if it tastes the same but it was certainly the BEST cinnamon roll recipe (AND FROSTING RECIPE BY FAR!) that I have ever found.  I did not make it in a bread maker, I followed another's advice on how to do it without.   Decreased cinnamon to 2 1/2 teaspoons instead of tablespoons because it seemed like a lot.  I would increase it next time though, it didn't seem quite cinnamon-y enough. Also, I had to take the rolls out earlier than the recipe called for and they browned quickly. And I would make a little more frosting next time, it was EXCELLENT!

Display Name:
SJMOLL

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fantastic!  You couldn't ask for anything closer to a Cinnabon!  I don't have a bread machine, so I prepared them by hand the night before and put them in the refrigerator, but they were still great.  My only complaint is that the icing had too much cream cheese flavor. I tried out 7 other icing recipes and came up with 2 good ones.  My favorite (that I reduced): 1 pound Margarine, 1 pound cream cheese, 2 pounds powdered sugar, 2 teaspoons lemon juice, 2 teaspoons vanilla extract.  For something with a little more cream cheese flavor: 8 oz cream cheese, 1 1/2 teaspoons of vanilla, 1/2 C butter, 3 C powdered sugar, 1 T cream.  My only other questions for some of you is why on earth would want to wait to let the frosting SET??  I don't even see how you can wait that long, let alone understand why :)

text:
my very 1st time making cinnamon rolls and it was not too bad. i left it too long in the oven and tops became a little on the crunchy side, but it was soft and moist on the inside-just right. i would definitely make this again. after rising,the dough just stuck to the sides of the bowl so next time i will definitely oil my bowl before putting my dough in it. i would also recommend doubling the filling. i just used a glaze, didn't have cream cheese and it was still great. thanks for sharing the recipe!

text:
Yum :)  I made mine with all purpose flour but I used about a quarter cup less of it than asked for because the dough seemed to solid.  They turned out perfect, although they needed a little longer to rise.  I baked them at 350 till just golden on top and then flipped the pan over for a little while to make sure to get all the good stuff.  They turned out perfect, although next time I'd use slightly less frosting, and maybe add raisins :)  Thanks for the recipe, they're awesome.

country:
None
text:
Amazing. I was craving conjured cinnamon rolls and these hit the spot.   These fabulous rolls are indeed a clone of a cinnabon, slightly smaller than a full size cinnabon, slightly bigger than a minibon - the perfect size.  I do not have a bread machine, so I used the suggestion of rising the ingredients in a warmed oven. I also cooked it at 350 for 33 minutes.  Slightly crisp on the outside - gooey on the inside. Melt all over divine frosting.  Just give in and do it.

text:
I just made these and they are almost gone! They do live up to the standard, the recipe is awesome. I was a little nervous about the dough being a little to dry, but when I let it rest it turned out to be okay. I also used a 1/4 c (4oz)of cream cheese for the frosting. I mixed the brown sugar, cinnamon and butter in a bowl then spread it all over the dough. I also didn't use a bread machine, I followed the instructions mentioned, of putting the yeast in the warm milk and then adding the sugar milk butter eggs salt then the flour. I kneaded it for a bit and it turned out just fine.

Phenomenal!  These were wonderful!  I did not use a bread machine; they turned out great.  I baked at 350 for 25 minutes in a metal 13x9 inch pan.  I may add to the cinnamon and brown sugar mixture a bit to make them more like Cinnabons (Cinnabons seem to have a LOT of gooey filling)-- but they really are perfect without any modifications to the recipe.  This one's a keeper for sure!  Thanks a million Marsha!

I have made numerous batches of these now, and they are certainly a hit.  My father is Cinnabon-crazed & thinks these may be even better!  I followed the other users suggestions and blended the butter/brown sugar/cinnamon filling & spread on the dough. These are definitely worth the time & effort!!

I made these for mother's day brunch and they are SSSSSOOOOOOOOO GOOD!! It was SO much easier and more uniform. With the frosting, I doubled it and used a whole 8oz brick of cream cheese. I didn't have a problem with the filling coming out of the buns(Maybe because I made these the night before and had them in the fridge?) So good.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/198395.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never been super comfortable baking bread but these looked so good I had to try them. I couldn't be happier about the outcome, this recipe is absolutely delicious. I don't have a bread machine so I followed other reviewers instructions on how to get the dough made, and it worked perfectly. I disolved yeast in warm milk (110-115 degrees) for 10 min then added it to a stand mixer with the sugar, and mixed that as I added the butter, eggs, sugar, and salt. Then I added flour 1 cup at a time untill the dough was pulling away from the sides of the bowl. I Turned it out onto a floured surface and kneaded dough untill elastic. Put dough in a lightly greased bowl covered with a damp cloth and put in heated but turned off oven. Let rise for 1 hour or untill doubled in size. Then I followed the remaining instructions on the original recipe. I also added a Tbsp. or two of milk to the frosting to get it the right consistencey. Thanks for such an amazing recipe. I will definately be making these again.

I've made these many times, and have found letting the yeast proof in the milk for at least 10 minutes, and kneading for the same, is necessary for soft, airy bread.  Also, 400 is way too high - the rolls burn at that.  350 works.

userID:
3043820
Display Name:
Selene
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
46
favoritesCount:
297
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/14.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
VERY, VERY delicious! Super cinnamony and sugary! For the first couple of times when I made it, the filling kept falling out. Then, I found that it is the butter that moistens the sugar into a paste and prevents it from scattering all over your working surface. So there are two solutions to it: either you decrease the amount of sugar to slightly less than 3/4 cup, or you can increase the amount of butter to 1/2 cup. Also, 1 1/2 tbsp cinnamon should suffice for a moderate taste - but if you like a lot of spice (like I do), then go on and add the other tablespoon!
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2009-03-03T06:00:10.237

Display Name:

text:
This is the best cinnamon roll recipe I have tried.  I was looking for something with a softer, more flavorful roll.  I modified to reduce the amount of butter:  I used the full amount in the dough.  When the dough was rolled out into the rectangle, I brushed the dough with melted butter instead of spreading with 1/3 cup.  I completely omitted the butter from the frosting--the cream cheese is enough.  Maybe the original tastes better, but our family absolutely loved these rolls without knowing what we were missing.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous!  I took some ideas of previous reviewers.  Mixed the butter/brown sugar/cinnamon and then warmed a bit in the microwave to make easier to spread over the dough.  I made them much smaller than 12.  I think I ended up with 28 rolls but then I rolled the dough out much bigger than 16x21.  I lined 3 round cake pans with parchment.  And then after placing in the pans, put in the fridge (covered) to bake in the morning in a cold oven and set temp to 350 baked for 30 min (probably should have taken them out at 25 but it was my first time making them).  Took them to the office and wham they were gone.  :)  2/22/09 update: I think I will modify the recipe to a King Cake for Mardi Gras.  Instead of cutting them into rolls, I will just bring the ends around. Might need to make 2 rings since they rose so much.  Then add colored sugar on top of the frosting.

text:
High Altitude??? I've never had a Cinnabon, but these were good.  I live at  7000 ft, so I'm not sure if it was the altitude, but these didn't cook right.  The rolls on the outside were done, but the middle ones were not cooked all the way.  I had to put them back in and bake them a while longer.  I think next time, I will only cook 6 at a time and make sure they are not touching in the pan. They tasted great and my husband abd boys ate them all and asked why I didn't make a second batch...guess I'll be making them again tomorrow.

I love this recipe. Coming right out of the bread machine, the dough isn't tacky or anything. the only thing that was a little bit more difficult was that the dough was really elastic and I had a harder time rolling it out, but it still turns out great. I would recommend doubling the frosting though. Thank you for changing my family's breakfast! Oh, and it's been great for my pregnancy cravings!

The reason I'm giving this recipe 4 stars is b/c I mistakingly followed the advice of a reviewer that said it was ok to refrigerate over night.  My dough smelled great, it rose as intended and my icing was perfect.  Woke up next morning to take out of the fridge and allow to warm up and rise again before baking and it never did.  I just wanted them to be hot for breakfast w/o having to wake up b4 the roosters to prepare.  Next time I will just bake and reheat.

text:
This recipe gets all the stars in the sky it is so GOOD! I made the dough in my bread machine. Too easy! I also mixed th butter and sugar together and added a little more cinnimon and rubbed it over the dough. The icing was good, but I think I will play with it to get a lighter icing next time just because I prefer it that way. If you don't have the money to buy someone a gift for a birthday, buy them a nice baking pan and fill it with this recipe and provide a lable for baking and what a nice gift to make. I did this for a close friend so she could bake on Christmas morning for her family and think of us. It was very nice.

Yummy!  I will definitely do what other reviewers suggested next time.  I will roll over the filling a few times before rolling into buns, flip the pan after removing from the oven so the filling can settle back into the rolls, and put on half the frosting while they are still hot, then the rest then they are cooled.  What a great recipe!

text:
Delicious!  What a treat!  I did cut down on the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture...3/4 cup and 1 1/2 Tbsp...too much cinnamon for us.  Oh and instead of mixing the butter with the b.sugar/cinn, I just soften the butter and spread on the dough then sprinkle with the br. sugar mixture.  I often make these in the bread machine, form into rolls in pan and stick in the freezer for up to a couple weeks.  Take them out of the freezer the night before you want to bake them, set on the counter and they will be ready to go in the morning!

text:
This recipe is a little too sweet for me. I was craving for cinnamon rolls last weekend and found one recipe that didn't need pudding mix from other site. It called for only 3 cups of bread flour. It was so so so moist and yummy. It was gone in that morning. This time, I thought I tried a different recipe, so I found this clone of a cinnabon. I made it the night before just as I did with the other recipe. It came out a little too doughy and thick. I don't remember how a real cinnabon tastes like, but I personally like it soft and fluffy. This recipe is also too sweet. If I were to give it another try, I would reduce bread flour to 3 3/4 cups and maybe 1/4 cup of sugar for the dough. I used the other icing recipe from cinnamon rolls III on this site. The icing recipe was the best for cinnamon rolls.

text:
Oh my gosh!! These are so close to the real thing.  I have never made cinnamon rolls before this, but I will again thats for sure!!!  I used a couple of others suggestions and they all made a wonderful roll.  For the filling I mixed the butter, brown sugar, and cinnamon together before spreading.  Very easy that way.  I also put waxpaper on the pan I baked it in, and i was able to just pull the rolls out and put it on the table. It made for very easy cutting and serving. For the frosting I added a little bit of lemon juice for an extra zip and it was wonderful, and of course I doubled the frosting too so we could dip the rolls in it just like we would if we were buying it at the store;)  The family gobbled it all up and raved about it too.  YUM!

text:
FABULOUS!!! I used to live in a town that didn’t have a Cinnabon store.  Whenever I would come home I made a B-line for the mall.  I consider myself a Cinnabon connoisseur- having said that this recipe is nearly dead on!  I have never attempted cinnamon rolls before but they were a success. The only issue I had was following other suggestion of turning them over when they are done.  Great idea but I suggest turning them carefully onto a plate so you won’t mangle them as I did.  I made them yesterday, refrigerated them over night and baked them this morning without letting them sit out to rise.  They are AWESOME!

text:
I've tried several cinnamon roll recipes and this one is summed up easily OMG! I took it to work for a potluck (thought we needed a breakfast dish) and I took home an empty pan. Everyone raved about how good they were and couldn't believe how easy they were to make when I told them. I did everything the night before up to the point of letting them rise 30 min. Instead I put them in the fridge and the next morning I let them rise in a warm oven, baked and then frosted. Out of this world - Thanks!

text:
These were really good. Next time though, I'll only roll the dough into a rectangle about half the size the recipe says to. It was way too hard to roll it out that big, and I think doing so really over-worked the dough. This also contributed to the dough being an uneven thickness, which made it really hard to  cook the rolls, as parts some were really thin and some were really thick. Also, I doubled the frosting recipe because I love frosting, but won't do that next time - it was way too much!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these for the first time this weekend...amazing!  My husband was in heaven and said he thought they were better than Cinnabon.  Used my bread machine to prep the dough, and after reading reviews decided to mix the melted butter, cinnamon, and sugar together for the filling rather than brushing on the butter and sprinkling with cinnamon/sugar - worked perfectly!  It stayed in the rolls and did not run out during baking.  I did not let the rolls double in size after assembly (I was running out of time!) so I simpy put them in the cold oven and allowed them to rise while the oven was preheating.  I'll definitely be using this recipe again and am going to try the suggestion of freezing the rolls and icing for single servings.

text:
I tried this recipe last night and wasn't to excited about it. They were good but not awesome. The cinnamon sugar mixture wasn't gooey like a real cinnabon, and it seemed to dry up a bit. And in my opinion there wasn't enough. I followed other reviews and mixed the cinnamon and brown sugar with the butter, maybe I shouldn't have done that..... I think I will try this recipe again, but make quite a few changes. For one, I won't roll the dough out that much and I will cut the edges off to make it a perfect rectangle. I might add walnuts or pecans to the filling, and I'll do the filling how the recipe says to. And I might line the bottom of the pan with parchment paper. Hopefully these changes might work out better for me. I guess I'll have to see when I try them again.

text:
It was good, but nothing to go gaga over. I don't have a breadmaker so I followed the suggestions given to make it without. This was also my first experience using yeast. Everything went well and they baked up beautifully. I also inverted the pan shortly after coming out of the oven. I didn't use the icing recipe given. I just made a confectioner sugar glaze and drizzled it over the top. I'm glad I did. The rolls were sweet enough on their own without the icing suggested. 
I will keep this recipe and probably make it occasionally, but I will also keep looking for that WOW recipe.

text:
Well, I wouldn't say these were out of this world, but they are good.  I have made these numerous times and always have a problem with them drying out if we don't eat them IMMEDIATELY out of the oven; maybe that's the nature of them?  Anyway, my 11-year old son requests these all the time and when I make them, he will eat them until he is blue in the face!  They freeze fantastically!  After you cut them into individual rolls, place on a cookie sheet in a single layer, freeze them then place into freezer bags for later enjoyment!  I think the amount of cinnamon is right on; I can't imagine any less like some have suggested; I guess it's just a matter of personal preference!  Thank you for this recipe.

text:
This recipe is great!  It's even easier if you start with frozen bread dough.  Thaw the dough as recommended on the package and prepare the cinnamon rolls the night before.  Cover and place in refrigerator.  The next morning, remove from the refigerator and warm for 30 min. - 1 hr on the counter.  Bake as directed.

text:
Following others' advice, I dissolved a packet of yeast in warm milk and kneaded the dough by hand instead of using a bread machine.  I also doubled the frosting recipe and sprinkled chopped pecans along with the cinnamon/sugar mixture before rolling the dough.  A few extra pecans on top won't hurt either!  Overall, the cinnamon rolls turned out delicious!  According to my family, they were even better than the store-bought ones!

text:
Oh My Gosh! That is all there is to say about these! Obviously they are great, (almost 2000 people have said so!) I used fat- free cream cheese and Splenda to lower the calories a bit... It was fantastic! A word of caution.. they need to be cooked 20 min at least becuase I did 15 and they weren't done all the way. Also, if you have leftovers, (which is rare), they don't heat up so well... at least in the microwave. They are still great, a litle tough, but still good! Thanks for the recipe!

On the latest batch I did not have enough cream cheese. So I added plain yogurt. However I let it sit in a coffee filter while I made the dough so I could remove most of the liquid from the yogurt. text:
I was impressed by these, but I think that I have had better. Althought they had the best aroma of all the cinnamon buns Ive made. It smelt as if you were standing in line at Cinnabon. I used another icing because I did not have cream cheese and it was very good indeed. Make sure your oven in calibrated correctly with these because the tops darken fast, and if your oven tends to run hotter than others, you must keep your eye on them. Good standard recipe, works wonderfully. A good recipe for first time cinnamon roll bakers. These are good for the type of person who doesnt like tooo gooey of cinnamon buns, but still very moist. Would be define with pecans.

text:
These are time consuming, but SO worth it. I made them the night before without a bread machine, using the recommendations from other reviewers. After all prep work was done, I covered the pan with sarap wrap and stuck them in the fridge. In the morning, I put them in the cold oven after setting temp to 350. Baked for 25 mins --they rose perfectly and tasted awesome! I will be making these from now on for special morning occasions. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
When they are at the stage where you have them formed and need to let them rise, freeze. Then, let them thaw at least 24 hours in the frig and then let them come to room temp and rise before baking. Throwdown: Sticky Buns You can freeze them for up to 3 months in airtight container or good zip bag.

text:
The family rates these only a 4 because they are so sweet. I can't think of any way to make them less sweet except to make less filling or frosting. I made 1/2 recipe and got 8 nice sized rolls that I put in the refrigerator over night and the next morning raised them on a heating pad (thanks to an earlier reviewer who suggested doing so).  The only change I made in the recipe was to substitute almond extract in the frosting for the vanilla--just a personal preference.  The only change I would make would be to make them in a bigger pan (used and 8x8 pyrex pan) so they get more done in the middle.  Oh...I also added raisins to the filling which every liked.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
simply delicious. i made it the semi-homemade way, tho. i used refrigerated biscuits and cut them in fours with a pizza cutter. i mixed the brown sugar/cinnamon mixture up ahead of time and put it in a tupperware container to pull out whenever i need it. i put the pieces in a single layer and bake with the directions of the biscuits, mine were 400 degrees for 10-12 minutes, i think. they were a little dry the first time so the second time i made them this is exactly what i did. i poured melted marg over the pieces and mixed them around. then i sprinkled the mix over them and baked them. at 10 minutes i pulled them out, mixed a little more of the mix with some more melted marg and stirred them around in it. then melted a little cream cheese frosting (thanks, betty crocker) in a bowl and drizzled it over them with a spoon. OMG! made it for a church breakfast and they were gone in seconds. i'm sure it's even better with homemade bread, but i just don't have the time. thanks!

text:
These were wonderful!!!  I made them for Easter brunch and everyone loved them!  I made the dough by hand using warm milk and 1/4c splenda with the yeast.  I refridgerated the cinnamon rolls and put them in a cold oven and heated it to 350* in the morning!  I baked them for 22 minutes!  I also doubled the icing, but I think it was toomuch, even for extra dipping.  I think next time I will make 1 1/2 times icing!  My husband has already asked me to make more, and there is still one left!  I have a feeling I will be making these on a regular basis!  Thanks for the recipe, it will save me lots of money!!!

This recipe turned out awesome! I followed the other users as I don't have a bread machine, and I put the dough in the fridge over night after kneading the dough the first time after everything was mixed. I also doubled the frosting.

The filling didn't fall out after they were baked, but more so when I was cutting them because it's so dry. I think mixing the stuff with butter may work, but I just scooped up the extra sugar mixture and sprinkled it on top.

Anyway, I have made tons of cinnamon rolls and these were by far the best!

text:
I give this recipe 4 stars instead of 5 based on personal preferrence.  I don't have a bread machine so I took the advice of another reviewer on making the dough the standard way without the help of the bread machine.  Aside from the fact that the recipe was a little time consuming like any yeast bread recipe it was really simple.  The dough came out great - a good texture and wasn't sticky at all.  I used the dough hook on my mixer, so the kneading part was really simple.  

As for why I give the recipe 4 stars instead of 5?  I think the filling needs more cinnamon, and next time I'll experiment with the icing making it with all cream cheese instead of butter and cream cheese.

text:
These are really good. My partner, who adores cinnamon rolls, declared these her very favorite. I'm more of a 'sticky bun' person, so while I liked these very much, there wasn't enough caramel gooey-ness for me. However, the frosting is very good -- I would NOT double the frosting, but that's because I don't like a lot of frosting. The dough is very nice and comes out fluffy and yeasty and delicious. Definitely do the flip and THEN frost. Very, very easy in the bread machine. I even messed up and somehow turned the machine off before they were done rising, but I just let them sit another 15 minutes and they still came out perfectly.

What I changed was that I used all purpose flour (about 5 cups), an 8 gram pack of dry active yeast and white sugar. Then put them in the fridge over night and in the morning put them in a warm place for 30 minutes. I baked them for 20 minutes in 180 degrees C. They came out delicious! 
I didn't use the frosting because they were too sweet.

text:
This recipe makes the best cinnamon rolls and all my friends, family, and even co-workers would agree.  I have never made cinnamon rolls before and I am a novice in the kitchen but I made THREE batches of these over the last week and everyone absolutley loved them.  I have a bread machine so it was super easy, I just added the ingredients in the order listed to the machine and the dough came out perfect.  I followed the recipe as shown and didn't have any problems at all. There was plenty of icing so I am not sure if I would double it like others have suggested.  The only thing I did differntly was put them in the fridge over night before baking them to save time in the morning.  Try them and you will see why they are rated so high!

text:
I am sorry to report I am dissapointed in this recipe.  I followed the roll recipe exacty as posted. Warmed milk to the exact temperature,eggs at room temp, measured flour correctly, rolled to the correct size, made 12 rolls... The rolls did not rise as much as they should and they were not airy, they were pretty dry.  I even let them rise much longer and definitely in a warm place in hopes they would. I will try again with more yeast & less flour. I did not use this frosting recipe as I prefer cream cheese frosting on pumpkin bars & carrot cake but not on rolls. Just needs some tweaking.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2007-12-24T13:21:58.147
helpfulCount:
0

text:
These were really good, but almost a little too sweet.  I doubled the frosting like a lot of people suggested, but I think next time I make them I'll just make the 1 batch of frosting.  I also don't have a breadmaker so I don't know if that was the reason, but my rolls didn't raise a whole lot.  They tasted really good, but were pretty dense, not "fluffy" like I was expecting.  I followed the suggestions on making it without the bread maker, but it just didn't work out as well for me.  I'll definately try them again though, and maybe next time they'll be a 5/5 star recipe!

text:
These are great. I got a lot of compliments on these. The only thing I find hard with these is the dough being so sticky, which makes it harder to make them pretty and not stick to everything. However, I didn't want to over flour (the board, rolling pin, etc...), so that's part of the reason why.The icing tastes a little too much like cream cheese, so next time I will cut back on the cream cheese, but that's just a prefernce. This is a really great recipe if you want to impress.

I just made these rolls and they are THE BEST.  I did use my SIL's recipe for the bread which is 1 yellow butter cake mix, 2.5c of hot water, 2 packages of yeast and about 5 c of flour.  mix together, let rise for 1 hr, beat down and roll out... text:
These were fantastic.  I live in the UK and have an American husband.  I have never had a cinnabon, but he was very impressed with these and said they were just as good.

I prepared the rolls the night before and stored them overnight in the fridge.  I took them out and allowed them to rise in the warm in the morning.  It worked well.

The frosting was very sweet, so I kept it on the side and allowed people to choose how much they put on.

Amazing.

text:
Not quite a Cinnabon but pretty darn good anyway. I've tried various recipes for cinnamon buns over the years and these are the best yet. I did not use my bread machine since one of things I like best about making homemade bread or rolls is kneading the dough. I used butter instead of margarine and made 16 smaller rolls instead of 12 large. They still took about 27 minutes rather than 15 to bake at 400. They are not difficult to make if you have the time and are truly worth the effort.

I got up very early one morning to make these, but the leftovers were so good the next day that next time I think I'll just make them in advance and reheat, as long as it's a casual setting.  Fantastic recipe.  Thanks so much for sharing it.

text:
Just chiming in here.  Clearly, this is a solid recipe that will produce beautiful rolls.  All the techniques people are suggesting to keep the filling in the rolls do work.  Add a little flour (I add a spoon of barley malt powder), increase the cinnamon, and then, if needed, turn the rolls over after baking.  You shouldn't have too much leaked filling to begin with, though.  Sometimes I double the filling and it still stays in the rolls.  No complaints from any cinnamon beneficiaries.

text:
This is a fantastic recipe!  The icing is amazing, and it is a relatively easy recipe... if you have the bread machine.  After the cinnamon rolls have baked for 10-12 minutes, I recommend transferring them to a new 9x13 pan, and pour the drippings from the old pan over the cinnamon rolls in the new pan, and bake for the remaining amount of time.  This is a fantastic recipe!

Good for an occassional treat, but I'll be making my usual recipe next time.

text:
Wow, these rolls are to die for!  I put about 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour in, instead of using all white flour.  I made them using my mixer because I don't have a bread machine.  They turned out terrific and got rave reviews from every member of the family.  I also made them the night before so that the only thing I had to do in the morning was let them rise (they really didn't rise much and I let them sit there for 1 1/2 hours!), and make the frosting.  It didn't seem to matter that they didn't rise again, because they still ended up growing in the oven and were huge!  Thank you for a great recipe!!

text:
I doubled the icing and should have doubled the cinnamon filling. As is, there's not enough filling to make the Cinnabon "gooeyness" and they end up dry. Also, unless you double the filling, it does no good to flip the roll when you're finished because there isn't any filling on the bottom to pour over the top. I mixed the cinnabon and suger with the butter as suggested by another reviewer -maybe that's part of why the filling didn't form the syrup on the bottom? The recipe definitely has possibilites through.

country:

text:
These were great!  My family loved them.  My only concern was how sticky the batter was when I went to roll them.  I had a hard time getting them to roll because they were sticking.  I used my bread machine which made them a snap to make.  Thanks for the recipe!

*Edit*  I have now been making these for years and they are just as good now (maybe better) then when I started making them.  What I have changed and has produced a better product for me was lowering the temp to 350 degrees and cooking them 10 minutes longer.  I used to get really brown tops and the rolls in the center were doughy and not completely cooked through.  Now they come out perfect.  BTW, I have a new oven and the temp is spot on.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe, have used both AP & bread flour to make this - better with bread flour.  I did not use a bread machine to make dough. Per others recommendations only used ~1.5 T of cinnamon and they turned out well. I've also made them the night before and put them in the fridge and they've been fine.  I did double the icing and am glad I did - although it was too much I think it would have been too sparce had I not done so.  I think 1.5 times the icing amount would be perfect (4.5 oz cream cheese, 6 T butter, 2 1/4 cups confectioners' sugar, 3/4 t vanilla, dash salt).

text:
It's all about the icing.  These are so close to Cinibon's it's scary.  My husband (and I) loved them.  16x21 sounds like a big rectangle but you also get really big rolls. I got 13 rolls and that was after I cut off the measly ends.  I mixed the gooey center part together then spread it on. Did end up needing to make a tad more that way.  I kept 8 and gave 5 to my daughter and son in law.  I thought the icing just made enough for eight.  Sent some store bought with them (hope it was ok cause sure wouldn't want to ruin those rolls). I did make mind with the bread machine but had to scrape the corners cause it wasn't mixing completely.  I made them the night before and let them sit out for an hour before baking.  Worked great.

These were really great, but I found that the baking time was a little long.  Next time I make them, I'll take them out about 2 minutes early...they seemed too crispy on the edges.  True Cinnabon goodness is the softness of the bun.  Also, as good as these were, they took a lot of time to prepare and make.  Probably better for special occasion cooking than for spur of the moment Saturdays.

text:
These cinnamon rolls are divine.  My in-laws were over when I made them, and the first thing that my father in-law said was that they reminded him of being in an airport eating cinnabon cinnamon rolls.  I smiled and told him the name of the recipe.  I actually used regular flour and margarine and I didn't regret it because they still tasted wonderful.  I had contemplated doubling the icing, (as one of the reviewers recommended) but I'm glad that I didn't because there was plenty of icing and we didn't even use it all. They were also just as wonderful the next day heated up in the microwave!

text:
This is a favorite. I enjoy the taste of CinnaMonsters to Cinnabons, so I alter this slightly to get the other brands taste. I use more real butter in the icing to create the change. Just from experience, NEVER make the icing with margarine. That was all I had one night, so I tried. Makes the icing too runny and not very smooth.

I have made these cinnamon rolls for years!  The cream cheese frosting is good to use on many other recipes like zucchini cake.  I have made these cinnamon rolls for friends and family with all great praises.  A must try for sure.  You can make large cinnamon rolls or smaller ones, which I do by just cutting the big sheet of dough in half length wise.  Then just make two log rolls, cut and place in pan like normal.

text:
The most amazing cinnamon rolls ever!! Better than a Cinnabon.  Better than anything I've ever had!  To the person whose recipe did not come out moist and soft:  I don't have a bread machine either.  When I first started making these I kneaded by hand.  You have to make sure that the dough is kneaded thoroughly, and I also add a bit more butter and milk just so the dough is easier to handle.  Also, if you have a food processor with kneading tool--USE IT!  I just got mine, and it does wonders!

text:
It is my first time making cinnamon buns and these are so easy(I do have a bread maker) and taste excellent!! For a minute when I was in my kitchen I thought I was at Cinnabon because of the smell of them. My daughter and I just got done eating one and she asked for another!!! They are rich but I can't believe how they taste exactly like Cinnabons!! I did lay down greased wax paper on a baking pan so they didn't stick and it worked. Thanks so much for the great recipe Marsha!!

This is the best sweet bun recipe ever.  I have made them about 5 times since February and they have turned out great every time.  I dont use a bread machine, i use a kitchenaid mixer with the dough hook. And i have decreased the flour to 4 cups or just a little more than that, I think because our the climate here. But they are great congrats to the person that developed this recipe.

text:
I have never made cinnamon rolls before and these really turned out tasty. The taste of these rolls certainly came very close to that of a real cinnabon. I don't think I let my rise enough though because I expected a fluffier, lighter roll. Using dental floss to cut these worked so well! And watch them as they bake because they will burn easily. I lined my pan with greased wax paper and that seemed to work well. My husband really liked these. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
These are delicious and using the bread machine makes them so easy.  The cream cheese frosting is the best!  I would reccomend making these early in the day or early afternoon though, as the dough cycle on my machine takes 1 1/2 hrs, then for the dough to raise (once before rolling out and again after cutting them) took an add'l hour or so.  I have made them 4 times within a month and everyone loves them. So much for my New Year's diet plan.  These are my little "treat" once in a while.

text:
I've made these over and over (and over) over the last year.  I don't have a bread machine, either.  What I did was buy the frozen bread dough (they also make a frozen sweet bread dough, which is better, but my store stopped carrying it).  2 loaves = this recipe.  I defrost the dough in the microwave and continue with the recipe.  Saves time, because, yes, they should be served warm, and making them the night before isn't an option.  Love them...Thanks!

text:
This is an easy recipe...The bread machine does most of the work.  You do have to wait for the dough to rise...It is worth the wait. 

One trick for cutting is to take a piece of thread or dental floss and wrap around the roll..hold each end of the floss ..criss cross the thread and pull until the dough is sliced.

text:
Excellent recipe!  I doubled the amount of cream cheese in the frosting.  I also put the cream cheese & butter in the microwave for 15 seconds before mixing and put the frosting in the refrigerator while the rolls were rising.  I didn't have a bread machine, so I did everything by hand and it came out great.  (I checked the breadworld website by fleischmann’s yeast for good tips about baking with yeast).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM.  The cream cheese frosting is what really gives it that Cinnabon flavor, and the brown sugar/cinnamon filling.  Our 11-year old daughter made these and they were delicious.  Thank you to the person who invented the bread machine!  There is virtually no mess involved except for when you turn the dough out onto the floured surface.  CHANGES TO THE RECIPE:  Next time I will add an additional 5 minutes, at least, to the baking time.  The middle cinnamon rolls were doughy.  HELPFUL HINT:  Use dental floss to cut your rolls, they come out beautifully!  Slide the floss under the dough and criss-cross it to make the cut.
